Nicky pulled back just enough to look up at her, eyes bright. "Did you see them? Rio let me help!" his little chest puffed with pride as he pointed toward the impressive stack of pancakes piled on a plate beside the stove. "I flipped some all by myself!"

Agatha's gaze flickered to Rio, who was watching the interaction with a careful expression like she was not sure how Agatha would react.

"You did?" Agatha replied, brushing a curl from Nicky's forehead. "And they didn't end up on the ceiling?"

Nicky giggled, shaking his head. "Nope! Rio said I did really good!"

Rio snorted, finally relaxing enough to smirk. "He did. No pancakes were harmed in the process."

"You have to try 'em, Mama," Nicky detached himself from her side, skipping to the stacked pile. He stopped a foot away from the counter, looking at Rio in a silent ask for permission.

"Go ahead," Rio encouraged him gently, grabbing the plate and placing it in his hands. "You got it?"

Nicky tightened his grip, testing the weight when Rio let go. "Yeah," he nodded before turning back to Agatha, who was watching the interaction in stunned surprise.

There was already familiarity between them, evident in the way Nicky knew not to reach for the plate himself or stray too close to the stove. Agatha wanted to believe she had drilled those habits into him, that his careful patience was a result of her teachings.

But she doubted it.

The exchange felt too practiced - like a continuation of something she had not been there to witness.

Unease coiled in her chest once again as she took in the silent understanding between them that seemed too natural for the short time they had known each other.

"Mama, let's go!" Nicky's impatient huff snapped her out of her thoughts, her gaze jumping between the plate in his hold and Rio, still at the stove, still looking domestic.

She hesitated again. "I'm not sure-"

"Nicky set the table for you," Rio interjected, making the boy grin.

"Because it's your birthday weekend!" he explained. "Rio said it can be like a gift!"

Agatha could not help the soft smile as it stretched her lips. "You already gave me a gift, baby," she said gently, nodding to the handmade card stuck to the fridge with a Baymax magnet they had gotten at Disney World.

Nicky shrugged, the pancakes wobbling precariously with the movement. "You deserve all the gifts, Mama," he said matter-of-factly as if it were the simplest truth in the world.

Agatha swallowed, her throat tightening in a way that had nothing to do with her lingering hangover. She reached out, steadying the plate in his hands before he accidentally sent his heartfelt gesture crashing to the floor.

"Well," she murmured, blinking rapidly. "Who am I to argue with that logic?"

His grin widened, his restless feet already carrying him to the dining room. "Come on, before they get cold!"

Agatha followed him almost mechanically, her steps slow, hesitant. She glanced back at the kitchen once, her mouth twitching as if she wanted to say something.

Rio was watching them, still holding the spatula, her expression unreadable. Something warm flickered in her gaze - something that made Agatha look away before she could try to name it but still lingered at the back of her mind when she obediently took her seat at the set table.

The vase caught her eyes almost immediately.

At the center of Nicky's carefully arranged chaos - mismatched plates, skewed cutlery, cups placed at odd angles - stood the bouquet Rio had given her. Bold and unapologetic, as if it had always belonged there.

She had forgotten placing it on the table, forgotten the unnecessary turmoil of deciding where to put the flowers so they would not feel like they were following her around the house.

Yet, here they were. Unavoidable, much like Rio.

Her gaze lingered on them for a second too long, tracing the petals before taking in the rest of the ensemble.

A subtle frown pulled at her eyebrows as she counted the plates.

Three.

Of-fucking-course.

Nicky slid into the seat on her right, the plate of pancakes balancing near the table's edge. She grabbed it automatically, moving it to rest a few inches from the vase, her eyes still glued to the unoccupied spot.

Did Rio know about it? Did she tell Nicky to take her into account?

"Mama, can you help?" Nicky shuffled forward on his chair, his small arm shooting out to reach the plate she had put just out of his range.

"Right, sorry," she pulled it closer, placing it between them.

Her heart almost melted when he carefully speared his fork through three pancakes, transferring them to her plate with a grin. "Here you go!"

She smiled, the growing lump in her throat almost bringing tears to her eyes. "Thank you, baby."

"You're welcome!" he mirrored her smile, his entire face glowing. Agatha felt happiness bloom in her chest at the satisfaction in his eyes, the unadulterated joy from helping her. Sometimes, she wondered what she had done to deserve such a sweet boy.

Then, Nicky shifted in his seat again, angling his body toward the kitchen. "Rio!"

Before Agatha could comprehend what was happening, the answering shout reached her ears, making her blood run cold. "Yeah, yeah, I'm coming!"

Right. Her.

She bit the inside of her cheek, thinking of the best way to tell Rio to make herself scarce with Nicky present. Somehow, the fuck off simmering on her tongue seemed inappropriate.

The soft patter of footsteps in the hall sent a fresh wave of dread rolling through her. It was slow but inevitable - an incremental rhythm, each step a harbinger of doom.

The prelude to disaster.

The arrival of the Four Horsemen.

Well, maybe that was a bit too dramatic.

But in her defense, she was still hungover. And annoyed.

Rio rounded the corner in all her domestic glory, a pot of fresh coffee and another, albeit smaller, plate of pancakes in her hands.

"Everything looks great, chef," she addressed Nicky with a playful wink, placing the pot within Agatha's reach. "You have a real feast set-"

Agatha saw the moment Rio's eyes fell on the empty seat, noticed the subtle twitch of her jaw, the flicker of hesitation in her gaze.

Suddenly, she realized the woman had nothing to do with the third plate.

It was all Nicky.

Oblivious to the sudden shift in the air, the boy leaned forward, casually scooping a serving onto his plate. The pancakes landed haphazardly, one barely making it onto the dish, but he did not seem to notice.

Instead, he glanced up at Rio - still frozen beside Agatha, still staring at the seat so obviously meant for her.

His forehead scrunched up at her hesitation. "Me and Mama always sit here," he said, pointing between the two occupied chairs, not noticing Agatha's shocked expression.

"I wasn't sure where you wanted to sit, so I just picked for you," he gave a little shrug, his face growing sincere. "But you can sit somewhere else if you want. I won't be upset."

With the promise, he focused on his pancakes, dousing them in a concerning amount of syrup.

Agatha jumped when Rio cleared her throat, stepping back from the table.

"That's very nice of you, Nicky," the woman said softly, gaze flicking between the unbothered boy and his mother. "But this is your gift for your mom. I'll eat in the kitchen."

Nicky frowned, stopping his attempt at cutting the pancakes with his fork. "Why? You helped!" he protested, looking at Agatha for help. "Rio can stay, right, Mama?"

Agatha hesitated, caught between the expectant look in Nicky's wide eyes and the alarm bells ringing in her head.

It was their second day of living together.

The deal had been on for barely forty-eight hours.

And Rio had already slipped into this space that was supposed to belong only to the two of them - dragged into it by the oblivious boy who was too kind for his own good. Helping him make breakfast. Teaching him new things.

All while dressed like she belonged.

And yet, Agatha could not find a valid reason to send her away.

"Of course, she can stay," she finally said, the words feeling heavier than they should.

Nicky beamed, scooting over to make more room as if they would need to squeeze together to fit at the enormous table. "See? It's better when we all eat together!"

Rio slowly rounded the table, her eyes darting to Agatha as if expecting her to change her mind, to shoo her away. When all she found was a tight press of lips and an impatient glare, she lowered herself into the seat. "Guess this is happening, then."

Our situation isn't normal; we both know it. But it's happening whether we like it or not.

Rio's words from the night before echoed in her ears, bringing forth the memories of their conversation. The ridiculously simple solution not to overthink their situation. To stop fighting it. Herself. Rio.

Her fingers tightened around her fork, her gaze locked onto the woman sitting across from her.

It would not be that simple. She could not just let Rio slip past every defense, could not allow herself to be laid bare. She had already let too much slip - had already let Rio take care of her when she was at her most vulnerable.

But she could try to be civil. To stop treating Rio like an intruder in her home. Like the enemy.

Catching the woman's eye, she eased the death grip on her fork, her lips parting on a silent word.

Truce?

Rio read it effortlessly, recognition lighting up her face as she nodded, her smile soft and genuine.

Truce, she mouthed back.

It had to be enough to survive the next three-hundred-sixty-three days.

Not that Agatha was counting.

The truce turned out to be more of a lax agreement scribbled at the back of a receipt than an elaborate document calling for peace. As feeble as Agatha's resolution to act civil toward the newest inhabitant of her home.

In all fairness, Rio was not a terrible person to live with. True to her words, she kept the house clean, stayed away from Agatha's part of the fridge, and moved through the shared spaces with the ease of someone accustomed to coexisting with others. Despite Agatha's suspicions, the plants did not multiply behind her back, and Rio tended to them with such gentle care that it became increasingly difficult to stay mad at the scattered greenery.

Nicky had developed a habit of insisting they ate together whenever their schedules aligned. But Rio was rarely up in time for breakfast - making Agatha suspect, with some reluctance, that the morning after her birthday had been a calculated effort to let her sleep despite Nicky's boundless energy. And she was often absent at dinner, caught between classes, work, and time with her friends.

If Agatha focused hard enough, she could almost forget about her.

Almost, because when Rio was home, she made sure her presence was felt.

Whether it was the faint hum of music drifting from the kitchen as she cooked, the sound of her laughter as she chatted on her phone, or the way she always seemed to take up space without trying - leaning against counters, sprawling on the couch, claiming the kitchen like it was hers by right.

It was not obnoxious, not a desperate attempt at trying to make a foreign space feel like home. If anything, it was maddeningly natural, like Rio had always been there, like she belonged.

And that, more than anything, was what got under Agatha's skin.

Because Rio did not belong.

She was supposed to be a temporary fixture, a name on a piece of paper that made the deal work - not someone who fit into Agatha's carefully structured life with such effortless ease.

Yet, every time Agatha walked into a room, there was a sign that Rio had been there. Even without considering the plants - she had begrudgingly accepted their existence - there was always a half-finished cup of tea on the counter or a blanket thrown haphazardly over the back of the couch.

And then there was Nicky.

If Agatha had thought her son would remain neutral in all of this, she had been sorely mistaken. Nicky liked Rio. He really liked her.

The kind of like that had him lingering in the kitchen to talk to her after school. The kind that had him asking if Rio would be home for dinner. The kind that made Agatha lift the rule of Rio not using the living room so they could play stupid video games together.

It irked Agatha - all of it - but overall, she had to admit the first three weeks of living together had passed in relative peace, disrupted only by meaningless arguments over the right way of putting the dirty dishes in the dishwasher and the volume of Rio's music.

In hindsight, she should have expected they had been too peaceful.

It was her life, after all. Things rarely stayed quiet for long.

The ball dropped on Sunday, right after she had sent Nicky to bed and settled on the couch with a book in hand, hoping to relax before another week of whiny clients and incompetent interns.

Her phone's insistent buzzing tore through the quiet like a knife, making her close her eyes behind her glasses in annoyance.

A sinking feeling in her stomach foreshadowed the caller's ID before she even saw it, but her breath still caught in her throat when the screen flashed ominously, the dreaded name staring back at her.

Mother.

Three weeks.

It took longer than she had anticipated. Agatha half-expected Evanora to call the day after her birthday - not on the day itself to spare herself the trouble of wishing her a happy birthday - to interrogate her about the sudden change in her marital status.

When the silence persisted, she figured her mother had been watching, trying to find the evidence to discredit her before calling to let her know the scheme had fallen apart in the first weeks.

With a shaky exhale, Agatha swiped her finger over the accept button, pressing the phone to her ear.

"Do I not deserve an invitation to your wedding?"

No 'hello'. No 'how are you?'. No 'sorry for missing your birthday'.

Just a prickly, aggravated hiss that made her sink further into the cushions, the book forgotten in her lap.

"Hello, Mother," she said, not bothering to hide the annoyance in her voice. "We didn't have a wedding, as I'm sure you're aware."

Evanora growled on the other side of the call. "Watch your tone, girl. Did you really think I wouldn't see through your lies?"

Agatha bit back a remark about how she was forty and certainly not a girl anymore. "I don't know what you're talking about," she said instead, pushing her glasses up and resting them at the top of her head.

"Your so-called marriage," her mother hissed.

"I understand your traditional views are too limited to recognize it as a real marriage, but-"

"Enough!" Evanora barked into the receiver, making Agatha flinch. "That's a separate problem. Do you think I'm stupid? Or that you can outsmart me? Your little plan doesn't change anything regarding my will."

Agatha sucked on her teeth, readying the script she had prepared for the conversation. "My plan?"

"Your sham marriage!" the roar pierced her ear with a ferocity akin to a rabid animal aiming for someone's trachea. She pulled the phone back, feeling an involuntary shiver run down her spine. "Does your greed know no boundaries?! I've given you everything! And yet, when I decide to help others, you enter an immoral relationship just to spite me!"

"Not everything is about you, Mother," she bit back, ignoring how her stomach churned with Evanora's every word. "Certainly not my love life."

Evanora scoffed, a mocking edge in her voice. "Love life? You cannot be that stupid."

Agatha's lower lip trembled, already predicting her mother's next words, but they still sank into her heart like precisely thrown knives.

"You're not someone people love," Evanora said as if teaching her a valuable lesson. "You're a burden, a disappointment, but not someone people want."

Agatha's grip tightened around the phone, her knuckles whitening as she forced herself to take a steadying breath. She had heard those words before - variations of them, at least - sharpened over the years into weapons her mother wielded effortlessly. And yet, somehow, they still found their mark.

Every. Single. Time.

She pressed her tongue to the roof of her mouth, swallowing down the familiar sting. "Well, someone wanted me enough to marry me, didn't they?" she said, the words almost defiant despite their untrue nature.

Evanora laughed, cold and humorless. "Oh, please. I don't know who this person is, but they certainly don't love you. They're using you. Just like you're using them."

Agatha clenched her jaw, still following her script. "Her name's Rio, and you don't know anything about our relationship."

"And you don't know anything about love," her mother countered. "Honestly, Agatha, do you really want me to believe anyone would want to marry you for you?"

The realization hit Agatha like a truck.

Evanora did not think the relationship was suspicious because of the convenient timing. She did not question not knowing about Rio's existence before the will had come to light or the almost clinical nature of their wedding.

No, she found it doubtful because it was Agatha - her unlovable, intolerable daughter who had seemingly found someone who wanted her.

Her tongue flexed uncomfortably in her mouth, a usually sharp knife dulled by her mother's callousness.

She scrambled for anything to say - a retort that would mask how deep Evanora's words had gotten under her skin - but before she could form a single syllable, a shadow moved in the doorway.

Rio.

She stood there, leaning against the frame, arms crossed, her expression unreadable. How long had she been listening? How much had she heard?

Agatha's heart lurched. Not from fear, not from embarrassment, but from the look in Rio's eyes - from the obvious, heavy concern shining in the warm pools of brown as they stared at her in silence.

Then, Rio moved.

She stepped forward in long, decisive strides, closing the distance between them until she stood by the coffee table, a mere foot from the phone trembling in Agatha's hand.

"My love," Rio said, steady and sure, loud enough for the speaker to catch every word. "I thought you were coming to bed?"

Agatha blanched, her gaze snapping up to search Rio's face for an explanation, but Evanora connected the dots faster.

"Was that your so-called wife?" she growled.

Agatha swallowed thickly around the lump in her throat. "I have to go," she said, hating how her voice wavered.

"Not until I say so," her mother snapped. "I had hoped we could resolve this in a civilized manner, but I forgot how difficult you can be. I expect you and that woman at Kestra on Thursday. Four o'clock. Maybe then I'll talk some sense into you."

"I don't-"

The line went dead before she could finish, and the silence that followed was suffocating.

Agatha stared at the phone in her hand, Evanora's words still ringing in her ears. Their weight pressed down on her chest, thick and unrelenting.

Honestly, Agatha, do you really want me to believe anyone would want to marry you for you?

Her fingers curled around the device like she could crush the lingering echo, but it was already seared into her skin, embedded in her bones.

Then, Rio exhaled. Not loudly, not dramatically - just a slow, deliberate breath, like she was forcing herself to stay calm.

"You okay?" she asked, her voice softer than Agatha had ever heard.

Somehow, the solemn expression on Rio's face startled her more than her mother's words. She was used to Evanora's outbursts - to the cutting remarks and screaming matches, to being ridiculed and put down for existing - but seeing Rio serious struck a chord she did not want to touch.

A chord dangerously close to unraveling her.

So, she scoffed instead, shoving the phone into her pocket and forcing her expression into something wry and unimpressed. "Just a fun little chat with my mother. Always a pleasure."

Rio didn't laugh.

She just tilted her head, studying Agatha the way someone studies a puzzle with a missing piece.

Then, her mouth opened again, another question simmering on the tip of her tongue.

Agatha shot to her feet, grabbing the book from her lap. "I'm going to bed," she announced, already halfway to the door, Rio's eyes drilling holes into the back of her neck.

"Agatha."

Her name left Rio's lips in a whisper - gentle, beckoning. But Agatha tensed as if she had shouted it.

"She's wrong."

Agatha froze. The words lingered in the air between them, heavy, undeniable.

She didn't turn around. She couldn't. If she did, Rio would see too much - how her fingers clenched around the book, how her throat bobbed as she swallowed back the sting in her eyes.

She didn't want comfort. She despised reassurances wrapped in soft voices and well-meaning looks. She loathed pity.

And yet-

She glanced over her shoulder.

Rio stood in the middle of the living room, hands moving restlessly near her hips like she was fighting to stay put. Like her instinct was telling her to do something, to reach out, to fix, but she knew Agatha would not accept it.

Agatha sighed, tearing her eyes away from the woman and turning to the dark staircase. "You don't know that. You don't know me."

"Then let me."

The words were so simple, so easy, and yet, they cracked something deep inside her.

Her grip on the book faltered, her shoulders slumped.

For a terrifying second, she considered it - turning around and letting Rio see past all the walls she had spent a lifetime building. Taking a sledgehammer to the stacked bricks and watching as the hurt poured out like infected blood from a wound. Cleansing her from all the rot her mother had caused.

But the walls were there for a reason. They were a dam holding back everything Agatha should not burden Rio with - Rio, who was in her house by design, a means to an end.

Tearing the walls would complicate the deal. It would make Agatha vulnerable, and business arrangements had no space for vulnerability.

So, instead, she straightened her spine, not sparing the woman another glance before walking out of the living room.

Her feet carried her to her bedroom on autopilot, her hands stiffly moving through her nighttime routine.

She purposefully avoided looking at herself in the mirror longer than necessary, wiping off her makeup in hard, decisive strokes that reddened her skin and sent sparks of pain through her nerves. When she stepped into the shower, the hot water rained on her in a steady stream, almost loud enough to drown out her thoughts as she scrubbed down her body until her pale complexion turned pink from the insistent drags of the loofah and the water's temperature.

By the time she slipped under the covers, her entire body ached, but the conversation still rattled in her mind like a pesky wasp circling her head to find the perfect occasion to strike.

Rio's gentle voice clashed with Evanora's furious hisses, making her temples throb and the lump in her throat grow.

Somewhere in the house, she heard the door to the guest bedroom close, and only then did Agatha let the tears flow, sliding down her cheeks and wetting her pillow. She clenched her teeth, stifling the sobs as her body trembled with the mixture of emotions suffocating her - the anger squeezing the air out of her lungs, the overwhelming despair wrapping tightly around her throat, the quiet acceptance creating cracks in her heart.

Evanora had been right. Rio did not want her for her. Their marriage was a ploy, a calculated move to secure the will.

Agatha knew all that.

Still, the situation, words, and conviction in her mother's voice stung.

They stung because, deep down, Agatha knew if it were not for the agreement, she would not be wanted, and her mother knew it too.

The realization made the tears flow harder, her muscles convulsing from the effort of staying quiet as she fell apart.

Chapter End Notes

Hiiii, we got some fluff to soften the blow of Evanora being a dick, but honestly I wanted to punch her when I was writing this. Leave something if you enjoyed the chapter (or not, I can't tell you what to do), and for everyone who thought there would be a bigger breakthrough after the bar: you really thought Agatha is mature enough for that? Pleaseee, she has the emotional intelligence of a rock. But I really do love the enthusiasm, and I promise we'll get there. Slowly. Painstakingly so. But we will!

Chapter 10: Happy fucking Monday

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The morning came too soon.

Agatha woke with a dull headache, brought on by the dehydration from a night of sobbing into her pillow and her mother's words still lingering in her mind, still clinging to her skin despite the thorough shower.

You're not someone people love.

She shook the thought away and forced herself out of bed. Monday meant routine. Routine meant control.

Moving on autopilot, she readied herself for the day, which included an abnormal amount of concealer to hide the dark circles under her eyes, and headed to the kitchen. The coffee pot gurgled to life as she packed Nicky's lunch, her fingers scrolling through emails - each action mechanical, predictable.

Then, a door creaked somewhere in the house, slicing through the mind-numbing comfort of routine.

Her eyes flickered to the time - at least fifteen minutes too early for Nicky to be up and functioning. Slow, decisive footsteps sounded from the staircase, and the illusion of control the predictability of the morning offered shattered.

Mondays were one of the few days Rio emerged before nine, forced out of her room by early classes. The restless night had conveniently erased that information from Agatha's mind, and her stomach lurched when Rio rounded the corner - a walking reminder of last night's events.

Agatha had already locked the conversation with her mother in a vault, tossing the key into the void. Her mind was filled with lockboxes of Evanora's cruelty, each shoved so deep that, with enough time, they blurred into a foggy dream. Someone else's memory. If she was lucky, she even forgot they existed. Until her mother dragged them back into the light.

But usually, she made sure no one else saw - no witnesses to Evanora's words. Nobody to remember them but her.

"Morning," Rio murmured, running a hand through her damp her.

Agatha forced her muscles to relax despite the dread coiling in her chest. "Morning," she responded stiffly, keeping her voice neutral, disinterested.

Rio shuffled around her, making a beeline for the coffee machine, and Agatha instinctively stepped aside, eyes glued to the email she had been reading before the woman entered the kitchen.

The words blurred, letters swimming in her vision, refusing to make sense. She wasn't really reading - just using the screen as a shield, a flimsy excuse to avoid looking up. To avoid acknowledging the way her pulse hammered against her ribs, adrenaline coursing through her veins as she waited for the ball to drop.

Then, Rio cleared her throat, drumming her fingers against the fresh mug of coffee in her hand. "About Thursday-"

"I'm not talking about it," Agatha said sharply, her voice slicing through the air before Rio could get another word in. She did not look up, her gaze locked on the phone screen like it held the secret to disappearing into thin air.

Silence stretched between them, charged and heavy.

Rio sighed, the rhythmical tapping of her fingernails stopping. "Okay, but my car's still in the shop. We should probably figure out how we're getting there."

Agatha's grip on her phone tightened. She braced herself for concern, for questions she did not want to answer - but practicalities? Logistics? That threw her off.

She finally looked at the younger woman, her forehead creased. "We're driving together. It would look weird if we came separately."

Rio hummed into her coffee, accepting the answer. "Great."

The exchange felt underwhelming, so unlike what Agatha had thought it would be that she found herself speaking again before she realized it.

"Is your car fine? It's been almost two months."

Rio stilled, just for a second, before taking a slow sip of her coffee. "Yeah. I told you, the parts are a bitch to get. Still waiting for one."

Agatha narrowed her eyes. "That long?"

Rio shrugged, the movement deliberately casual. "Some things take time."

It wasn't a lie, exactly, but it wasn't the truth either. Agatha knew that tone - carefully even, like walking on glass without drawing attention to the blood on your feet.

Her grip tightened around her mug.

The car wasn't in the shop because of a back-ordered part. It was in the shop because Rio could not pay for the labor.

Agatha should let it go. It wasn't hers to deal with.

Except it was, at least partially.

Moving into her house meant Rio had to commute everywhere - to work, university, even to see her friends - and there was only so far public transport could take her. Agatha had specifically told her to not crash at her old apartment after work, which left only one option: finding a way back to the house in the dead of night. And knowing Rio's limited resources, she doubted the woman was splurging on Ubers.

The implications - the long walks, the waiting at bus stops in the dark, the possible danger - made something unpleasant coil in Agatha's stomach.

"Who's the mechanic?" she asked, aiming for casual.

Rio frowned, eyeing her suspiciously. "Why?"

Agatha shrugged, tapping her nails against the counter. "Just wondering if they're actually working on your car or if you've been scammed into a never-ending repair job."

Rio snorted, shaking her head. "It's a shop Alice recommended. She knows the owner, so I doubt they're screwing me over."

"And yet, two months later, you're still hitchhiking your way around the city?"

Rio arched an eyebrow over the rim of her cup. "I don't hitchhike."

"Then how do you get back?"

For a split second, Rio hesitated, barely noticeable, but enough to set off alarms in Agatha's mind.

"I manage," she said after a beat, setting her cup down with a quiet clink.

Agatha's jaw clenched. Manage. It was such a non-answer that it might as well have been a flashing neon sign screaming I don't want to tell you.

"Rio," she started, a warning laced in her tone.

But before she could push, Nicky came bounding into the kitchen, his presence immediately filling the space. "Good morning! Mama, have you seen my shoes? I want to wear the new ones."

Rio used the distraction to slip away, carrying her coffee as she headed for the stairs.

"I'll be late tonight," she called over her shoulder, her voice light and easy, as if the conversation had never happened.

Agatha watched her go, her fingers still curled into the countertop. The unease from earlier had not gone away. If anything, it settled deeper, urging her to take action.

It wasn't about concern - she didn't care if Rio got herself murdered or froze her ass off at a bus stop. Well, maybe she cared a little, but only because Rio was no use to her if she was dead.

No, it was about flashing her influence to regain control over the situation, about showing Rio she was not a damsel in distress, bullied by her own mother and unable to get herself home after a night out.

By lunch, she had all the needed details.

An hour later, the mechanic informed her that the car was ready to be collected.

Two hours after that, the door to her office swung open, cutting through the tranquil air.

The pen in Agatha's hand froze mid-word, pressing into the post-it note as her head snapped up, ready to berate the person barging into her space unannounced.

The sharp retort died on her lips the moment she saw Rio.

The door had barely clicked shut before Rio crossed the room in three quick strides, her expression a storm of barely restrained fury. She planted her hands on the desk, leaning in as she hissed, "What the hell do you think you're doing?"

Agatha set the pen down, unbothered by the steely look in Rio's eyes. "Working. How did you get into the building?"

"You paid for my car," Rio snapped, ignoring her question.

Agatha resisted the urge to lean back in her chair, keeping her expression neutral. "I did. Did you break in here?"

Rio's nostrils flared. "Why?"

"I'm not answering any more of your questions until you answer mine," Agatha tilted her chin up, withstanding Rio's scalding glare. "How did you get into the building?"

Rio exhaled sharply through her nose, the muscle in her jaw twitching. "The security guards downstairs let me in," she bit out as if the words pained her. "Apparently, being your wife has its perks in this place, especially when said wife looks pissed enough."

Agatha made a mental note to talk to security about letting in furious women with unresolved issues. It felt like the basics of keeping everyone in the office safe. "Good to know."

Rio's hands flexed on the desk's sturdy surface as she leaned closer. "Don't change the subject. Why did you pay for my fucking car?"

"Because it needed fixing," she shrugged, tilting her head. "Also, in case that wasn't obvious, don't go around telling people here that we're married. I like to keep my life private."

Rio dismissed her comment with a scoff. "I didn't ask for your help. I don't need your help."

"You didn't, but it was inconvenient," she said simply. "I fixed the problem."

Rio let out a humorless laugh, pushing off the desk. "No. I fix my problems. You decided to swoop in and - what? Make me feel like a damn charity case?"

Agatha exhaled through her nose, fighting the urge to roll her eyes. "It's a car, not a Make-A-Wish situation. And before you get too dramatic, it wasn't even that much."

"That's not the point!" Rio growled, making Agatha look toward her assistant's desk. Mercifully, she had sent him on an errand moments before Rio decided to disturb her peace, so he was not there to witness the exchange.

"Then what is the point?" she challenged, her gaze snapping back to Rio. "Would you rather keep taking the bus? Or whatever the fuck you were doing after your shifts? Or maybe you were hoping you'd stumble upon a pile of cash on your way back to the house?"

Rio's lips parted, but no sound came out.

Agatha took the opportunity to press on.

"It's done," she said, firm and final. "I don't expect anything in return. Just take the car and stop making it an issue."

Rio stared at her, expression unreadable. The anger was still there, simmering beneath the surface, darkening her brown eyes, but something else had taken root, something more vulnerable, almost hesitant.

Then, she blinked, and the look was gone, replaced by a defiant spark. "I'll pay you back," she declared, almost threatening, and Agatha rolled her eyes.

"Be my guest."

Before Rio could fire back, the sound of approaching footsteps made Agatha's stomach drop. She only had enough time to consider hiding Rio under her desk or tossing her out the window before the door to her office swung open.

Lilia and Jen strolled in like they owned the place, ignoring the dark glower Agatha shot their way.

"I'm busy," she grumbled, hoping they would take the hint.

"Yeah, yeah, you always are," Jen shot back, completely unbothered as she let the door swing shut behind her. "We were just coming in to-"

"Rio?"

The room stilled.

Agatha inhaled sharply at Lilia's startled tone, but it was Rio she looked at first. Because for a moment there had been something like regret flashing in those dark eyes, quickly stamped out and replaced with a practiced, easy smile.

"Hi, Lilia," Rio said, casual as ever. She even had the nerve to wave.

Lilia blinked once, then twice, her keen eyes flickering from Rio's face to Agatha's, to Rio's left hand, to finally rest on an identical gold band adorning Agatha's ring finger.

They watched her put the clues together in real-time, the gears in her head spinning as the pieces clicked into place with a shaky gasp.

"You married Rio?"

Jen frowned, following her friend's line of sight. "Wait, you're married?"

Agatha sank further into her chair, pinching the bridge of her nose.

She always knew they would find out - eventually. There was only so much she could do: drowning the wedding ring in other jewelry to make it unnoticeable, keeping her hand buried in her pocket, or tucking it beneath any available surface.

The behavior was unreasonable, it defeated the purpose of the marriage, which was to convince everyone, Evanora in particular, that the arrangement was real. Still, some people were private, unwilling to share their personal lives in the workplace, and Agatha figured that it didn’t undermine the lie, but simply fed into the persona she had developed at work - all business, no play.

The office was not a place for heartfelt confessions and personal revelations. She rarely participated in small talk, let alone deeper conversations, unless either Lilia or Jen cornered her. Which they hadn’t because she made sure to bend over backwards to keep the truth from them.

To be fair, she was surprised it had worked for that long.

But judging by the look on Lilia's face, she suspected the woman had noticed the moment the ring slipped onto her finger. She had simply chosen to wait, biding her time for the perfect moment to strike.

And now, that moment had arrived - delivered straight into her lap in the form of a pissed-off Rio, unable to use her phone to yell at Agatha like a normal human being.

"Honestly, Jen," she scoffed after a beat of silence, letting her hand drop. "How are you a lawyer? We're supposed to be observant."

Jen's mouth snapped open, ready to deliver a sharp retort, but Lilia's raised hand stopped her. "Don't. She's trying to distract us."

Agatha gasped, clutching her chest in mock offense. "Me?"

"It's not my fault you have an unhealthy addiction to jewelry," Jen huffed. "The ring is barely visible!"

"Almost like that's on purpose, huh?" Agatha fired back, glancing at Rio and hoping her eyes would convey the message of why the fuck are you still here?

They did.

Rio cleared her throat, stepping away from her desk. "Well, this has been lovely, but-"

"You're not going anywhere," Lilia cut in, her voice laced with quiet authority. To Agatha's surprise, Rio's shoulders slumped in defeat. She stuffed her hands into her pockets, her expression suddenly pliant like a scolded child's.

Agatha's curiosity spiked.

"How do you two know each other?" she asked, her eyes flicking between them.

Lilia arched a brow. "How do you know each other?"

"We're married," Rio quipped, earning twin unamused stares from both Agatha and Lilia. Pressing her lips into a thin line, she relented. "We met at the bar. And Lilia's Alice's godmother."

Agatha held back a groan. The universe really hated her.

"I knew you looked familiar!" Jen snapped her fingers, stepping closer as she eyed Rio. "You work at-"

"Okay, great," Agatha interrupted, pushing to her feet. "We all know each other. Now, get out of my office. I have work to do."

Jen rolled her eyes. "Oh, please. Like you were working before we got here."

"I was!"

"Really? Because it looked like you were arguing with your wife!"

Before Agatha could argue, Lilia took a deliberate step forward, fixing Rio with a pointed look. "You," she said, her voice still carrying that quiet authority that had so easily made Rio stand down before. "Explain yourself."

Rio's eyes flickered over to Agatha, a silent question in them.

Do you want them to know?

She didn't, not really.

The list of people who knew was already too long for her liking, and the more names they added to it, the greater the chance the deal could fall apart. The ice was already thin. Evanora was nowhere close to believing their marriage was real, and disclosing its true nature to an even wider audience posed a significant threat.

Then again, one look at the crease between Lilia's brows told her she already had her suspicions accompanied by an itch to get to the bottom of the issue.

She knew if Lilia put her mind to it, the deal could be uncovered by the end of the week.

"It's a long story," Rio finally said after Agatha's unhelpful silence stretched for too long.

Lilia crossed her arms, not buying the non-answer. "I have time."

"I don't," Agatha rounded her desk. "We're all at work, and Rio shouldn't even be here."

"Damn," Jen whistled, shooting the mentioned woman a compassionate look. "You met at your job, and she won't let you visit hers?"

Rio chuckled, vaguely gesturing to their modern surrounding. "Slightly different vibes."

"Yeah, slightly," Agatha deadpanned, impatiently tapping her foot against the floor. "Unless you have something important to discuss..." she motioned to the door, a clear sign for everyone to leave.

Lilia didn't budge, her eyes narrowed as she crossed her arms. "I'm not going anywhere until you answer my questions."

"Yeah, actually, I'm kinda curious, too," Jen agreed. "We didn't know you were dating anyone. And why weren't we invited to the wedding?"

The vein in Agatha's forehead throbbed. She ran her fingers across it, willing to cast out the budding headache spreading across her skull.

"There was no wedding," she snapped, leaning back against her desk and bracing her hands on its edge. Upon noticing her friends' unbothered faces, she sighed, "Listen, this really isn't the place, okay? I have work to do, and so do you. We can talk about it some other time."

Lilia eyed her carefully as if calculating the risk of Agatha fleeing the country to avoid the topic.

Eventually, she relented with a slow exhale. "Fine, but this isn't over. We will discuss this."

"Can't wait," Agatha deadpanned.

"Come on, Jen." Lilia turned to leave, shooting Rio one last knowing glance before heading for the door. Jen shot them one last suspicious look before following her out, the door closing with a soft click.

Agatha slumped against her desk, leaning forward with a resigned groan.

Happy fucking Monday. The week was off to a fantastic start.

"Well," Rio mused, stuffing her hands into her pockets. "That was fun."

"This is your fault!" Agatha growled, straightening her spine. "You know phones exist, right? You didn't have to come here to yell at me for being altruistic."

"Altruistic? You-" Rio stopped herself, the angry spark in her eyes dying before it could take root. When she spoke again, her voice was measured, calm, "What are you going to tell them? Lilia won't believe our story."

"Yeah, Jen won't either."

"So...?"

Agatha slowly returned to the other side of the desk, sinking into her chair with a resigned sigh. "I'll tell them enough to stop them from digging into it."

Rio looked unconvinced. "Meaning?"

"I'll handle it," Agatha snapped, her words final. She grabbed the discarded pen and glanced at the half-finished note, only to realize she couldn't remember what she'd been writing before Rio barged in. "You can go now."

"I'm not your employee; you can't dismiss me," Rio pointed out. "They're your friends. Just tell them the truth."

Agatha's jaw tightened. "Did you not hear my mother? She already doesn't believe this is real. Every person we tell is a liability."

Rio studied her carefully, brows knitting together. "And out of everyone we told, you think lawyers will blab?"

It sounded ridiculous. It was ridiculous. Lilia and Jen were probably the safest people to trust - tight-lipped, trained to withhold the truth even under pressure, with years of courtroom experience, and used to dealing with entitled people like Evanora.

Agatha exhaled sharply through her nose, fiddling with the pen. "It's not about what I think. It's about control."

"Control?" Rio scoffed. "Over what?"

"Over how this plays out," Agatha leaned back in her chair, arms crossing tightly over her chest. "The second too many people know, the second she finds out, it's all gone."

Rio's expression shifted, her frustration melting into something sharper. "I don't know Jen, but Lilia won't run off to Evanora."

"It's not about that," Agatha snarled. "It's about loose ends. It's about keeping things airtight. Every person who knows is a risk, and you've already told Alice and Billy."

"You told Wanda," Rio argued defensively, making Agatha roll her eyes.

"Yes, and that's three people too many."

Rio stared at her for a long moment, something unreadable in her gaze. "Doesn't going through life without trusting anyone get exhausting at some point?"

The pen slipped out from Agatha's fingers, clattering loudly against the desk, but she barely heard it over the sudden rush of blood in her ears. Her eyes snapped to Rio's, searching for something - mockery, pity, frustration - but all she found was quiet sincerity, and somehow, that made it worse.

It made it worse because Rio saw through yet another defense, another carefully constructed wall.

She couldn't have that - couldn't give the woman the satisfaction of thinking she understood her actions.

"I trust people," Agatha hissed. "But this isn't about trust. It's about risks."

"What risks?" Rio challenged, taking a slow step forward. The desk still separated them, but it felt like a feeble defense against the storm brewing in the air. "Lying to them is more dangerous, and you know it. Lilia won't leave a single stone unturned if she realizes we lied, which she will because she won't believe we got married for-"

Agatha's mind supplied the unspoken word for Rio.

Love.

Lilia wouldn't believe they got married for love.

You're not someone people love.

Agatha inhaled sharply the moment recognition lit up Rio's eyes.

"That's not what I meant," the younger woman rushed to explain, her words quick, frantic as if they could erase the memory replaying in Agatha's mind.

But the damage was done.

Rio had unknowingly discovered the root of Agatha's reluctance to tell her friends about the true nature of their marriage.

It wasn't about keeping a secret. It wasn't about liabilities, dangers, and trust.

It was about testing people close to her, seeing if they would believe she had found someone who wanted her - someone who loved her.

Agatha bristled, noticing Rio's face soften, her stormy frustration ebbing into something gentler, dangerously close to concern.

"Fine, I'll tell them," she grumbled, once again reaching for the pen and focusing on the half-written note. Was it about that newest client? It could be. Maybe it was about that deal-

"Agatha," Rio said, her voice quieter. "You don't have to."

Agatha briefly considered throwing the pen into the woman's face, but she refused to look up from the unfinished memo.

"Can you make up your fucking mind? I said I'd tell them. It's the best course of action," the words were sharp, laced with venom meant to discourage further comments.

Rio shifted on her feet, filling the heavy, thick silence hanging between them as Agatha's eyes bore holes into the flimsy piece of paper. The pen trembled in her hand, the dread from their encounter in the kitchen resurfacing like a dormant beast.

Even without seeing Rio's expression, she could imagine her concerned face. She had seen it too many times already - the tensed jaw, the creased forehead, the subtle frown that made the woman's eyes seem darker.

However, no matter how many times Rio looked at her like that - like every clue offered her a deeper understanding of Agatha's actions, thoughts, person - it never failed to make her feel exposed.

Agatha had spent her entire life under a microscope, scrutinized either by her mother or the circle of her colleagues. She was used to the weight of people's stares, the way their gazes skimmed over her, searching for something they could dissect and pick apart. Every room she entered was filled with silent judgments and examining glances.

She had learned early on how to read those looks - how to recognize the moment someone decided she was too sharp, too distant, too abrasive. The flicker of wariness in their eyes when she spoke to bluntly. The subtle recoil when she didn't soften her edges to make them more comfortable. The quiet dismissal when they realized she wasn't the kind of woman who could be molded, who could be tamed.

It never mattered.

As long as they respected her competence, her intelligence, her status - Agatha let them believe whatever they wanted. She let the false assumptions pile up, let them build like bricks around her until their weight felt more permanent than the truth. The cold, untouchable mask molded to her face, eventually searing into her skin so she could never take it off, and whenever she met someone, it served as a warning sign, a bold statement that she was a force to be reckoned with.

But Rio looked at her through the spaces between the bricks, the tiny gaps where time had worn the mortar thin, leaving parts of Agatha exposed. She saw the cracks in the mask - the minuscule fractures no one had ever looked close enough to notice. But Rio had.

She had noticed those imperfections that night at the bar when Agatha had let her guard slip just enough, thinking it wouldn't matter. Thinking no one would look.

Of course, Rio had. And worse - she kept looking, refusing to focus on the parts Agatha voluntarily showed her: the cold, practiced exterior as hard as a shell.

No, Rio watched her through the cracks, as if that was the only way of seeing her properly. As if she wanted to understand her.

It left Agatha feeling exposed. Lost, even. Because nobody had ever looked past her facade with such ease.

Nobody cared enough to see.

Rio inhaled softly. "I know you don't want to talk about it, but-"

"Then why fucking revisit it?" Agatha's voice trembled with the effort of keeping it even. Getting into a screaming match was not an option, not at her office, not where people could hear.

"Because she's wrong," Rio repeated the words from last night with even more conviction. "You're not unlovable."

Agatha's head snapped to look at the woman, and sure enough, the concern was right there - carved into Rio's worry lines and gleaming in her dark eyes. She clenched her teeth.

"I didn't ask for your input."

Rio didn't relent, her expression remaining stoic. "I'm giving it to you anyway because somebody has to tell you that. You're not unlovable."

She could feel the words fall on her, wrap around her, embrace her. They felt warm despite the steely conviction in Rio's eyes, soft despite the edge in her tone, and Agatha let them soothe her, let herself fall into them as they healed the gashes left by her mother's cruelty.

For a moment, she wondered if being seen was such a bad thing.

Her lips parted, the prickly defiance melting away into something quieter, something dangerously close to acceptance.

For once, Rio’s eyes on her didn’t feel intrusive, they didn’t make her think the younger woman was seconds away from learning her darkest secrets. They were filled with honesty and emanated that warmth Agatha always fought from fear of letting it swallow her whole.

But maybe it wouldn’t be that bad. Maybe she could-

A knock on the door startled them both. The pen in Agatha's hand ripped through the Post-it note, leaving a small indentation in the polished wood.

Her eyes shifted away from Rio as she looked at the door, straightening her spine and bracing her elbows on the desk, an indifferent mask on her face. "Come in."

Unlike her friends, who barreled into her office without a second thought, her assistant entered with the caution of a man stepping into shark-infested waters - without much of a choice, but still desperately hoping he wouldn't be the one bitten.

He squeezed through the barely open doorway, his lanky frame contorting awkwardly as he stumbled inside, his focus glued to his phone.

"I'm so sorry to interrupt, but-" he glanced up mid-sentence, his words dying in his throat the moment his eyes landed on Rio. He blinked as if his brain needed a moment to process what he was seeing. "Rio?"

Agatha's fingers twitched. You've got to be fucking kidding me.

Before she could tell her assistant to get lost, Rio grinned, her posture relaxing.

"Sup, Billy," she said casually as if her presence at the office was the most natural thing in the world, and Agatha groaned.

She remembered Rio mentioning Billy - an assistant at some firm. But in a city of over half a million people, there had to be hundreds, if not thousands, of Williams. The odds that this Billy was her Billy?

Fucking astronomical.

And yet, here they were.

She cleared her throat, dragging Billy's attention away from Rio. His eyes snapped to her, widening slightly at the unmistakable irritation written all over her face.

"I'm busy, Teen," she said, each word sharpened at the edges.

Billy gulped, but the warning in her tone was not enough to stop his gaze from dropping to her hand. His face shifted in real time, confusion melting into realization, into shock.

"Oh. Oh," he staggered back as if the revelation physically hit him, his gaze bouncing between Agatha and Rio. "You - and - oh my God."

Rio chuckled, watching as Billy floundered, his mouth opening and closing like a fish gasping for air.

"I think we broke him."

Agatha was not amused.

She pinched the bridge of her nose, once again wondering what she had done to deserve the universe's hatred.

Unable to come up with an answer, she braced her palms on her desk, pushing herself up as her eyes drilled into her assistant, carrying the weight of her next words.

"Teen," she said sternly, snapping him out of his stupor. He looked at her, wide-eyed and scared. "I hope you understand your knowledge of our... situation is confidential."

The warning in her voice unlocked his stunned body, making him nod vigorously. "Yes, of course."

"Which means," she continued, too focused on scaring the man into silence to flinch at the title. "That if anybody at this office learns about our deal, you'll be held accountable for it."

Billy's throat bobbed nervously. "I won't tell anyone," he said quickly. "I already promised Rio."

"He did," Rio added unhelpfully.

Agatha clenched her jaw. "I don't care what you told her. Right now, you're not her friend, you're my assistant, and I need you to tell me."

The prospect of finding another assistant was daunting.

Even without a law degree, Billy was good at keeping her professional life running like a well-oiled machine. He was equal parts gatekeeper, problem solver, and fire extinguisher - anticipating issues before they arose and handling them with efficiency. He had an uncanny ability to juggle ten tasks at once, from managing her impossible schedule to fielding calls from clients who thought "urgent" meant "mildly inconvenient".

However, his organizational skills weren't what made her reluctant to even consider finding someone to replace him. Organized people weren't rare, and with the company's reputation, she doubted she would have any trouble with lining up the candidates for the position. Agatha hated job interviews with a passion, but she could sit through a day or two of grilling people and making them squirm to see who would break.

Except she knew she wouldn't find anyone as adaptable as Billy.

He could read Agatha's mood with frightening accuracy, knowing exactly when to push, when to back off, and when to slip a much-needed coffee onto her desk without a word. His sharp memory, quick thinking, and ability to handle pressure made him indispensable.

He also had a habit of pushing his luck just enough to be amusing - but never enough to get fired.

"Mrs. Harkness," Billy hesitated, once again looking like a deer in headlights. "Wait, should I call you Mrs. Harkness-Vidal?"

Rio snorted just as Agatha's face contorted in a dangerous snarl. "Are you trying to get yourself fired, dude?"

"It's not my fault!" he argued, but his voice was more scared than defiant. "You were so secretive about it! Oh, I got married, but it's a plan to pay off my student loans. If anybody asks, I’ve been dating her for a year. Anyway, don't worry about it," Rio rolled her eyes at the higher pitch of the words, an inaccurate imitation of her.

"I don't sound like that," she pointed out, crossing her arms. "And I told you enough."

"You could've warned me you married my boss!"

"I didn't know she was your boss! You rarely mention her name!"

"You could've given me a better description than a hot-" he stopped himself, eyes darting to Agatha's raised brows and pursed lips. Clearing his throat, he ran a hand through his well-maintained curls, undoubtedly greasing it. The amount of hair gel he used was concerning. "I-"

"No, please, keep acting like I'm not here, in my office," Agatha growled. "We didn't hyphenate our names."

She wouldn't be caught dead adding Rio's surname to her own. The deal had already taken enough from her - control, pride, free will - she would never give it her identity.

Not to mention that she would probably spontaneously burst into flames if anybody called her Mrs. Harkness-Vidal.

"Of course, of course, I'm sorry," Billy muttered quickly, averting his gaze. "I won't tell anyone about this, I swear. I wouldn't do anything to jeopardize your reputation here or anywhere else, Mrs. Harkness."

Agatha lustrated him briefly, weighing his sincere tone and the subtle spark of fear in his eyes. Satisfied with the answer, she nodded, removing her hands from the desk and bracing them on her hips.

"Great," she said, turning her attention to Rio. "I have to get back to work. Leave."

Rio rolled her eyes at the sharp tone, her gaze flicking to Billy as if debating whether to tell him to step outside so she could finish their previous conversation. Agatha could already see the thought forming and opened her mouth to shut it down before it left Rio's lips.

But Rio, ever the pain in her ass, simply smirked and strolled toward the door at her own pace, ignoring the tension humming in the air. As she passed Billy, she clapped a hand on his shoulder in mock sympathy.

"Good luck," she laughed, her tone dripping with amusement. Billy flinched like she had just handed him a live grenade.

Agatha was seconds away from snapping at her, but Rio was already reaching for the door handle. Just as she pulled it open, she glanced back over her shoulder, her smirk widening into something deliberately smug.

"See you at home, wifey."

Agatha's fingers shot toward the nearest object - a stapler, maybe, or a paperweight - but before she could launch it across the room, Rio was already gone, leaving nothing but the faint echo of her laughter behind.

Chapter End Notes

Hi, honestly, I don't have much to say except the usual "I promise I have a point here and something WILL happen". Either way, I hope you enjoyed the chapter (and maybe leave a comment if you're not too mad about how slowly this story is progressing? hahaha). See you next week!

Chapter 11: Partners

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The next day, Agatha found herself in a private booth of a restaurant near the office, still dressed in her work clothes, Jen and Lilia's expectant eyes on her as she sipped on her water.

The reason for the impromptu dinner hung heavily in the air, gaining weight with every second she spent sifting through the menu, talking to the waiter, and checking her phone as if the passing time could discourage her friends from interrogating her.

She put down her glass and reached for her phone again when Jen finally snapped.

"Stop ignoring us and start talking!"

Agatha slowly put the device on the table, screen up so she could see any incoming messages, and leaned back in her chair.

"The weather's been improving, don't you think?" she asked casually, relishing the frustration simmering in Jen's eyes.

"Agatha," Lilia said, the warning in her voice clear and sharp. "You know why we're here. Wouldn't you rather get this over with and go home?"

She would, especially since the regular babysitter could only watch Nicky for the next hour. Then, Rio would take over - a new development stemming from Sharon's unavailability for the rest of the evening.

Who knew annoying widows had such a busy life?

Still, she refused to let up that easily.

"Am I supposed to read your minds?" she scoffed, raising her eyebrows in a challenge. "If you want something from me, ask."

Jen groaned, rubbing her temples as if Agatha's games physically pained her. "Do you have to be a pain in the ass about everything?"

Agatha snapped her fingers. "Excellent question - yes."

Lilia exhaled sharply, cutting in before Jen could take the bait. "What's the story with you and Rio?" her voice was steady, measured - the same tone she used in court when cornering an uncooperative witness. "Tell us from the beginning."

Agatha pursed her lips. She knew that tone. Once it entered a conversation, there was no escaping it. The time for sarcasm and deflections had run out.

She leaned back in her chair, crossing her arms. "I met her at the bar the night Jen abandoned me," she began, shooting the mentioned woman a nasty glare to make her scorn clear.

"I had a break-"

"Let her talk," Lilia interrupted, raising her hand to silence Jen's protest. Jen huffed but nodded for Agatha to continue.

Agatha drummed her fingers on the table, her eyes flicking toward the door to make sure they were still alone. Their collective status had secured them a private room at the restaurant - no prying ears, no curious ears. Good.

Before Evanora's call, she didn't care about discussing the arrangement in public places, aware that her mother was not that interested in her life to have people follow her around the clock. But now that the battle had begun, the warhorn blaring loud the moment the word "Mother" flashed on her phone screen two days ago, she had to take every precaution.

Now, she had to be careful. Every conversation was a risk: every word, a weapon.

Satisfied that they were alone, she exhaled. When she spoke again, her voice was quieter but sure. "I stayed to drown some sorrows, and Rio took over the bar for Alice. She grilled me about my life, and after I told her why I was there, she offered a solution to my problem. We got married a few weeks later. She moved in the day before my birthday."

Silence settled over the table, thick and expectant.

Then the door swung open.

A waiter entered, arms stacked with plates. He moved quickly, sensing the tension in the room, and disappeared with nothing more than a polite nod.

Jen waited until his footsteps faded before speaking. "That was vague as shit, and you know it," she grabbed the cutlery, pointing a knife at Agatha for emphasis.

Lilia didn't touch her food. Instead, she studied Agatha with sharp, calculating eyes. "What was the problem?" she asked. "And why did you have to get married?"

Agatha tilted her head, chin jutted out in defiance. "Is it that hard to believe we fell madly in love and decided to get hitched?"

Jen snorted. "Knowing you? Yes."

The words stung more than she cared to admit. Before she could mask their impact, Lilia shot Jen a warning glare, her expression softening when she turned back to Agatha.

"You're crazy, but not that crazy. You wouldn't do it without considering Nicky," she said as if apologizing for Jen's reaction. "So, why did you have to get married?"

Agatha sighed, the fight gone from her body.

"I'm not telling you every detail," she warned, taking a page out of Rio's book - she would give the essential information to satiate her friends' curiosity and then tell them the version designed for everyone else. "But it was because of my mother. I married Rio to throw a wrench in her plans, and now we have to convince her the marriage is real. The official story is that we'd been dating for a year before the trip to the courthouse."

Jen and Lilia exchanged a glance.

Lilia, ever the composed one, folded her hands on the table. "Evanora forced you to marry Rio?"

Agatha reached for her fork, swirling it in the pasta, her appetite gone. "Forced is a bit strong, and it didn't have to be Rio. But sure, you can say that."

"Jesus," Jen whispered, her voice lacking the usual mocking edge. "That's fucked up."

"You're not going to give us more details, are you?" Lilia prodded, still looking at her questioningly.

"The less people know, the better," Agatha put the food in her mouth. Despite the high-quality ingredients, it tasted like cardboard, sitting uncomfortably on her tongue before she swallowed it with difficulty.

In truth, it didn't matter how much she told them. After admitting the marriage was fake, she had to count on them to keep up the lie - whether she shared only a fragment or every detail of the story. But she couldn't bring herself to retell every step of the process she had gone through to end up in this place, not when every word felt like a punch to her dignity.

To her surprise, Lilia merely nodded, slowly digging into her own food.

Jen didn't look pleased. "We're just letting her off the hook? With that non-answer?"

Lilia ignored her. "What's the plan now?" she asked calmly, cutting into her steak. "If you're against Evanora, you need a good one."

Agatha reached for her water to wash down the food sticking to the roof of her mouth. "We're meeting her in Kestra on Thursday to sell the story."

"How long have you been married?"

"Three weeks."

Lilia hummed. "And you haven't made any public appearances yet?"

Agatha scrunched her eyebrows at the question. "No?"

"You should," Jen cut in. "It'll look weird if you keep her in your house like a hostage."

Agatha sighed, rubbing her temples. "I'm not keeping her hostage."

Jen pointed her fork at her. "Yeah? Then why does it look like you're hiding her?"

Agatha didn't have an immediate response to that, mostly because Jen had a point. She and Rio had slipped into a quiet routine - one that kept their interactions primarily confined to the house. Public appearances weren't a part of that equation.

Lilia chewed her food thoughtfully before setting the knife down. "If this is about optics, you need to control the narrative. If you want people to buy this marriage, you need to be seen together. Make it believable."

"The story is we've been dating for a year," Agatha reminded them. "It would look suspicious if we started flaunting it right after the marriage."

Jen tapped her fingers against her chin before shaking her head. "No, I don't think so. You didn't have eyes on you then."

"She's right," Lilia added. "Evanora was in the middle of losing a race for the past year; she probably didn't pay much attention to your life. But now? She will."

Agatha clenched her jaw. She hated it when they ganged up on her, especially when they were right.

Jen smirked, sensing her irritation. "A dinner, maybe? A charity event? It has to be public enough to reach your mother."

"Preferably with people who know you, so the rumors spread faster," Lilia sipped her wine, deep in thought.

Then, Jen snapped her fingers, a victorious grin on her face. "The gala in two weeks!"

Agatha's hand froze in the air. The pasta slipped off the hovering fork and fell back on the plate with a wet splatter.

"No," she hissed, eyes darting between her friends. "Absolutely not."

"It's the perfect opportunity," Jen pointed out, glancing at Lilia. "Back me up?"

"It is. A work event always produces rumors faster than a glossy magazine."

The image of an immense yet stifling room, teeming with coworkers and clients, pressed in on her mind. The air would be thick with polite conversation, glasses clinking, and the weight of too many scrutinizing eyes. And beside her - Rio. Close enough that Agatha would feel the warmth radiating off her skin, possibly even touching her to sell the story as they accepted murmured congratulations on their marriage.

It sent a sharp twist of discomfort through her stomach.

"Just think about it," Jen urged, practically vibrating with excitement - far more than Agatha thought appropriate. "You always come alone to these events-"

"Because dragging anyone else along would be cruel and unusual punishment," Agatha interrupted, setting her fork down with a pointed clink. "I wouldn't even go if it weren't for Lilia's constant threats."

Lilia rolled her eyes, unimpressed. "You're a partner, Agatha. It's expected," she said, repeating the same line she had been drilling into her for the past five years. "And just like that, it's expected that you bring your spouse."

"But-"

"Rio isn't just some girl you're stringing along," Lilia pressed, her tone sharp, cutting through Agatha's rising agitation. "She's your wife. That means certain things are required of you. And the gala? It's the perfect opportunity to introduce your marriage to the world."

Agatha gritted her teeth.

She should have been used to it by now - the words wife, home, and Mrs. Harkness had been tossed at her so relentlessly over the past three weeks that they should have lost all weight, worn down by Rio's relentless teasing. A part of her suspected that was Rio's plan: to desensitize her to the terms, make them familiar so she wouldn't flinch whenever she heard them.

It worked to a degree, but they still caught her off-guard sometimes, especially when someone other than Rio used them as freely as Lilia had.

"If that's not convincing enough," Jen raised her finger, pointing it at Agatha. "People in the office already know you're married because of yesterday. The gossip mill will spin out of control if you come alone."

Agatha made a mental note to yell at Rio again for breaking into her workplace.

She drummed her fingers against the table, mulling over the words. It made sense. Evanora would undoubtedly hear about the gala and possibly have one of her lapdogs attend it to spy on them. Showing up alone would give her an advantage, something to exploit in the long run, and Agatha didn't want to give her more ammunition.

She sighed, her jaw tightening. "Fine. I'll bring her."

Despite her surrender, Lilia still seemed unsatisfied. "You should also think about other outings. Regular dates, visiting each other at work, even shopping together, could cement the lie."

The idea made Agatha's eye twitch. Deep down, she realized their marriage couldn't be as low-profile as she would like, contained only to living together and wearing the rings on their fingers. It was a performance, an act meant for a broader audience, and her qualms about keeping her private life under wraps had no place in the equation.

Somehow, it didn't help that the marriage wasn't real, that it wasn't actually a part of her private life but a stack of legal documents and an infuriating woman haunting her house.

If anything, that made it worse.

Because it meant convincing everyone that she found someone to love her while distinctly aware that the marriage had a precise termination date.

While knowing that, at the end of the agreement, she would be alone.

Again.

Agatha silently cursed Lilia and her accurate observations.

"You don't even know what's at stake," she grumbled, realizing the silence had stretched for a beat too long. "Why are you invested?"

Lilia shrugged, a hint of a smile crinkling the corners of her eyes. "Watching Evanora lose is always a pleasure."

Something in her expression told Agatha that it wasn't the case, that her motivation ran deeper than Evanora's downfall.

Before she could question it, Jen spoke again, her voice tinged with amusement.

"So, are you wearing matching outfits?"

Agatha almost climbed over the table to strangle her.

After almost three hours of withstanding Lilia's inquisitive looks and fighting the urge to stab Jen with her fork, Agatha sighed in relief as she entered her house.

Even though her friends had, mercifully, dropped the topic of her marriage, the gala, and other possible outings after a while, the conversation had her spent. It was the first time she had shared the more nuanced logistics of the arrangement with someone other than her reflection - she had a habit of talking to herself, admittedly the only person in the world worth talking to - and the constructive criticism irked her.

The lie was fragile, she realized that, but Lilia and Jen picked it apart almost effortlessly, examining the details and pointing out flaws. Flaws that Agatha knew existed but refused to consider because of the actions fixing them would mean.

Now, she couldn't ignore them. She had to patch up the cracks before the entire construction crumbled, and she blamed, perhaps unfairly, Rio.

Rio, who couldn't wait until they were at the house to yell at her, who showed up at her work unannounced.

Rio, who materialized in the hall almost as if conjured.

"We have a problem."

If only one.

Agatha shrugged off her coat and tossed it on the rack without sparing Rio a glance.

"We do," she hissed, unlacing her shoes and placing them beside Rio's sneakers. "Thanks to your stunt, I had to spend three hours trapped in a room with Lilia and Jen."

"Agatha."

Something in Rio's tone - low, clipped, serious - made Agatha look up. Her stomach tightened at the tension in the woman's face.

"We have a problem."

This time, the words landed right, threading a cold shiver down Agatha's spine. Her eyes flicked toward the staircase. Without another word, Rio gave a slow, deliberate shake of her head.

Agatha understood instantly, already moving toward the living room - the furthest they could get from Nicky's bedroom.

"Speak," she ordered as soon as they were safely out of earshot.

Rio dragged a hand through her hair, sinking onto the couch with a sigh as if she were choosing her words carefully. Finally, she met Agatha's gaze.

"Sharon asked me why Nicky calls me his mom's friend today."

Agatha froze.

The words settled over the room like a suffocating blanket, pressing down on her lungs. She had prepared for a lot of things - skepticism, scrutiny, the occasional raised brow from people who thought she, of all people, would never settle down - but not this.

Not fucking Sharon.

"What?!"

"I know," Rio exhaled, rubbing a hand across her face. "She said it in more words, but essentially, she thinks we're hiding our true selves from him."

Agatha blinked, once, twice, processing the information.

Deep down, she knew telling Nicky one version of the truth while everyone else got a different one was bound to backfire. The web of lies she and Rio had woven was fragile, delicate - one wrong step and the whole thing could shatter. She told herself she was keeping Nicky out of it for his own sake, shielding him from the complications of a situation even she struggled to grasp at times.

But the truth was far less noble.

Telling Nicky would cement the lie far more than if she shouted it for the entire world to hear. It would mean pretending to be Rio's wife in the house, outside of it, everywhere. It would make the situation even more confusing, more complicated than it already was.

So, she avoided it, hoping nobody would try to talk to Nicky about it, discouraged by his tight-lipped approach to Rio's presence at the house.

But Agatha had never been that lucky.

Lies had a way of unraveling, no matter how carefully spun.

And, of course, fucking Sharon created the first tear.

"Shit," she finally said, sitting in her favorite chair as her legs threatened to buckle under the revelation's weight. "What did you tell her?"

"A version of the truth," Rio's eyes locked onto hers, unwavering. "That he's still getting used to me, and we don't want to rush him."

Agatha exhaled sharply through her nose. It was a good answer, a safe one, but that wasn't the problem.

The problem was that Sharon had asked in the first place.

"Do you think she'll try to talk to him about it?"

Rio hesitated, and her solemn expression unnerved Agatha more than the conversation itself. Rio's gravity stripped her of the illusion that they could sweep Sharon's words under the rug and keep Nicky in the dark. It spoke volumes about the severity of the situation and the need to handle it.

"She might. And if not her, then somebody else," Rio said slowly, her chest rising with a deep inhale. "It's a miracle we've gotten through three weeks without anybody bringing it up to him."

Agatha knew she was right, but the alternative to lying made blood freeze in her veins.

"We're not telling him," she warned before Rio could even say the words, her voice sharp and non-negotiable.

Rio worried her lower lip with her teeth, visibly conflicted. "I don't think we have a choice," she said gently.

Despite their softness, the words hit Agatha like a truck, making her recoil in the chair. She inhaled sharply, straightening her spine and pinning the woman under a hard look. "No, Rio."

"Agat-"

"No," she repeated more forcefully, keeping her voice low so it wouldn't travel through the house and up the stairs to Nicky's room. "I'm not dragging him into this."

"We have to say something," Rio argued. "You said we control the narrative; we need to contain this before somebody beats us to it."

Agatha's nostrils flared. "Don't use my words against me."

"They're the only words you'll listen to."

"How do you expect me to explain this to him?" Agatha demanded, her jaw tightening. "He's ten."

"We don't have to tell him about the deal," Rio said, sinking further into the cushions when Agatha's face twisted with rage.

"Oh, so you think it's best to tell him we're married for real?" she hissed, the idea as absurd as the situation itself.

Lying to everyone else was one thing.

Lying to Nicky was something else entirely.

Especially when it came to the way he adored Rio.

Rio sighed, rubbing the back of her neck, her frustration clear but measured. "Agatha, I know this isn't ideal, but he's going to find out one way or another. Even if he doesn't bring it up, what about Sharon? One of the teachers? Your mother?"

Agatha's eyes snapped to Rio's at the idea, her upper lip curled in a snarl. "She won't come near him."

The thought of Evanora hounding Nicky for information created a painful pit in her stomach, a black hole of dread threatening to suck her into the abyss. It hurt because she knew it was possible. She knew her mother could corner Nicky without her by his side, either by visiting the house when he was with Sharon or coming to his soccer practice.

And what was even worse - she knew Evanora was calculated and cruel enough to do it.

Rio's expression softened. "I hope so too, but we can't overlook it."

Agatha swallowed hard, her throat tightening. She hated this. Hated that Rio had a point. Hated that she fooled herself into believing that she could keep the lie contained outside the walls of her home.

She could lie to the world, but Nicky?

"I just..." her voice was uncharacteristically small, a rare crack in her armor. "I don't want to confuse him."

Rio nodded as if she understood her hesitance, and it seemed worse than if she'd pressed harder. Sympathy was a sharp blade in Rio's hands, and Agatha had yet to learn how to block its blows.

"Then we make it simple," Rio said, shifting forward so her elbows rested on her knees. "We tell him we got married because we care about each other and make a good team."

Agatha scoffed, but it lacked the usual bite. "It's still a lie."

Rio's face remained stoic. "We're already lying to him," she noticed. "And this is as close to the truth as we can get without telling him everything."

It was dangerous, stupid, wrong. Agatha could think of a million ways it could backfire, including Nicky getting attached to Rio, only to see her move out in less than a year.

Still, they couldn't risk somebody blindsiding him with the revelation. It would not only threaten the arrangement but make him feel left out, omitted in an aspect that he should be the first to know about.

Besides, as reluctant as Agatha was to admit it, Nicky had already gotten attached to Rio, and she predicted it wouldn't matter if Rio stayed with them for two months or a year - Nicky would pout about her leaving all the same.
