Rio's relationship with his mother played a small role in the inevitable reluctance that would follow the woman's moving out.

Agatha wet her lips, sinking further into the chair. "We do make a good team when it comes to lying," she finally said, unwilling to dwell on the first part of Rio's sentence.

They didn't care about each other. The only thing holding them together was the money tied to their deal, but Nicky didn't have to know that. And they could pretend for his sake.

"Yeah," Rio watched her expectantly as if waiting for more.

Agatha drummed her fingers against the armrest, her gaze traveling the room to avoid the inquisitive eyes drilling holes into her face. "I'll talk to him today."

"Great," Rio relaxed on the couch, the tension seeping out of her muscles. Agatha realized the woman must have prepared for a longer match, a sharp back and forth that would undoubtedly transform into a hissing battle of wits, but she was too tired to argue after the conversation with Lilia and Jen.

Especially when she knew Rio was right.

Agatha hated it when other people were right.

The quiet agreement barely settled between them before she inhaled slowly, deciding to rip the band-aid off. The sooner she told Rio, the better.

"We'll have to be more public."

Rio's eyebrows shot up, her confusion immediate. "With?"

Agatha gestured between them, the ring on her finger catching the light like it wanted to offer Rio a clue. Not that she needed one.

"I have a work event in two weeks. We're going together."

Rio sat up straighter, suspicion flickering across her face. "Wait. You've yelled at me - four times, by the way - for showing up at your office. And now you want to make a public statement?"

Agatha rolled her eyes. "You kept count?"

"You were loud. Hard to forget."

Agatha let the comment slide, exhaling through her nose. "Look, it wouldn't work in the long run," she admitted, ignoring the part of her that had - stupidly - hoped they could keep their arrangement quiet forever. Wishful thinking.

Rio's gaze sharpened. "You mean your mother wouldn't let it work."

Agatha's jaw tightened. "She's already making moves. We have to be one step ahead."

Rio studied her for a moment, unreadable. "Did she call again?"

"No," Agatha said. "Once was enough. She's watching, and we need to up our game."

"By parading our marriage in front of your coworkers?"

Agatha ignored the amusement laced in Rio's tone. "By making it look real. After the gala, we'll discuss other outings."

"Other outings?" Rio repeated, crossing her arms, a knowing smirk tugging at her lips. "Dates, you mean?"

Something uncomfortable settled low in Agatha's stomach at the word. Dates.

She hadn't framed it like that, hadn't even considered it. To her, these would be strategic appearances - planned, discussed, and executed with precision. A means to an end.

Without spontaneity, blurred lines, or room for mistakes. Just another clean-cut puzzle to finish the picture of their marriage in other people's eyes.

And yet, the word lingered, unsettling in a way she couldn't quite shake.

Agatha cleared her throat, shifting her weight. "As I said, we'll discuss it later," she fiddled with the rings adorning her fingers, purposefully avoiding touching the wedding band as if it might burn her on contact. "We have dinner with my mother first, then the gala. That should be enough for now."

Rio, unfortunately, wasn't done. She leaned in slightly, amusement dancing in her eyes. "So, do I get flowers?"

Agatha's head snapped up. "What?"

"For our date," Rio grinned, unbothered by the stunned silence stretching between them. Then, with a thoughtful tilt of her head, she added, "You're right, though. I should keep up the tradition of giving you flowers. Do you have favorites?"

"There's no tradition," Agatha snapped, begrudgingly recalling the bouquet Rio had gifted her for her birthday. The one that, despite her best efforts of conveniently forgetting to change the water, had lasted two whole weeks on the dinner table, proudly displayed and frequently admired by Sharon.

"There will be no flowers," she added, voice firm.

Rio pressed her tongue into her cheek, studying her with the kind of amusement that set Agatha's nerves on edge. "You look like you'd like azaleas."

Agatha groaned, dragging a hand down her face. "I hate you."

Rio chuckled, pushing off the couch with the confidence of someone who knew exactly what they were doing. "You'll love me by the time our third date rolls around."

Agatha glared at her retreating form, her pulse unsteady for reasons she refused to acknowledge.

Rio was having too much fun with this.

She shook off the unsettling feeling spreading across her chest and stood up, marching straight toward the stairs.

Putting off the conversation with Nicky was impossible now. The ground had already shifted beneath her feet, an earthquake set off by Sharon's question.

Knowing her neighbor, Agatha suspected she wouldn't last long without at least hinting at something she shouldn't. Sharon had probably already spread the news to anyone with functioning ears, and Agatha had to stop her before everyone and their dog knew.

So, with her heart in her throat, she knocked on Nicky's door and stepped inside after hearing his muffled "Come in."

He sat cross-legged on the bed, his small hands gripping his Nintendo Switch, his face scrunched in deep concentration.

"Hi, Mama," he muttered, not looking up.

Agatha closed the door behind her, her eyes instinctively flicking to the plant Rio had given him. It sat proudly on his desk, somehow thriving despite the controlled chaos of his room.

"The plant looks good," she noted, easing onto the edge of his bed.

"His name's Luci," Nicky corrected, still fixated on the screen. "Rio says it's 'cause I take special care of him."

Agatha exhaled softly. "I'm sure you do."

The silence stretched between them, interrupted only by the game's sound effects and Nicky's occasional grumbles. Agatha let it linger, choosing her next words carefully.

Eventually, she sighed, almost defeated.

"I wanted to talk to you about something," she watched him closely, but he only hummed in vague acknowledgment, too distracted to pick up on the weight in her voice. "It's important," she added, tapping his hand lightly - a wordless request to pause the game.

Nicky groaned. "I'm almost done, Mama. Can't it wait?"

It could - for the next five minutes it would probably take him to finish - but if she didn't say it now, she might never get the words out.

"It'll only take a minute, Nicholas."

The use of his full name did the trick. Nicky sighed dramatically but slapped the pause button, turning to her with cautious curiosity.

"Yeah?"

Agatha smiled, though it felt stiff, forced. "You know how Rio's been living with us?"

Nicky's expression immediately turned suspicious. "She's not moving out already, right?"

"No, she's not," she assured him. She reached up to run a hand through her hair but stopped short, remembering it was still pulled into the tight bun she wore to work. The hand dropped uselessly into her lap as she inhaled slowly. "And you know how some people get married when they want to be a family?"

Nicky's eyes narrowed slightly, but he nodded.

"Well," Agatha swallowed against the tightness in her throat. "Rio and I got married."

His eyes widened slightly, the console nearly slipping from his grasp. "Oh."

Agatha shifted, tucking one leg beneath her to face him fully. "I wanted to tell you earlier, but I wanted to make sure you had time to get used to things first."

Nicky pressed his lips together, his expression thoughtful.

"So... you're together like Aunt Wanda and Uncle Vis?"

The question hung in the air. Agatha opened her mouth, searching for the right words - ones that weren't a lie but weren't the whole truth either.

Eventually, she nodded. "Kind of."

Nicky frowned. "But you don't act like them," his nose scrunched as if he were working through a puzzle. "They kiss and stuff."

Agatha made a mental note to yell at Wanda for unnecessary PDA in front of her son.

"Every family looks different, baby," she said carefully. "Some people get married because they fall in love, some because they want to take care of each other. Rio and I chose to get married because we wanted to be a team - to make sure we're all safe and happy."

Nicky tilted his head, still thinking. "So... you're like partners?"

The words hit something deep in Agatha's chest, but she forced a small nod. "Exactly. We're partners."

He considered it for a beat longer, then shrugged. "Okay."

"Okay?" Agatha repeated, unsure whether to be relieved or concerned.

"Okay," Nicky said again as if confirming it for himself.

Agatha waited for more - anything - but her son just blinked at her, his fingers idly tapping against the edge of his console.

"That's it?" she asked, unable to keep the disbelief from her voice.

Nicky shrugged. "Yeah. I mean, you already act like partners."

Agatha blinked. "We do?"

"Well, yeah," he wrinkled his nose as if she were the slowest person on the planet. "She cooks for us when you're busy. She helps with my math homework even though she makes a face the whole time. And she gives me the good cereal-"

"The cereal I buy."

"No, you buy the healthy cereal. Rio gives me hers when you're not looking," Nicky flinched, his eyes widening. "Don't tell Rio I told you."

Agatha suppressed a frown and made a mental note to throw out Rio's shitty cereal.

"And," Nicky continued hastily, hoping to distract her from the divulged secret. "You argue, like, all the time. But it's not your lawyer arguing, you know? It's like you're having fun, and sometimes you even laugh, so I know it's not serious."

Agatha stared at him, caught completely off guard. "I don't-"

"You do," he said simply. "So, yeah. You're partners. Makes sense you got married."

Her throat tightened.

This should have been easier. He had accepted it so readily, hadn't even questioned the why of it, and yet-

And yet, something about the way he said it, like it was obvious, like it was natural, sent an unfamiliar ache curling around her ribs.

Nicky didn't see a business arrangement. He saw a team.

And somehow, despite everything, Rio had become a part of that team in ways Agatha hadn't even noticed.

"...Okay," she murmured, brushing his hair back in a quiet, automatic gesture.

Nicky grinned, ducking away from her hand. "Can I go back to my game now?"

She huffed a laugh, shaking her head. "Yeah, go ahead."

"Cool," he said, already shifting back into position, eyes glued to the screen once more. But just before unpausing, he added, "Can Rio watch me more often since you're married? It was fun today."

Agatha barely flinched, her answer almost automatic. "Sure."

As she left the room, closing the door behind her, she exhaled a breath she hadn't realized she was holding.

She had expected this conversation to be difficult, to require a delicate balancing act of truth and omission.

She hadn't expected it to shake something loose inside her.

And she certainly hadn't expected Rio to already fit into their lives so seamlessly that her son - her observant, stubborn, impossibly clever son - had thought this marriage made perfect sense.

God help her.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! Thank you for all the comments and kudos (I think it's over 700 at the moment? That's fucking crazy, thank you!). Anyway, I hope you enjoyed the chapter, though I have to admit, I'm not its biggest fan, and I'll see you next week when I thiiink we'll have dinner with Evanora. Stay safe out there!

Chapter 12: The dinner

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The week blurred into a frenzied haze, and before Agatha could brace herself for the inevitable, Thursday arrived in all its dooming glory.

They were as prepared as possible - their story was practiced, memorized, and rehearsed like a school play. Or, more accurately, a Broadway production, where even the slightest misstep could ruin the illusion. Without room for improvisation, for error.

If they failed this first test, the rest of the year wouldn't matter. Their performance had to be sterling.

"You're going to break your fingers."

Rio's voice, gentle yet firm, cut through the tension hanging thick in the car.

Agatha blinked, glancing down. Her knuckles had gone white against the steering wheel, her fingers locked in a death grip. With effort, she forced herself to loosen them.

"We'll be fine."

The words felt hollow the moment they left Rio's lips, an empty promise neither could be sure would come true.

"We need to be better than fine," Agatha muttered, eyes glued to the road ahead. "We have to be perfect."

"And we will be."

Rio's unwavering confidence did nothing to settle the unease crawling under Agatha's skin.

Because Rio didn't know Evanora.

She didn't know how cunning, how merciless the woman could be in an interrogation - how effortlessly she wove traps, spun delicate webs of deceit, coaxing you forward until you were too tangled to escape.

Agatha had spent a lifetime preparing for this moment. She had studied her mother's tactics, learned to withstand her cutting remarks, and trained herself to recognize the invisible lines she dared others to cross.

And yet, even she sometimes fell into the snares.

Years of court battles, of staring down the best lawyers in the city and grinding them to dust beneath her heel - none of it compared to arguing with Evanora.

Her grip tightened again, the steering wheel creaking under the pressure.

"Agatha, seriously. You're going to hurt yourself."

Before she could loosen the hold or snap at the woman to mind her business, a warm hand settled on her wrist, just below her sleeve.

Skin on skin.

Agatha inhaled sharply, the touch more grounding than she wanted to admit.

They had talked about this - set the rules and defined the limits. What touches were necessary, and how far did they have to go to make this believable?

The conversation had been painful, mostly for Agatha.

She hadn't expected to feel so ridiculously exposed just discussing something as simple as hand-holding. But Rio had been infuriatingly at ease, watching her with barely concealed amusement as Agatha struggled to answer questions that should have been straightforward.

What counted as a natural display of affection? Would touching her arm be normal? A hand on her back? Sitting close together?

It was absurd. They were adults, not teenagers, stepping into their first relationship. It shouldn't have been difficult.

And yet, every hypothetical situation had made Agatha uncomfortable in ways she didn't have the patience to analyze. Not because of the idea itself, but because picturing it - picturing Rio touching her, standing too close, leaning in with easy familiarity - felt entirely too real.

She had rushed through the conversation, spitting out answers in clipped tones, desperate to move on before she embarrassed herself further. But Rio had taken her time, pushing just enough to get under Agatha's skin, like she found every inch of her discomfort entertaining.

And now, here they were.

Rio's palm rested against her wrist, warm, steady, grounding - just as they had discussed, just as they had agreed would be normal.

So why the hell did it feel anything but?

Agatha found the answer simmering on the tip of her tongue and didn't bother to hold it back. "Keep your hands to yourself until we're in public."

Despite the warning in her voice, Rio's fingers lingered. A deliberate pause, a fraction too long - just to make Agatha notice.

Then, finally, they slipped away.

"Whatever you want, sweetheart."

Agatha's grip on the wheel tightened again. She turned, glaring at Rio from the corner of her eye. "Do you want to get out of this car alive?"

Rio only laughed, drumming her fingers lazily against the door. "Am I that distracting?"

Yes.

"We should've worked on that," Rio mused.

Agatha scowled. "On you being distracting?"

"On you not flinching every time I touch you. Or use a pet name."

The words settled between them, heavier than Rio's tone suggested.

For a moment, too brief, too fleeting, Agatha saw it.

Sitting on the couch, book in hand, while Rio played absently with the loose strands of her hair. Gentle fingertips grazing her skin, slow and thoughtless, mapping out the uncovered space like she had every right to.

She imagined sighing at the touch, leaning into it, letting it soothe her instead of setting her on edge.

The image vanished as quickly as it came, leaving something unsettled in its place.

"Sweetheart is a shitty pet name," Agatha grumbled. "You're not a sixty-year-old lunch lady."

"Okay, snookums."

A growl formed at the back of Agatha's throat, low and threatening.

Rio, the menace that she was, only grinned. "Sweetcheeks? Pookie? Lovebug?"

Agatha's jaw twitched as she exhaled slowly, struggling to hold on to her fleeting patience. "I'm reconsidering this entire ordeal."

Rio's smirk only widened. She saw the crack in Agatha's resolve, and like any good opportunist, she dug in.

"Ah, come on, muffin, don't break my heart like that," she sighed, full of mock despair as if Agatha was the one being insufferable. "Honeybun? Boo thang?"

The bark of laughter that escaped against her will was less than dignified. A betrayal.

She bit her lip, trying to shove it back down, but the damage was done. Her shoulders shook with barely restrained giggles, her grip on the wheel finally loosening.

"Boo thang?" she wheezed, completely losing the battle. "Have you ever met a woman who actually wanted to be called that?"

"Not yet," Rio said, completely unbothered, leaning back in her seat. "But I like to think of myself as a trendsetter."

Agatha shook her head, still laughing despite herself.

This woman was unbearable.

Worse?

She liked it.

"Well, I'm vetoing boo thang," she mused, dragging out the last word with deliberate disdain. "And everything else you used. Some of those should be illegal."

"Your wish is my command, gorgeous."

Oh.

Yeah, she could get behind that one.

It was stupid how easily the word slid out of Rio's mouth, effortless and smooth, like it belonged there.

Agatha's brain stuttered for half a second too long, and before she could school her reaction, warmth crawled up her neck, settling on her cheeks.

Rio saw it immediately.

Her grin slowly stretched, sharp and self-satisfied, pure Cheshire Cat levels of smugness.

"Looks like we have our winner."

Agatha scowled, hating how weak her voice sounded when she muttered, "Shut up."

It lacked bite, venom, anything that would make Rio stop grinning like that.

So, of course, she didn't.

Instead, she leaned in just a fraction, left arm casually slung over the back of Agatha's seat, studying her with that infuriating amusement, like she had all the time in the world to watch her squirm.

"Say the word, gorgeous," Rio drawled. "And I'll never call you anything else."

Agatha refused to look at her.

Because if she did, she had a feeling she'd lose her dignity, her self-control, herself.

Thankfully, before Rio could test her patience even further, the restaurant's entrance came into view like a lifeline.

Agatha barely let the car roll to a stop before she practically threw herself out of it, yanking the keys from the ignition and striding toward the valet.

"Miss Harkness," the man greeted her with a polite nod, hand outstretched.

Rio materialized beside her a second later - too close, too casual, too damn pleased with herself.

"It's Mrs. Harkness, actually," she corrected the valet with an easy smile.

Agatha fought the instinct to flinch when a warm hand settled around her waist - a clear reminder of the roles they had to play.

Her body went stiff at the touch, but she refused to let it show. Not here, not now.

To his credit, the valet barely blinked at the gesture. He caught the car keys as they slipped from Agatha's frozen hand, the motion smooth and professional.

"My apologies, ma'am," he said softly, his voice polite but detached as he motioned toward the entrance. "My colleague inside will take care of you from here."

Rio nodded appreciatively, sending the man a charming smile.

"Wonderful, thank you!" the hand on Agatha's waist tightened, urging her forward.

Agatha's muscles tensed at the pressure, but she didn't pull away. She couldn't, not in front of the valet, not with the scene they had to sell. So, she allowed Rio to guide her, even as her body screamed to break free of the touch.

"Relax," Rio's voice was low, almost teasing as she leaned in just enough for Agatha to hear, the warmth of her breath sending an involuntary shiver down Agatha's spine. "We've got this."

If it were anyone else, Agatha might have snapped, but Rio's words were a quiet, disarming reminder of the stakes. They had to keep up appearances if this was going to work.

She took a steadying breath, forcing her muscles to relax into the touch as the door opened for them. The air felt cooler inside, the soft hum of chatter and the clink of glasses creating a layer of noise that made it easier to pretend. The maître d' looked up, and a polite smile stretched his lips.

"Right this way, Mrs. and Mrs. Harkness," the man said, the titles falling easily from his lips as if he had been addressing married couples like them for years.

Agatha opened her mouth to protest - after all, they hadn't changed their names - but Rio's fingers dug into her side, stopping her.

"Doesn't matter," Rio whispered, pulling her to follow him to their table.

Agatha swallowed her annoyance, allowing herself to be led through the upscale restaurant.

In another lifetime, she might have paused to admire the sweeping sea view beyond the grand windows, the way the golden light reflected off pristine white tablecloths and sleek gray marble. She could have appreciated the intentional decadence, the quiet hum of wealth and power woven into every polished surface.

But not in this lifetime.

Here, the air was thick with ghosts - dinners where she sat stone-still beneath Evanora's scrutiny, her mother's sharp gaze cutting through her like a scalpel. Every detail had been a reason to tear her apart - her clothes, her order, her posture, her life.

Even now, stepping into this space felt like stepping back into a battlefield.

"Your mother has already arrived, but she had to step out for a minute," the maître d' informed her as they reached the usual table.

The ghosts in Agatha's mind screamed like banshees.

Step out.

More likely, Evanora had orchestrated this deliberate absence, giving Agatha a moment to stew, to sit in the familiar trap and feel the walls closing in before she even arrived.

"May I?"

Agatha's eyes snapped to the man, her mind jolting back to the present. He was waiting, hands outstretched, for her coat.

She exhaled through her nose and shrugged it off in a smooth, mechanical motion, watching Rio do the same.

"I will be right back with your meals."

Agatha merely hummed in acknowledgment as she slid stiffly into the plush chair, her spine locked straight as a blade. She could see her mother already, seated across from her, posture flawless, gaze razor-sharp, lips curved into that signature arch of wordless disapproval.

A phantom presence, a shadow that never left.

Rio settled beside her, her attention drifting across the lavish interior, eyes sparkling with silent awe.

"Is this place so fancy they read your mind?" she mused. "We haven't even looked at the menu yet."

Agatha's scowl deepened.

"My mother ordered for us," she said, voice tight as she glanced toward the entrance.

Still no Evanora.

"You okay?"

A thumb brushed against the back of her hand, making her realize she had been gripping the table's edge as if afraid it would float away.

That grounding sensation from the car returned, spreading through her like a slow burn. A quiet warmth, insistently pressing back against the creeping chill inside her. A tether.

Her breath caught, eyes snapping to Rio's.

The raw concern in those deep brown irises unnerved her more than her mother's absence.

Her lips parted, an easy lie already forming - something dismissive, something sharp, something to make Rio back off.

But the words never made it out.

Instead, she let out an unsteady breath.

"I just want to get this over with," she admitted, voice quieter than she intended - almost shy.

Rio's expression softened even further, her hand settling fully over Agatha's, the warmth no longer fleeting but solid and steady. A touch that didn't demand but offered.

"We'll be okay," Rio whispered, her gaze locked onto hers. "Just tell me if it becomes too much, okay? We can leave whenever you want."

Under any other circumstances, Agatha would've clenched her teeth, stifling the vulnerability blooming in her chest. She would've snatched her hand away, probably hissing at Rio to stop being so soft, so understanding, so warm.

Because warmth was dangerous, it made her want to lean into it, let it melt her frozen shell, and let Rio see.

But these weren't normal circumstances. And for reasons she couldn't untangle, she didn't pull away.

Instead, she turned her hand, lacing their fingers together on the pristine white tablecloth - a silent agreement, a fragile surrender.

Rio gave her a small, reassuring squeeze, and somehow, in the opulent battlefield of her mother's choosing, that simple gesture felt like armor.

"Agatha."

The sharp tone cut through the softness of the moment like a knife, making her instinctively flinch away from Rio, like a child caught with their hand in the cookie jar.

The warmth evaporated from her body the second she met Evanora's eyes - steely, calculated, unforgiving.

The same eyes people always said they shared.

God, how she hated those eyes.

"Mother," she greeted, pleased to find her voice steady despite the ice settling in her veins.

Let the game begin.

Agatha rose, spine straight, chin high - the picture of composure she had spent years perfecting.

"This is my wife, Rio."

Evanora's mouth barely tightened, but the faint flicker of disdain in her gaze was enough. Unbothered, Rio pushed back her chair and stood, her posture relaxed, a polite, easy smile curling her lips.

"Pleasure to meet you, Mrs. Harkness," she said brightly, extending a hand.

Evanora didn't move.

"Senator," she corrected, the single word carrying enough venom to corrode steel.

Agatha's jaw tightened, a silent warning aimed at Rio, but the woman was already tilting her head, studying Evanora with something dark and unreadable gleaming in her eyes.

"Oh," Rio muttered in surprise, too overzealous to be genuine, letting her hand drop. "I thought you lost the last election. My apologies, I must've read that wrong."

The tension cracked, stretching and coiling like a snake readying for attack.

Agatha barely kept her expression neutral, though inside, a flicker of admiration warred with exasperation. Rio was playing with fire - dangerous, unforgiving fire.

Evanora's lips pressed together, her jaw tightening just enough for Agatha to recognize it as a restrained reaction. To anyone else, she might have appeared unaffected, but Agatha had spent years decoding the subtle shifts in her mother's mask.

"How charming," Evanora finally said, voice smooth but laced with steel. She turned her gaze back to Agatha, dismissing Rio without another glance. "I see you've made some... interesting choices, as always."

Rio whistled softly, so low that only Agatha caught it.

"Damn," she muttered under her breath, just loud enough to poke at Evanora's composure. "Didn't think I'd need that coat back so soon, but I swear it just got colder in here."

Agatha swallowed a sigh and shot Rio a look, one she hoped conveyed, for the love of God, behave. Rio merely quirked a brow, a picture of innocence.

"Shall we sit?" Agatha suggested, cutting through the tension before it thickened further. She gestured toward the table, forcing her voice into its usual cool detachment. "I'm sure we have a lot to discuss."

Evanora's eyes flickered between them before she gracefully lowered herself into her seat.

"Yes," she murmured, watching them settle back into their chairs with an unreadable expression. "We clearly do."

Let the game begin, indeed.

A waiter approached with their food, and Agatha clenched her jaw as he wordlessly brought a salad to her.

The unspoken insult settled like a stone in her stomach as she stared at the meal meant to remind her, to put her back in her place.

The same way it always had.

"I took the liberty of ordering for you," Evanora said smoothly as if it was an act of kindness and not a planned move to make Agatha's composure waver.

The waiter disappeared, chased away by a dismissive flick of Evanora's wrist, but Agatha could not look away from the salad.

From the crisp leaves and delicate vinaigrette. From the sparse chunks of cheese and the abnormal amount of tomatoes.

It wasn't just food; it was a symbol of control, of expectations, of the suffocating way Evanora always tried to shape her.

The carefully crafted, calorie-conscious meal was a subtle jab, but it was one Agatha had endured countless times before. She could practically hear her mother's voice in her head, telling her that this was for her own good.

Her stomach lurched, but as she reached for a fork, Rio's voice cut through the thick tension, smooth as silk. "That's very kind."

It was a simple sentence, but the weight behind it was undeniable. The understanding, the way Rio had already pieced together the puzzle.

Before Agatha could react, Rio took action.

With effortless grace, she picked up her own plate with a glorious heap of creamy pasta with shrimp, the kind of dish meant to remind one of indulgence, of freedom.

And then, in one swift, deliberate move, she swapped their plates.

"But I fear I'm not a fan of shrimp."

It was a lie, Agatha realized. She had seen Rio devour shrimp-laden pasta more times than she could count, her eyes lighting up with satisfaction at every bite. If anything, Evanora had unknowingly chosen the perfect meal for Rio.

Agatha’s chest tightened as a sudden, undeniable warmth flooded her when she met Rio’s gaze. It was the warmth of something she hadn't felt in a long time: solidarity. It was a defiant unity, a shared understanding that transcended the arrangement.

Evanora's reaction was almost imperceptible, but Agatha caught it. Her eyes flickered with the faintest flash of disbelief, a sharp intake of breath, and then the tiniest widening of pupils. She had never been defied like this, certainly not by someone like Rio. To have someone like that refuse to be cowed, to refuse to bow to her will, was an anomaly. It was almost enough for Evanora to lose her composure.

But Rio was already digging into the salad, her expression unbothered as if she hadn't just flipped the script to defy the most powerful woman at the table.

Agatha didn't even care that Rio was eating the insulting dish with genuine enjoyment. It wasn't about the food anymore, but the act itself - about standing in solidarity when she needed it most. And that was far more revolutionary than what most people did when faced with Evanora's power.

Emboldened by Rio's casual defiance, she reached for her fork, swirling it in the pasta before meeting her mother's gaze head-on.

"I assume you didn't invite us here for pleasantries," she said, her tone measured. "Let's skip the theatrics, shall we?"

Evanora's lips curled into something resembling amusement, though her eyes remained sharp. "Always so impatient," she sighed, smoothing out the napkin in her lap.

"I wouldn't want to waste your precious time," Agatha shot back, raising the fork to her mouth. "I'm sure you have better things to do than interrogating me and my wife."

The word had the desired effect as Evanora's jaw ticked in annoyance.

"Very well," her mother folded her hands on the table, her manicured nails tapping once against the linen before she spoke again. "Let's hear what lies you have prepared for me."

Agatha didn't blink. "Lies?"

Evanora tilted her head slightly, studying her like a predator sizing up its prey. "Oh, Agatha," she murmured, voice laced with false sympathy. "Did you really think I wouldn't notice how... convenient this little arrangement is?"

Agatha forced herself to hold her mother's gaze, refusing to let the words unnerve her. "I don't know what you're insinuating."

Rio, to her credit, played her part perfectly. She placed a hand over Agatha's, her thumb stroking the back of it in a way that looked effortless - affectionate, even.

Evanora's lips twitched at the display, but the frown quickly transformed into a smirk. "Oh, darling, I don't insinuate; I observe."

Unhurriedly, she dug her fork into her salad, letting the words gain weight as she chewed.

"For instance," she continued smoothly. "It's curious that your so-called relationship was nonexistent until it wasn't. No hints, no whispers, not even a single public appearance. And then, out of nowhere, you're married?" her brow lifted.

Agatha clenched her fork, already gearing up for a sharp retort – something about Evanora not paying enough attention to her life to realize she’d been dating someone - but Rio was faster.

"Agatha's always been private about personal matters," she said calmly. "I’m sure being a public figure makes you appreciate privacy more than most, Mrs. Harkness. You should know some things aren’t meant for a broader audience."

Evanora hummed, unconvinced but momentarily thrown off course by the directness of the words.

Agatha seized the opening. "Mother, if you want to come out and accuse me of something, please do. Otherwise, I'd rather enjoy my meal without baseless theories about my life."

Evanora smiled, cold and detached as she raised her shoulders in a small shrug. "I didn't come here to accuse anyone," she tilted her head, eyes focused on Agatha. "But a marriage? What a bold step for someone who's never believed in commitment."

Agatha didn't flinch. "People change."

"Do they?" Evanora countered smoothly. "I always thought love was supposed to soften people. Yet, here you are, as combative as ever."

Agatha bit back a remark about how little her mother could know about love - an old crone, incapable of loving even her own daughter.

"I wasn't aware love required submission," she said instead, putting down her fork.

"It requires something," Evanora murmured, taking a slow sip of wine before shifting her gaze to Rio. "Tell me, dear, do you find my daughter's sharp edges charming or exhausting?"

Rio barely hesitated, offering a small, easy smile. "A bit of both."

Agatha shot her a look, but Rio continued without missing a beat. "But I knew what I was signing up for. And I wouldn't change a thing."

"How romantic," Evanora said, voice smooth but laced with skepticism. "I must say, this all feels so... sudden. How long have you two been together?"

"A little over a year," the practiced answer rolled off Agatha's tongue effortlessly.

Evanora turned back to her, eyebrow raised. "A year? You haven't mentioned a relationship once."

"You don't ask about my life," Agatha pointed out. "Hard to bring something up when you never show interest."

Evanora made a quiet, amused sound. "Oh, I'm interested now."

Agatha forced a smirk. "So I've noticed."

"It's funny," Evanora chuckled, shaking her head as if amused by Agatha's audacity. "I always assumed that if you ever settled down, it would be with someone... well, let's say, accustomed to handling difficult people."

Agatha stiffened, fingers tightening around Rio's.

Rio's expression didn't change, but the shift in her posture was unmistakable. Her muscles tightened, shoulders squaring up as if she were getting ready to climb over the table and stab her mother-in-law with her fork.

"Difficult?" she repeated, her tone mild but with an unmistakable edge.

Evanora waved a dismissive hand. "Oh, come now. Apparently, you've known my daughter long enough to realize she can be a handful. Stubborn. Controlling. And, if I recall correctly, not particularly adept at forming long-term attachments."

Agatha felt her stomach tighten, but she didn't let it show. This was Evanora's favorite game - finding the old scars and forcefully splitting them open until they bled again.

"Not very likable either," Evanora continued, sounding almost defeated. "Which makes me wonder," her gaze slid back to Rio, her lips curving in something meant to resemble a smile. "Why her?"

The implication hung in the air like poison.

Agatha swallowed hard, heat creeping up her neck. She didn't need to hear the rest of that sentence to know exactly where her mother was going.

Why would anyone choose her?

Before she could formulate a response, Rio laughed - actually laughed. The sound was light, dispersing the dark cloud hanging over the table. "You make it sound like being with Agatha is a burden."

Evanora arched a brow. "Isn't it?"

"Not to me," Rio said smoothly, her fingers tightening around Agatha's. "I happen to like her sharp edges. I respect them."

Agatha inhaled sharply, not expecting the way those words settled in her chest, warm and steady.

"Respect is a lovely sentiment," Evanora chewed thoughtfully on another forkful of lettuce. "But do you understand what you've gotten yourself into? Agatha, well, she's never been easy."

Rio's smile sharpened. "I don't want easy. Easy gets tedious after the novelty has worn off."

Evanora leaned back in her chair, tapping her fingers against her wine glass, her gaze flickering between the two women.

"And handling her moods doesn't?" she asked coolly as though testing Rio's resolve. "You don't find it exhausting, being in a relationship where one side is perpetually distant?"

Agatha's stomach twisted at the insinuation, but she kept her expression composed, refusing to show the crack of vulnerability Evanora had just exposed. It was a game of manipulation, invented and perfected by her mother.

Rio squeezed Agatha's hand just enough to remind her that she wasn't alone. "See, that's your problem," she said evenly, making Evanora's brows jump. "You see something exhausting, but I see a challenge. The distance you're talking about isn't an impassable obstacle, it's a part of who she is. And I'm not afraid of it."

Evanora's lips pressed into a thin line, a hint of a sneer on the edge of her smile. "Oh? You've been together for a year, I'm sure you've heard about her other... flings. What makes you think you're the one to last? The one to pass the obstacle?"

"I'm not a fling. I'm her wife," Rio replied coolly, her eyes unwavering as she met Evanora's gaze. The calm confidence in her voice carried a weight impossible to ignore, but Evanora remained unbothered.

"A wife," she repeated as if testing the word on her tongue. "Only a year and you have already earned that title. Makes one think there weren't many other options, not many others able to handle her."

"Not everybody likes a challenge."

"Is that what this is?" Evanora tilted her head. "You sign up for a lifetime of her moods, her distance, and her inability to let anyone in for a challenge?"

Rio leaned in slightly, her voice laced with warning. "We've already established I'm not looking for easy. Do you see this as a test? A game where the prize is a perfect relationship with no issues?" she shook her head. "It's not. What I've signed up for is the woman sitting beside me, with all her strength, her imperfections, and yes, her distance. But you know what? I'm here, and I'm not going anywhere."

Agatha felt a surge of something she couldn't quite name - pride, relief, maybe even something more profound. Rio was defending her. Genuinely defending her, not with a simple rebuttal or dismissive remarks, but with an unshakable certainty.

For a moment, she forgot it was a ploy, that Rio's words didn't carry the weight her tone suggested, that she would eventually leave. It seemed impossible with the steely conviction edged into Rio’s voice and the weight of her hand pressing into Agatha’s. With the clear annoyance hidden under her cool mask, as if Evanora’s attempts at tearing Agatha down did nothing but enrage Rio.

Evanora's eyes narrowed, her hands resting on the table's edge, fingers tapping softly against the white linen as she processed the words.

Finally, her lips stretched in a slow, calculated smile.

"Well, I've always enjoyed a challenge too," she said, her voice low and honeyed. "This... this will be interesting to watch. You think you're immune to the messiness of it all, but even the most determined people eventually lose their interest."

Agatha's chest tightened, the sting of the words settling deep as her mother twisted another knife to make her feel like she wasn't quite enough.

"I'm not afraid of the mess," Rio leaned back slightly, her tone softening just a fraction but still steady. "What's love without getting your hands dirty?"

The silence that followed felt thick, suffocating. Evanora didn't say a word, her lips pressing tightly together, her gaze colder than before. For a moment, Agatha thought she might say something sharp - lose her composure - but instead, Evanora merely picked up her glass, swirling the wine slowly as though considering her next words.

Finally, after what felt like an eternity, she put the glass down, her gaze fixed on Agatha.

"You've always been a disappointment," she said, her voice heavy with years of bitterness. "You know that, right?"

The words hit Agatha like a slap, and for a second, she couldn't breathe. All the old wounds, all the years of trying to be enough for her mother, came crashing back. The ghosts of not just the conversations held in the restaurant but everywhere else - her childhood home, various events, rides to school - screamed around her, their voices blending into an anguished choir.

She felt Rio's hand tighten almost painfully around her fingers, the pressure serving as a tether keeping her from surrendering to the ghosts' cries.

Then, Rio moved, her face twisting in a scowl that made her look almost feral, ready to leap over the table and squeeze the life out of Evanora with her bare hands.

Before she could do something neither could undo, Agatha squeezed her fingers back in a silent plea to stay civil, and straightened her spine.

The screams were familiar, bringing a sharp sting of never being what Evanora wanted her to be.

But this time, they didn't sting quite as badly.

"Maybe I've never been what you wanted," she said, her voice quiet but steady. "But I'm enough for myself. And for her."

Something akin to disdain flashed in Evanora's eyes, but she said nothing further. Instead, she turned her attention back to her salad, methodically gathering the ingredients on her fork as though she were done with the conversation.

The grip on Agatha's hand loosened, and she instinctively clenched her fingers around Rio's, afraid she would pull away. She sighed softly when a gentle thumb ran along hers in a wordless promise.

There were no grand victories here, no triumphant final words, but something had shifted. For once, she had stood her ground. And for once, her mother's words didn't make her crumble.

Evanora leaned back in her chair, her expression calculating. "I do wonder how this... marriage will progress," she mused, her voice now distant as if the conversation was over for her. "I suppose I will see."

Agatha recognized the thinly veiled threat but didn't respond. She knew Evanora would be watching them, searching for clues to build her case and discredit their relationship, especially after the tense conversation.

But it was a problem for another time. For now, all that mattered was that they had survived the first battle.

The rest of the dinner passed in tense, charged silence, the air between them thick enough to choke on. They finished their meals without bothering to engage, each bite a battle of wills rather than an act of necessity.

Evanora's expression remained impassive, but her eyes, cold and assessing, lingered on their joined hands, on the way Rio had gravitated toward Agatha, close enough for their shoulders to nearly brush. The occasional flicker of disgust visible in the sharp twitch of her brows and the faint downturn of her lips was enough for Agatha to know her mother was bothered.

Good.

She leaned into Rio's touches, allowing them to linger just a second longer than necessary, relishing the subtle tells of discomfort as they needled at her mother's composure.

Still, Evanora said nothing. Not in public, where the wrong tone or a misplaced word could draw attention she had no interest in attracting. Her silence, however, was razor-sharp, brimming with all the words she couldn't say but Agatha could easily guess. Eventually, she finished her meal, snapping at the waiter when he inquired about dessert and rising from her chair with a clipped farewell.

She didn't wait for them, didn't so much as glance back as she strode out, stiff-backed and seething.

Agatha watched her go, finally letting her muscles relax as she picked up her glass.

"So," she murmured, taking a slow sip of water, "that went well."

Rio hummed around the mouthful of lettuce she was chewing. "I stand by my first judgment," she said after swallowing, making Agatha look at her in surprise. "She is a bitch."

Agatha chuckled, putting down her glass and leaning back in her chair. "I'd say you get used to it, but..." she shrugged, eyes lingering on the exit before moving back to Rio, who was fitting another leaf into her mouth. "You don't have to keep eating that."

The unsaid words lingered between them.

You didn't have to do that.

Rio made a quiet sound of acknowledgment, putting her fork on the almost empty plate and pushing it back. "Honestly, you'd think a restaurant like this would splurge on something other than lettuce," she said good-naturedly, reaching for her water. "But I could tell it was expensive lettuce, you know? The fanciest I've ever tasted."

Agatha smiled, but the gesture didn't reach her eyes. "The salad normally has more cheese and croutons."

"A bitch indeed," Rio muttered, so low Agatha wasn't sure she was even supposed to hear it.

She ignored the irritation woven into Rio's voice as if she was genuinely angry at Evanora for the stunt and turned to attract the waiter's attention. With her mother gone, there was no point in staying at the haunted restaurant.

Almost reluctantly, Agatha untangled their hands to reach for the check.

"Don't tell me you'll also have to pay for that heap of lettuce," Rio grumbled as her eyes swept over the sum, widening slightly. "What the fuck."

Agatha bumped her knee against the woman's under the table to silence her and handed the waiter her card. "That will be all."

The man nodded, his eyes flickering between them. "I'll be right back."

Rio sighed dramatically, slumping in her chair. "For that price, he should return with a commemorative plaque saying 'Survived dinner with Evanora Harkness'. Etched in gold."

Agatha snorted, rubbing her temples. "I don't think my house is big enough to fit one of those after every dinner with her."

"Do you have to go through this often?" Rio nodded toward Evanora's empty seat, her expression softening.

"Not anymore," Agatha pursed her lips, drumming her fingers against the table. "She used to insist on seeing me at least once a week after I moved out and started college. But, eventually, she realized the older I got, the less power she had over me and my decisions, so she gave up."

Rio hummed, tilting her head as she studied Agatha. "Gave up, or just got more creative with her tactics?"

Agatha exhaled through her nose, a humorless smirk tugging at her lips. "You catch on fast."

"She doesn't seem like the type to just 'give up'."

Agatha couldn't disagree. Evanora had always been strategic in her cruelty - never direct, never reckless. If she wasn't pulling the strings, she was waiting in the wings, ready to strike when the moment was right.

"She's not," Agatha crossed her arms, leaning back in her chair. "Evanora will try everything to prove she's right, no matter how many bridges she'll have to burn or how many people she'll hurt in the process. The only thing that matters is the finish line."

"How Machiavellian," Rio sipped on her water, expression thoughtful. "I can't imagine growing up with someone like that."

Agatha shrugged, pausing the conversation as the waiter approached again.

"Thank you, Mrs. Harkness. Have a wonderful evening."

Rio muttered something under her breath that sounded suspiciously like highway robbery as Agatha tucked the card away.

"It's just who she is," she continued, sliding her chair back.

"That doesn't make it okay."

Agatha didn't have an answer for that.

Rio sighed, threading her arms through her coat's sleeves and reaching for Agatha's hand as if it were the most natural thing in the world. "Let's go. Before they charge you for breathing."

Agatha huffed a quiet laugh, letting herself be led to the exit.

To her surprise, once they reached the valet, Rio snatched the keys out of his hand before Agatha could.

"What exactly are you doing?" she asked, her voice low as they walked to the car.

Rio grinned, opening the passenger door for her to get in. "The evening's still young, and I don't know about you, but I could use a drink."

Agatha hesitated, narrowing her eyes as she slid into the seat. "And where exactly are you planning to take me?"

Rio shut the door and rounded the car, slipping into the driver's seat with a smirk. "Relax, wifey," she teased, adjusting the mirrors like she hadn't just hijacked Agatha's car. "It's just a drink. I think we both deserve one after that circus act."

Agatha exhaled slowly, leaning back against the headrest as Rio started the engine. "I don't need a drink."

"Well, I do," Rio countered, expertly pulling out of the parking lot. "And you're mine for the evening, so..."

Agatha ignored the spark of swooping heat the offhanded comment lit up low in her belly. "If you take me to your bar, I'm jumping out at the next red light."

"Please," Rio scoffed. "I'm not subjecting you to another line of questioning. Not when you look one comment away from strangling someone."

Agatha crossed her arms. "I don't look like that."

Rio shot her a sideways glance, unimpressed. "You just paid a stupid amount of money for a dinner you barely touched, and listened to your mother questioning your entire personality. I'd be surprised if that didn't awaken some murderous thoughts."

"And yet, you trapped yourself in a car with me," she noticed, gesturing to the confined space. "Aren't you afraid of my murderous thoughts?"

Rio snorted. "I think I can handle them. Besides, if I mysteriously disappeared, you'd be the first suspect."

"Oh, really?"

"Yeah," Rio shot her a smirk, wiggling her eyebrows. "The spouse is always the prime suspect."

Agatha rolled her eyes, but the corners of her lips twitched despite herself. "I'll make it look like an accident."

Rio gasped dramatically, clutching her chest with one hand while the other remained steady on the wheel. "Betrayed by my own wife. The tragedy."

Agatha shook her head, looking out the window as the city lights flickered past. The tension from the dinner still pressed heavily against her ribs, but Rio's effortless banter was starting to loosen it, piece by piece.

"So, where are you taking me?" she asked after a beat of silence, not recognizing the street they were on.

"Into the woods to murder you," Rio replied without missing a beat, amusement lighting up her voice as she shot Agatha another glance. "Relax. I think you'll like it."

"Getting murdered? You could've done that before I had to sit through dinner with my mother," Agatha shot back, earning a chuckle.

The road ahead stretched into the distance, dark but not ominous. They weren't heading toward the kind of place Agatha expected - not a loud, crowded bar with dim lighting and a sea of sweaty bodies pressed together on the dancefloor. Instead, the neon signs and busy sidewalks had given way to something quieter, something slower.

When Rio finally pulled up outside a small, cozy building, Agatha blinked.

"You do realize bookstores don't sell alcohol, right?"

Rio grinned as she killed the engine. "This one does. It's a hidden gem."

Agatha eyed the warm glow spilling out from the large front windows, where shelves of books lined the walls, stretching high up to the ceiling. Nestled between them was a long wooden bar with a bartender lazily polishing a glass behind it. The place was quiet and intimate - nothing like the rowdy nightmare she had braced herself for.

"Come on, gorgeous," Rio said with a grin, hopping out of the car. "Let's get you that drink."

Agatha hesitated for only a second before sighing and stepping out, letting the door click shut behind her. She followed Rio to the door, the scent of aged paper and whiskey hitting her the second they stepped inside.

The space was small but well-curated, lined with towering bookshelves that gave it a hushed, almost sacred air. Tucked in the back, past cozy armchairs and dim reading lamps, the bar stretched in a neat curve, manned by a single bartender who barely looked up as they entered.

"Go ahead and choose a seat," Rio nudged her toward one of the tables overlooked by the massive bookshelves. "I'll be right back."

Agatha nodded absentmindedly, her sharp heels clicking against the polished wood as she approached a table set by a window, her eyes skimming the shelves. Fiction, history, philosophy - the titles stacked in well-loved rows, some even with scribbled notes sticking from between the pages.

She could imagine why Rio brought her to a place like that after the nerve-wracking dinner. The ambiance emanated peace and warmth, so different from the restaurant's cold marble and pristine gold that Agatha felt her muscles relax as she sat in the plush chair, letting the comforting air drain her body of the residual tension.

"Here you go," Rio reappeared, handing her a glass of whisky before easing into the chair opposite her.

Agatha raised her brows, eyes jumping between the beer in Rio's hand and her own drink. "I'm not leaving my car here," she said, moving to put the glass on the table. "Or letting you drive drunk."

"Would you relax for a second?" Rio sipped on her beer. "This barely has any alcohol in it. I took the lightest one they had."

"Weren't you the one in need of a drink?" Agatha countered, but leaned back in her chair, glass still in hand.

"I didn't spend an entire dinner getting insulted," Rio's face softened slightly, her dark eyes shining in the faint light. "Can I ask you something?"

Agatha's grip on the glass tightened. Something told her she wouldn't like the question, but Rio didn't wait for an answer.

"Why do you keep in touch with her?"

"She's my mother."

It was an instinctive answer, one she had been giving her friends ever since they had known her enough to ask.

Repeated until they stopped questioning it, accepting the words with a defeated sigh and a nod as if finding a rebuttal was too tiring.

Rio didn't seem to think so.

"It doesn't mean anything if she treats you like that," she said, voice measured.

Agatha sipped on her drink, nails clinking against the glass in a slow, steady rhythm. "Doesn't it?" she sighed when Rio shifted in her chair, visibly readying herself to argue. "It's not that simple. I can't just... stop picking up the phone and forget she exists. Especially now."

"And before?" Rio prodded. "What stopped you before?"

She hesitated, unsure what the correct answer would be. For once, she settled on the truth. "She did."

The silence stretched for a moment, and Agatha let it, using the reprieve to gather her thoughts. If not for the exhaustion caused by spending two hours in her mother's presence, she would cut the conversation short, but she didn't have the strength to ward off Rio's questions.

"I tried to leave her in the past after I started practicing law," Agatha said slowly, each word burning her tongue more than the alcohol. "I blocked her number and cut ties with everyone who could spy on me for her. I even considered leaving the state, but I already had a job here, so I moved to a different apartment instead."

Rio listened intently, the usual teasing glint in her eyes replaced by something thoughtful, almost concerned. Agatha exhaled, the sight an immediate throwback to the night they had met - the night she had opened up to Rio about her mother for the first time, thinking they would never cross paths again.

Now, the words kept pouring out of her mouth despite the knowledge that she would not be free of Rio by the end of the evening.

"It worked for a while," she continued, her fingertip tracing the rim of the glass. "Three months without a single word from her. I almost thought I was free."

Rio's gaze sharpened. "But?"

Agatha huffed a humorless laugh. "But we've already established that Evanora Harkness doesn't give up," her fingers tightened around the glass. "She came to my apartment. Said the time was to let me cool off, to make me realize the legacy I was throwing away on a whim."

"Legacy," Rio echoed like the word left a bad taste in her mouth.

"She always called it that. Like my entire life was some grand inheritance I could only accept," Agatha shook her head. "I knew her visit was only the beginning, a warning. It wouldn't look good for her if the press found out her daughter cut ties with her."

Rio's jaw twitched. "It was about her image."

Agatha chuckled humorlessly at the subtle shock layering the woman's voice. "Well, it certainly wasn't about me. Either way, I unblocked her number by the end of the visit and just.. stuck around. It was the lesser of two evils."

"What was the other evil?"

"Ruining my career," Agatha leaned back in her chair, swirling her drink with a thoughtful look. "I was making my name as a lawyer, aspiring to be a partner. My mother could've easily stalled my career at the time."

Rio frowned, narrowing her eyes. "Wasn't Lilia the one who made you a partner? She hates Evanora."

"It didn't matter. Becoming a partner means bringing in clients, and my mother knows everyone who is anyone in this city, hell, in this state," Agatha sighed, looking out the window at the almost empty street. "The visit made me realize I'd never be free of her, and I learned to live with it."

When Rio stayed silent, Agatha glanced at her, immediately noticing the familiar tension in the woman's face. The urge to fix, the same one she had shown the night Evanora had called, was carved into Rio's worry lines, deepened by the dim light.

"It could've been worse," she added as if the words could erase the look from Rio's face. "Between my job and Nicky, I rarely have time to entertain her. The dinners are few and in between."

Rio pressed her lips into a thin line. "That's why she added the clause to the will, right? Because you started pulling away again."

"She’s creative with her punishments," Agatha shrugged, lifting the glass to her lips. "She probably didn’t expect me to fight it, though. I don’t think we’ll hear from her for a while. She'll take her time to regroup and prepare a new strategy."

"That's daunting," Rio leaned further into her chair, kicking out her legs under the table. "And here I was thinking my parental situation was rough."

Agatha raised her brows at the offhanded remark. Ever since her unfair assumption about Rio's parents, they had not spoken about her childhood - her past, for that matter.

It didn't mean Agatha wasn't curious. Due to their arrangement, Rio had found out more about her life than she would like, and whenever she caught the woman staring wistfully at the framed photos in her house or talking on her phone in rapid Spanish, she felt the urge to prod - to get to know her more.

Still, Rio never volunteered information about it. Their relationship, whatever it was, had been built on the present, on contracts and sharp banter, not on the ghosts that trailed behind them, so Agatha never asked.

But tonight felt different. Maybe it was the whisky, maybe the lingering tension from dinner, or maybe the quiet way Rio had said the words. Like she wasn't making a joke or deflecting.

For once, it felt like an opening rather than a defense mechanism. And Agatha, for all her instincts to avoid messy, heartfelt conversations, stepped through it.

"You don't talk about it," she noted, not an accusation but a simple observation.

Rio lifted a shoulder in a lazy shrug, but the way she avoided Agatha's gaze betrayed the forced nonchalance. "I figured we weren't in this to get to know each other."

"You know plenty about me."

"Oh, so it's a tit-for-tat situation?" the humorous lilt in Rio's voice fell flat between them as Agatha tilted her head. Rio rolled her eyes at the gesture. "Not much to talk about."

Agatha set her drink down with a quiet clink. "I find that hard to believe."

"Look at you," Rio chuckled, the sound almost forced. "All curious all of a sudden."

Agatha didn't respond, just waited. She knew Rio well enough by now - if she pushed too hard, the woman would deflect, turn it into a joke, redirect the conversation before Agatha even had the time to catch up.

Rio sighed, toying with the glass in her hands. "You already know my parents died, and I had to move."

"What do you remember about them?"

Rio blinked as if the question caught her off guard. She frowned slightly, gaze drifting somewhere past Agatha, to a place neither of them could see. "My ma loved flowers," she murmured after a beat. "The entire house was always covered with them; we had more vases than cups."

Agatha smiled but stayed silent, letting Rio continue at her own pace.

"My dad was a morning person. Annoyingly so," Rio huffed a quiet laugh, shaking her head. "He'd blast music while making breakfast, sing off-key just to get a rise out of ma. It worked every time, especially when I joined him."

Agatha could see it - the warmth behind the words, the way Rio's face softened with the memory. But it didn't last.

"They were happy," Rio said, the words hollowing out as she exhaled. "And then they were gone. Just like that," she snapped her fingers, the sound sharp in the quiet space between them.

"Then, my abuela moved me to live with her before I even knew what the hell was happening," Rio leaned back in her chair, rubbing a hand over her face. "One day I was home singing with my dad, and the next I was in a city I'd never been to, living with a woman I barely knew."

Agatha frowned. "You didn't know her?"

"She visited a couple of times and called on birthdays. But she was a voice on the phone, you know? Not a person in my life," Rio shook her head. "Same with the rest of my ma's family. Most of them I couldn't remember ever seeing, and then they were raising me."

"Why didn't your family from New York take you in?" Agatha asked cautiously. "You must've known them better."

Rio pursed her lips. "They decided a fresh start would be better. Away from the ghosts and the memories."

"That's bullshit," Agatha said before she could process her words, smiling when Rio laughed.

"That's the explanation they gave me," she shrugged again. "It worked out in the end. As strict as my abuela is, I wouldn't be here without her."

Agatha studied Rio for a long moment, letting the words settle between them. It was strange, seeing her like this - unguarded, reflective. The woman who usually wielded sarcasm like a shield, who teased and taunted like it was her second nature, suddenly seemed... exposed.

And yet, Rio didn't seem uncomfortable.

Maybe it was the dim lighting, the hushed atmosphere of the bar, or the fact that Agatha hadn't pressed, had simply listened. Whatever the reason, Rio hadn’t shut down or changed the subject.

“You miss them,” Agatha said quietly.

“Yeah,” Rio’s fingers traced the condensation on her glass. “It seems so stupid. I was barely old enough to remember them when they died, and I still wake up every day feeling like a part of me is missing.”

“It’s not stupid,” Agatha opposed, her tone firm but gentle. “It’s grief.”

Rio’s gaze flickered up, searching her face. “You’re speaking from experience.”

It wasn’t a question, but Agatha nodded anyway, swallowing another sip of the whiskey. “My dad died when I was five. Heart attack,” she admitted. “I barely remember anything about him, but I miss the idea of him, you know? All the things that could’ve been, all the words my mother wouldn’t have said if he were there,” Agatha sighed, feeling a lump form in her throat. “I like to think she wasn’t like that before he died. That love softened her edges, and the loss sharpened them irrevocably.”

Rio pursed her lips, her fingers stilling their movements to wrap around the glass. “Grief doesn’t turn people into monsters,” she noticed slowly, eyes thoughtful as they rested on Agatha’s face. “But you deserved someone to protect you. You still do.”

The words hung between them, raw and heavy from their implications.

“I learned how to take care of myself,” Agatha said finally, voice quiet but without self-pity. Like she was stating a fact. “Relying on other people for protection is foolish.”

Rio didn’t look away. “It’s not about surrendering your autonomy, though. Just about letting somebody else care for you,” she drummed her fingers against the glass, eyes never leaving Agatha’s. “Just because you learned how to protect yourself doesn’t mean you don’t deserve somebody who’ll fight for you. With you.”

Agatha didn’t reply. She wasn’t sure she could. The ache in her throat had solidified, lodged somewhere deep in her chest. She hated how well Rio could read her sometimes - how she never looked away when the sharp parts showed.

Rio leaned back in her chair, finally shifting her attention from Agatha to gaze out the window. The warm glow of the street lamps softened her edges, making her look more like a helpless girl still haunted by the past than the woman who had faced Evanora without flinching.

“You know,” Rio murmured, voice low, “when I was a kid, I used to think grief would make me stronger. Like I’d grow up tough because I knew loss early,” she let out a soft snort, almost self-mocking. “Turns out, it just made me lonely. And a very annoying teenager set on making my abuela’s life difficult.”

Agatha’s lips curled faintly, barely a smile, but present. “You’re still annoying.”

Rio looked back at her, eyebrow arched. “It’s a conscious choice now.”

“Of course it is,” Agatha muttered, making Rio laugh quietly.

There was a long pause then, both letting the moment settle.

Agatha leaned forward, resting her arms on the table. Her glass was nearly empty, but she didn’t reach for it again. “I think I used to believe something similar. That being alone meant being safe. That needing anyone meant giving them a weapon.”

Rio nodded. “Yeah. That tracks.”

Agatha tilted her head, meeting her eyes. “But it doesn’t really work, does it?”

“No,” Rio said simply. “It just means you’re the one holding the weapon. And eventually, you start cutting yourself on it.”

That made Agatha fall still.

No deflections. No clever retorts. Just quiet.

And then, finally, she said, “I don’t know how to let someone do that. Fight with me.”

“You don’t have to know,” Rio muttered, her eyes as warm as her tone. “You just have to want to try.”

Agatha looked at her, at the softness behind the words, at the way Rio’s fingers had stopped fidgeting. She’d gone still in that rare way again, unguarded, but solid.

And something inside Agatha moved, not suddenly, but distinctly.

She didn’t say anything more. She didn’t need to.

But she didn’t look away either.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! So, how are we feeling? I think this is the longest chapter yet (the next one probably won't be shorter either), and ngl I was pretty excited to share it with you, so let me know what you think! As always, thank you for all the comments and kudos, and see you next week at the gala!

Chapter 13: Galas and gardens

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Something had shifted.

Agatha didn't know when or how it happened, but she felt it in every unspoken moment, every effortless interaction.

It hung in the air when she walked into the kitchen and found Rio already there, humming along to the music as she chopped vegetables, stirred a simmering pot, or flipped pancakes with practiced ease. A few days ago, Agatha would have rolled her eyes, grumbled about the noise, and maybe even snapped at Rio to turn it down. Now? Now, she found herself tapping her foot to the rhythm, humming under her breath as she lingered in the kitchen for a second longer than necessary.

It stretched between them at the dining table, a silent thread of understanding as Agatha sifted through contracts and emails while Rio graded papers or jotted down notes for her research. For weeks, this had been a point of friction with Agatha claiming the space out of habit and Rio invading it out of necessity. She used to glare at Rio's presence like it was an offense, snapping her laptop shut and retreating to her office without a word. But now? Now she stayed. Now, she acknowledged Rio's company with a nod, accepting it like a natural part of her routine.

It stole her breath every time Rio disappeared into the kitchen for a snack and returned with a cup of tea or a glass of water, setting it beside Agatha without a word. A small, thoughtful gesture so ordinary that it shouldn't have felt like everything, but it did.

Domesticity bordering on softness.

None of it was new. But it had never felt like this before.

It felt like the brittle truce established almost a month ago solidified, taking on its rightful shape and springing into existence before Agatha could process the shift.

Suddenly, the nature of the arrangement - the contracts, the logic, and the boundaries - changed, softened under the pressure of the dinner with Evanora and the dim light of the bar where they had talked without deflecting or running away.

It wasn't just about tolerating each other anymore.

Agatha noticed it in the way Rio moved through her home - their home, technically. She had always been comfortable in the space, making herself at home with an ease that had once irritated Agatha beyond reason. But now, instead of seeing it as an invasion, she watched. She observed the way Rio leaned against the counter, scrolling through her phone as the coffee machine whirred to life. The way she stretched her arms overhead in the morning, her spine arching like a lazy cat as she grumbled a raspy "morning", her voice thick with sleep.

Despite living with Rio for almost a month now, Agatha had never bothered to pay attention - or rather, suppressed the urge to follow the woman with her eyes as she went about her day. She had never initiated conversations unless they involved the deal or something in Rio's behavior that she wanted changed.

Now, she caught herself asking Rio about her day and actually wanting to hear the answer.

Now, every time she ordered takeout for dinner, she automatically included Rio's favorite, stashing it on the woman's side of the fridge for an after-work snack.

Now, she waited for Rio to come home, listening for the jingle of keys at the door. She noticed when Rio was running late and found herself annoyed - not because it disrupted her routine, but because it left an absence where something familiar should be.

She also noticed that Rio had learned her rhythms - how she didn't push when Agatha was immersed in her work, wordlessly handed over a cup of coffee at just the right moment, and always found a way to make Agatha laugh when she least expected it.

Everything was the same. Rio's behavior had not changed, but the way Agatha felt about it did.

It was infuriating. It was terrifying.

But she couldn't stop.

She couldn't revert to her old ways of shutting down every conversation, of treating Rio like an annoying ghost haunting her house, no matter how hard she tried.

Because Rio wasn't a ghost - she was undeniably there, woven into the fabric of Agatha's days in a way that felt almost natural.

Agatha had spent years perfecting the art of keeping people at a distance. She knew how to compartmentalize and draw lines that no one was allowed to cross. And yet, somehow, Rio had sidestepped them entirely, not by force, but by simply being there.

By defending her against Evanora's scrutiny. By taking her to the bar to unwind before returning home. By listening without judgment.

The dinner had shifted something. And Agatha wasn't sure if she could - or even wanted - to shift it back.

Still, it wasn't a big deal.

If anything, it worked in their favor. Their arrangement required more than mere tolerance; they needed to sell it. Convince the world their marriage was real, not just in name but in presence, in familiarity, in the way they occupied the same space without friction. The shift made that easier. More believable.

That was all Agatha cared about.

At least that's what she told herself when she found Rio asleep on the couch, head propped against the armrest, one leg extended parallel to the cushions while the other slid off the seat and rested limply on the floor.

She must have dozed off mid-grading, the papers scattered across her stomach, the coffee table, and the floor, one hand loosely gripping a red pen that had smudged ink along her fingers.

Agatha hovered in the doorway, arms crossed, trying to decide what to do.

The best approach was to wake the woman, preferably by violently shaking her and growling about occupying the entire couch.

Normally, she would.

She should.

But Rio looked soft: mouth parted slightly, hair messily falling over her face, the usual sharp edges dulled by sleep. It was a far cry from the woman who had met Evanora's gaze head-on at dinner, keeping her chin lifted in defiance as she dismantled the politician's strategy of exposing them. Here, Rio was unguarded. And Agatha, for reasons she refused to examine, couldn't look away.

She sighed, shifting her weight on her feet. Fucking ridiculous.

A smarter person would have shaken Rio awake or retreated from the room. Instead, Agatha quietly approached the couch, her eyes glued to Rio's face to watch for any signs of awareness as she gathered the scattered papers and set them in a neat pile on the table. Then, she gently plucked the pen from between Rio's fingers and grabbed the throw blanket draped over the armrest.

She hesitated for only a moment before unfolding it and carefully draping it over Rio.

It was simple practicality. Rio was always complaining about the house being too cold, and Agatha knew she would already be cranky in the morning from sleeping on the couch. The blanket was damage control.

It certainly wasn't because something in her chest did an unfamiliar twist at the sight of Rio curled up on her couch, so completely at ease in a place Agatha never expected anyone else to belong.

Shaking her head, Agatha turned away, determined to put the whole thing out of her mind.

Half-heartedly, she also made a mental note to yell at Rio in the morning for hogging the couch. For good measure.

But as she settled into her bed that night, she caught herself listening for movement, for the telltale creak of the couch or the soft shuffle of Rio waking up and retreating to her room.

When it didn't come, when the house remained quiet, Agatha stared at the ceiling for far too long before rolling onto her side with an exasperated sigh.

It wasn't a big deal.

Just an adjustment.

Nothing more.

Between the shift, a week even busier than regular, and the lingering weight of seeing her mother again, Agatha felt worse about the gala than she typically did.

Which said a lot, considering these events were the bane of her existence.

A bane dressed up in elegant clothes, expensive alcohol, and a crowd of people so detached from reality she was convinced half of them wouldn't know their right from their left without an assistant whispering into their ear.

As she combed her hair into a bun - looser than her usual style, but still sharp enough to scream don't talk to me - she wondered if it was too late to fake an emergency. Maybe she could call Lilia, cough like she'd smoked three packs a day since birth, and plead contagion.

In hindsight, she should've soft-launched her fake illness during the partner meeting two days ago.

Not that Lilia would've believed her, but still.

A soft knock broke her from the fantasy. "You almost ready?"

Agatha groaned. Right. That was the other reason she dreaded this particular gala more than usual.

How could she forget?

Suddenly, coming down with the flu sounded downright luxurious.

"Have you ever heard of being fashionably late?" she called back, adjusting the collar of her shirt and staring at her reflection like it might offer her an escape route.

Well, at least she looked good.

The purple suit, so dark that it seemed black unless it caught light, hugged her frame like it was made for her, which it was. The silk blouse beneath added just enough softness to take the edge off the razor-sharp tailoring, while the loose bun gave her an air of effortless control. She looked like someone you didn't argue with. Someone who didn't flinch under pressure.

Too bad she had to waste that look on a stupid work event.

"Nothing about being late is fashionable," Rio's voice came through the door, slightly muffled but carrying a noticeable note of urgency. "It's rude."

Agatha resisted the urge to groan, slipping on her heels. "This is a work event, not a hostage situation."

"Could've fooled me."

She opened the door with a sharp tug, already midway through an eye-roll, only to stop dead in her tracks.

Rio stood in the hallway, leaning against the wall with one heeled foot tapping the floor in a steady rhythm. Her dress was simple but elegant, the green deep and rich against her skin, her hair pinned up with a kind of effortlessness that many envied.

For a moment, Agatha couldn't remember why she hated the events.

"Something on my face?" Rio drawled, tilting her head.

Agatha blinked, realizing her eyes weren't even on Rio's face. They dipped dangerously low, mapping out the neckline of the dress.

Snapping them up took more effort than it should.

Not that it helped because Rio was watching her with that knowing smile, lips painted the same shade as trouble, and eyes lined in smoky defiance.

What was the question again?

Ah, right.

"An annoying smirk," Agatha managed, somehow steady. "Now, stop making us late."

Rio scoffed, pushing off the wall. "I've been ready for half an hour."

"You want an award or something?"

If the sarcasm stung, Rio didn't show it. She just stepped forward, slow and confident, her fingers brushing over Agatha's shoulder and smoothing out the fabric with maddening care.

"Yes, actually," she murmured, fingers drifting to the lapel of Agatha's blazer, straightening it with far more intimacy than necessary. She leaned in, voice low enough to feel like a secret. "Can you promise me you'll at least try to enjoy it?"

Agatha stared at her, heart skipping in a way that had nothing to do with gala speeches or client schmoozing.

"I'll try not to commit a felony," she said flatly.

Rio grinned like that was better than a yes. "Perfect," her fingers lingered for a second longer before pulling back, leaving Agatha's pulse at an unhealthy rate and her mind in shambles.

Yeah. That was another shift.

After the dinner with Evanora, Rio had become... more physical.
