Nothing overt. Nothing inappropriate. But definitely more: a hand on the small of Agatha's back in the kitchen, a brush of fingers passing a coffee mug, a casual squeeze to the shoulder when she needed her attention.

They didn't talk about it, didn't acknowledge it.

But Agatha felt every single touch like a live wire under her skin.

She suspected that - much like the slow infiltration of endearments - Rio was trying to desensitize her. To train her not to flinch and prepare her for a world that expected ease and familiarity.

It didn't make it any less maddening.

And yet, Agatha couldn't bring herself to tell her to stop.

Okay. So maybe she was touch-starved. Maybe she hadn't had sex in longer than she was willing to admit, even under oath.

Sue her.

Agatha sucked in a steadying breath, hoping it looked more like a fight for patience than a desperate attempt at calming her erratic pulse. "Let's just go before Lilia sends someone to collect us."

Rio raised her brows. "Has she ever actually done that?"

"Yeah," Agatha started toward the stairs, the memory of two burly men showing up at her doorstep replaying in her mind. "Even gave them permission to use force to put me in the car."

"Okay, now I'm more inclined to be fashionably late," Rio laughed. "I'd pay good money to see them try to tame you."

Agatha stopped on the first step, shooting Rio a smirk over her shoulder. "Oh, honey, there's no taming this tiger."

Well, at least she could give as good as she got if the blush spreading across Rio's cheeks was anything to go by.

After a brief obstacle in the form of Sharon, who gushed about how good they looked together and how long it had been since she'd been to a party of any kind, they said their goodbyes to Nicky and stepped out the door. A sleek black SUV was already idling at the curb, polished to perfection.

Rio's eyes landed on the man leaning against the passenger door. His spine was ramrod straight, his blazer strained at the biceps, and his face was set in that unnerving, perfectly neutral way that said he'd wait another hour without blinking.

"Did Lilia send him?" she asked as they descended the porch steps, eyes narrowing as she scanned him. "Because if he starts dragging you into the car, I'm letting it happen. Might even film it."

Agatha rolled her eyes. "He's my driver. But I'm touched by your loyalty."

Rio glanced at her with an amused squint. "You have a driver?"

"Only for events like this," Agatha said with the kind of practiced indifference that usually meant she expected judgment and had already decided she didn't care. "I'm not sitting through any of it sober, and calling an Uber is..." she trailed off, searching for the right word.

"Beneath your tax bracket?" Rio supplied, smirking.

That earned her a second, more dramatic eye-roll. "These events are about appearances. The more money you look like you have, the more the clients trust you."

"Well, that's pretentious."

Agatha gave a small, elegant shrug. "Pretentious keeps the lights on."

"Still," Rio said, stepping closer as they reached the car. "I could've driven us. I think your car's nice enough for pretentious pricks."

"You wouldn't want to take Greg's job, would you?" Agatha quipped, nodding at the man. "Good evening, Greg."

"Good evening, Mrs. Harkness, Mrs. Vidal," Greg said with a crisp nod. He stepped forward to open the back door with the kind of smooth professionalism that only came from a hundred other events.

Agatha glided into the car like it was second nature. She buckled her seatbelt and crossed her legs as Greg rounded to the other side and opened the door for Rio.

"We should be there in fifteen minutes," he informed them once they were on the move.

Agatha hummed in acknowledgment, then turned fully to Rio, her expression frozen in calm professionalism.

"Alright. Rule number one," she said, holding up her pointer finger. "Do not call anyone there a pretentious prick."

Rio's mouth twitched. "Not even behind their back?"

Agatha considered it. "Fine. Behind their back is acceptable. Just make sure they're at least four tables away."

"Yes, ma'am."

Agatha raised her middle finger, ignoring Rio's snort. "Rule number two: if you hear someone mention obscure art auctions, horse breeding, or owning a vineyard in Italy, run. You're being lured into a conversation no amount of alcohol will help you survive."

"That doesn't sound so-"

"No," Agatha shook her head. "It's bad. Trust me. And rule number three," her ring finger joined the other two. "Only answer the questions you're asked. No unnecessary delving into details, especially about our relationship."

Rio's brows lifted slightly, glancing at Greg. His eyes stayed trained on the road ahead, but the faint smirk tugging at the corners of his mouth gave him away.

"Isn't the point of this to spread the word?" she asked, lowering her voice as if keeping the conversation between them, even though Greg had clearly clocked every word.

"Yes, but that doesn't mean I want everyone to know everything," Agatha pointed out. "These are people I work with. People I work for. They only need to see what I choose to show."

Rio nodded slowly, settling deeper into the leather seat, fingers tapping a distracted rhythm against her knee. "So, to recap: I can talk shit in whispers, flee at the first sign of horses or vineyards, and I'm a mysterious, shiny arm candy who doesn't talk too much."

Agatha didn't laugh.

Her jaw tightened, the comment grating in a way she hadn't expected. Not because Rio was joking, but because she wasn't wrong.

She glanced over, taking in Rio's relaxed posture, the perfect mix of beauty and confidence. The kind of aura people noticed before they even registered anything else.

It wasn't fair.

Because Rio wasn't just beautiful. She was brilliant. She had the kind of mind that unraveled the complexities of her work with casual ease and explained scientific breakthroughs like bedtime stories.

But here, at the kind of event Agatha had to drag her to, they'd only see what they wanted to see. A younger woman on the arm of someone powerful.

They wouldn't see Rio.

"I don't like that," Agatha admitted quietly. "You're not arm candy."

Rio turned toward her, surprised by the shift in her tone, but still looking amused.

"A trophy wife, then," she quipped.

Agatha gritted her teeth. "No," she said, gaze steady and voice firm. "You’re a brilliant PhD student who wants to change the world and happens to be my wife. Not a trophy."

It hung between them for a moment, heavier than the air in the car, warm in a way that made Rio's amusement melt away into something more honest.

Then, Rio reached across the middle seat and rested her hand gently on Agatha's jumping knee.

"I know," she muttered softly. "I was just joking."

Agatha exhaled slowly, the tension in her muscles lessening.

Greg, still focused on the road, said nothing, but the smile on his face widened just enough to be noticed.

The car pulled up to the curb outside a grand hotel, its towering entrance illuminated with soft golden lights and the glow of too many chandeliers. The kind of place that screamed elegance and luxury, where not even the warm lights could make one feel welcome without enough zeroes in their bank account.

Greg stepped out first, a well-rehearsed move, the starting gun for the performance. He rounded the car to Agatha's side, pulling it open and stepping aside.

When her feet hit the pavement, the cold air almost made her shiver, the soft hum of conversation and laughter slipping past the closed door and reaching her ears.

By the time she adjusted the hem of her coat, Greg had already crossed over to Rio's side. She emerged from the car with a quiet kind of elegance, the uncovered parts of her dress catching the light like the surface of a dark lake, subtle and smooth.

Agatha stood up straighter without meaning to.

Rio joined her with a calm curiosity, eyes tracking the movement behind the tall glass doors. She leaned closer.

"That's some Gilded Age shit," she muttered, eyeing the guests inside - people draped in designer brands, their laughter just a little too sharp, their smiles a bit too wide.

Agatha huffed a laugh, brushing her index finger against Rio's hand in silent invitation. "Ready?"

Rio didn't hesitate. Her fingers slipped between Agatha's with ease, warm and grounding.

"Born ready," she whispered back with a smirk, then leaned in just enough for her breath to graze the shell of Agatha's ear. "Just point me to the nearest pretentious prick."

Agatha bit back a smile and gave her a warning glare, but pulled her toward the door.

They crossed the threshold together, into marble and gold and music that hung in the air like expensive perfume. Eyes turned to the almost instantly.

Sharks sensing blood. Like in those stupid documentaries Rio loved so much.

Agatha tightened her grip, already scanning the crowd. She needed a buffer, someone tolerable, familiar. Lilia, maybe Jen. Anyone to slow the inevitable parade of small talk and subtle jabs masked as compliments.

Rio followed quietly at her side, taking in the extravagance like a foreign language. Everything shimmered - gold leaf embellishments and polished floors reflecting the crystal overhead. It was beautiful in a cold, detached way.

The crowd moved like clockwork, laughter striking on cue, each conversation a veiled flex - yachts, estates, vintage wine collections - and yet everyone pretended not to care about the money they so clearly had.

"You know," Rio murmured, her lips near Agatha's ear. "I think this room is just entirely pretentious pricks."

The corners of Agatha's lips twitched. "Took you long enough,"

That was when she spotted Lilia across the room, deep in conversation with one of their wealthier clients. When their eyes met, Lilia gave a subtle, beckoning nod.

"Still want me to enjoy it?" Agatha asked, leading them forward.

Rio chuckled under her breath. "Not committing a felony seems like a bigger ask by the minute."

Agatha gave her a sidelong look. "Jury's still out on that."

She steered them toward Lilia, the lights bright above, the noise thick around them.

"Come on. Let's say hello."

When they were close enough to hear the conversation - unsurprisingly focused on money and work - Lilia flicked her wrist toward them, making the man stop mid-sentence to glance over his shoulder.

"My, my," he said, voice smooth like aged whiskey and just as sour in the aftertaste. "Agatha Harkness. And here I thought you'd make your usual late entrance, with just enough time to be seen and not spoken to."

Agatha smiled tightly, resisting the urge to step back from the overwhelmingly potent cologne surrounding the man like an oppressive cloud. "I would never miss a good party, Mr. Fisk."

His broad shoulders shook as he chuckled, hollow and cold. "Of course not," his gaze drifted to Rio, pausing like he was sizing up a piece of art he hadn't decided how to price yet. "And you are?"

"Rio Vidal," she said, extending her hand with polite confidence. "Agatha's wife."

Fisk took her hand and bent slightly, brushing his lips over her knuckles with an old-world flair that felt more calculated than courteous. "Ah," he said, straightening with a hum. "So the rumors were true."

The shift in his focus was instant. Back to Agatha as if Rio had been a footnote.

"Congratulations," he added dryly. "Though I hear your mother's not particularly thrilled with the arrangement."

Agatha's spine stiffened. She opened her mouth, ready to slice through his arrogance with something less than professional, but Lilia beat her to it, her tone dipped in velvet steel.

"Mr. Fisk, I didn't take you for a man so easily swayed by gossip."

He chuckled again, this time more briefly. "Information can be just as useful as money, Ms. Calderu."

His eyes flicked down to Agatha and Rio's joined hands before returning to Lilia. "But very well. I'll leave you ladies to your evening. We'll finish our chat later."

When he walked into the crowd, his imposing statue sticking out like a sore thumb, Agatha exhaled sharply through her nose. "He's as slippery as ever."

Lilia nodded, eyes lingering on the man's back. "Comes with his line of work, I'm afraid."

"And what's that?" Rio chimed in, visibly confused.

Agatha blinked. "You don't know him?"

Rio shook her head.

"That's Wilson Fisk," she said, observing Rio's face. "Half the city in his pocket. Political influence, corporate takeovers, alleged criminal ties..."

"Are you even allowed to say that?"

"Alleged," Agatha emphasized. "Do you live under a rock or something?"

Rio laughed at the genuine surprise in her voice, shrugging. "I don't keep tabs on rich assholes in the city. It's bad for my mental health."

"Smart," Lilia commented, adjusting her silk shawl. Despite her black dress being relatively simple, her stacked bracelets and the way she carried herself made her stand out like a queen among pawns. She glanced at her watch. "Time for the speeches. I'll see you later."

Then, with a meaningful look at Rio, she added, "Keep her from leaving too early, would you?"

"She's not my babysitter," Agatha scowled, but Lilia was already melting back into the crowd like smoke.

Rio gave Agatha's hand a gentle squeeze. "Well, that's it," she said with mock seriousness. "Boss's orders. You're officially under supervision."

Agatha rolled her eyes, but the corner of her mouth betrayed her. "You're enjoying this, aren't you?"

"Deeply," Rio said, her smile wide. "Come on, Mrs. Harkness. Let's get you a drink and find a quiet corner to talk shit about people."

Okay, so maybe that particular gala wouldn’t be so bad.

After the speeches - uninspired, repetitive, and almost criminally sleep-inducing - the energy in the room shifted.

Lilia's closing toast to future possibilities and continued collaboration had barely finished echoing before half the room started moving. Some took it as their cue to leave, their obligations fulfilled. Others trickled back to their circles of power and politics, glasses of wine in hand, laughter already laced with self-importance. The smallest group drifted toward the dance floor.

The band played on, their string humming a familiar classical piece with just enough flair to be impressive but not enough to be remembered. The parquet floor gleamed beneath the chandeliers, polished to a mirror finish and wide enough to host a small wedding. Or a war.

Agatha lingered by the bar with Rio at her side, her eyes scanning the room like she was still on the clock. Which, technically, she was.

"Do people actually dance at these things?" Rio asked, sipping her drink, looking amused as she watched a couple begin the first slow, carefully choreographed movements.

Agatha shrugged. "Mostly the ones who think they have something to prove. Or want to close a deal and think stepping on their future partner's toes is a good idea."

"Sounds like there's a story there."

"A tragic one."

Rio leaned against the bar, turning so her body faced Agatha more fully. "So you dance?"

"You don't have to sound so surprised," Agatha chuckled, fingers tracing the stem of her glass as she glanced toward the few couples twirling on the polished floor. "My mother made sure I could survive any social death trap, including the ones set to a string quartet. I can dance. Well."

"Confident," Rio noted with a grin. "And here I thought lawyers only danced around questions."

Agatha glanced sidelong at her. "Please. I dance around subpoenas. Waltzing is comparatively easy."

"I promise not to step on your toes," Rio said, voice dropping slightly.

Agatha turned toward her then, eyebrow arched, mouth tugging into something sly. "All you do is step on my toes."

"Not on a dancefloor."

"Are you asking for a dance?"

Rio's grin widened. "Maybe."

But before Agatha could reply, a voice cut clean through the moment.

"Mrs. Harkness."

They both turned, the mood shifting with the precision of a well-timed cue. A woman approached, each step deliberate, her heels clicking against the marble floor like punctuation in a speech she hadn't rehearsed because she didn't need to. She was all lines and angles - sharp suit, slicked-back hair, and eyes lined with black makeup, flicking between them curiously.

Familiar, Agatha realized. Not immediately, but enough. It clicked the moment the woman stopped in front of them. "Ms. Odinsdottir," she greeted, polite and distant with the practiced ease of someone who could fake interest for a living.

Of all the potential interruptions, Hela Odinsdottir was at least an entertaining one. Razor-witted, slightly venomous, and never quite predictable. The kind of woman who could scare a room full of billionaires with a single smile and enjoy doing it.

"Are you enjoying the party?" Agatha asked, offering a courteous nod.

Hela's lips twitched like the question had amused her. "Immensely," she said. Her gaze flicked to Rio, appraising. "Your wife, I assume."

"Correct," Agatha confirmed, keeping her tone polite but firm.

Rio offered her hand. "Rio Vidal."

Hela took it, but instead of shaking, she held it for a second longer than necessary, her short nails scraping against the tan skin. "An academic, aren't you?"

Rio blinked. "Uh. Yes. Biological and biomedical sciences."

"I can always tell," Hela said smoothly, finally releasing Rio's hand, though her gaze lingered. "You have that sharp look in your eyes. The kind most people here lose after one too many dollars in their bank accounts."

Rio tilted her head, curiosity sparked. "Is that a compliment or a warning?"

Hela's smirk was sharp enough to draw blood. "Depends on what you do with it."

Agatha stepped in subtly, a shift in her stance placing her ever-so-slightly between them. "Rio's doing quite a bit with it. She's working on a thesis that'll probably make most of this room feel more obsolete than they already are."

Hela's eyes flicked to her, amused. "I don't doubt that. Though I must admit, it's hard to focus on academic accolades when someone looks like that."

Her gaze slid back to Rio, openly appreciative now, and Rio - fucking Rio - offered a polite smile, probably remembering their conversation from the car. An arm candy. A trophy wife. "The dress is doing most of the work."

Treating the words as an invitation, Hela's gaze dipped lower, past Rio's collarbones. "The cover rarely makes the book interesting."

Agatha's jaw clenched subtly when Rio laughed, brushing the comment off like it was just another wry remark from a rich stranger examining her with the curiosity of a child at a zoo seeing a strange animal for the first time.

"I'll let my advisor know I'm still worth reading," she joked, finishing her drink and putting it back on the bar.

Hela's smile didn't waver. "They'd be a fool not to."

Agatha had had enough.

She didn't interrupt so much as intervene, moving with a grace honed from years of courtroom poise and PR training. Her arm slid around Rio's waist, casual to the outside, but calculated down to the angle of her wrist. It was a territorial gesture dressed up in silk gloves and diplomacy, but the downright possessive way her fingers splayed over Rio's hip betrayed her.

For the appearances, of course.

"Don't let her fool you," she said, voice cool even as something warmer and far less professional coiled in her chest. "Rio's modest to a fault, but she has many aces up her sleeve."

"Ah," Hela turned her gaze on Agatha, and though her smile remained, her expression turned knowing. "Modesty? Such a rare trait in your line of work."

Agatha met her look head-on, unblinking. "I like to think I surround myself with the best qualities. It saves me from adopting even more terrible ones."

There was no mistaking the subtext in Hela's glance - she knew exactly what she was doing. And worse, she knew Agatha knew.

"Wise," Hela murmured. "Though I'd argue a little arrogance never hurt anyone."

Rio looked between them, sensing something but unable to name it. "This feels like a lawyer thing."

Agatha didn't look away from Hela. "Not everything's a lawyer thing, darling."

Okay, where the fuck did that come from? She decided not to dwell on it.

"No," Hela agreed, her tone almost lazy. "Some things are just human nature."

Before Rio could ask what that meant, a passing server offered champagne. Hela gracefully plucked a flute from the tray and took a slow sip, tipping her head in mock farewell.

"Well, I've monopolized enough of your time," she said, eyes already scanning the room for her next target. "Enjoy your evening."

They watched her go, her silhouette cutting through the crowd like a razor through silk.

Agatha finally let out a breath she hadn't realized she was holding.

"That was... different," Rio said, her voice light with confusion, her head turning toward her. The soft lighting brushed her cheekbones, catching the edges of her smile. "Darling?"

Agatha didn't think before responding. "Yeah?"

"No, I mean - you called me darling. Where did that come from?"

Agatha hesitated. Just for a second. Long enough to matter.

"She was seconds away from shoving her tongue down your throat," she said evenly, keeping her expression composed. "I figured some possessiveness might help sell the story. Appearances and all."

Rio didn't press. She simply nodded, looking back toward the dancefloor like it hadn't stirred anything beneath the surface.

But for Agatha?

Her stomach twisted, slow and deliberate, a knot forming in the space between reason and something else she didn’t dare name.

It was just an act.

And yet-

The way Hela's hand lingered on Rio's skin. The unguarded appreciation in her voice. The casual way she leaned in like she had every right to.

Agatha wanted to believe her reaction was about the optics. About the performance. About maintaining the lie.

She wanted to believe the tension in her jaw, the heat still radiating from where her hand had rested on Rio’s hip, was only part of the role she played so well.

In this room, at this moment, their marriage was real.

And Agatha was a phenomenal actress.

That was all.

She withdrew her hand with the same composure she always wore, then extended it, palm up. When she spoke, her voice had softened, a thread of something warm curling beneath the surface.

"Still want to dance?"

Rio looked at her, blinking as if the offer had caught her off guard.

Then, slowly, she smiled. The kind of smile that reached her eyes.

"I thought you'd never ask."

Her fingers slid into Agatha’s with an ease that felt dangerous, like something Agatha might actually want to believe in.

Just for tonight. Just for this dance.

The music swelled, building into a crescendo before the strings stilled, offering a brief respite as the players shuffled through the music sheets. Agatha led Rio onto the parquet floor just as the first notes of a simplified waltz filled the air, a piece designed for people pretending they knew how to dance.

Agatha did know.

And for the first time in her life, she was grateful for the hours spent swaying on the dancefloor in uncomfortable shoes with her mother pointing out her every mistake because the moment Rio's hand settled in hers, and her other rested lightly on Agatha's shoulder, her mind stammered.

They began to move, slow and measured, each step almost too effortless for their first dance together.

Agatha's heels clicked against the polished floor as they turned, the crowd blurring into a wash of color, perfume, and polished smiles. But Agatha wasn't watching them anymore.

Rio's dark eyes gleamed in the warm light, two pools of brown filled with so much trust that Agatha suspected she could lead the woman off a cliff and Rio would simply accept it.

Just a performance. Just a part of the deal.

It didn't feel like it. Not when Rio's fingers curled slightly in hers, not tight, not tentative, just there, and Agatha felt it all the way down her spine. The warmth of her palm. The closeness of her body. The faintest floral trace of her perfume, something soft though earthy, not overly expensive, so inherently Rio.

Agatha guided her through a slow turn, catching the moment Rio's eyes darted to her lips before flicking away again.

It must've been the light. It had to be.

They were surrounded by people who thought they were in love. People who expected smiles and soft touches, and intimate glances. Rio was a phenomenal actress as well, aware of the message the dance should send. They had to keep the act up, had to convince everyone this was real.

Agatha shifted a little closer, letting the hand on Rio's waist rest a fraction lower, her thumb tracing a barely-there motion against the smooth fabric of her dress.

Rio looked up at her with that same easy smile, as if she truly believed this was just a game. As if none of it mattered.

Agatha's throat was dry.

"I thought you didn't like dancing at these things," Rio murmured, her breath hitting Agatha's cheek.

Jesus, they were so close.

"I don't," Agatha said quietly. "But you make it tolerable."

Her voice came out lower than intended, warmer. Something vulnerable threatened to slip past the edges, but Rio didn't notice. Or maybe she did, but chose not to say anything.

Agatha turned them again, slower this time. She let the moment linger like the notes of a song that should've ended by now. But it didn't. It kept going, impossibly delicate.

So did the lie.

So did she.

Just one more step, one more spin, one more second pretending it didn't feel real.

The music began to taper, the violins growing softer and more distant, signaling the end.

Couples around them slowed, breaking apart with the subtle choreography of a practiced crowd, a smile here, a murmur there, hands falling away like petals from a stem.

But Agatha held on a second longer than she needed to, not long enough to be noticeable but just to feel it.

Rio's breath was even, her hand still resting gently against Agatha's shoulder. She looked up, her eyes wide with something unreadable, and so, so warm.

Agatha had to remind herself to breathe.

"You're a good lead," Rio said, too soft for teasing.

Agatha's mouth curved into something halfway between a smile and a defense mechanism. "I'll make sure to tell my mother that."

She tried to let go then - really, she did - but Rio's fingers caught her hand for just a second longer, an unconscious reflex. Like neither of them quite wanted to leave the moment behind.

Agatha's heart stuttered.

Then Rio stepped back, brushing a loose strand of hair behind her ear. "I didn't take Evanora for someone who let a woman learn how to lead."

"She was strongly opposed," Agatha admitted, pulse still thumping in her temples. "But has that ever stopped me before?"

The orchestra shifted, notes rising again with a new rhythm. Another song. Another chance. Around them, dancers began to gather once more.

They could do one more, right?

It wouldn't be strange to ask again.

Agatha turned, readying herself to offer her hand-

"Rio!"

Billy's voice cut through the moment, bright and unbothered, slicing through Agatha's thoughts.

She stiffened, irritation curling sharply under her ribs. Why the fuck was he here? Since when were assistants invited?

But Rio lit up, her whole face changing at the sound of his voice. "Billy, hi!"

He approached with his usual bounce, suit crisp but worn like a borrowed costume. He had the energy of someone who'd found the wrong door to the right party and decided to stay anyway.

"Mrs. Harkness," he said brightly, giving Agatha an appreciative once-over. "You two look amazing together."

Agatha crossed her arms, voice flat. "Not an appropriate comment to make to your boss, Teen."

Rio shot her a side glance, eyebrows raised, before smoothing things over with practiced ease. "What she means is thank you."

"Where's Eddie?" she added, scanning the room.

Billy jerked a thumb toward the bar, his mouth twisting. "Cornered by some finance guy from his firm. They're talking about... numbers? I stopped listening once someone said diversify your portfolio," he turned back to Rio with a grin. "Figured I'd find you before I expired from boredom, and then I saw you two on the floor, absolutely obliterating everyone else's dignity."

Rio laughed, light and real, and Agatha hated how much it tugged at something deep in her chest.

"It was all her," Rio nodded at her with a smile so bright it should be illegal. "She's scarily good at this."

Agatha shifted her weight, trying not to let it show. She wasn't used to praise. It made her feel uncomfortable, especially when genuine. She should have made a joke. Deflected. Instead, she just stood there, still as a statue.

Billy turned to her, clearly oblivious to the tension cracking just beneath the surface. "You're full of surprises, Mrs. Harkness."

"Don't get used to it," Agatha muttered. It came out more tired than sharp, the edge dulled by something she didn't want to name. Her gaze swept the room, looking for a lifeline.

She needed distance. Breathing room. A moment to slip back into herself, away from the ghost of a dance and the weight of something unspoken clinging to her skin.

A familiar face caught her eye. One of her newer clients, conveniently waving a drink and radiating small talk energy. Perfect.

"I should do some networking," she said abruptly, already angling her body away. She barely looked at Rio when she added, "You good here?"

Rio blinked, eyebrows lifting at the shift in tone. Whatever softness Agatha's voice had was gone, replaced by the usual cool detachment.

"I- yeah. Sure."

"I'll find you later," Agatha tossed over her shoulder, already moving, heels tapping against the wood as she disappeared into the crowd without looking back.

The rapid exit didn't free her of the moment, though. It kept clinging to the back of her blazer like perfume or smoke that didn't wash off easily, even as her face reset itself into a collected mask. She made eye contact with the client, a man with too much cologne and a handshake that lingered a beat too long.

He had to do.

She smiled, crisp and professional, and started the conversation like she hadn't just been seconds away from... what? Something dangerous. Something soft.

She couldn't afford soft.

Especially not with Rio.

"She's beautiful," the client said, unprompted, eyes flicking in the direction she'd just come from.

Agatha didn't flinch.

"She is," she agreed coolly. "And terrifyingly smart. Taking her anywhere usually ends with job offers or marriage proposals."

The client laughed, and she smiled again, hollow and practiced. Her attention drifted as he spoke about some investment, dressed in a polite yet boastful tone.

Agatha nodded, talked, and smiled in the right places, but her mind was still on the dancefloor. Still two songs back, when Rio's hand had fit into hers like a secret they weren't ready to tell.

She hated it.

Hated that she wanted to look back. Hated that she wanted to know if Rio was watching her. If she'd noticed the shift. If she felt it too.

Agatha took a sip of champagne she didn't want, letting it burn on the way down.

This was the deal they'd made. A fake marriage, a perfect lie.

Nothing more.

She could feel the weight of her wedding ring on her hand like it was mocking her.

The conversation bled on. She heard the client’s voice in pieces - phrases about quarterly growth and competitive edge - but it was all background noise. Muffled. Like someone had dropped her underwater and left her there to smile through the surface.

She nodded again, excused herself with a promise to circle back, and moved toward the edge of the ballroom.

Her moment of peace didn't last for two seconds before Lilia and Jen materialized around her, their blurry reflections crowding her in the tall window she was facing.

"Great speech, Lilia," she said, keeping her voice even. "I lasted almost two full sentences before zoning out."

Lilia laughed, unfazed by the sarcasm. "Thank you. I hope you committed those lines to memory. It's your turn next year."

Agatha hummed, tracing the string lights outside with her eyes. "I'll fake an emergency."

"I'll have Rio bring you."

The words felt like a punch in the gut, but Agatha powered through the blinding pain with a tight-lipped smile that looked more like a scowl. "She won't be here next year."

It was imprecise, but her friends were lawyers accustomed to reading between the lines.

She won't be my wife in a year.

Agatha kept her eyes on the lights, fingers folding neatly around the base of her glass. She wasn't sure what to make of the faint ache pressing against her ribs. It wasn't new, but it was getting harder to ignore.

"You can still bring her," Jen said after a pause. "This is the longest you've lasted on one of those things."

"And the only time I saw you genuinely enjoy dancing," Lilia added softly.

"That wasn't real," Agatha replied, tone flat. "None of it is."

It was the kind of line that should have closed a conversation, but it didn't. Jen just tilted her head, studying her. "Isn't it?"

Agatha didn't give her the satisfaction of an answer.

"I need air," she muttered, walking away without waiting for a reply.

She didn't hear Lilia or Jen follow. And that was good.

Because when she stepped out onto the patio, the brisk air was almost enough to clear her mind.

Almost.

The sharp bite of the evening wind slithered under her blazer, grazing her collarbones and cutting through the heat still lingering on her skin from the dance. She welcomed it - needed it - like a slap on the face. Like something that could shock her back into sense.

She moved toward the marble railing unhurriedly, each step calculated like grace was the only armor she had left. The string lights twinkled in the lush garden, mapping out the paths like the arrows leading to an emergency exit.

Agatha set her glass down on the ledge with a soft clink, fingers curling loosely around the delicate stem. The crystal was cool, smooth, and utterly unhelpful.

Blaming everything on alcohol would be so easy.

It was a built-in excuse, the kind that slipped easily off her tongue in the morning after's half-light. Much like after her birthday, she could write everything off - say the champagne got to her, that the pressurized evening and the strain of pretending finally cracked something.

That the way her fingers dug into Rio's hip had meant nothing.

That the softness in her voice was just an echo of the music.

That the way she held on at the end of the song was muscle memory.

She could swear off drinking around Rio. Laugh about it later.

But she wasn't even buzzed.

Three glasses, carefully spaced out and light enough to keep her thoughts knife-sharp.

No excuse.

The worst part was knowing that nothing about tonight had been accidental. She hadn't stumbled into softness. She'd chosen it. Allowed it. Leaned into it.

Like a fucking fool.

Because something in her had cracked open the second Rio’s hand slid into hers, warm and steady. And the way Rio looked at her - like she saw right through the mask and liked what was underneath - had set something loose in Agatha she didn’t know how to name.

She wasn’t built for this kind of ache. This slow unraveling.

And yet here she was, standing out on the patio like she needed distance to keep herself intact. Like she couldn’t trust herself not to ask for one more dance. One more moment. One more lie that felt too good to correct.

She exhaled through her nose, steady and silent.

The door creaked open behind her.

She didn't turn, but she knew who it was before she heard the steps. Knew it from the quiet way they moved, from the instinct that curled warm and unwelcome under her skin.

Rio.

Of course it was fucking Rio.

Her heels clicked softly against the stone, slowing as she approached. She didn't speak at first, just came to stand beside her, leaving a respectful space between them.

Agatha kept her eyes trained on the string lights, twinkling and unbothered as if they were laughing at her inner turmoil.

"I figured I'd find you here," Rio said after a moment, voice low. "Lilia said you looked like you were considering bolting."

Agatha's mouth twitched. "No way. I'm setting a new record."

Rio smiled, but it didn't reach her eyes. She looked out at the garden, mirroring Agatha's stance. "You okay?"

"I'm fine," Agatha said automatically.

Rio didn't believe her. But she didn't push either.

The silence stretched, not uncomfortable, just... full. Brimming with things neither of them was sure how to name.

Agatha finally glanced at her out of the corner of her eye. "You didn't have to come out."

"I know."

And yet, she had.

Agatha looked down at her hands, still wrapped around the fragile glass, and untangled them slowly, fingers tapping against the cold marble.

The question swelled on the tip of her tongue.

Had Rio felt it too? Not just this evening, but since the dinner with Evanora? Could she sense the shift between them? Was that why she had searched for her?

"The party should've been here," Rio muttered, eyes sliding appreciatively over the well-maintained garden, each bush trimmed to perfection, every flower carefully spaced out. "It's beautiful."

Agatha forced the questions down, swallowing the bitter taste they left on her tongue.

"Too cold for the clients," she said, voice quieter than she meant. "God forbid they feel uncomfortable for a second."

Rio huffed a soft laugh. "Right. Pretentious pricks."

"I hope you didn't call anyone that after I'd left," Agatha half-joked, her tone flat.

"Not to their face. As agreed," Rio mused, leaning just a fraction closer, her face softening. "You sure you're okay? You left kinda suddenly."

Agatha felt her defenses shoot up, but something felt wrong. They felt weaker, like one more question would crumble them entirely. "I'm on the clock. Networking is required."

Rio nodded slowly, eyes still on her, not buying the excuse but respecting the space Agatha clearly needed. "Sure. I just-"

She hesitated.

It startled Agatha into looking at her again. Rio rarely hesitated. She rarely thought before speaking.

Now, she was standing with her arms wrapped around her body to ward off the cold, her expression lost like she'd been thrown into a situation way beyond her competencies.

"The dance felt good."

That, well, that nearly fucking undid her.

Agatha straightened, spine stiffening as she reached for the champagne glass again, desperate to keep her hands occupied.

To stop herself from pulling Rio into her, from offering her body heat to the shivering woman.

"We're both good dancers," she deflected.

Rio exhaled softly, a small huff that wasn't quite a laugh. "That's not what I meant."

Agatha didn't reply.

She couldn't.

The words settled between them like mist, clinging to their clothes, their silence. Neither of them looked at the other, not directly - like eye contact would make it real.

A beat passed. Then two.

Agatha finally spoke, her voice low. "I'm not used to... dancing like that."

"Me neither," Rio said, and that was all.

It didn't need more.

They stood in silence, shoulder to shoulder, staring at the garden bathed in soft moonlight - trimmed hedges, clean paths, manicured flowerbeds.

"You know," Rio said eventually, almost as if she were thinking out loud, "when I first moved in, I was weirdly excited about your backyard. I think I spent more time staring at the grass than unpacking."

Agatha tilted her head slightly, a quiet shift, just enough to catch Rio's profile in her peripheral vision.

It was easier, somehow, to focus on this than on the electric thread still stretching taut between them.

Rio smiled faintly. "I know I have a lot of potted plants, but I always wanted to grow more than just what fits in a pot. Herbs, tomatoes, maybe squash if I'm feeling ambitious."

Agatha looked back out, lips tugging into something caught between fondness and resignation. "You've already started claiming corners. The gardener mentioned a mysterious rosemary bush near the back gate."

"Narc," Rio grumbled, mock-serious. "Here I thought we bonded over soil and fertilizers while he was reporting back to you."

Agatha huffed a small laugh. "For all its worth, he seemed happy to have somebody who cares about that kind of stuff in the house. Maybe slightly afraid you'll steal his job."

Rio drummed her fingers against the marble, shaking her head. "I'd never. Somebody has to take care of the rosemary after I move out."

Agatha ignored the unease curling between her ribs at the comment. "It's not my fault plants die out of spite."

"They just need attention," Rio said. Then, quieter, she added, "Not everything thrives on distance."

Agatha's fingers tightened slightly on the glass, the weight of the words landing somewhere in her stomach.

"You can do what you want with it," she said after a beat. "The garden."

"Really?"

Fuck, the excitement in Rio's voice made her feel stupid for not offering earlier.

"You already are," Agatha muttered. "Might as well go all in."

Rio smiled like a child in a candy store, her eyes shining. "I promise not to turn it into a jungle."

Agatha nodded, her throat tighter than she'd like. "I'll tell the gardener to cut down any lianas on sight. I wouldn't be surprised if they tried to strangle me in my sleep."

"Dramatic," Rio laughed, bumping their shoulders together. "I can run everything by you, not a single seed planted without your approval."

"No need," Agatha breathed out. "I trust you."

Rio stilled beside her, the subtle hitch of her breath cutting through the silence like a startling gunshot. She didn't say anything right away. Just looked at Agatha, not with amusement or teasing, but with something steadier. Something like awe.

"You trust me," Rio echoed carefully, surprise lacing her voice.

To her credit, Agatha was just as startled by the admission.

The realization struck with a quiet but seismic force, reverberating through her chest like the aftermath of dropped glass. She could almost hear it, the pieces falling into place with a deafening, inevitable click.

That was it. The shift.

The elusive thread that had been tugging at the seams of their every conversation since the dinner with Evanora. The thing that lingered in the charged silences and wrapped itself around every touch, every glance that lasted a second too long.

Trust.

Not the calculated, conditional kind she extended to colleagues or clients, but something quieter. The kind that crept in unnoticed, like water through cracks, until she was already soaked through.

She had given it to Rio slowly, incrementally. A crumb at a time. Letting her cook dinner. Letting her stay with Nicky, even when the stakes felt too high. Letting her fix things - like that stupid front porch railing - without protest or second-guessing. Each moment was small enough to ignore on its own, but together, they formed a pattern. A quiet surrender.

And then, without even realizing it, Agatha had handed over the whole damn thing.

She'd watched Rio sit in front of Evanora like a shield, catching every backhanded comment, every thinly veiled insult with calm, deadly precision. Not for show or credit, but because - for some reason - defending Agatha's dignity had become non-negotiable. Because Rio had drawn a line in the sand, planted her feet, and decided that Evanora would not cross it. Not if she could do anything about it.

That was the moment, Agatha realized. The silent transition from holding her breath around Rio to exhaling deeply whenever she was around.

The moment everything had shifted.

Agatha swallowed thickly, feeling Rio's eyes on her, honest and soft like she knew what the realization had done to her.

How it had ruined her.

Because Agatha Harkness didn't trust people. Not without knowing them for years. Not without making them prove they were worth it over and over again.

And yet, something about Rio made it almost easy. Effortless.

Agatha's tongue flexed uncomfortably in her mouth as she shifted her grip on the champagne glass again, eyes falling away from Rio to stare at the garden. "Don't let it go to your head," she said dryly, but her voice lacked its usual bite.

Rio didn't smirk. She didn't press. She just tilted her head a little like she was still parsing the moment, still letting it settle between them.

"I won't," she said, soft and certain.

And somehow, Agatha knew she meant it.

Then, Rio shivered, abruptly and violently like she had been fighting it for a while now, and Agatha immediately pushed away from the railing, flicking her wrist toward the door. "Let's grab our coats and get out of here. We've already stayed longer than necessary."

The moment fell apart around them, but the shards embedded deep in Agatha's skin.

Rio simply nodded, sending the garden one last glance as if saying goodbye before following her back inside.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! Once again, a pretty long chapter (I'm a yapper, what can I say), packed with Agatha being an idiot and Rio just patiently watching her struggle (they're both idiots, who am I kidding). Thank you for all the kudos (how this story is nearing a 1000 is beyond me, so really, truly, thank you!), and the comments, and see ya next week!

Chapter 14: Lost battles, bruised egos, and confusing feelings

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Whoever decided to organize the gala on a Saturday deserved a raise. Or a promotion. Or both.

Either way, they were currently Agatha's new favorite person.

Because after Saturday came Sunday. And Sundays meant soccer games - early alarms, a chaotic scramble out the door by nine-thirty, and hours spent on uncomfortable plastic chairs, surrounded by overzealous parents and overpriced concession stand coffee.

But most importantly, it meant getting out of the house.

Long before Rio could saunter down the stairs and waltz - walk - into the kitchen with that barely-there look on her face and hair still tousled from sleep.

Agatha had never been more grateful for youth soccer in her life.

Because the alternative? The alternative was staying home, trapped with Rio and the echo of last night.

The echo that, despite her best efforts, had followed her out of the ballroom, into the car, and all the way home.

I hadn't faded. Not after the needlessly long shower. Not while she changed into pajamas with trembling fingers. And certainly not when she lay awake, rigid beneath her sheets, staring at the ceiling like it might offer an answer.

Her mind kept drifting back to the way Rio's hand had settled in hers. To the soft laugh that escaped her lips when Agatha had muttered some dry comment about one of the speeches. To the warmth of her breath ghosting over Agatha's ear when she leaned in just a little too close to whisper her own observation, like the two of them were sharing some delicious secret.

The moments looped endlessly, her body still tingling with the memory of Rio's touch, the scent of her perfume, the way everything had felt lighter.

And that? That was unacceptable.

She couldn't blame the champagne - three glasses weren't remotely enough to make for a plausible excuse.

She couldn't blame Rio either. The woman had done absolutely nothing wrong. She hadn't crossed any lines, hadn't done anything different.

Which left only one explanation: the dry spell.

Touch-starved after months of celibacy from before the arrangement, emotionally compromised by the weird shift between them, and biologically cornered by the fact that Rio was, objectively, beautiful.

Agatha was only human. She was allowed to be a little off about it.

That didn't mean anything.

The tingling from feeling Rio's body pressed against hers as they danced? That had been a simple reflex, her nerves coming back online after being dormant for too long. It didn't mean anything.

The way her stomach twisted when Hela eyed Rio like she was something to own? That was feminism, rage on behalf of a fellow woman. It didn't mean anything.

And the trust, well, that was natural, a byproduct of circumstance. They'd been living together for over a month. Shared space, routines, the occasional crisis - of course, that built some level of trust. That was inevitable.

Still, it didn't mean anything.

It couldn't.

Which was exactly why some space was necessary. A little distance to clear her head, to get her bearings. Just until she could rein everything back in and lock it in tiny boxes at the back of her mind.

Attraction, she could handle. She could stifle it down, using the contract as a fire extinguisher for the sizzling sparks of desire prickling at her skin whenever Rio touched her. Then, she would wait it out, maybe a little miserable, but keeping her professional integrity intact. It wouldn't be the first time she had to put logic above her desires.

But softness?

Softness was dangerous.

Because combined with attraction, it resembled something perilously close to wanting, not just in her bed but in her life.

It resembled wanting to see Rio curled up on her couch every night, arms open and inviting her to join.

It resembled wanting to return home to soft music and Nicky's excited chatter in the kitchen as Rio cooked dinner.

It resembled, well, longing for a relationship.

Thankfully, she didn't want any of that. She never wanted any of that and would not start now, at the worst possible time, with the one person who was off limits.

With the thought planted firmly at the front of her mind, Agatha made her way toward the bleachers, watching Nicky make a beeline for the twins already warming up on the sidelines.

The sun was too bright, the air smelled vaguely of turf and cheap deodorant, and the steady hum of conversations between the parents had her regretting every choice that had led her to an underfunded community park at 9:30 a.m. on a Sunday.

But it was better than being at home.

She noticed Wanda immediately, her red hair standing out in the sea of blondes and brunettes like a sore thumb, and slowly walked over to the empty seat on her friend's left, feet dragging against the gravel.

"Hey," Wanda said casually, taking a long sip from her thermos - coffee so diluted with sweeteners and milk that it should be a criminal offense if Agatha remembered correctly. "You're here early."

Agatha slid onto the hard plastic seat with a sigh, adjusting her glasses and blinking against the early morning glare. "Nicky was excited," she grumbled, nodding at the man on Wanda's other side. "Hi, Vision."

"Hello, Agatha," he muttered gently as if he could already sense the inevitable and pitied Agatha's fate.

Then, almost on cue, Wanda smiled. A little too bright, a little too curious.

"So," she started innocently, tapping her fingers against the thermos, "how was the gala?"

"Full of pretentious pricks," Agatha replied, her eyes glued to the field where the teams were still warming up. "And boring. As usual."

Wanda quirked an eyebrow, studying her with amusement. "Really? Because you look like you haven't slept much."

"Gee, thanks," Agatha scoffed, glancing at Vision. "You got yourself a real charmer."

Vision held back a smile but didn't comment, probably unwilling to get roped into whatever back-and-forth would happen next.

A smart man. Agatha had to give him that.

"I'm just saying," Wanda pressed, maintaining her innocent tone. "It was your debut as a married woman. Something interesting must've happened."

Agatha pressed her lips into a thin line, considering finding an empty seat away from her friend and her stupid questions.

Deciding that it would be too much of a hassle - and could potentially lead to an unwanted conversation with another parent - she turned to face Wanda with a serious look.

"You're right: something did happen," she said, lowering her voice as if to share a secret. Wanda leaned forward, her green eyes sparkling with curiosity. "When we entered, the ballroom erupted in rainbows, and the band started playing 'Born This Way' by Lady Gaga. It was magical."

Wanda blinked, then threw her head back, her laugh loud enough to attract a few other parents' attention.

"You're funny when you're deflecting," she said between giggles, her shoulders shaking. "But you know it's not gonna work."

"Who says I'm deflecting?" Agatha asked with a smirk, adjusting her sunglasses as if preparing for a battle. "You've been to a few of those events with Vision. The strangest shit happens there."

Vision cleared his throat quietly. "She's right. Remember that time they got an entire team of acrobats to perform?"

"Exactly," Agatha nodded. "And his firm is tame."

Wanda gave Vision a look, and he wisely pretended to be interested in the field where the boys were getting into positions.

"I know there was no Lady Gaga or rainbows," the redhead crossed her arms, jutting out her chin as she glared at Agatha. "And you're hiding something."

Agatha shrugged. "Aren't I always?"

Wanda didn't push further. Not yet.

Instead, she leaned back in her seat, fingers wrapping elegantly around the thermos. Her gaze lingered on Agatha for a beat longer, just enough for the message to land.

This isn't over.

And Agatha, as always, hated how easily her best friend could see through her.

So, she turned her focus back to the field, the shrill sound of the referee's whistle cutting through her thoughts, almost startling enough to make her forget about the warmth of Rio's hand in hers.

Just soccer, Nicky, and an unremarkable Sunday.

Without any lingering images of Rio smiling at her like she was something worth looking at.

For the first time since she'd started coming to Nicky's games, Agatha found herself wishing the match would never end.

Usually, the bleachers were a special kind of purgatory - too hard, too cold, and always positioned awkwardly enough to guarantee lower back pain. Most weeks, she sat stiffly with one eye on the field and the other glued to her watch, tracking the time with all the desperation of a prisoner counting down a sentence. Soccer, as far as she could tell, was mostly running, yelling, and pretending offsides weren't made up.

She swore the field existed in some cruel pocket dimension where every second stretched into a minute and every minute into an hour.

But not today.

Today, Agatha barely registered the hard plastic digging into her spine. She didn't flinch when the overly caffeinated mom two rows behind her screamed at her kid like he was up for the Premier League draft. The usual distractions were just white noise, background static to the thoughts swirling restlessly in her mind.

And then came the whistle. Long, sharp, final.

Game over.

Agatha tensed instinctively, dread settling across her shoulders like an unwelcome shawl. That was it. The buffer was gone. Now came the part where they packed up, got in the car, and headed home.

Back to Rio.

And she wasn't ready. Not even close.

Before she could untangle the thought, a blur of movement came barreling toward her.

"We won!" Nicky shouted, his face lit up like he'd just scored at the World Cup. The twins were right behind him, breathless and triumphant, all three grinning like they'd just conquered the universe.

Agatha managed a smile, shaky but sincere, as she reached down to straighten the strap of Nicky's back where it had twisted awkwardly across his shoulder. "I saw. You were amazing."

Tommy jumped in immediately, practically vibrating with adrenaline. "Did you see the pass I made?"

Billy cut in without missing a beat, "And my interception after halftime?"

The three launched into a rapid-fire recap of the entire game, each detail more chaotic than the last. It didn't matter that she'd seen it all. It didn't matter that half the game was a blur of identical jerseys and shouting.

Agatha listened, nodded, and interjected with the occasional 'wow' or 'no way', clinging to every second like it was a lifeline.

"You play like a pro," she said to Nicky, brushing a strand of sweaty hair off his forehead. "They didn't stand a chance."

Her son beamed. The field buzzed with post-game chatter. Beside her, Wanda chuckled, her body angled toward the twins, but her eyes trained on Agatha with a knowing look.

Even though she hadn't said so out loud, Wanda had noticed how the usual rush to escape the cursed bleachers had vanished, replaced by a strange hesitation, a quiet, lingering dread that Agatha wasn't quick enough to mask.

Agatha could feel it in the air between them.

Wanda didn't push, but the slight tilt of her head and the too-casual smile tugging at her lips said enough: she'd seen it. She was waiting.

Agatha gulped, realizing with a quiet kind of horror that the longer she lingered, the more obvious she became. She had to choose: usher Nicky toward the car and start the short drive back to a house that suddenly felt like enemy territory, or stay here and let Wanda's radar ping harder and faster with every second of avoidance.

Before she could decide, Wanda did it for her, opting for a secret, third option that somehow made everything worse and better at once.

"Well," Wanda announced brightly, rising from her seat with a dramatic stretch, "I think a victory like this deserves some pizza. Wouldn't you agree?"

She didn't look at Agatha. Not directly. Just enough of a glance to make it clear the offer wasn't a suggestion but a lifeline.

And when the boys erupted into cheers, jumping and spinning like they'd won a second game, Agatha found herself nodding, the decision taken out of her hands.

"Pizza," Tommy chanted like it was a holy word, already skipping down the bleachers.

"Can we get the one with jalapeno?" Nicky asked, too happy to notice the tension still coiled beneath his mother's skin.

Agatha sighed, her feet moving mechanically against the gravel. "Sounds great," she said distractedly.

Wanda's smile softened, her voice low as she leaned in. "We'll order in. Drive to our house."

Agatha didn't respond, aware of what it meant.

Wanda's house offered privacy, the kind they wouldn't find at the nearest pizza joint or the soccer field. There would be no hiding behind the possibility of strangers overhearing their conversation or convenient distractions. Only a soft couch, the smell of pizza, and Wanda. Patient, annoyingly perceptive Wanda.

She would wait until the kids were busy and until Vision, with his impeccable emotional radar, offered some flimsy excuse to slip out of the room with a glance and a nod.

Then she'd start asking. And Agatha would be cornered.

Still, it was better than going home.

So, Agatha followed Nicky off the field, chasing the sound of his excited chatter and clinging to the short reprieve like it might stretch long enough to breathe.

It didn't.

The reprieve lasted exactly the two minutes it took Agatha to steer the car out of the parking lot and back onto the main road.

Then, just as she started to exhale, Nicky stirred in his seat, gripping his seatbelt and leaning forward with that bright, bouncy energy only a ten-year-old could summon before noon on a Sunday.

"Did you know Rio used to play soccer?" he asked, eyes wide with delight.

The question hit her like a punch to the chest. It was so unexpected that Agatha nearly rear-ended Vision's Skoda Karoq, her foot slamming onto the brake just in time. The car jolted, and she caught Vision's startled expression in the rearview mirror, but he quickly looked away, likely afraid she'd take offense and press harder on the gas out of spite.

Once again - smart man.

Agatha cleared her throat, doing her best to sound unfazed. "Yeah, I knew that."

It was one of the first things she had learned about Rio, thrown at her at the bar the night they met. The night Rio had taken it upon herself to convince Agatha to marry her by feeding her useless facts about her life.

And Agatha still fucking remembered each of those useless facts. She still had them tucked away in that drawer in her mind that had, at some point, stopped being labeled "possibly insane bartender", and now sported a polished little plaque that read: "Rio Vidal."

And the worst part?

She kept adding to the drawer, transforming it into an entire file cabinet.

Favorite color? Green. The deep kind, like pine needles or dark wine bottles.

Guilty pleasure? Stupid documentaries about shark migrations or dinosaurs because, apparently, Rio was a five-year-old boy in disguise.

Biggest pet peeve? People stopping in the middle of the sidewalk because, quote, "How the fuck can you go through life without any kind of spacial awareness?"

Useless. And yet, Agatha's traitorous brain cataloged each fact like she was prepping for a trivia night that would never come.

"She said she played until high school," Nicky added, pulling her back to the present. "But she did something to her knee and had to stop."

And fuck, Agatha knew that too. Not because Rio had told her, but because she had noticed - noticed how Rio would sometimes walk with the slightest limp on damp days, how she would try to keep from bending her right knee too much after a long shift.

Agatha swallowed thickly, fingers tightening around the wheel. "That sounds terrible."

"Yeah," Nicky nodded solemnly as if mourning Rio's career as a professional soccer player. "Can we invite her to my next game?"

Well, she probably should've expected that. The equation was pretty simple: Rio liked soccer and Nicky, and Nicky adored Rio and soccer. If anything, Agatha should be surprised it had taken her son over a month to solve for X.

It didn't make the result any less daunting.

"I don't know, baby," Agatha said slowly, mentally flipping through excuses like flashcards. She needed a reason, something watertight, something better than I'm spiraling because your fake stepmom danced with me for one song, and now I don't know what to do with myself.

The list was short.

"Rio usually works late on Saturdays," she offered weakly. "She's still asleep when we leave."

"She'd get up earlier for me," Nicky replied without missing a beat.

And the worst part was he was right.

Rio would.

Agatha didn't even need to ask. If Nicky invited her to a game, Rio would be up, showered, and probably waiting by the front door in a jersey with one of those dumb foldable chairs before Agatha even got out of bed.

And that made everything worse.

Because Agatha was still a mess of tangled nerves and quiet panic from last night. Because she had deliberately chosen interrogation over returning home to avoid Rio, and now her son wanted to stitch the woman directly into another part of their life.

Agatha blinked hard at the road ahead, jaw tense.

It was not a fight she could win.

"You'll have to ask her," she finally said, feeling like a martyr.

Nicky's grin was almost worth the inner turmoil. Almost.

They pulled up to Wanda and Vision's house ten minutes later, the boys tumbling out like overeager puppies, racing for the door while Vision trailed behind with the calm dignity of someone used to chaos.

Agatha lingered by the driver's side door, letting the spring sun warm her shoulders, hoping it would melt away the knot twisting tighter in her gut.

Wanda appeared beside her a second later, her tone deceptively light. "I half-expected you to bolt."

"You promised pizza," Agatha said as if the food was the only reason she hadn't returned home right after the game.

Wanda hummed, patting her shoulder with the gentleness of someone who already knew exactly what kind of spiral her best friend was in. Then, she turned and headed toward the house, her pace unhurried, her posture the very picture of casual.

Agatha narrowed her eyes.

It was a trap; she had known that much the moment she agreed to the detour.

The conversation was waiting behind the door, crouched low and patient like a lion in the tall grass. Wanda would give her just enough time before pouncing.

Agatha sighed, muttering to herself as she followed. "Should've rear-ended the fucking Skoda."

To her mild surprise, Wanda didn't start the interrogation immediately.

She didn't pounce when they stepped inside the house and kicked off their shoes at the door. Didn't bring up Rio over slices of greasy, glorious pepperoni. Didn't so much as glance her way when the boys announced they were headed to the backyard to practice penalty shots, probably for the next three hours straight.

No, Wanda waited.

She waited until the house had quieted. Until Vision disappeared into his office, the living room grew cozy enough that Agatha dared to believe she was in the clear.

Then came the coffee.

Pressed into her hands with suspicious gentleness. Black, unsweetened, and hot, just as Agatha liked it.

She narrowed her eyes again.

"Oh, come on," Wanda said, plopping down beside her on the couch with a smile that was far too innocent. "Don't look at me like I laced it with truth serum."

"It wouldn't work," Agatha bit back, blowing on the steaming liquid. "I'd power through the effects out of sheer spite."

Wanda leaned back, raising her own cup to her lips. "So?"

"So?"

"So." Wanda angled her body toward her, legs tucked up, voice low and patient. "Are you gonna tell me what happened, or do you want to play the guessing game?"

Agatha took a long sip, the roof of her mouth protesting at the hot temperature. She ignored the burn. "Is there an option where you drop this and let me enjoy my coffee in peace?"

"That version expired this week," Wanda answered easily.

"I want to buy the premium upgrade."

"Your card got declined."

"I haven't even swiped it yet!"

Wanda didn't miss a beat. "Preemptive rejection."

Agatha groaned, flopping back against the cushions with the theatrics of someone who knew the battle was lost. Apparently, the day was one of lost battles, bruised egos, and confusing feelings.

So much for an uncomplicated Sunday.

"Come on," Wanda said softly. "You didn't want to go home after the game and flinched when Nicky mentioned Rio as if he'd asked you to live with Evanora. And you've been unusually quiet for, like, an hour. What's going on?"

"Nothing," Agatha said, too quick to sound convincing, her voice high and thin. She cleared her throat and tried again, steadier this time. "I'm fine. Everything's fine."

Wanda tilted her head, her smile turning more soft than teasing. "Agatha."

It was the tone she used on Tommy when he tried to sneak a cookie before dinner. On Vision, when he insisted he was fine after spending the entire day at the office without lunch.

The tone of someone calling you out without judgment. Of someone who saw the unraveling before you did.

Agatha hated that fucking tone.

"I don't flinch at Rio's name," she muttered into her mug, flinching. Wanda raised an eyebrow. "That was a shiver. It's cold here."

"Right."

Agatha rolled her eyes at the flat, skeptical tone. "I don't know why you're so invested."

"You want a list?" Wanda asked, continuing before Agatha could speak again. "Let's see... you're my best friend, that's one. Two: you showed up to the game almost thirty minutes earlier than usual, something that's never happened before. Three, you looked ready to jump off the bleachers when I asked about the gala, and four, Nicky talked about inviting Rio to the next game, and you almost choked on pizza."

An outstretched finger accompanied each reason, and the red paint coating Wanda's nails brought Agatha thoughts of claws dripping in blood.

Then, true to the metaphor, Wanda went for the jugular.

"She got to you."

It wasn't a question, but a firm statement like Rio's hold on her was apparent.

Agatha bristled, her hold on the mug tightening. "No one got to me."

Wanda raised an eyebrow. "So you're brooding and avoiding your house because... you're passionate about youth soccer now? You don't even know what an offside is."

"Not everyone is married to a Brit obsessed with dudes kicking a ball around," Agatha snapped.

"From what Nicky said, your wife could give Vis a run for his money."

Agatha flinched again, and Wanda's expression softened. "Ags, I've known you for years, and..."

The hesitation made Agatha huff impatiently. "And?"

"And I've never seen you like this."

Agatha's breath hitched, the sound sharp and unintentional. She looked away as if staring at the living room wall hard enough might force Wanda to vanish from beside her. No such luck.

"I don't know what you mean," she said, but the words came out hollow.

Wanda sipped her coffee, eyes thoughtful like she was choosing her next words with the carefulness of a person walking through a minefield.

"I've seen you furious," she began, her voice calm. "Worried. Exhausted. Soft, usually with the boys. But never... this."

Agatha narrowed her eyes. "What's this?"

"Lost."

Agatha swallowed around the tightness in her throat, forcing a short laugh. "You've seen me lost multiple times. Case in point: the day I found out about the will."

"No," Wanda said quietly. "You were angry, sure. Upset? Absolutely. But Evanora's been throwing punches your entire life, and that one wasn't any different from the rest. It left you bitter but not lost."

Agatha didn't answer right away.

Her fingers curled tighter around the sturdy mug like it could anchor her, but it was just ceramic. Useless, like half the lies she kept telling herself.

"You've always known how to navigate chaos," Wanda went on, softer now. "Even if it's messy, even if you scream the whole way through, you always have a plan."

Agatha thought back to when she found out she was pregnant.

She had been a lawyer for four years by then, climbing the ranks with disciplined precision. The path to partnership had been straight and narrow, paved with long nights, airtight cases, and the sheer willpower to prove Evanora wrong.

Her life had structure, a rhythm dictated by court dates and billable hours.

Then came one dinner too many with her mother and one comment too far.

Evanora had looked at her over the rim of her crystal glass with a smirk that could be mistaken for affection if not for the steely look in her eyes. "Do you think you're winning by pretending to be something you're not? No, Agatha, you're just making yourself unlovable, a freak no man will want once you abandon your silly quest of making my life difficult. You're only proving me right."

The words had landed like a slap, and Agatha - humiliated, furious, aching - had walked out before the main course even arrived.

She hadn't planned to end the night in a bar, hadn't meant to let some cocky, forgettable man buy her a drink, smiling at her like she made sense.

But something inside her had cracked wide open, and suddenly, proving her mother wrong, or worse, proving her right, felt like a battle she needed to win that night, even in the worst possible way.

A few weeks later, she sat on the bathroom floor of her apartment with her knees pulled up to her chest and a pregnancy test clenched between shaking fingers. Two pink lines stared back at her, unfazed by the tears spilling down her cheeks.

She remembered laughing, a broken, hollow sound bouncing off the tiled walls. Because, somehow, she'd managed to blow up her entire life while trying to convince herself she had any control over it.

For the briefest moment, there was no plan. Just a terrifying, gaping future Agatha hadn't prepared for.

But once she had gotten up from the floor and wiped her face, she started figuring it out - one impossible step at a time.

How could this feel so much harder? Why did the thought of Rio feel more terrifying than the moment her entire life had derailed?

Agatha ran her tongue over her dried lips, exhaling slowly.

"I need a plan," she said, her voice steadier than she felt. "A way to navigate this."

Wanda studied her for a moment. "I can help with that," she offered sincerely. "But you need to talk to me."

Agatha took a deep breath, bracing herself for the words simmering on her tongue. "I'm attracted to her."

She expected a dramatic gasp or a small intake of breath, at least. But Wanda merely nodded, clearly waiting for her to elaborate. When the silence stretched for a full minute, she pressed gently. "And?"

Agatha frowned. "What do you mean by 'and'? That's it."

Wanda looked at her, her expression somewhere between confusion and exasperation. "That's why you're spiraling?"

The disbelief lacing her best friend's voice felt like a personal attack. Wanda could see through the bullshit, they both knew it, but Agatha wasn't admitting anything out loud. Not when even thinking about it made her skin crawl and her breath stutter.

"Spiraling is a bit strong," Agatha bit out, lifting the mug to her lips only to realize it was empty. She set it down on the coffee table with more force than necessary, the dull clink resonating across the otherwise quiet room.

"Okay," Wanda ran a hand through her hair, exhaling slowly. "You've been married to her for over a month and realized that she was hot just now?"

"Not just now," Agatha muttered petulantly. "Yesterday."

Wanda pursed her lips like she was giving Agatha a chance to hear herself and correct course.

When Agatha just stared back at her, arms crossed and eyes daring her to say something, Wanda sighed. "And what happened yesterday?"

Agatha shifted on the couch, suddenly very interested in a loose thread on her sleeve. "The gala," she almost growled as if the event could be blamed for every bad thing that had ever happened in her life. "I thought she'd wear a suit or something, but no, she had to wear a fucking dress that showed off her arms and clung to every curve."

"Right, because you wouldn't find her attractive in a suit."

"It doesn't matter," Agatha hissed, eyes snapping to her best friend. "The point is that it's inconvenient, and I have to stop."

"You have to stop... being attracted to her?" Wanda lifted her mug and took the slowest, most judgmental sip of coffee Agatha had ever witnessed. "How exactly do you want to do that?"

"I wouldn't be fucking talking about this if I knew!" Agatha snapped, tugging at the thread hard enough to rip it off. "You're my best friend, give me advice."

Wanda rolled her eyes at the demanding tone. "I would, but I can't do that if you're lying to me, and, more importantly, yourself."

Agatha scowled. "I'm not lying."

"Ags," Wanda said more gently, her mild amusement thawing. "It's not just about the dress."

"Yes, it is," she fired back, crossing her arms. "And for future reference: invalidating somebody's feelings after nagging them to talk to you isn't the greatest strategy."

Wanda didn't so much as flinch at her harsh tone. "I'm not invalidating anything. I know you're attracted to her, but you're downplaying it."

"Downplaying it?" Agatha scoffed, choosing to treat the words as a challenge. "Fine. I can tell you all about how I want to feel if her arms are as strong as they seem, trace her tattoo with my tongue, and check if-"

"You know that's not what I meant," Wanda raised her hand with the patience of a saint. "You're focusing on physical attraction because it's easier to admit."

Easier? Agatha nearly scoffed. Nothing about the physical part felt easier. It felt like falling through ice - sharp, disorienting, and humiliatingly loud.

God, she hoped the twins inherited Vision's emotional intelligence. They were doomed otherwise.

"There's nothing else to focus on," she said flatly.

Wanda raised her eyebrows, leaning forward to put her empty mug on the table with the deliberate grace of someone about to lay out undeniable evidence. Then, she settled back against the couch cushions with her hands folded neatly in her lap.

All she needed was a notepad and one of those mildly judgmental therapist smiles, and she could charge Agatha a hundred bucks an hour. Probably more.

"Remember when we went out with Lilia and Jen after you closed that big case last year?" she asked like she was flipping to Exhibit A.

Agatha blinked. "...Sure?"

"Do you remember the woman you met at the bar?"

Her frown deepened. She didn't like where this was going. "Vaguely."

"She was undressing you with her eyes from the moment we sat down. It was so obvious, Jen clocked it between ordering her drink and flirting with the bartender."

Wanda shook her head with a fond little smirk. "You ignored it for about two hours - probably out of spite because Jen kept teasing you - until the woman finally got up the nerve to walk over and ask for your number."

"And?"

"And you told her you didn't need her number because you could leave with her right then and there. Which you did."

"This feels like slut shaming," Agatha muttered, raising her chin in false indignation.

"It's hard to call someone a slut when they've been celibate for months," Wanda deadpanned. "The woman gave you her number anyway. You met with her two more times. Then what happened?"

Agatha shrugged, still not seeing the point of the story. "She got clingy."

"Exactly." Wanda's eyes sparkled like she'd just dropped the winning argument in court. "That's how you are when it's just about sex. You're cool, detached, borderline smug. You flirt, ghost, and move on."

Agatha narrowed her eyes. "And now you're making me sound like a frat boy."

"If the baseball cap fits," Wanda said sweetly.

Agatha groaned, dragging a hand down her face. "You're so annoying."

"I'm also right," Wanda shifted slightly, her tone growing gentle. "You never spiral like this over wanting to sleep with someone. You either take the woman to bed and forget about her the next morning, or decide it's not worth the trouble and ignore the pull. You don't hide in my living room because someone looks good in a dress."

Agatha opened her mouth, then closed it again. There was something uncomfortably accurate about the phrasing. She was spiraling. Not because Rio was attractive - that was a fact, not a crisis - but because Rio had shown up in her life like a lightning strike: unexpected, bright, and far too close to the part of her Agatha had spent half her life trying to lock away.

Wanda softened, leaning in a little. "You're lost because she makes you feel something."

"No," Agatha said quickly. "You said it yourself: I either bang the person or never see them again. But I don't have that choice here. I can't sleep with her. I can't avoid her because I live with her. That's the problem. That's why I'm lost."

Wanda tilted her head. "And you think that's all it is?"

Agatha hesitated.

She could feel it again - that thrum in her chest, that restless energy every time Rio entered a room. It wasn't just attraction. It was curiosity - a need to see her, hear her, understand how she could walk easily through the walls Agatha had spent years reinforcing.

"It's simple biology," she said slowly, trying to sound convincing, but her voice broke. She tried again. "I- I haven't gotten laid in months."

Wanda sighed, clearly not buying the weak argument. "Alright," she conceded, running her hand through her hair in a gesture that screamed exasperation. "So, in short, you want to fuck your wife, but can't, and it makes you a sexually flustered mess hiding in my living room."

Agatha pursed her lips. "It sounds pathetic."

"It's understandable," Wanda shrugged as if they were discussing the weather. "Rio's objectively hot, and you're stuck with her in close quarters. You're only human."

"Exactly," Agatha said, sitting up straighter, content that her friend was finally seeing the issue for what it was. "It's proximity. Frustration. Nothing more."

Wanda didn't argue but merely nodded. "Okay. So you're sexually frustrated, and the only solution is to either wait it out or work it out."

Agatha frowned. "I don't like either of those options."
