"I know," Wanda said sympathetically. "You could sleep with her, but considering your living arrangement and history, it doesn't seem like a good idea."

Yeah, Agatha wasn't even touching that solution.

"Maybe I should try yoga again," she said after a beat. "Or sign up for a martial arts class. Punching other people sounds like something I'd enjoy."

Wanda tilted her head, an amused smirk tugging at the corners of her lips. "The last time we did yoga, you almost threw your water bottle at the instructor because her voice was annoying."

Agatha made a disgusted face. "She sounded like Minnie the Mouse. I couldn't focus on finding my center and releasing my tension with a cartoon character breathing down my neck."

"You got banned from the building," Wanda deadpanned. "And almost took me down with you."

"A true friend would've thrown the water bottle while they escorted me out," Agatha exhaled slowly, leaning back. "So, I should just... wait it out?"

"If it's simply attraction? Yeah," Wanda's tone remained perfectly neutral. "The novelty will wear off. Eventually. Then, you'll repress it, which we both know you're great at."

Agatha smirked faintly. "That's the most validating thing you've said all day."

“I give credit where it’s due,” Wanda replied smoothly, a smile in her voice.

They fell into silence. Real silence. Not the charged kind that filled the gaps between arguments, or the strained kind that trailed behind confessions. Just the quiet of two people who knew how to sit still together.

Agatha stared down at her hands. The urge to fidget was strong, but even her anxiety felt tired now.

Eventually, she muttered, “This is hell.”

Wanda didn’t pretend to argue. “Yeah. But I’m open to sitting in the pit with you.”

Agatha didn’t thank her. She didn’t need to.

Wanda didn’t press or fill the silence with more questions or clever insight. She just let it settle. Let her settle.

Agatha still didn’t have a plan. That was the worst part.

Avoiding Rio wasn’t a solution. It was a stall tactic. And judging by the way her brain kept replaying every moment from the gala - Rio’s hand in hers, the smell of her perfume, that stupidly soft smile - she wasn’t stalling very effectively.

But it didn’t matter.

Because it was only attraction. Just inconvenient chemistry and unfortunate timing. Nothing she couldn’t outthink or outlast.

And since it was only that, there was nothing to worry about.

Not really.

They stayed well into the evening, but, eventually, Agatha had to usher Nicky into the car and drive back to the house with Wanda's knowing look following them out of the driveway.

Nicky went quiet in the backseat almost immediately, worn out by the game and whatever feral chaos the twins had roped him into. His sleepy eyes stared out the window blankly, watching the city move past them at a sloth pace as Agatha refused to press on the gas harder than necessary.

Without Nicky's chatter to distract her, Agatha cranked up the radio loud enough to make the speakers buzz. The obnoxious pop songs, endless commercials, and the DJ's fake-laughing monologues flooded the car, and she hummed along, content with the noise. It was good. It kept the dread from turning into something she couldn't stuff back down.

It also didn't work.

By the time she pulled into the garage and caught sight of Rio's Toyota parked neatly in its usual spot, Agatha's hands tightened reflexively on the wheel.

For a brief moment, she considered throwing the car in reverse and disappearing with Nicky on some impromptu, wildly irresponsible cross-country trip. New identities, new lives. Problem solved.

Instead, she exhaled sharply through her nose and turned off the engine.

She could do this.

Just a normal evening in a normal house with a normal, painfully attractive wife.

Agatha rested her forehead against the steering wheel for a moment, whispering, "I hate my life," before climbing out to shake Nicky awake.

He blinked up at her sleepily, his hand reflexively falling to the side to unbuckle the seatbelt. "Are we home?"

"Yeah," she whispered, moving back to help him out of the car. "I'll get your stuff inside. How about you go get ready for bed?"

Technically, his bedtime wasn't for another hour, but he didn't seem to care. Instead, he rubbed at his eyes, nodding tiredly. "Okay."

When he shuffled through the garage and disappeared into the house, Agatha gathered his duffel bag and the leftover food Wanda had given them before following him with her back ramrod straight.

The house was quiet when she hesitantly slid inside. She dropped her keys in the bowl by the door and glanced around warily, half-expecting Rio to leap out at her like a horror movie villain. But there was nothing - just the low hum of the dishwasher running and the faint smell of something warm and homey lingering in the air.

Agatha blinked. Homey?

She needed to get a grip.

The sound of a door clicking shut floated down the stairs, snapping Agatha out of her unexpected stupor. She shook herself, dropping the duffel bag by the banister with a heavy thud before marching toward the kitchen, the tote bumping against her hip and the plastic containers inside rattling with every step.

Wanda always cooked enough for a small army, especially when she had guests over. It bordered on a cry for help.

When she entered the dining room to cross over to the kitchen, Agatha froze.

Rio was there, barefoot and cross-legged at the table, lost in her own little world. She wore a pair of soft joggers and a hoodie that looked about two sizes too big, the sleeves bunched up around her forearms to keep them from covering her hands, and the hood slipping halfway down her messy bun.

Three thick textbooks lay cracked open around her, surrounded by a storm of papers, highlighters, and crumpled Post-it notes. She was hunched over the table, chewing absently on the end of her pen, a faint frown of concentration tugging at her features.

She looked... normal.

Not like the force of nature that had wrecked Agatha's defenses at the gala or the gravity well that had thrown Agatha's world off-kilter.

Just a girl doing homework, sleeves too long, hair a mess, bare feet tucked onto the chair.

And somehow, that was worse.

Because nothing about the image should be attractive, especially not in light of how Rio had looked the night before.

And still, Agatha's breath hitched without warning, a sharp sound she couldn't bite back in time. Rio's head snapped up immediately, the frown melting away.

"Hey," she said, offering a tired but genuine smile that hit like a punch to the gut. She put her pen down, posture shifting like she was ready to talk. Like she was happy to see her.

Agatha clutched the tote bag tighter, the edge of a Tupperware digging into her side. She forced herself to move, inching toward the doorway with the stiff gait of someone crossing a minefield.

"Hey," she croaked back, keeping her steps slow and casual despite the budding urge to bolt out of the room.

"How was the game?" Rio asked just as Agatha walked past her, her voice tinged with genuine curiosity.

"Nicky's team won."

Despite her best judgment, Agatha glanced at Rio, mentally kicking herself for the moment of weakness a second later.

Because Rio's face lit up like a Christmas tree at the news, joy blooming across her features without hesitation, without artifice. It made her eyes seem even softer, her entire posture relaxing like she hadn't realized she'd been tense until now.

"That's amazing," Rio said, her voice almost giddy with pride as if she'd been personally invested in the outcome.

Agatha blinked, momentarily stumped by how real it was - how real she was - and nearly lost her footing on the hardwood floor.

"Yeah," she muttered, almost to herself. "We went to Wanda's to celebrate."

Before Rio could add anything else, she resumed her trek to the kitchen, almost throwing herself into the space like it might shield her from the warzone of her own thoughts.

Behind her, she heard the scrape of a chair shifting and the soft patter of feet.

"She gave you leftovers?" Rio called lightly, her voice sounding closer by the second.

Agatha exhaled through her nose, clattering the tote onto the counter harder than necessary. "Of course she did."

She busied herself with pulling out the containers, lining them up mechanically, pretending she couldn't still feel Rio's presence creeping up on her like a heat wave.

A beat passed. Then another.

And just when Agatha thought she might be in the clear - that maybe Rio had turned toward the stairs instead - the woman emerged around the corner like a domestic nightmare.

"Anything I can steal?" Rio asked, leaning casually against the counter.

Agatha didn't look up, concentrating intently on folding the tote bag into a neat square. "Help yourself. A small army wouldn't eat it all."

"You underestimate my appetite," Rio mused, crossing over to inspect the containers. Her movements were unrestrained, natural, like this was their normal. Like being around each other should be easy.

Agatha wanted to scream. Or maybe bang her head against the fridge until her mind decided to kindly shut the fuck up.

Instead, she wordlessly shoved a Tupperware toward Rio and yanked open the silverware drawer, needing something, anything to do with her hands.

"Thanks," Rio said, her fingers brushing lightly against Agatha's when she took the container.

It was a featherlight touch - accidental and forgettable.

Agatha still felt it burn all the way up her arm and lodge itself behind her ribs.

She didn't say anything else. She couldn't.

She just focused on extending a fork toward Rio without looking at her, then turned her attention to shoving the rest of the food into the fridge with mechanical efficiency.

Her skin definitely wasn't buzzing like she'd been struck by lightning. Her heart definitely wasn't hammering against her ribs like the mere act of touching Rio could give her a stroke.

It was fine.

It was just proximity.

It would pass. With time. With distance.

Agatha crammed the last container into the fridge, slammed the door shut with a little more force than necessary, and fled the kitchen before Rio even had time to put the cold lasagna in the microwave.

Chapter End Notes

Hiiiii, I have nothing to say in my defense. Even I am getting annoyed by how dense Agatha is (while being fully aware that I am, in fact, the one who controls her actions here), BUT we're getting somewhere. Still, feel free to yell at me in the comments, and *ehem ehem* THANK YOU FOR OVER A 1000 KUDOS! Y'all are the best!

Chapter 15: Hard work

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The following morning, everything was fine.

Okay, so maybe she got up a few minutes earlier to avoid bumping into Rio in the kitchen while she made breakfast.

Maybe the moment she heard the guest bedroom's door open, she told Nicky she would wait in the car, and he looked up from his half-finished cereal with a confused crease between his brows.

Maybe she sat in the driver's seat for fifteen minutes, simultaneously feeling like an idiot for hiding and the cleverest person alive for finding a way to do it.

It was all circumstantial.

Agatha was fine.

But she needed distance to keep that up, to regain her bearings and disconnect whatever synapses had woken up at the gala, making her life difficult.

Hence, hiding in her car until Nicky joined, ready for school, and still visibly confused by her abrupt exit.

Combined with spending the entire Sunday at Wanda's and then retreating to her bedroom after putting the containers away, her behavior started creating a pattern of carefully planned avoidance, but Agatha didn't care. Needing space to get herself in check wasn't a crime, and if that made her spend the evening locked in her room, equal parts terrified and hopeful that Rio would find some lousy excuse to knock on her door, well, that was just life.

It was also pathetic.

Like, objectively pathetic.

But the alternative was sitting at the table with Rio, who would undoubtedly ask about her day in that soft, curious voice that, for some reason, made Agatha feel important and wanted. So, Agatha remained trapped in her bedroom of her own volition, listening to every creak and shuffle as Rio obliviously lived her life while Agatha's dignity crumbled.

At least now, it was Monday.

She didn't have to invent excuses anymore - except for the convenient changing of her morning routine - and could readily sink into the familiar structure of the beginning of the work week.

Somehow, it still felt wrong.

She sat at her desk, flipping through a stack of case files with the enthusiasm of a corpse, the fluorescent light above her buzzing like an insect she couldn't swat away.

Usually, Mondays were the reset button, a way to submerge herself in deadlines, caffeine, and emails, and keep her mind sufficiently occupied.

Today, the piles of issues she needed to look into felt inadequate, a drop in a bucket of more pressing thoughts that emerged every other minute.

By ten-thirty, she realized she'd been rereading the same page for twenty minutes straight, the words blurring into meaningless ink patterns.

By noon, she caught herself staring at Billy through the door like a creepy lurker, trying to figure out what Rio had told him about the gala.

By one, her spacious office started feeling like a poorly ventilated enclosure, and she rose to her feet, slamming her laptop shut with an annoyed growl.

She needed more coffee.

When she pulled open the door, Billy jumped up from his desk like a puppet whose strings had been yanked too hard, his eyes widening at her scowl.

"Is everything alright, Mrs. Harkness?" he asked tentatively.

"I'm getting coffee. At ease, Teen," she grumbled, breezing past him only for him to lurch awkwardly into her path with the gracelessness of a baby giraffe.

Honestly, the guy was well into adulthood and still moved with the gangly nerves of a freshman at his first homecoming dance. Nicky was more coordinated, and he was ten.

"I can get that for you!" Billy squeaked, his voice suspiciously high and almost pleading.

Agatha frowned, gesturing to his desk. "I've given you different tasks. Fetching myself a cup of coffee from the kitchen won't kill me."

Billy's face glitched momentarily, a look of horror flashing in his eyes. "The kitchen?" he repeated, his voice cracking. "Don't you want one from the stand downstairs? I could also go to the cafe down the street. The coffee there is way better, and they use ethically sourced beans, which-"

"Teen," she snapped, crossing her arms. "Get back to work and stop telling me where to get coffee."

He blanched at her tone, his mouth opening and closing a few times before he nodded with a defeated sigh. "Yes, ma'am."

Agatha shot him one last withering look as he sank miserably back into his chair, then turned and disappeared into the maze of corridors she had learned to navigate with practiced ease over the years.

Her office was tucked away in the south wing, overlooking the busy street lined with mediocre cafes selling overpriced coffee and high-end restaurants perfect for meeting clients. Choosing the particular room was a no-brainer - it was well-lit, spacious, and, more importantly, secluded from the other partners. The location usually prevented anyone from bothering her unless they had actual business to discuss, reducing unnecessary pop-ins to a minimum.

The only downside was the inconveniently long walk necessary to reach the closest kitchen, which, on average days, annoyed her so much that she opted for sending Billy to fetch her coffee.

But not today.

Today, Agatha felt almost relieved to weave across the maze of desks, whiteboards, and file cabinets, listening to the rhythmical tapping of keyboards and hushed conversations between the employees.

Typically, it all faded into meaningless background noise, but today, there was an undercurrent - a buzz she couldn't entirely ignore. Conversations seemed more insistent, faces a little too animated.

Agatha didn't bother eavesdropping. Whatever drama had them wound up was none of her business.

When she finally reached the kitchen, which was unusually empty considering the time of day, she quickly made a beeline for the coffee machine.

With her hip propped against the counter and the high cabinets obstructing her from view, Agatha watched the dark liquid trickle into the company-issued mug, wondering if she should Google the lethal dosage of caffeine before drinking it.

She hadn't decided how beneficial dropping dead mid-Monday from a caffeine overdose would be when the kitchen door swung open with a soft creak.

Voices spilled in, casual and unhurried. A group of associates, by the sound of it, probably taking a break from their endless meetings.

Agatha stayed behind the cabinets, sipping on the coffee. It wasn't even about eavesdropping - she couldn't care less about their conversation - but emerging from her hiding spot would undoubtedly bring a chorus of greetings and the kind of brittle smiles that screamed Please don't murder me. And if she overheard anything, well, they were the ones talking too loudly.

"No, seriously," a woman laughed, the sound light and incredulous. "Have you ever seen her do that at a party?"

Another voice - a man this time - snorted. "I honestly didn't think she had the necessary programming. I mean, Harkness? Dancing? Like that?"

Agatha stiffened, gripping the mug tightly.

Another guy chimed in, cackling. "C'mon, if you had a wife like that, you'd want to stake your claim. Have you seen Ms. Odinsdottir-"

"Yes!" the woman interrupted excitedly. "God, I thought I was the only one who saw it! Harkness looked ready to rip her throat out when Hela started flirting."

"It was like watching a National Geographic special," the man agreed, audibly delighted. "Alpha wolf guarding her mate before performing a mating dance."

"That's for birds, you idiot," a different woman grumbled. "But honestly? Same vibe."

There was a short burst of laughter, light and cruel in that effortless office way. Agatha took a careful sip of coffee to cover the fact that her hands felt a little too warm.

"You guys have to admit," she added after a beat, "they looked good together. And I've never seen Harkness so... relaxed. Like she was actually enjoying herself instead of searching for the nearest emergency exit."

Someone hummed in agreement. "I thought the paralegals were pulling our leg when they said Harkness was married to a human being and not her job."

"Right?" the first woman sighed. "I figured she was incapable of emotions other than anger or indifference, but, shit, I want someone to look at me the way she looks at her wife."

Agatha casually cleared her throat, having heard enough.

It slashed through the silence like a guillotine.

She let them sweat for a moment longer, rounding the cabinets slowly, coffee in hand, fixing them with a level, unimpressed stare.

The associates - six of them, she noted absently - looked like they were bracing for impact, a mixture of terror and poorly concealed regret tightening their features.

No one dared move.

No one dared breathe.

Agatha tilted her head lazily and offered them a sugary smile.

"No, please," she said, her voice laced with steel. "Don't stop on my account."

Six pairs of eyes stared at her in unadulterated fear as she walked past them and out the door, her heels striking the tile like gunshots.

As it swung shut behind her, she caught the faintest whispers of desperate voices:

"Since when does she leave her office?"

"Holy shit. We're dead."

"Fuck, the job market is awful right now."

Agatha barely registered them, too focused on the thoughts bouncing around her head like tennis balls.

Wife.

Alpha wolf guarding her mate.

She walked through the halls, fingers loose around the mug and her back straight. The buzz of whispered conversations still carried through the office, and she noticed how it quietened the moment she stepped into another space, shifting into an almost guilty silence as she breezed through the room.

Too focused on the existential crisis caused by the gala, Agatha had almost forgotten about the primary reason behind dragging Rio to the event.

It had been about optics, about providing evidence - tangible, visible, undeniable proof - that her marriage was authentic enough to survive scrutiny. The plan had been simple: spark gossip, let it snowball, and finally worm its way through the grapevine until it reached Evanora's ears, twisted and inflated by every mouth it passed through.

And, apparently, it had worked spectacularly.

The office hummed with it, a low, pulsing current of rumor she could almost taste in the air.

And that didn't even account for Evanora's direct little spies lurking behind champagne flutes and polished smiles at the gala.

Agatha reached her office and slipped inside, closing the door with a firm click. She set the mug down with more force than necessary and sank into her chair, the leather creaking under her.

She should have felt nothing but satisfaction - the smug, burning kind she had learned to associate with the rare occasions she gained the upper hand on her mother.

Instead, the cold, uncomfortable feeling from the day before resurfaced, wrapping around her lungs even more persistently.

The one Wanda had kindly identified for her.

The plan had worked perfectly. Everybody at the office was talking about her and Rio just as intended.

And yet, Agatha still felt lost.

The chatter kept replaying in her head, unwelcome and persistent.

"God, I want someone to look at me the way she looks at her wife."

Her jaw ticked.

It was stupid. Agatha didn't care for the opinions of junior associates, who had nothing better to do than gossip. If anything, she should be glad they had added aspects to the story that would enhance its credibility.

Whatever they had seen was a part of the act - each touch, look, and word crafted for the audience.

Agatha repeated the thought like a mantra, jabbing her finger into the laptop's power button, but the raw envy in the associate's voice kept ringing in her ears.

"God, I want someone to look at me the way she looks at her wife."

Agatha pinched the bridge of her nose, squeezing her eyes shut against the memory that surfaced - Rio laughing at something ridiculous, head tilted back, face lit up, and Agatha's chest squeezing painfully at the sight.

No calculation. No strategy. Just an instinctive, helpless kind of awe.

And people had seen it.

Worse, they had recognized it for what it was - something real, something tender.

Her eyelids fluttered, her reflection staring back at her from the laptop's black screen - eyebrows scrunched, lips pressed into a thin, unamused line - a picture of perfect denial.

Was she in denial?

Wanda had already backed her into a corner until she admitted the low, constant hum of want she had worked hard to ignore. And Agatha was halfway to compartmentalizing it, tucking it away in a lockbox and burying it in the deepest corners of her mind where it couldn't do any damage.

Maybe the associate was just lonely. Maybe she hadn't gotten laid in a while. Maybe the way she looks at her wife meant something shallow. Something greedy and skin-deep, not anything more dangerous.

That Agatha could live with. She had enough self-awareness to realize she had probably spent the better part of the gala devouring Rio with her eyes. Everybody else certainly had, and at least she had some twisted right to do it.

Because it was a part of the performance.

The performance she and Rio had sold to a room full of people who earned money by seeing through bullshit.

That was all that mattered.

Not the way some shallow, reckless part of her - the part she usually kept buried six feet under- purred contently after hearing other people calling Rio hers.

She wasn't happy about it. She was satisfied because it meant the deal was paying off.

And that was the entire point of Rio being in her life in the first place.

A sharp knock rattled her doorframe. Agatha looked up, frowning.

Billy stood there, nervously wringing his hands. "Uh, I have Mr. Bradford on hold?" he pointed to the phone on her desk with a shaky hand as if she needed help locating it. "It sounded urgent."

"How urgent?" Agatha drawled, leaning back in her chair. "Don't I pay you to gather information?"

"Mr. Bradford wouldn't say," Billy rushed to explain, stepping back toward the door. "I could try-"

Agatha waved a dismissive hand at him, already reaching for the phone. "And Teen," she called after him when he grabbed the handle to flee her office. He glanced at her uncertainly. "I don't need protecting from rumors. Your relationship with Rio doesn't change anything. Stay in your lane."

Billy lowered his gaze, looking guilty. "Yes, Mrs. Harkness."

Satisfied with the quick capitulation, Agatha waited until the door closed behind him before raising the phone to her ear.

"Mr. Bradford, good afternoon," she greeted emotionlessly, powering up her laptop again to rid it of the pale face staring back at her.

"Mrs. Harkness, apologies for the unscheduled call," Bradford said, his voice tense but polished - the tone of a man familiar with urgency but unused to handling it himself. "I'm afraid an issue has come up regarding the Harper acquisition."

Agatha drummed her fingers against the desk, watching her wallpaper come to life. She almost groaned at the onslaught of new notifications. "What sort of issue?"

"They've amended the indemnity terms - rather aggressively - and are demanding execution by tomorrow morning. Our internal counsel flagged it, but frankly..." He trailed off, an unspoken admission hanging in the air.

Frankly, they didn't trust their internal team to handle it without her.

Agatha leaned back in her chair. "You've sent me the revised documents?"

"Yes. Just now. I wouldn't ask if it weren't critical, but I need your eyes on it today. We can't afford to move forward without your sign-off."

Of course. After all, they didn't pay the company a ridiculous amount of money to take care of their own problems.

"Understood," Agatha said coolly. "I'll review the amendments and advise you on the appropriate course of action. Expect my call within the hour."

There was a sharp exhale of relief on the other end. "Thank you. I know it's an imposition-"

"It's my job to protect your interests, Mr. Bradford," she interrupted smoothly. "We'll handle it."

"Much appreciated, Mrs. Harkness," he said, recovering some of his composure.

Agatha ended the call, lowering the receiver with deliberate care.

Her hand hovered over the coffee mug for a moment before she turned to her laptop instead, pulling up the incoming email flagged URGENT in the subject line.

The amended contract was already waiting for her, along with a panicked note from Bradford's in-house team that reeked of desperation.

Her eyes skimmed over the first few lines, her frown deepening.

Harper's counsel hadn't simply amended the indemnity terms. They had gutted half the representations and warranties section as well, tucking it under a deliberately vague heading.

Agatha bit the inside of her cheek, glancing at the clock in the bottom right corner of the screen.

Nicky had Spanish after school - a compromise born out of negotiation and stubbornness, as most things with her son were these days. He'd been adamant about learning the language, charmed by Rio's bilingualism, and Agatha, unwilling to let that particular can of worms open, had pushed for official lessons instead.

Her son had spent the afternoon sulking after Agatha had explained that Rio was too busy to teach him, but got over it quickly when the woman had almost face-planted into the wall from exhaustion that evening.

The additional hour bought by the extracurricular should have given her just enough time to tackle the mess now blinking at her furiously from the laptop screen.

But it wasn't.

The Harper amendments were a carefully planted minefield, and rushing through them was a mistake Agatha simply couldn't afford. She needed at least four hours to get through the document, make the necessary adjustments, and talk them over with Bradford's team. And her client's urgency made her doubt she could start working on it now, take a break to collect Nicky, and finish the assignment from home.

Her hand hovered over her phone, her mind already flipping through options.

Wanda? No. Her brother was in town for barely forty-eight hours before returning to Europe, and Agatha had enough humanity left not to rip her away from the little time she had with him.

Mrs. Hart? No. From what Rio had told her - because, apparently, the woman had nothing better to do than chat with their annoyingly friendly neighbor - Sharon was visiting her sister and would be back by Wednesday.

She gritted her teeth, feeling the walls closing in.

The list of people she trusted with Nicky was laughably short. Shorter still, when factoring in who could drop everything on such short notice.

There was only one name left.

One name she had authorized to pick her son up from school a few weeks ago, vowing to never use the option.

And now, that name was her only option.

Agatha exhaled sharply through her nose, reaching for her phone with the resigned precision of someone pulling a knife out of their gut. If she wanted to fix the mess Bradford's team had dumped in her lap and not leave Nicky stranded outside the school gates, she would have to ask Rio for help.

She didn't like how natural the thought felt.

She liked even less how it didn't feel like an imposition but a reluctant sort of relief.

Her thumb hovered over Rio's contact for a beat before she pressed call, jaw tightening as she listened to the first two beeps.

"Hey," Rio said, her voice mixing with the distant hum of music and conversations. "Everything alright?"

Agatha swallowed back the immediate urge to snap at her to stop sounding so concerned.

"Are you done with classes?" she asked instead, the question a futile attempt at pretending she didn't have Rio's schedule memorized.

Rio paused, and Agatha could imagine the frown pulling at her eyebrows. "Yeah, I'm running some errands."

"Great. I need you to pick up Nicky," she said in the professional tone she had used minutes before with Bradford. "Something came up at work."

A part of her knew she should've asked, not ordered. Rio had no obligations to her or Nicky. She could've easily brushed the ridiculous request off and told Agatha she wasn't Nicky's babysitter.

But, of course, Rio merely hummed like the demand was the most natural thing in the world. "Sure. Is he done with Spanish at the usual time?"

"Yes," Agatha confirmed, staring blankly at the document open on her laptop as if it might somehow finish itself.

"Got it. I'll be there."

There was no Is it serious?

No Can't you just do it?

No guilt-tripping or theatrics, just simple, unquestioning acceptance.

The sort that made Agatha's throat feel uncomfortably tight.

She cleared it. "Thank you," she said, brisk but sincere.

Rio chuckled softly, and Agatha hated how much it curled around the edges of her self-control. "You don't have to sound like you're sending him off to war. It's just me."

Agatha bristled automatically, out of habit more than actual offense. "I know," she said dryly.

"I'll text you when I have him," Rio promised. "Don't worry, and focus on work. Te veo."

The line clicked dead a second later, leaving Agatha staring at her phone.

It should have been a simple transaction, but it lingered strangely, like the ghost of a touch she hadn't realized she missed.

She set the phone down carefully, flexing her fingers once before returning them to the laptop.

Work. Focus on work. She had bigger problems than the disorienting realization of how easy it felt to trust Rio with the most important person in her life.

Or worse, rely on her in moments of weakness.

Agatha had always seen her office as a battlefield where she was the only competent soldier thrown into a lost battle in hopes of turning it around. Her professional attire was her armor, her knowledge was her weapon, and her enemy was whatever problem the clients threw at her.

And right now, the enemy was winning.

The glowing red flags in the document screamed at her from the screen, creating a contractual landmine set up by Harper's counsel and mapped out by Bradford's team.

Her eyes burned. Her coffee was cold. Her mouth tasted like defeat and bureaucracy.

And then, her phone buzzed four consecutive times.

Rio Vidal [5:14 PM]

our precious cargo's picked up

he explained Spanish grammar to me in detail

I barely survived, had to buy him churros

we're heading home now

Agatha stared at the screen, rereading each message like she'd stumbled into someone else's life.

Then, one more came in:

Rio Vidal [5:16 PM]

want me to start dinner? or should we tackle the problem of tupperware reigning over our fridge?

Her fingers wrapped tightly around the phone as she scanned the texts.

Not your son.

Not I picked up Nicky.

Not even let me know when you're on your way.

Our precious cargo.

We're heading home.

Agatha's fingers hovered over the keyboard, unsure what to do with the warmth spreading across her chest. It shouldn't feel that effortless. She shouldn't feel that comfortable reading the messages and seeing those words that indicated a level of domesticity and understanding she had never known before.

She inhaled slowly, willing her brain to figure out an appropriate response.

Me [5:20 PM]

The leftovers are fine. Don't let him have more sugar.

Perfectly detached and commanding.

The response came a second later.

Rio Vidal [5:20 PM]

Ay, ay, captain

Agatha let out a soundless exhale, halfway between a scoff and something she'd never admit was a laugh. She tossed the phone onto her desk like it might explode if she held onto it any longer.

It was just a part of the performance. She had asked Rio to keep their conversations light over text to maintain the illusion in case her mother got hold of them.

It didn't mean anything.

The words like home and our didn't mean anything.

Agatha focused on work, ignoring how it hurt a little more than it should.

By the time she finally left the office, her spine was stiff from sitting for too long, and her eyes stung despite the custom-made glasses designed to protect her from blue light. The streets were already cloaked in the amber haze of early evening, and traffic crawled with the kind of resigned lethargy only a weekday could produce. She didn't bother with music in the car, her brain still too cluttered from the painfully long call with Bradford's team to accept any more stimuli.

When home came into view, Agatha didn't even have the strength to stress over what awaited inside.

The house - hers, technically, though the pronoun had partially lost its weight - stood calm against the dimming sky, filling her with the underrated sense of belonging. She rolled the car into the garage and stepped out, the weight of the day slipping off her shoulders as she walked into the hall.

Her ears instinctively perked up, listening for the soft music she'd learned to associate with Rio's presence in the kitchen, but the house was eerily silent. She set her bag down on the bench by the door, heels clicking against the floor as she moved further into the house.

The silence felt out of place. Agatha had grown used to Rio's background noise, to the hum of some old sitcom rerun whenever Nicky didn't reign over the TV or a playlist that made parkour seem easy. It had taken her weeks to notice, but now its absence felt loud. Rio didn't like silence. She filled it instinctively like someone with too much on their mind who needed static to drown out the noise.

"Nicky?" Agatha called softly, not expecting an answer but needing to say something.

No response.

She glanced at the kitchen as she passed, noting the running dishwasher and a half-full glass of juice next to a few worksheets displayed along the counter's edge, each filled with Nicky's messy handwriting.

Feeling like a detective on a case, she crossed over to the back of the house, cringing whenever her heels struck the floor too hard, the sound echoing in the quiet space. The garden lights had clicked on automatically with the dusk, casting long shadows against the glass doors. Still, Agatha heard the conversation outside before she saw the two silhouettes through the windows.

"-about peppers?" Nicky's curious voice reached her through the small crack left by whoever walked out last.

"Pimientos," Rio answered easily. "We could do those too, but we'd have to buy seedlings. It's a bit too late in the year to sow them ourselves."

"Pimientos," Nicky repeated carefully, tasting each letter on his tongue. "And how do you say seedlings?"

Rio laughed, the sound low and relaxed. "Plántulas, but I can't imagine a scenario where you'd use that."

Agatha stayed frozen for a moment, one hand resting on the cool metal of the door handle, the other braced against the frame.

She could see them now - Nicky crouched by a raised bed that Agatha was sure wasn't there when she had left the house in the morning, and Rio beside him, seated on the ground with her back resting against the polished wood. Her face shone with a thin layer of sweat in the dimming light, her sleeves pushed up, and her hands dirty. There were gardening tools scattered around them and a few empty bags of soil nearby, like they'd been out there longer than they planned to be.

It was... domestic. Intimate in a way that didn't reach for attention.

Nicky hummed, eyeing the raised bed with the exaggerated seriousness of an engineer about to file a patent. "Why do we need this?" he asked, pointing to the wooden structure. "We could just dig holes in the ground. It'd be faster."

"It would be," Rio agreed, her voice playful. She used the back of her wrist to sweep a strand of hair from her brow. "But I thought your mom would appreciate the visual aspect. It looks more organized, and I have big plans for your garden. Planting things at random would just turn it into a jungle, which I am not to do."

"You mean our garden," Nicky corrected with a toothy grin, already standing and brushing the dirt off his jeans.

Rio smiled, warm and patient, her gaze drifting toward the darkening sky. "We'll call it yours until your mom approves. Then it can be ours."

Something about the phrasing lodges itself in Agatha's throat. Ours. Like it was a place built for three.

"C'mon," Rio pushed up to her feet with a soft groan, eyes sweeping over the controlled mess around them. "Let's get this cleaned up before it gets dark."

Nicky scrambled to gather the scattered tools, piling them in his arms with Rio's help before skipping over to the edge of the property where a small shed was situated. The small, careless intimacy of it, the quiet agreement between them, made Agatha's chest ache in a way she didn't have the vocabulary for.

She finally opened the door, the soft creak pulling Rio's attention away from the half-empty bag of soil she busied herself with.

"Hey," she said, voice low and sure. There was no surprise in her tone, just the quiet certainty of someone who had expected her to come. Maybe even someone who had waited for it. "Welcome back."

Agatha stepped onto the patio, her heels clicking softly against the stone. "You've been busy," she noticed, eyes flickering between Rio's disheveled appearance and the newly built raised bed. It was cleanly constructed, the soil creating a smooth, dark surface resembling a peaceful sea.

"A little," Rio replied, brushing her palms on her jeans. There was something unreadable in her expression, open but waiting. "The weather was too perfect to waste, and Nicky was very enthusiastic about helping."

Agatha nodded, her eyes skimming over Rio's rolled-up sleeves and the dirt smudges across her cheekbone like a careless brushstroke. Her forearms were lean and dusted with soil. The kind of raw, tactile beauty that Agatha had not expected to find in her garden.

Rio in a smoky eye and a flattering dress was attractive. Striking, even.

But Rio like this - in flannel and worn-out jeans, her hair half-tied, gloves sticking out of her back pocket - was hot.

Like, criminally, unfairly, and frustratingly hot.

"I'm glad you like it," Rio said, her voice pulling Agatha back to the surface. She looked up, startled. "The raised bed?" Rio added, a flicker of amusement warming her eyes.

Agatha cleared her throat, desperate to push past the heat crawling up her neck. "You didn't have to rush," she said, keeping her tone even. "It's not like I'm going to change my mind about the garden."

Rio grinned, flashing the small gap between her teeth, and Agatha almost groaned in frustration.

So much for compartmentalizing the attraction; she should look into the nearest yoga instructors.

"I got excited," Rio shrugged, bending to grab the bag of soil.

Agatha's breath caught again. The flannel shifted with the movement, uncovering a thin strip of skin on Rio's lower back, and Agatha's higher-than-average IQ plummeted to sixty.

By the time she pulled herself together, Rio was already lifting the bag and walking it toward the garden's edge. Her steps remained light, her arm barely flexing under the weight, but it was enough for Agatha's mouth to run dry.

She suspected no amount of yoga could pull her mind out of the gutter.

"You know," Rio called back over her shoulder, tone light but coaxing, "you could join us for the next one."

Agatha folded her arms, grateful for something to do with them. "Rolling around in dirt and compost? Hard pass."

"Rolling around is encouraged but not required," Rio replied, setting the bag down with a grunt and turning around to look at her with a smirk. "Besides, you could use the vitamin D. You're starting to look like printer paper."

"Some of us spend our days chained to desks, busy preventing billionaires from becoming millionaires."

"Ah, yes," Rio mused, stepping back toward the porch. "A noble cause. Don't worry, though - the paleness is working for you. It's giving powerful vampire energy."

Before Agatha could decide whether the words were a compliment or an insult, the sound of rapid footsteps cut through the silence.

"Mama!"

Nicky came barreling toward them, hands and arms streaked in dirt, eyes wide with excitement. He looked like he'd been rolling, required or not.

Before Agatha could react, his grubby fingers wrapped around her wrist and tugged. "Did you see what we did?!"

"Nicky!" she groaned, twisting her arms as delicately as possible, trying to avoid collateral damage to no avail. There was already a dark smudge staining the crisp white cuff of her button-up. "This is dry-clean only."

Nicky didn't even blink, too busy vibrating with pride as he dragged her over to the raised bed, nearly hopping in place. "Do you like it? We built it all by ourselves!"

Agatha stared at the long, tidy frame, the soil leveled neatly across its surface, the little white stakes already marking out rows for planting. It was a rectangle of dirt, yes, but it carried intent. Care, even.

"I see that," she said, adjusting her sleeve. "Very Bob the Builder of you."

"Yes, we can!" Nicky giggled, beaming. "Rio said this one's for tomatoes and basil because they're friends-"

"Companion plants," Rio supplied gently, standing on Agatha's right.

"-but when we build more, we can have cucumbers and peppers! For peppers, we'll need..." he paused, face scrunched up in concentration. "Plántulas!" he exclaimed, turning to Rio with a proud grin. "See? I used it!"

"Good job," Rio praised him with a warm smile before glancing at Agatha with a teasing glint in her eye. "That's seedlings. For those who don't know."

Agatha huffed, but it came out more as a chuckle. "Thank you, professor. I can't believe he's four lessons in, and you two are already ganging up on me."

"I can teach you, Mama," Nicky offered sincerely. "Plants are plantas, which is easy, and basil is alba- al-"

"La albahaca," Rio interjected again, shaking her head to get a loose strand of hair out of her face. She groaned when it fell into her eye instead.

Without realizing what she was doing, Agatha reached over to tuck it behind her ear, stopping dead in her tracks when her fingers brushed against Rio's sweaty temple.

Rio blinked.

Agatha froze.

The strand of hair stayed obediently in place behind Rio's ear, but neither of them moved for a heartbeat too long.

Nicky, blissfully unaware of the tension that had just cracked open between the adults, had already turned back to the raised bed, poking at the dirt with his fingers and mumbling something about needing a sign that said "Tomato Town."

Agatha's hand hovered awkwardly in the space between them for a second more before she pulled it back - carefully, almost reluctantly.

"Thanks," Rio muttered, her smile crooked and playful. Her eyes locked onto Agatha's like she was reading a manual only she could understand. "It was driving me nuts."

Agatha cleared her throat and stepped back, the space between them feeling dangerously small. "What's the point of having gloves if you still end up with dirt under your nails?"

Rio shrugged, unfazed, wiggling her mud-caked fingers with a grin. "I had the gloves on. Got the cheapest ones the store had, though. Who knew quality costs money?"

Agatha's frown deepened as she glanced from Rio's hands to the newly constructed raised bed and the empty soil bags strewn around. "Wait, don't tell me you paid for all of this?"

Before Rio could answer, Nicky perked up again, apparently deciding that the sign could wait. "We went to Home Depot! And Rio got me a new pot for Luci! It has a Creeper on it!" he bounced on the balls of his feet, eyes gleaming with delight.

"They had a collab with Minecraft," Rio added with another shrug as if the logic behind it was a mystery to her.

"I'll show you!" Nicky yelled, already bolting toward the house in a blur of dirt-smudged joy.

Agatha barely registered the horror of what state he'd leave the floors - and possibly the walls - in. Her focus was entirely on Rio, who was still standing there with soil on her jeans and a quiet, unapologetic calm in her eyes.

"The errands you were running when I called," she said slowly, the pieces clicking into place. "You were buying things for the garden?"

"Browsing," Rio replied with an infuriating smirk. "I left the store to pick up Nicky and returned with him."

Agatha looked at the construction again, wondering how much money Rio had poured into it. "Why didn't you tell me? I could've-"

"I know," Rio interrupted, her voice even. "You'd insist on Venmo-ing me down to the last cent. It would've turned into a thing."

"It is a thing," Agatha countered without any bite, her voice more resigned than combatant. "You're spending money and time on something that isn't..." her voice faltered, the word real refusing to leave her throat. "That you won't get to see in a year."

The silence between them stretched.

Rio shifted beside her, the rustle of denim and flannel urging Agatha to look at her. The porch lights barely reached them, but she could still see the change in Rio's expression: the easy amusement was gone, turned into something quieter.

"Then I'll have to enjoy it while I can," she said softly, eyes moving from the raised bed to Agatha with unhurried precision.

The solemn look in them was enough for Agatha's breath to hitch. "Why put in the effort if it's temporary?" she asked quietly.

Rio smiled, warm and genuine, her voice softening even further. "It doesn't feel temporary."

The words slipped under Agatha's skin with an intimacy she hadn't been prepared for. They weren't talking about the garden anymore - about wooden structures, soil, and money - and she didn't know what to do with that. She didn't know what to make of the gravity in Rio's tone, the gentleness of her eyes.

It all felt like too much and not enough at the same time, like they'd tiptoed past too many boundaries without ever acknowledging the line. Like the things they weren't saying were pressing against them, still lingering in the cool air and the dark garden soil, waiting for permission to be spoken aloud.

She swallowed thickly, the silence wrapping tighter around them, its weight almost suffocating.

Rio's lips parted, and Agatha waited for a clever remark, a joke, anything to break the tension. But all that came out was a soft exhale that sounded almost like surrender.

It drew Agatha in - a small, barely noticeable step forward as she held Rio's gaze, searching her eyes for something, anything, that would help her make sense of the pull.

Then, a sharp crash erupted from inside, followed by Nicky's gleeful shout: "I got it!"

Agatha flinched, snapping away from the tantalizing warmth of Rio's eyes to look at the house. Through the glass, Nicky was trying to wrestle the door open with his elbow while holding the potted plant in both hands.

"I-" she cleared her throat, the word coming out quieter than intended. "I'll look at it inside!"

Nicky gave her a thumbs-up and a grin before disappearing behind the blinds.

Rio chuckled, the sound more strained than usual, and stepped back to gather the empty bags. "I think you have about a minute before he breaks through the window."

Her voice was steady, teasing, even, but something about it felt different. Like she was trying to guide them away from the edge of something too unguarded. The kind of truth that shifted the ground if you looked at it too long.

Agatha stared for a beat, watching Rio gather the empty bags into her arms with more purpose than necessary.

"I'll pay for the next one," she finally said, the words louder than she intended in the hush between them. They dropped into the space like a pin in a still room. "And for whatever else you need."

As she expected, Rio straightened her back, her eyes sharp even in the soft glow of the patio lights. Before she could argue, Agatha pressed on.

"It's the least I can do," she added, almost coaxing. "I doubt I'll be much help around here."

Rio didn't answer immediately. Her gaze searched Agatha's, something unspoken ticking behind her eyes like a clock trying to decide what hour they'd landed in.

Then, her mouth curved into a lazy, familiar grin. "So, you're the fundraiser, I'm the labor, and Nicky's the dreamer."

Agatha blinked, caught off guard by the ease of it. It sounded like a unit, permanence wrapped in a joke.

"You're making it sound like we're something," she said slowly, the words out before she could decide if she wanted them to be.

"A team," Rio replied with a shrug, but her voice carried something steadier beneath the playfulness.

The words didn't feel like enough. Not with the image still fresh in her memory: Rio with her sleeves rolled up and dirt on her cheek, smiling like it meant something. Nicky kneeling in the soil like he'd found treasure. The way she had searched through the house for them both, not just her son.

Team was too small. Too clinical.

Because this didn't feel like delegation or logistics. It felt like trust, like the beginning of something that could change them if they let it.

Agatha didn't know much about family. Not in the way people talked about it when they said the word like a heartbeat. Her picture of it came from sitcoms and grocery store aisles in December - something framed and glossy and unreachable.

But standing there, watching Rio unguarded and disheveled, hearing Nicky's impatient huffs through the glass, she suspected this might be it.

Chapter End Notes

Hi, hope you like the chapter! Thank you for all the comments (shout out to all the people who pointed out the feminism part in the last chapter, I was giggling while writing it, I love Agatha's denial) and the kudos, and see you next week!

Chapter 16: The weight of responsibility

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Agatha groaned when she heard the door to her office open abruptly, barely sparing Billy a glance as she buttoned up her blazer.

"Whatever it is can wait until tomorrow," she said before he could get a word in, eyes flicking to her watch.

She was supposed to leave over two hours ago, with plenty of time to get groceries and pick up Nicky from school. Now, she had barely twenty minutes before Wanda was set to drop him off at her house after picking him up with the twins.

"Mrs. Harkness-"

Agatha grabbed her purse, ready to make a break for the door without acknowledging Billy's presence any further, when she noticed the phone pressed tightly to his ear.

"I'm off. Take the message, which I pay you to do, and I'll get back to them tomorrow," she muttered, keeping her voice low so the microphone wouldn't pick it up. As she moved to step past him, Billy blocked her path, his eyes flashing with something close to panic as if he couldn't believe his own actions.

A threatening growl formed at the back of Agatha's throat. "Teen, I swear to-"

"It's Rio!" he blurted out, yanking the receiver from his ear and pressing it into Agatha's hand.

Her gaze caught on the caller ID: Alice. Agatha frowned. "No, it's not. I don't have time for this."

She tried to shove the phone back at him, but Billy shook his head, looking close to a heart attack.

"It's about Rio," he insisted, voice tight. "She's hurt."

Agatha's stomach dropped.

The irritation that had been simmering beneath her skin vanished instantly, replaced with something colder, sharper - something dangerously close to panic.

She stared at Billy, her grip tightening around the phone. "What do you mean, hurt?"

Billy swallowed, shifting on his feet. "I- I don't know exactly. Alice called, told me Rio's hurt, and asked to get you on the-"

Agatha didn't wait for the rest. She pressed the phone to her ear, her voice coming out steadier than she felt.

"This is Agatha Harkness. What happened?"

The woman on the other end exhaled in relief. "Oh, thank God. Some guy threw a chair at Rio, and one of the legs caught her head. I wouldn't call you, but I have to get this shitshow under control, and I'm her emergency-"

Agatha's pulse roared in her ears. "Where is she?"

"They took her to Massachusetts General about five minutes ago."

"On my way."

She didn't wait for a response.

Billy barely had time to stumble backward before she stormed past him, shoving the phone in his direction. It nearly clattered to the floor.

The sharp click of her heels barely registered, drowned out by the furious pounding in her temples. She barely noticed the soft chime of the elevator, only that it wasn't fast enough. Shoving past the half-open doors, she hammered the close button with trembling fingers until they finally slid shut.

Her stomach twisted as the elevator crawled downward, her mind racing with every worst-case scenario.

She'd hung up too fast. Had Rio been conscious when they took her? Was she in surgery? Had she bled out on that grimy bar floor?

The drive was a blur of sluggish traffic, red lights that lingered too long, and pedestrians moving as if time wasn't of the essence. She remembered bits and pieces: blaring her horn when a driver hesitated at a green, her fingers locked so tightly around the steering wheel she half expected it to snap.

But the details slipped through her grasp, and before she knew it, she was bursting through the hospital doors, breath unsteady, hands shaking.

"I'm looking for Rio Vidal," she said quickly, the sentence blurring into a single string instead of a sequence of separate words.

The nurse behind the counter - an older woman with glasses too big for her face and a perpetual frown that made her look like she was there against her will - gave her a once-over before her unconcerned eyes slid back to the computer screen.

"Relationship?" she asked, her voice disinterested.

"I'm her wife."

The words left Agatha's mouth without hesitation, sharper than intended, but she didn't care.

At least they got the nurse's attention. The woman glanced up again, scanning her with new scrutiny as if trying to decide whether she was lying. Agatha's fingers drummed an unsteady rhythm against the counter, aching to do something.

"Vidal, Rio," the nurse muttered, typing the name into the system at an agonizingly slow pace.

Agatha's fingers tightened around the counter's edge to fend off the urge to rip the keyboard from under the woman's hands and check the information herself.

Instead, she clenched her jaw. "Yes. Where is she?"

The nurse nodded toward a set of double doors, not sparing her another glance. "Room 165. Down the hall, to the right."

Agatha was already moving before the woman had finished speaking.

The sterile floors echoed her steps, carrying them across the halls illuminated by the fluorescent lights that made everything feel too bright. The knot in her stomach twisted with every passed room, her eyes sliding across the numbers as the adrenaline from the drive morphed into something heavier - something that settled in her chest like lead.

And then, finally, she saw her.

Rio sat upright in the hospital bed, propped against a pillow, speaking in hushed tones with the nurse leaning over her, their expressions tight. Agatha's eyes locked onto the stark white bandage wrapped around Rio's forehead, her dark curls piled into a messy heap, some held back by the dressing, others spilling loose, framing her face.

Dazed, bruised, but alive.

Agatha exhaled, only then realizing she'd been holding her breath.

Rio's head turned at the sound, surprise flickering across her face as their eyes met. "Agatha?"

Something inside Agatha loosened at the sound of her name on Rio's lips, but it wasn't enough to cool the fire still coursing through her veins. Arms crossed, jaw tight, she stormed forward until she was at the foot of the bed.

"A chair?" she snapped. "You had a fucking chair thrown at you?"

Rio blinked. Then, to Agatha's absolute frustration, she grinned.

"Technically, I dodged it. Mostly."

Agatha inhaled sharply, fingers digging into her arms to stop herself from strangling the infuriating woman.

The nurse cleared her throat, a hint of a smile pulling at the corners of her lips. "I'll give you two a minute," she said, glancing at Rio. "Then, we'll finish our conversation."

Something flickered across Rio's face - something tight and unspoken - but Agatha barely registered it.

"It's not funny," she hissed the moment they were alone. "You could've gotten killed."

"By a chair?" Rio scoffed, arching a brow. "You underestimate me. I'm practically immortal,"

She chuckled, only to wince immediately, the movement sending a ripple of pain through her face.

Agatha didn't even flinch.

Rio's amusement faded, softening into something quieter. "Hey," she murmured, beckoning Agatha closer with a gentle nod. Like a moth to the flame, Agatha circled the bed to stand with her knees almost pressing into the frame. Rio reached for her wrist, squeezing gently. "I'm okay."

Her eyes were warm, oozing tenderness. It only made Agatha's chest ache more.

She wasn't the one lying in the hospital bed. If anybody deserved concern, it was Rio, not her.

"What's the diagnosis?" she asked after a beat, sinking into the uncomfortable-looking chair the nurse had been using, her hand remaining in Rio's grasp.

Rio pushed her tongue into her cheek. "Six stitches and a very persistent headache," she smirked. "The good news is my skull is stronger than a chair, so it didn't crack."

Agatha winced at the mental image, eyeing her warily. "No concussion?"

Before Rio could answer, the door swung open, and a middle-aged man in a crisp white coat strode in, tapping his finger against the tablet in his hand.

"I hear you still haven't changed your mind about the CT scan, Mrs. Vidal," he said, eyes fixed on the screen. "I understand this isn't ideal, but with an injury like yours, I must stress - it's vital."

Agatha's gaze snapped to Rio, eyes narrowing.

"You refused a CT scan?" her voice was sharp, her fingers tightening around Rio's wrist before she even realized they were still holding onto each other.

Rio exhaled through her nose, her mouth pressing into a firm line. "It's not necessary," she muttered. "I feel fine, just a little sore. Nothing a good nap can't fix."

The doctor sighed, clearly used to difficult patients. "That's the problem. Head injuries can be deceptive. You could feel fine and develop severe complications later. The scan is standard procedure for a reason, especially with a concussion."

"Oh, so you are concussed," Agatha shot Rio a look so sharp it could've sliced through steel. "You're getting the damn scan."

Rio scoffed. "And who's going to pay for it?"

Silence settled over the room.

Ah. So that was it.

Agatha schooled her features into something unreadable, aware she was entering dangerous territory. The last thing she needed was to repeat the scene from her office after Rio had learned about the car. "If money is the issue-"

"It is," Rio cut in, jaw tightening. "It's a $2000 test, and it'll only prove something we already know. That I'm fine."

Agatha's patience, already running dangerously thin, snapped. "You don't know that," she hissed, standing up from the chair and ripping her hand out of Rio's hold. "You got hit on the head hard enough to get a concussion, and now you're sitting here debating whether your brain - your life - is worth two grand."

Rio pursed her lips, eyes flashing with a rebuttal, but Agatha wasn't finished.

"You're getting the scan," she said, her tone indicating the end of the discussion. "And I don't care if it costs two thousand or twenty thousand. I'll handle it."

Rio frowned. "You can't make me."

"I will personally knock you out to make you unfit to decide," Agatha growled, crossing her arms and eyeing the woman. "You're risking dying in your sleep from a brain bleed for pride."

Rio looked away, her fingers flexing against the hospital blanket.

After a long pause, she muttered, "It's not pride. I already owe you for the car. I don't want to owe you more."

The words shouldn't have stung, but they did.

Agatha forced herself to breathe through it, running a hand over her face. "You don't owe me anything," she said, her voice softer. "We're not keeping score here. Otherwise, I'd owe you for every meal you cook for us. I'd have to pay you for every second you spend with Nicky when I'm not home, for the raised bed in the garden, and every little thing you've fixed around the house,"

Rio opened her mouth, but Agatha shook her head, cutting her off before she could argue.

"I don't want a tally," she continued. "I just want to know you're okay, and $2000 is a small price to pay for that."

Rio's shoulders slumped, her teeth sinking into her lower lip. It made her look smaller, almost vulnerable.

Finally, she exhaled. "Fine," she muttered, sounding defeated. "But if the scan comes back clear, I'm cooking the blandest, most repulsive meals for a week as payback."

Agatha smirked, some of the tension in her chest easing. "I'll be fine. I thrive on coffee and spite alone."

Rio huffed a small laugh, leaning further into the pillow. "Unbelievable."

The doctor, who had wisely remained silent through the exchange, cleared his throat. "I'll put in the order," he said, barely hiding the amusement in his voice as he stepped toward the door. "A nurse will come to take you down in a minute."

As soon as the door shut behind him, Rio closed her eyes, sighing. "Just so you know, you wouldn't win that easily without the headache."

"Sure," Agatha smirked, easing back into the chair, her gaze fixed on Rio's face.

She didn't realize she was still watching her until Rio peeked an eye open again, brow lifting.

"What?"

Agatha shook her head, feigning indifference. "Just making sure you don't drop dead before your scan."

Rio chuckled softly. "If I do, you have my permission to say 'I told you so' at my funeral," she shifted on the bed, fingers restless against the hospital blanket as her expression grew more sober. "You don't have to stay here with me."

The words landed like a slap, and Agatha almost flinched.

Did Rio not want her there?

Alice may have called her and asked her to come, but Rio didn't know that. Had she overstepped? Was this too personal? Too much?

It dawned on her that she had not thought about their deal once since Billy burst into her office.

Her first thought should have been about keeping appearances, about rushing to Rio's side because it was expected. Her second thought should have been the deal itself - how an injury could complicate things, how a more serious outcome might give a premature out.

But none of it had crossed her mind.

All she could think about was the overwhelming, breath-stealing terror of losing Rio.

And that was ridiculous. Irrational.

Because Rio wasn't hers to lose.

The thought settled in Agatha's chest like a lead weight, heavier than she wanted to admit. She should've brushed it off, made a sarcastic remark, and put space between them. That was how this was supposed to work, how every good business deal operated.

But when she looked at Rio now, pale-faced with slumped shoulders and the white bandage obscuring her forehead, all she could feel was that same sharp, gut-churning panic from the moment Billy had said: "She's hurt."

She forced a smirk, its pull on her lips almost uncomfortable. "Am I such unpleasant company?"

"It's the middle of the week," Rio noticed. "You should be with Nicky, not wasting time at a hospital."

Agatha blanched. "Shit. Shit."

Her hand flew to her phone, plucking it out of her back pocket under Rio's attentive gaze. "Everything alright?"

"Wanda was supposed to drop him off at the house half an hour ago," Agatha quickly dialed her best friend's number, pressing the phone to her ear.

How could she forget? What kind of a mother forgot about her child?

Wanda answered after a beat, her voice riddled with worry. "How is she?"

Agatha frowned. "What?"

"Rio. How is she? Is she okay?"

"How did you-"

"Billy called me."

God, Agatha should give that kid a raise.

"She's..." Agatha hesitated, studying Rio's battered state, "...going to live. We're waiting for a CT scan."

Wanda exhaled with relief. "That's good."

Agatha pinched the bridge of her nose, inhaling sharply. "Yeah. Good."

Her voice felt foreign to her own ears, clipped like she was holding something back. She hated that Wanda could probably hear it.

"Listen," she continued, shaking off the feeling. "I lost track of time. I can get-"

"I'll watch Nicky until Rio's discharged," Wanda interrupted immediately. "He's fine, Ags. You had other things to worry about."

That should've been reassuring. Instead, it only made Agatha's stomach twist. She shouldn't have forgotten. No matter how chaotic the evening had been, how much Rio being at the hospital had shattered her focus, forgetting Nicky wasn't an option.

"I'll be home soon," she said, softer. "Tell Nicky I love him."

Wanda hummed knowingly. "I already did. And listen, call Billy when you get a second, or have Rio contact him if she's up to it. The kid's been worried sick when he called me."

Agatha swallowed past the lump in her throat. "Okay."

"I'll see you later," Wanda ended the call, and Agatha closed her eyes, the guilt sitting uncomfortably against her ribs.

When she opened them again, Rio was watching her. Not with judgment or amusement, but something quieter, something she couldn't quite name.

"Go home," Rio murmured, her eyes warm even in the artificial light. "You shouldn't put me above Nicky."

"I'm not," Agatha said immediately. She may have forgotten about her son for a moment, but he was still the most important person in her life. "He's safe at home. You, on the other hand, could be bleeding internally as we speak."

Rio huffed out a laugh, but her expression softened further. "I'll be fine."

The words felt like a dismissal. Not unkind, not harsh, but a silent permission - to leave, go home, and forget about the entire thing.

Agatha should take it. She should get up, tell Rio to call her when she is discharged, and walk out of the room without a second thought. That was the kind of person she was. She didn't waste time on feelings, especially ones that weren't real.

Except nothing about this felt fake.

She thought back to the moment Billy had told her the news. How her stomach had plummeted so fast that she thought she might be sick. How the world narrowed down to a single need: get to Rio.

Not for the arrangement. Not for appearances. Just for her.

It unsettled Agatha.

This wasn't what she had signed up for. The performance was supposed to stay just that - a well-defined act lacking unnecessary complications. At best, she had expected some level of companionship. But this wasn't companionship. This wasn't casual.

This was something else entirely.

And it terrified her.

She shook her head, crossing her arms. "We'll see what the scan shows."

Rio studied her for a moment, brows crinkled, and lips pursed. Then, she sighed. "Alright. If you wanna stay, stay. But feel free to change your mind."

"I won't."

Rio only hummed, her eyes drifting closed again, and Agatha couldn't help but stare. She looked at the way the woman's curls had piled over the bandage, at the soft rise and fall of her chest. This isn't yours, she reminded herself. She isn't yours.

A traitorous part of her felt hurt by the thought.

Getting Rio into a wheelchair took a Herculean effort, complete with threats, sharp glares, and long-suffering sighs. Rio grumbled the entire time, pouting like a child as she protested. Her legs were fine. She didn't need pity. The hassle was entirely unnecessary.

By the time the nurse finally rolled her away, Agatha had to resist the very real urge to turn the mild concussion into a severe one.

With Rio gone, she busied herself with the charges, her jaw twitching as she scanned the bill.

It wasn't about the money - she couldn't care less about dropping a few grand - but it made something else glaringly obvious.

Rio's insurance was awful; it had barely covered the preliminary exam, let alone the ambulance ride, the stitches, or the scan she'd been so adamant about avoiding.

Agatha swiped her card with a sharp, fluid motion, making a mental note to talk to Rio about getting her on better insurance. Whether she liked it or not.

After the payment was finalized and the nurse returned to ignoring the world around her, Agatha sank into one of the uncomfortable waiting room chairs and took out her phone.

Rio, apparently, had gotten her nurse to contact Billy and discourage him from coming to the hospital, insisting that it was unnecessary. Billy, of course, had mentioned that Agatha was already on her way, but Rio's memory was spotty, making it difficult to piece together what had happened around the time of the attack.

So, after an excruciatingly long conversation with Billy, full of hesitant silences and worried questions, Agatha finally got her hands on Alice's number.

She dialed as she watched the corridor for any sign of Rio.

"Hello?"

"Hello, Alice. This is Agatha," she paused before adding, "Harkness."

"Right, yeah. Billy said you might call. How's Rio?"

In the background, Agatha could hear the steady murmur of conversations, the clinking of glasses, and the faint hum of music.

The bar was still open.

"Being forced into a CT scanner."

Alice sighed, the sound barely audible because of the noise. "Yeah, I wanted to warn you before you hung up. Rio doesn't take hospitals well - bad memories. I'm sure she'd have refused to go there if she could."

Agatha frowned, something tightening in her chest.

"If she could?"

Alice hesitated. "...She was out when they took her."

A cold weight settled in Agatha's stomach.

She barely processed the next breath she took, nausea curling in the back of her throat. Unconscious. Bleeding.

Her grip on the phone tightened. "What happened, exactly? Rio doesn't remember much."

"Give me a sec."

There was some shuffling, then the background noise dulled - still there, but distant.

Alice's voice was quieter when she spoke again. "The guy was a college kid. Barely old enough to drink, tipsy, but nothing we hadn't seen before. He didn't seem like trouble, so Rio served him. After that, he was just... around, letting his friends buy the next rounds. Then, when he came back to the bar for shots..." she paused, searching for the right words. "He was plastered. Started hitting on Rio, reaching over the counter, grabbing at her."

Agatha inhaled sharply, bracing for what she knew was coming.

"So she cut him off," Alice continued. "Told him to leave."

Silence stretched between them for a beat.

"Nobody had time to react when he grabbed the chair," Alice's voice wavered for the first time, anger leaking through her otherwise steady tone. "Honestly? It's a miracle Rio moved enough that only one leg caught her."

Agatha's fingers clenched around the phone.

"He tried to run after he saw Rio wasn't moving, but one of the regulars tackled him," Alice added, a sharp edge to her words. "Even gave him a nice shiner in the struggle."

Agatha decided to personally thank that regular. Possibly offer legal services if that drunken imbecile had the nerve to sue. Oh, she would tear him apart in court.

"The cops and EMTs showed up fast, but honestly?" Alice exhaled shakily. "I barely noticed. Rio looked dead. Half her face was covered in blood. The other half was white as a sheet."

Agatha closed her eyes. Her knuckles ached from the death grip on her phone.

"I tried to stop the bleeding, but it wouldn't let up," Alice admitted. "I know head wounds bleed worse than they are, but... Jesus. It was a bloodbath."

Agatha forced herself to breathe evenly, to shove down the burning anger clawing at her ribs. It wouldn't help. Not now.

Rio was okay. She had to focus on that.

But the image Alice had painted wouldn't leave her. Rio lying there, motionless as blood pooled beneath her.

Dead.

Alice had said she looked dead, but for a moment - for who knew how long - everyone in that bar must have thought she was.

Agatha gritted her teeth, her free hand pressing against her temple. "Is that idiot in custody?"

"Yeah," Alice said, her voice dark. "Drunk and disorderly, assault... not sure what'll stick, but at the very least, he's spending the night in a cell."

Not enough.

Agatha wanted more than an uncomfortable night in a holding cell. She wanted him to pay.

"She should press charges," she said flatly.

"I know," Alice agreed. "But it's Rio."

And Rio didn't ask for help. She didn't take things to court or spend money she didn't have on lawyers. Rio handled things her own way, usually by pretending they weren't a problem at all.

"I'll talk to her," Agatha decided, earning a humorless chuckle.

"Good luck with that."

Before Agatha could respond, a door down the hall swung open. A nurse stepped out, pushing Rio - still pale, still visibly annoyed - back toward the waiting area.

"I have to go," Agatha said. "Thanks for telling me."

"Take care of her," Alice murmured as if afraid Rio would somehow hear her. "She'll pretend she doesn't need it, but she does."

"I know."

Agatha ended the call and stood, meeting Rio's gaze as the nurse wheeled her forward.

"You survived," Agatha said dryly, folding her arms. "What's the verdict?"

"The doctor will see you soon to give you the diagnosis," the nurse responded, nodding toward the examination room Rio had previously occupied. "You can wait in there if you'd like."

Rio spoke before Agatha could answer. "Great. I hate waiting rooms."

There was some heaviness behind the words - an unintentional vulnerability - but one look at Rio's exhausted face stopped Agatha from prying. It wasn't the place.

"Do you want me to wheel her in or-"

"I can walk," Rio interrupted the nurse, already trying to stand.

Agatha pressed a firm hand to her shoulder, almost sighing at the solid warmth under her palm.

Alive.

"I'll take her," she muttered without moving to actually grab the wheelchair's handles, the warmth too soothing to let it go. "Thank you."

The nurse smiled, her eyes flicking between them in silent understanding. "Call me if you need anything."

Reluctantly, Agatha removed her hand from Rio's shoulder, stepping behind the wheelchair and gently pushing it toward the room.

It made Rio pout even more. "I can walk," she grumbled, crossing her arms. "It's not like you'll carry me to and from your car when I'm released."

"If you're released," Agatha said sternly, stopping the chair beside the bed. Before she could help Rio out, the woman hoisted herself up, wincing at the sudden movement but somehow managing to sit on the bed's edge.

Agatha suppressed the urge to roll her eyes at the stubbornness, the quiet defiance visible in the tight press of Rio's lips.

"I don't care what the doctor says," Rio huffed, shuffling back to lean against the pillow. "I'm not staying here for the night."

It could easily be because of the shitty insurance - which would certainly not cover the cost of an overnight visit - but Agatha doubted it was the main reason behind the refusal.

Rio doesn't take hospitals well - bad memories.

Agatha wished she had asked Alice to elaborate or give her advice on how to deal with Rio in case the prolonged stay turned out to be necessary.

Without the information, she could only nod.

"Okay," she said quietly. "Unless it's absolutely essential, we won't stay," Rio frowned, opening her mouth to argue. "Which I'm sure it won't be. After all, you're perfectly fine, right?"

Rio studied her suspiciously before a victorious smirk stretched her lips. "Exactly."

Maybe Rio wasn't that fine if she couldn't sense the sarcasm in her voice.

"So, who were you talking to? In the hall?"

Agatha sat back in the uncomfortable chair, crossing her legs. "I called Alice to tell me about the attack."

Rio rolled her eyes. "Attack is a bit far-fetched."

Agatha arched a brow. "You were knocked unconscious. There was blood everywhere," her voice was sharp, not with anger but frustration.

Because, of course, Rio was casual even about almost dying.

"I've had worse."

That shouldn't have bothered Agatha as much as it did.

She tapped her nails against her thigh, eyes fixed on Rio's. "Alice said you looked dead."

Rio flinched. It was minuscule, a slight tremble of muscles, but Agatha caught it.

For a moment, neither of them spoke.

Then, Rio sighed and dragged a hand down her face, staying mindful of the bandage. "It doesn't matter. I'm fine. We can leave it behind us."

Agatha let out a hollow, humorless chuckle. "It doesn't matter? Rio, you were bleeding out behind the bar because some moron threw a chair at you," she leaned forward, eyes razor-sharp as she leveled Rio with a glare. "You're pressing charges."

It wasn't a question. It wasn't even a statement.

It was a clipped, straightforward order.

And still, Rio had the audacity to shake her head. "No."

"Yes," Agatha's voice was firm, unyielding. "I don't care how much of a hassle it is. I don't care how much it costs. That guy is not walking away from this with a hangover and a slap on the wrist."

Rio's jaw tensed, her injured brain clearly working on a retort.

Agatha seized the opportunity.

"If you don't want to do it for yourself," she said slowly, deliberately. "Do it for the next woman he tries this with."

That landed. Agatha could see it in the subtle twitch of Rio's brows and the conflict flashing in her eyes.

After a long moment, Rio sighed. "Fine."
