It wasn't the most enthusiastic agreement, but Agatha would take it. She'd been prepared for a fight - a long, exhausting debate, maybe even a PowerPoint presentation.

"Great. I have a friend in criminal law, I'll call her tomorrow."

"You don't have t-"

"Oh, I'm sorry, do you have a lawyer friend?"

Rio hesitated.

"Exactly, Agatha smirked. "Now, since we're on a roll here-"

"You're literally bullying an injured woman into agreeing to whatever you want."

"I thought you were fine?"

Rio pursed her lips, realizing she'd walked straight into a trap.

Agatha leaned in slightly, pressing the advantage. "Anyway. I'm putting you on my insurance."

"Agatha-"

"No. No arguments," Agatha raised her hand, cutting off the protest before it could start. "Given our... situation, it's in my best interest that you stay healthy. And - more importantly - alive."

Rio's lips parted, but Agatha steamrolled ahead.

"Your insurance doesn't cover shit, and I'm not risking you refusing treatment because you're too stubborn to deal with the bill."

Rio blinked, then exhaled sharply, shifting on the hospital bed. "You can't just-"

"I can," Agatha's smirk was razor-sharp. "And I will."

"I don't need charity."

The scoff that escaped Rio's lips hit harder than Agatha expected.

Because it wasn't about the deal. About keeping Rio unharmed for leverage, for Evanora, or some neat line item in their arrangement.

Sure, she had framed it like that - it was simple, clean.

But the truth wasn't clean. It was tangled and insistent, wrapped tight around her ribs and refusing to be dismissed.

The truth was that she cared.

Not for the contract or appearances.

For Rio.

Rio, who was fighting that care with every breath. Who saw it as transactional - something bought, not offered. Something conditional that transcended the obligations imposed on Agatha by the contract.

And it hurt in a way Agatha didn't know how to name. But she didn't let it show.

"It's not charity," she said finally, the smirk slipping into something quieter. "It's me giving a damn whether or not you bleed out on a bar floor."

Rio didn't look away, but something shifted in her gaze, an emotion Agatha couldn't quite place lurking behind the exhaustion.

"I wouldn't be here if I didn't give a shit," Agatha continued, voice low. "I wouldn’t be arguing, I wouldn't have paid the bill, and I sure as hell wouldn't be putting you on my plan if I didn't think you were worth it."

That silenced Rio.

The tension between them shifted, no longer sharp but fragile.

"I will find a way to do this, even if you don't agree," Agatha said, not unkindly. "Because I'm not letting you get killed just to prove a point."

Rio exhaled slowly, visibly chewing on the words.

"I'll pay you back when I get the money," she murmured. "I mean it."

Agatha sighed, recognizing that was the closest she'd get to a yes. "Fine. But that means you'll have to stay alive for a while."

It earned her a faint, reluctant smile.

Agatha returned it, softer than before, settling back into the chair as the air between them had changed.

The doctor entered the room a moment later, making Agatha wonder if he had lurked behind the door, waiting for them to stop hissing at each other like feral cats in a cage.

"Alright, Mrs. Vidal," he glanced at the tablet before pressing it to his chest, arms crossing with clinical finality. "Aside from the mild concussion, the scans look good. No bleeds or fractures."

Agatha straightened in her seat, the words not as reassuring as they should be. "And the concussion? What does that mean for her?"

"Bed rest for the next 48 hours," the doctor replied immediately, voice smooth with practiced repetition. "No screens, reading, bright lights, or loud noises. And absolutely no strenuous activity."

Agatha nodded along, committing each line to memory, the weight of responsibility settling deeper with every word.

It didn't even cross her mind that it wasn't necessarily her responsibility.

The doctor turned to Agatha more fully, his expression softening around the edges. "I recommend someone keep an eye on her day and night," he said, his gaze steady. "Let her rest, but if she becomes hard to wake, starts slurring, gets confused, or if the headache spikes, bring her back immediately. The scans are clear, but we don't like taking chances."

Something must have shifted in Agatha's expression - some subtle tightening of the mouth, or a flicker of fear - because his voice gentled.

"It sounds worse than it is," he reassured. "These are mostly precautions. She'll bounce back, just needs time."

Rio stirred on the bed, drawing the doctor's attention with a dry, impatient question. "When can I get back to work and classes?"

"After your stitches are out, so at least ten days if there are no complications," he pulled a small notepad and pamphlet from his coat pocket, holding out the papers. "I've written you a note and a prescription for painkillers."

Then, with the kind of dramatic irony only fate could orchestrate, he handed the colorful pamphlet to Agatha. "And here's everything you need to know about caring for her at home."

Agatha accepted it with a stiff nod, swallowing hard as she stared at the cheerful print on the front. A cartoon brain with a Band-Aid smiled up at her like this was all very manageable.

"Thank you," she murmured.

The doctor gave a small nod, already stepping back toward the door. "Good luck, you two. Take it easy."

And just like that, they were alone again - except now, the air between them was heavier. Quieter.

Of course, Rio wouldn't have that.

"No screens or reading?' she groaned, slowly swinging her legs over the bed's edge with exaggerated drama. "I'm gonna die of boredom before the concussion gets me."

Agatha pocketed the pamphlet with one hand and offered the other, her voice dry. "You can meditate. Or ponder the meaning of life."

Rio huffed and, to Agatha's surprise, accepted the offered hand. Her fingers curled tightly around Agatha's wrist, knuckles white with effort as she eased herself off the bed.

"That sounds strenuous."

"You're right," Agatha said, but the words didn't carry her usual edge. "Your brain isn't used to thinking. It might make everything worse."

The joke landed flat. Because all she could focus on was how Rio swayed once her feet hit the floor. The way her grip tightened reflexively, trying not to show how much she was leaning on Agatha.

She looked pale. Unsteady. A breath away from collapsing.

Agatha's heart lurched, hot and cold at once. The doctor could be wrong. What if he missed something? What if this wasn't mild? What if she were walking Rio out of the hospital only to watch her fall apart somewhere worse?

"I'm a PhD student," Rio muttered, breaking through her spiral. "I think all the time."

Agatha forced a breath through her nose, grounding herself in the petty normalcy of Rio's petulance. "Congratulations," she murmured. "You just diagnosed yourself with a chronic condition."

Rio grinned - weak, but genuine - and leaned into her just a little more. "I knew something was wrong with me. Only masochists go for PhDs."

Agatha didn't laugh. She couldn't. Not with her body still coiled like a spring beside this woman who joked her way through bruises and blood loss.

Instead, she tightened her grip and said, more gently than she meant to, "Let's get you home."

Rio complied, allowing the gentle press of Agatha's hand on her lower back to guide her through the halls.

The walk to the car passed in silence. Rio was seemingly too exhausted or in too much pain to keep up the banter, and Agatha was too focused on keeping her from stumbling over her feet to make conversation.

The concern still pressed uncomfortably against her ribs whenever Rio winced or grunted, making her want to check the doctor's credentials. Visions of walking into the guest bedroom in the morning only to find Rio cold and unmoving after a brain bleed circled her head like harpies, and by the time they reached the car, Agatha was halfway to picking Rio up and marching her back into the hospital.

Knowing it wouldn't work, she settled on opening the passenger door for the woman, helping her in, and buckling her seatbelt. All while ignoring weak hands trying to push hers away and half-hearted protests.

The hospital parking lot faded behind them, swallowed by the night. It must have rained sometime after Agatha had gotten to the hospital, small puddles littering the street and pavements.

Agatha kept one hand on the wheel, the other hovering uncertainly over the console, ready to steady the woman beside her if needed.

Rio was unusually quiet in the passenger seat, head tilted back and digging into the headrest, eyes half-lidded. A sliver of moonlight caught the edge of her bandage, making her look ghostly pale.

Agatha glanced at her, jaw set. "You okay?"

"Peachy," Rio murmured, but her voice sounded off.

After a quick stop at the pharmacy to collect the painkillers, Agatha resumed driving to the house, eyes darting between the road and the pale woman.

Then Rio moved in the seat, a choked sound slipping past her lips as she pressed a hand to her stomach.

"Rio?"

"I'm fine," she said too quickly, inhaling sharply through her nose. "Can you just... drive a bit slower?"

Agatha frowned, staring at the tantalizingly empty road stretching before them. Still, she eased off the gas, watching the speed on her dashboard fall well below the limit.

But it was too late.

Rio's hand shot to the door, and her entire body tensed like a coil.

"Pull over," she choked out, already fumbling with the handle. "Agatha, now."

Agatha swerved smoothly into the side street and threw the car in park just in time for Rio to stumble out, one hand clutching her abdomen, the other bracing against the door as she emptied her stomach onto the wet pavement.

Agatha was out in a flash, her boots splashing in a shallow puddle. She didn't speak - just circled the car and rubbed a soothing hand over Rio's back as the woman shook.

"Shit," Rio whispered once she could breathe, her voice thick with humiliation. "God, I'm so sorry. I-"

"Don't," Agatha said quietly, her hand pressing circles into Rio's spine. "Don't apologize."

Rio didn't look at her. She leaned against the car door, closing her eyes and exhaling shakily.

"This sucks."

"I know."

"I feel pathetic."

Agatha's hand slid up, traveling to Rio's arm and wrapping around her elbow. "You took a chair to the head and have a concussion. You're allowed to be human for five minutes."

That earned her a shaky, small laugh.

Her hand squeezed comfortingly, ready to gently nudge Rio back into the car when she noticed the goosebumps littering the tan skin. Of course, in the haste of getting the woman to the hospital, nobody thought to grab her jacket from the bar.

Without thinking, she pulled off her blazer and draped it over Rio's shoulders. The younger woman stiffened at first, but didn't shrug it off.

"You'll get cold."

"I'll live."

It sounded almost like a dismissal, and Rio turned to look at her - actually look at her, her eyes sharper than they had been the entire evening.

"You really don't let people take care of you much, do you?" she asked, sounding curious.

Agatha blinked. "You're one to talk."

They stood there, Rio in Agatha's blazer, Agatha's hand still wrapped around her elbow like she was anchoring them both.

Agatha wondered if Rio was thinking about the night of her birthday. About how she fought every helping gesture, every offered hand as if they offended her, feeling equal parts confused and terrified by the ease with which Rio made her compliant.

The truth was that Agatha didn't have a problem with letting other people take care of her. Deep down, she craved it.

She just never had anyone who wanted to bear that cross.

And Rio - stubborn, confident, Rio - hauled it over her shoulder the night of her birthday and carried it around with a teasing smirk without even realizing it.

The thought lodged itself in Agatha's throat like a secret too heavy to say aloud.

She looked at Rio - sweat-damp curls stuck to her forehead, her skin pale and clammy beneath the streetlight, wrapped in her blazer - and something uncomfortably tender twisted in her chest.

For the first time since they had met, Rio was the vulnerable one, the one who needed help that went beyond throwing money at the problem, and Agatha jumped into the role automatically, guided by instinct and worry.

And Rio, even with all the grumbling, huffing, and pouting, accepted it, making something quieter settle between them. Something real.

Something dangerously close to a partnership surpassing what the deal called for.

Rio straightened her spine, brushing the hand Agatha wasn't holding across her mouth.

Wordlessly, Agatha reached into the back seat, taking out a bottle of water she kept stashed for emergencies. "Rinse. Don't swallow."

Rio took it with a grateful nod, too wrung out to argue.

After a few moments, she leaned back against the car, head tilted toward the sky. "You're good at this," she murmured, voice hoarse.

"Vomiting roadside maintenance?" Agatha teased, though it came out softer than intended.

"No," Rio said, turning her head to look at her again. "This. I've been told I'm not the easiest when it comes to injuries or sickness. But you... You know when to push and when to back off."

Agatha's brow arched. "Not sure anyone's ever accused me of tactfulness."

Rio gave a tired chuckle, the sharpness in her gaze slowly melting into weariness. "You don't give yourself enough credit."

That struck something vulnerable and unguarded in Agatha. She wasn't sure what to do with it. So, she deflected.

"Yeah, who am I kidding? I'm amazing," she mused.

"I knew feeding your ego was a bad idea," Rio groaned, pushing away from the door.

When she swayed again, Agatha's other hand shot out to her waist, steadying her. "Come on, we're about five minutes out. You can feed my ego more somewhere warmer."

Rio didn't argue. She let Agatha guide her back into the passenger seat, the blazer still draped around her, its warmth still lingering.

As Agatha closed the door behind her and slid back into the driver's seat, she glanced sideways, watching Rio settle.

The thought hummed just beneath the surface:

Let me take care of you. Just for a little while.

Of course, she didn't say it aloud.

Still, her eyes flickered over to Rio every chance she got for the rest of the drive.

When they finally walked through the door, it was almost 8 PM. Agatha automatically reached for the light switch, but the doctor's words echoed in her mind before she could flip it.

No bright lights.

"It won't kill me," Rio grumbled, catching her hesitation. Her voice was hoarse, but the defiant edge was still intact.

Agatha didn't dignify that with a response. Instead, she steered them further into the house, guiding Rio toward the guest bedroom.

They didn't make it far before Wanda appeared, materializing at the foot of the stairs like a silent sentinel. Her eyes swept from Agatha's arms wrapped tightly around Rio's waist to the tight bandage, and then back to Agatha again.

"How are you doing?" she asked gently, though her tone gave no hint as to who the question was really for.

"Thriving," Rio said, flashing a grin that was pure bravado, all teeth and no strength behind it.

Agatha rolled her eyes, grip tightening like she could physically hold Rio's nonsense at bay. "She has a mild concussion," she corrected dryly.

Wanda's brows creased with concern, her eyes softening. "If you want me to take Nicky tonight..."

Agatha hesitated. It was a generous offer - practical, even - but she didn't need to answer. Rio shook her head so hard she winced, one hand instinctively pressing to her temple.

"No," she rasped. "Absolutely not. You're not sending Nicky away because I've got a headache.

"It's a concussion," Agatha hissed, her eyes narrowing. "Stop downplaying it. You threw up on the way here."

"Because you drive like you're auditioning for a Fast & Furious reboot!"

"I was going five over the limit!"

"That's not comforting! That's-"

"Okay," Wanda interjected, a knowing look on her face. "So... no to Nicky. Got it."

Agatha exhaled through her nose, resigned. "We'll be fine. Thank you for staying with him."

"Always," Wanda smiled, nodding toward the living room where the unmistakable sounds of preteen squabbling echoed through the halls. "I told him you got held up at work. Didn't want him to worry. But... he knows something's off."

Of course, he did. He had her instincts, sharp and unflinching.

Agatha sighed. "I'll talk to him later."

"I'll get out of your hair," Wanda said, already retreating, but not before she offered one last glance - sympathy threaded with something else. Understanding. "Let me know if you need anything."

"Yeah, thanks, Wands," Agatha said.

"Thanks," Rio echoed, a beat behind, voice fainter. Her attention was already fixed on the staircase - on the climb ahead - her posture bent with exhaustion.

Before Agatha could stop her, she felt Rio shift, easing out of her grip. One unsteady hand reached for the banister.

Then, Rio's foot uncertainly shuffled up to the first step, the muscles in her neck straining as she pulled herself forward.

Agatha felt ready to murder her.

"What do you think you're doing?" she snapped, jumping forward to spot the woman.

Rio didn't flinch, but she did pause, one hand white-knuckled around the banister.

"Walking," she said as if it were obvious. "You have to talk to Nicky."

"You can barely stand."

"I can stand just fine," Rio muttered, even as her shoulder brushed the wall a little too hard.

"I am not driving you back to the hospital with a cracked skull," Agatha growled, easily jumping the two steps Rio had managed to conquer and returning her hand to the woman's waist. "Or letting you bleed on my hardwood."

That shut Rio up for a beat. She looked at the stairs like they'd betrayed her. Like this house, this night, this whole fucking situation had turned against her.

Agatha caught the look and softened, her voice quieter. "Let me help."

Jesus, she was close to begging just to protect the woman from herself.

For a second, Rio just stood there, pride and pain wrestling behind her eyes. Then, with a defeated sigh, she nodded.

They climbed slowly, carefully. Agatha counted each step - there were too many for her liking - and mentally calculated the time she'd need to catch Rio if she stumbled. Her arm remained tight around the woman's waist, guiding her, until finally they reached the landing.

A few steps later, they were in the guest bedroom, and Agatha almost stumbled, caught off guard by how much the space had changed.

She remembered what it used to look like. Stark, clean lines in shades of grey and white, cold by design. It had been intentionally impersonal, curated by a designer to discourage lingering guests. Where her room was functional and Nicky's was filled with life, this one had always been more modern office than a cozy retreat.

But Rio had undone all of that without ever asking.

Plants now ruled the room - lush greens crowding the windowsills, hanging from hooks in the corners, tucked onto shelves and bedside tables in mismatched pots. Books and papers lay stacked in organized chaos, interrupted only by random trinkets: a strangely shaped rock, a glass orb, an action figure Agatha recognized from Nicky's room.

It should've felt messy, but it didn't.

Somehow, it felt lived-in. Warm.

It felt like Rio.

Agatha stood frozen for a moment, her gaze sweeping over the soft, intentional clutter. The room smelled faintly of eucalyptus and soil. The white walls were a mere canvas to the flurry of colors. And underneath it all, a quiet sense of order - messy to her, perhaps, but curated with care. Everything had its place.

"Welcome to my humble abode," Rio mumbled as she shuffled toward the bed. She moved like her limbs were too heavy, her stubborn pride barely keeping her upright. Agatha let her go, still caught in that odd little ache in her chest as she took in what the room had become.

It wasn't hers anymore. It was Rio's.

"Mama?" Nicky's voice floated up from downstairs, small and tentative.

Agatha blinked, snapped out of her daze. She turned toward the doorway, already moving, but not before glancing back.

Rio was already halfway curled beneath the covers, grimacing as she eased herself onto the pillows.

"I'll be fine. Go," she said, waving her off with a flutter of fingers that couldn't hide the wince in her eyes.

Agatha hesitated only for a second longer, then nodded.

"I'll talk to him," she said gently. "And I'll bring you something to eat."

That earned her a soft grunt in return. She lingered for one more beat, her hand resting on the doorframe, eyes flicking once more across the space.

Then she stepped out into the hallway, pulling the door nearly shut behind her - just enough to let the light stay soft, just enough to hear Rio in case she needed something.

Nicky waited for her on the first step, lips pursed and forehead creased. If not for the exhaustion catching up to her, Agatha would've smiled at the determination in his eyes.

"Let's talk in the kitchen, baby," she said softly before he could bombard her with questions. "Did you have fun at school?"

But Nicky wouldn't be distracted that easily. He obediently followed her into the kitchen before crossing his arms and jutting out his chin.

"Why'd you come late?" he asked as Agatha opened the fridge, biting back a smile at the two containers of food Wanda had left for them.

At least she didn't have to make a last-minute grocery trip or feed Rio cereal.

She pulled out the soup and a half-full bottle of apple juice, buying herself time as she tried to think of an answer. Not a lie, but not the truth either. Her son didn't need the full, blood-stained version.

She set the items on the counter and turned slowly, leaning against it.

"There was an... accident," she said carefully.

Nicky's eyes widened. "Was it you?"

"No," she softened her voice. "Rio."

His expression twisted, and Agatha could see worry melting away the defiance. "Is she okay?"

"She will be," Agatha bent at the waist slightly to be eye-level with him. "She got hurt, but we went to the hospital, and she's going to rest for a few days. She just needs quiet, sleep, and maybe a little soup."

Nicky glanced over his shoulder, toward the stairs, then back at Agatha. "Did someone hurt her?"

Agatha stilled.

There it was - that sharp, shrewd awareness that he always carried, barely hidden behind his baby cheeks and innocent eyes.

God, she dreaded his teenage years.

"Yes," she said after a pause. "But she's safe now."

Nicky nodded slowly, but his frown didn't fade. "Are you mad?"

"What?" Agatha blinked, straightening her spine. "Why would I be mad?"

"I dunno," he shrugged, a gesture that seemed too mature for someone with cartoon socks.

Then again, Rio wore cartoon socks.

"You always get mad when someone trips me on the field," he added, glancing up at her. "Even if I'm okay."

Agatha stared at him, stunned for a second.

Because he wasn't wrong. She did get mad - furious, actually - whenever she saw some brat trip her son on the soccer field. She'd jumped out of her seat more than once, ready to curse out a kid half her size, only for Wanda to yank her back down with a glare that promised judgment and possibly jail time.

But she hadn't expected this. Hadn't expected Nicky to put Rio in the same mental category as himself - someone Agatha cared for. Someone Agatha was supposed to protect.

"Yeah," she admitted, her voice coming out steadier than she felt. "I'm a little mad right now."

"Are you gonna do something?"

He didn't sound curious. He sounded certain, like he already knew the answer.

Agatha ran a hand through his curls. "I am."

Nicky studied her momentarily before nodding. "Okay."

She pulled him into a hug, tight and warm, momentarily silencing the storm clawing at the edges of her mind.

After a second, muffled against her side, he asked, "Do you think Rio'd want my switch? I can leave it for her when I go to school. If she's bored."

Agatha smiled, leaning back to kiss his forehead before turning toward the stove. "I'm sure she'd love it, but she can't look at screens for two days," she said gently, already reaching for a pot.

Nicky walked over, holding the soup container with both his hands, frowning. "Why?"

"You know how sometimes if you spend too much time watching TV or playing games your head hurts?" he nodded slowly. "Well, that's because your brain is tired and needs a break. Right now, Rio's head hurts a lot. Screens will just make it worse."

Nicky nodded again, brow furrowed in concentration as he watched her pour the soup.

"What about books?" he asked after a moment. "I can give her Percy Jackson!"

The eagerness in his voice nearly broke her. He wanted to help. He didn't just care, he wanted to do something about it.

"I'm sorry, baby," she said, turning toward the cupboard for a glass. "She can't read right now either. But it's only for two days," she added quickly, seeing his face fall. "After that, you can ask her if she wants to borrow something, okay?"

Nicky hesitated, lips pressed together in thought, before finally sighing. "Okay. Can I bring her the soup?"

"You can pour her some juice," Agatha handed him the glass like a peace treaty. "It's almost time for bed. You have school tomorrow."

Nicky huffed, opening the juice bottle with a scowl. "But I wanna see Rio!"

Agatha's eyebrows twitched. She knew where this was going.

"It's late," she said firmly. "She needs rest, and so do you."

"But-"

"You can see her tomorrow after school," Agatha cut in gently but with finality. "I know you're worried. I am, too. But I need your help, okay? We're taking care of Rio together. I can't do that if you're too tired to listen tomorrow."

That gave him a pause. His small fingers flexed around the cap. He looked down at it, jaw working slightly as he thought. Finally, he exhaled, shoulders drooping. "Okay. I can wait 'til tomorrow."

Agatha reached out and squeezed his arm. "Thank you," she said warmly. "I'll tell her you wanted to visit tonight."

She turned back to the pot as Nicky carefully poured the juice, filled the glass nearly to the brim, and - predictably - left the almost empty, uncapped bottle on the counter.

Before she could remind him to put the juice away, he darted forward, arms wrapping briefly around her waist. "Goodnight. Tell Rio goodnight,t too."

Agatha smiled, smoothing her hand up his back and pressing a soft kiss to his temple. "I will. Goodnight, baby."

Once he disappeared around the corner, Agatha sighed, reaching for the ladle and mechanically stirring the soup.

Her hands worked while her mind spiraled.

The ladle clinked against the pot, too loud in the quiet house, and she winced.

No bright lights. No screens. No loud noises.

The doctor's list of instructions played on a loop in her head, too clinical to comfort her and too vague to settle the anxiety coiling in her gut.

Rest. Hydrate. Monitor for worsening symptoms.

What if something did worsen?

What if she missed it? What if Rio fell asleep and didn't wake up? What if the staggering on the way home hadn't come from exhaustion but something else? Something worse?

She adjusted the flame under the pot as if the motion could settle her spiraling mind. Focusing on now wasn't working. She knew Rio was upstairs - safe, breathing, and refusing help like a particularly hard-headed stray cat. It was good, normal.

But normal was fragile if the past hours were anything to go by.

Agatha leaned against the counter, fingers curling around the edge, grounding herself. This wasn't supposed to be a part of the deal. Not the call, not the hospital, and certainly not the fear.

She stirred the soup slowly, watching it swirl.

Even she had enough self-awareness to know her reactions couldn’t be written off as attraction. The dull throb pulsing behind her ribs, deeper than worry and heavier than obligation, didn’t stem from something as easy as finding Rio pleasant to look at.

She pressed the back of her hand to her forehead, sighing quietly.

Fucking get it together.

The timer on the stove ticked past the third minute. She grabbed a bowl from the cupboard, methodically filled it with the soup, and set it on a tray with a spoon, the medication, and the glass Nicky had poured.

Then she paused, her fingers hovering over the edge of the tray.

You don't have to stay here with me.

The memory echoed, making her clench her jaw.

She could already predict the argument that would follow her next move.

Good thing she didn't really fucking care for Rio's broken brain's thoughts.

She picked up the tray and turned toward the stairs.

With her hands occupied, Agatha used her elbow to push the door open, letting more dim light into the otherwise dark bedroom.

Well, dark except for the artificial gleam coming off the phone currently in Rio's hand.

Agatha almost dropped the tray as she watched Rio squint at the screen, her face even paler with the light reflecting off the bandage and her cheeks.

"Are you fucking kidding me?"

The question cracked through the air like a whip, cutting the soothing silence short as Agatha pressed her foot into the door to shut it with a soft click. With the light from the hall gone, Rio's phone was the only thing illuminating the space, making Agatha even more furious.

"Turn on the lamp and put down the fucking phone," she growled, marching over to the bed in slow, deliberate steps. When Rio just stared at her, eyes wide and mouth slightly open, Agatha put the tray down on the unused bedside table and ripped the device from Rio's hand. "Now, Rio."

To her credit, Rio listened immediately, fumbling for the light switch just as Agatha locked the phone and slipped it into her back pocket.

The room was filled with warm, gentle light, but it did little to soothe the anger clawing its way up Agatha's throat.

"Did the concussion impair your ability to process information?" she hissed, crossing her arms. "Did you not hear the doctor say 'no screens'? Should I read you the pamphlet he gave me? Or maybe you want me to go on WebMD and make you listen to all the horrible things that can happen if you don't follow his fucking orders?"

Rio sank back against the pillows like a scolded teenager, her lips parting as if to speak, but nothing came out. Maybe it was guilt. Maybe it was shock. Either way, she looked caught, but Agatha wasn't done.

"You threw up on the way here," she continued, voice low but heated, the kind of anger that wasn't loud but burned. "You couldn't even stand straight five minutes ago, and you think this-" she held up a hand and mimicked swiping on a screen. "-is a good idea?"

Rio finally found her voice, and it came out quieter than Agatha expected. "I just... I had to respond to a message."

"Fucking hell, Rio," Agatha ran a hand across her face. "You're not a CEO. No one's dying because you don't text back."

"It was Billy," Rio muttered, sounding almost defensive. "He wanted an update."

Agatha spun around, eyes blazing. "So call. I know your generation is allergic to phone calls, but I feel like a bruised brain is a good justification!"

Rio winced, more from the tone than the volume. "I didn't mean to-"

"I know you didn't," Agatha snapped, cutting her off. "But I swear if I catch you staring at another screen, I'm duct-taping mittens to your hands."

The threat hung in the air, ridiculous and yet somehow not entirely unbelievable coming from her.

There was a pause, the anger finally beginning to ebb from Agatha's limbs, leaving her chest tight and her head pounding in its place.

She looked over at Rio again - still pale, exhausted, and looking like a kicked puppy despite having clearly broken the rules - and her fury deflated further.

"I'm sorry," Rio mumbled, putting out the anger's dying flames entirely. "I didn't mean to upset you."

Agatha sighed, voice softening. "I'm not upset," Rio raised her brow as if not believing her words. "I'm scared."

Fuck, did she say that?

She didn't mean to say that.

Something in Rio's eyes shifted, her expression crumpling at the edges. "I didn't mean to scare you either."

"Well, you did," Agatha said, realizing there was no point trying to take her words back now. "You can make it up to me by eating this soup and refraining from doing anything stupid for the next two days. Can you handle that?"

Rio nodded, subdued. "Yes, ma'am."

Agatha narrowed her eyes but didn't comment, placing the tray gently on her lap with a precision that spoke of how much effort it took to stay calm.

She lingered for a moment, eyeing the bandage before her eyes slid down to the neckline of her shirt, still spotted with dried blood.

"You should change before we head to bed," she noticed absentmindedly, almost making Rio drop the spoon back into the soup.

"I'm sorry, we?"

Agatha rolled her eyes at the startled look on the woman's face. "Well, you're heading to bed. I will drag the chair from my office in here to keep an eye on you."

Rio gaped at her, clearly thrown. "You want to sleep in a chair?"

"It reclines," Agatha said flatly as if that somehow made it a luxury. "And it's temporary. Don't make it a big deal."

Rio watched her for a beat, something tugging at the corners of her mouth. "You know, most people would just set an alarm every couple of hours or leave it to chance."

Agatha folded her arms. "Yeah, well, I'm not most people. And you're a hazard to yourself."

"I'm not a toddler," Rio muttered, but there was no real heat in it. Just a quiet sort of surprise.

"No, you're right, toddlers listen."

Rio huffed a laugh, spoon halfway to her mouth. "Fair enough."

Agatha tilted her head slightly. "Eat your soup, take your meds, and then change. I'll bring in the chair."

To her surprise, Rio shook her head. "No."

"For fuck's-"

Rio's voice was quiet but steady, eyes not leaving Agatha's. "We can share the bed."

Agatha blinked. "Excuse me?"

"You're exhausted," Rio said as if it were obvious. "And the chair's gonna wreck your spine. It's stupid."

Agatha's jaw flexed, her instinctive response ready to fire, but never making it past her throat. Because Rio wasn't smirking, she wasn't teasing or pulling her leg. She looked earnest.

The idea was reckless. Too close. Too personal. But the bed was big. And Rio was injured. And maybe, just maybe, Agatha was more tired than she wanted to admit.

"...Fine," she finally grumbled, pointing at Rio warningly. "We're staying on our sides, and if you start talking in your sleep, I'm turning your concussion from mild to severe."

"I only talk in my sleep after alcohol."

"Yeah, I know, and you’ll be high on painkillers. Same thing."

Agatha froze, realizing what she had said a second too late, but Rio was already grinning like the cat that got the cream.

"I told you that at the bar. You remembered?"

"Shut up and eat your soup."

Chapter End Notes

Hi! I think this might be the longest chapter yet. Did I come up with the idea of Rio being hurt as an excuse to have them share a bed? Maybe. Will this be a pivotal moment in the story? Also maybe. Anyway, hope you enjoyed it, thank you for all the kudos and comments, and see you next week!

Chapter 17: Late night revelations

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Rio finished the soup with minimal protest, each attempt silenced by a single pointed look from Agatha. She took the meds without complaint, chasing them down with a small sip of juice, and sighed contentedly, leaning further into the pillows, which Agatha took as her cue to leave.

She quietly took the tray back to the kitchen, leaving the woman to change into something more comfortable and brush her teeth. She hesitated for a moment, an offer to help Rio change forming on her tongue, but it died just as quickly. It was too personal, too intimate.

Instead, she ducked into Nicky's room to make sure he was in bed. A soft smile tugged at her lips when she found him already fast asleep, face half-buried in his pillow, one arm hanging off the mattress.

Then, she moved on to the master bathroom and started the shower, eager to wash off the lingering scent of antiseptic and hospital air. The hot water felt like a reset, scrubbing away the weight of the last few hours and filling her ears with the steady rhythm of the stream hitting the tiled floor. By the time she was brushing her teeth, the fog on the mirror had started to clear, and so did her thoughts.

That was when her phone started buzzing on the counter, vibrating in small, insistent bursts, inching closer to the edge.

She sighed and reached for it, arching a brow at the number of new notifications. Most were from work, whiny clients, incompetent coworkers, none of which she had the energy or patience to deal with tonight. She scrolled past them, ready to put the phone down again, when one name made her pause.

Lilia.

Sent nearly two hours ago.

You're working remotely until Rio gets better. And only urgent cases.

Which, yeah, that was her plan. But something about Lilia spelling it out made it seem official. Like it was normal, expected even.

Agatha didn't reply, just moved on.

The next few were from Wanda, sent not long after she had left with the twins.

I'm driving Nicky to school tomorrow

Not a question btw

You need to take care of wifey

Too tired to argue - or text-yell - she settled on reacting to the first message with a thumbs-up and sending an eye-rolling emoji to the third.

The last ones were from Billy, and she realized he was the one who almost made her phone commit suicide by buzzing off the counter.

I'm sorry to bother you, but Rio's not responding to my texts, she okay?

Once again, sorry for texting so late

Or texting at all

I just want to know if she's okay, can you let me know?

I really don't wanna get fired for this

But like, if you fire or block me, can you give me an update on Rio first?

She stopped reading after that, already seeing the spiral gain momentum. With a tired sigh, she typed out a reply:

No one's getting fired. Rio's not allowed screens for two days and doesn't have her phone. She's alive, now stop bothering me.

She barely hit send before Billy reacted with a heart emoji.

Unprofessional, but she'd let it slide this once.

After assuring Alice, who, too, texted and called, that Rio was okay, she locked her phone and tossed it back on the counter with a sigh.

Her reflection stared back at her, the lack of makeup making the dark circles under her eyes and the paleness of her skin even more prominent. She did look like printer paper, but slaving away in her own garden wouldn't change that. No amount of sun could erase the ghostly whiteness of her cheeks because, as she looked at herself in the mirror, wide-eyed and lost, Agatha knew vitamin D deficiency wasn't the issue.

The issue was the worry pressing uncomfortably against her ribs. The slow unraveling of her firm belief that the confusing feelings holding her by the throat whenever she was near Rio were superficial.

Agatha shook her head, turning away from the mirror. She'd had a long, stressful day. Anybody would look like a shitty caricature of a person after that, and as much as she liked to disagree, she was only human. All she needed was a good night's rest.

Ideally, it would be in her own bed, but the universe still fucking hated her.

As she walked back to the guest bedroom, her steps slow and wary as if dragging out the moment would change anything, Agatha glanced down the hall, toward her office. Rio had been right: the chair would fuck up her back, even when reclined, but somehow, spending the next three days with stabbing pain gripping her spine seemed better than the alternative.

The alternative meaning sleeping beside Rio, in Rio's bed, close enough to touch.

Not that Agatha would or wanted to. Her attraction hadn't fizzled out, making her realize it probably never would unless Rio stopped being annoyingly good-looking and caring, which seemed unlikely. Still, she had caught all the butterflies in her stomach in a net and locked them away, using logic as a foolproof key. Rio was off limits, and that knowledge was enough to act professional about a situation that was anything but. Agatha had kept her distance, dutifully averted her gaze whenever the butterflies threatened to reappear, and stayed, at all times, at least two feet away from Rio.

And it all went to hell because Rio decided to have a fucking chair thrown at her.

Somehow, Agatha's life had turned from a Greek tragedy to a soap opera - the shitty kind with painful acting and choppy editing.

She exhaled slowly before tentatively knocking on the guest room door, silently praying that the pain meds had already knocked Rio out, sparing them the awkwardness of adjusting to the situation.

The soft permission to enter shattered the hope before it could bloom.

"Come in."

Agatha tensed her shoulders as if preparing for Rio to leap out at her when she opened the door and slid into the room, swallowing the unidentifiable feeling rising in her chest at the sight.

Rio lay where Agatha had left her, half-sunken into the pillows, her body swallowed by the comforter. The harsh traces of sweat and smeared makeup were gone, wiped away and replaced by something cleaner but no less raw. Her shirt was soft-looking and oversized, the collar loose around her collarbones, and her hair had been pulled into a high ponytail, making the bandage on her temple look like a bandana. Her eyes, though, were the same - dark and ringed with exhaustion, barely open, tracking Agatha with the effort of someone clinging to consciousness by sheer willpower.

Under the amber wash of the bedside lamp, Rio looked fragile and unguarded in a way Agatha hadn't seen her before, like one more terrible day might undo her entirely.

Agatha froze, hand resting on the edge of the comforter. Her holdups aside, climbing into bed could be harmful for Rio. What if she moved wrong? She hadn't shared a bed with someone other than Nicky, who was half Rio's size, for a long time, and she often woke up in the middle of the bed, starfish style. They were one flung elbow away from a second ER visit.

"I can feel you overthinking it," Rio muttered, her voice hoarse but amused, a faint smirk pulling at the corner of her mouth. "Just get in bed."

"Oh, I'm sorry for worrying about your health," Agatha snapped, fingers curling around the edge of the blanket but still not pulling it back.

Rio cracked one eye open, the smirk melting away. "You won't kill me by shifting the mattress," she noticed, tilting her head to look at her properly, something shifting in her eyes. "I'm not letting you sleep in a chair, but you don't have to stay if you're uncomfortable. I promise to let you know if something feels off."

Agatha scoffed, dropping the covers and crossing her arms. "Yeah? You're planning to text me from the afterlife with the phone you're not allowed to use? Or will you call out during a brain bleed?"

Rio blinked slowly, her mind too sluggish to form a clever comeback. "I'll figure something out," she eventually muttered, her eyelids fluttering as if she were trying to fight off sleep. "Also, I'm gonna need to call Billy. He'll worry."

"He texted me," Agatha said briskly, pulling the covers with a huff of finality. "I let him and Alice know you're relatively fine and banned from using screens."

The mattress dipped under her weight as she slid in beside Rio, stiff as a board, her movements careful but unmistakably reluctant. She angled her body toward the edge, leaving a canyon of space between them. Her right leg dangled off the bed as if she were leaving an opening to bolt if necessary.

The silence stretched as Agatha closed her eyes and tried not to focus on how the pillow smelled faintly of Rio's perfume, earthy but light. The blankets were soft and dark green, a shade she now automatically associated with Rio. And beneath all of it was that unbearable sense of ease. Safety, even.

It was too much. The perfume was suffocating, the softness threatened to swallow Agatha, and the warmth was enough to melt her if she let it.

From beside her, Rio exhaled as if the added presence in her bed was comforting. Then, softly, "Thank you."

Agatha hummed, hoping her hammering heart wasn't audible in the quiet room. "He almost made my phone throw itself off the counter. I had to intervene."

"Not just for texting Billy," Rio clarified quietly. "For everything. I know this isn't what you signed up for."

It wasn't, but not for the reasons Rio probably thought.

Marrying a stranger was supposed to ensure objectivity and professionalism. It should've created a detached, transactional relationship secured by a detailed contract like a birthday present tied with a neat bow.

In her previous understanding of the deal, the hospital visit should've been inconvenient, not a nerve-wracking experience. Seeing her wife bruised and vulnerable shouldn't have stirred anything under the surface because she was supposed to be a pawn in the chess match against Evanora. An exchangeable, unimportant pawn that Agatha didn't care about.

Instead, she almost had an aneurysm because some drunk idiot had tried to knock the pawn off the board.

So, Rio was right. Agatha hadn't signed up for the worry, the responsibility, or the unidentifiable emotions slithering between her ribs. She was out of her depth, lost in a situation she didn't know how to handle without jeopardizing the deal.

Agatha kept her eyes glued to the ceiling, mapping out the pristine white paint. Her voice was barely audible when she spoke again, but it still cut through the silence like a sharp knife. "There's a lot I didn't sign up for."

A beat passed. Then two, and Agatha tilted her head slightly, expecting Rio to be fast asleep beside her, finally defeated by the pain meds.

Instead, she fell straight into Rio's half-lidded eyes.

There was no smugness there, no teasing glint or clever remarks waiting to be delivered. Just Rio, stripped bare by the pain and exhaustion, watching her like she could see the invisible wires frying in Agatha's chest in real time.

"Same," Rio said after a long pause, barely above a whisper. "But I'm glad it's with you."

The words landed with unbearable weight, simple, honest, and entirely too much.

Agatha looked away again, her gaze returning to the ceiling. It didn't offer any relief. It was just another sterile space, reminding her of how the deal should've been - clinical and detached. And here Rio was, bleeding through every carefully placed boundary without trying.

She wanted to say Don't do that, don't make this any harder. But the truth clung to the back of her throat like something bitter and familiar, overpowering any feeble attempts at pretending. It was already hard. The magnetic field around Rio had already pulled her in, and Agatha felt like crying.

Because Rio probably didn't mean to do it; she didn't mean to crack something open in Agatha's chest by simply being there.

And yet, she had.

"Go to sleep, Rio," Agatha eventually muttered, her voice thick and carrying the weight of all the unsaid words. "It's late."

The silence stretched before the sheets rustled slightly, and the lamp turned off, enveloping the room in darkness.

"Goodnight," Rio whispered into the quiet.

"Goodnight," Agatha whispered back, fingers clenching around the comforter's edge as if it could shield her from the truth.

The night settled over them like a weighted blanket, warm and heavy. Outside, the thick walls and closed windows muffled the occasional hum of passing cars, and the soft tick of the hallway clock kept time with the tightening in Agatha's chest.

Rio drifted off seconds after switching off the lamp, finally succumbing to the painkillers. Agatha remained wide awake, stiff as a board with one arm folded across her stomach and the other half-curled beneath her head as she stared at the ceiling. Rio's shallow, steady breaths filled the silence like some fragile metronome she couldn't stop listening to. They mixed with mumbled comments as fragments of conversations happening in Rio’s head surfaced to the land of the living, cutting through the stifling silence. Most of them was intelligible, catching on Rio’s teeth or unable to make it past her tongue in a comprehensive manner. Still, Agatha’s heart quickened whenever a soft whisper reached her ears, the idea of keeping her promise and worsening Rio’s concussion never crossing her mind.

Agatha stared at the ceiling, Rio’s soft grunts and words a soundtrack to her unraveling. Her thoughts turned like slow gears, metal grinding against metal and jolting her awake every time she closed her eyes.

The pull toward Rio, which she'd stubbornly labeled as just attraction, had been manageable when it stayed in its lockbox. It was easy to explain away a glance, a smile, or the occasional skip in her pulse. Chemistry was harmless.

But this wasn't that.

Attraction didn't sit heavy in her ribcage like this. It didn't wrap around her throat or root her in place when Rio winced in her sleep. It didn't make her imagine what it would be like to care for someone, not out of obligation, but want.

She turned her head slightly, gaze falling to Rio's hand, half-curled on the blanket between them. Too close but not close enough.

This marriage was supposed to solve problems, not create them - a contract to push Evanora off her high horse. A deal forged in logic, delivered in legalese. Rio was supposed to be a placeholder, not a heartbeat that kept throwing hers off rhythm. But somewhere between signing the paperwork and watching Rio in a hospital bed, she'd stopped being a means to an end and started becoming, well, something. Something Agatha didn't know how to want without unraveling.

It was fucking terrifying.

She let her eyes drift shut for a moment, just to pretend. Pretend she could sleep. Pretend the steady sound of Rio's breath didn't matter. Pretend the hollow ache in her chest was exhaustion and not the shape of feelings for which she had no name.

She couldn't. Not really.

Then, Rio sighed again, a relaxed, content kind of breath that warmed Agatha in ways she couldn’t describe. A word tumbled out of her mouth, soft and accentuated, each syllable pronounced with reverence.

"Agatha."

Her eyes snapped to the sleeping woman, half-expecting to meet a pair of bleary eyes looking at her from the other side of the bed. But Rio was fast asleep, her lips stretched in a gentle smile like she was dreaming of something pleasant.

Agatha froze, glancing toward the door. She could leave. Set an alarm and return to the room every two hours to check on the woman. She could free herself of the overwhelming heat climbing up her spine and the longing curling in her chest.

"Please."

What was Rio asking her for? What was she dreaming about?

"Stay."

Even in her dream state, the pleading in Rio’s voice was unmistakable.

Agatha blinked owlishly, watching the gentle smile disappear from Rio’s lips, replaced by a subtle frown. Her eyelids fluttered, eyes moving rapidly as if she were searching for something. Someone.

Before Agatha could think better of it, she reached for Rio’s hand, stretched on the duvet between them, and caressed the back of her palm.

"I’m here," she rasped, her voice not sounding like her own. Rio sighed contentedly like her body could recognize the touch even in her sleep, and stilled again, lips parting on soft breaths.

She didn’t say anything else.

After a few beats, Agatha withdrew her hand, turning to lie on her back and ignore the hammering of her heart.

She lay awake well into the small hours, haunted by every quiet inhale, every brush of warmth beside her. All the while, her mind kept returning to a truth she couldn't run away from any longer.

This was never just an attraction.

Eventually, Agatha's exhausted body claimed its due, dragging her mind into uneasy sleep despite its desperate grip on consciousness. But rest offered no mercy, only a visual interpretation of Alice's story, enhanced and casting Agatha as the show's main star.

In her dream, the bar floor was slick with blood, the air thick with the metallic sting of panic. Rio lay crumpled and unnaturally still, her breath gurgling, a red halo spreading around her at an alarming rate. Agatha's hands were trembling as she pressed down on the wound, her knees slipping on the wet ground, her throat aching from screaming for help that never came. The pressure wasn't enough, nothing was, and Rio's eyes, those impossibly expressive, clever eyes, stared back at her, unfocused and full of accusation.

You should've done something. You should've protected me.

Her chest clenched, her heart hammering a tattoo against her ribs. She couldn't breathe. She couldn't save her.

And then, a final breath. Unbearable stillness as Rio's face, pale and lifeless, froze mid-blink.

The shrill buzz of her phone cut through the nightmare like a blade, dragging Agatha back with brutal force. Her eyes snapped open, her left hand shooting out to silence the noise before her mind caught up with reality.

The room was dim and quiet, unlike the neon-lit, noisy bar. Her skin was wet, not with Rio's blood but sweat. Her fingers weren't pressing against Rio's wound, but curled into her shirt.

Wait.

That wasn't right.

Agatha froze, the nightmare dissolving like cotton candy in water, erased by more pressing matters.

Her gaze dropped, disbelieving, to the pale hand that peeked out from under the comforter. Long fingers gripped the neckline of Rio's faded shirt, and a palm rested squarely over the slow, steady rhythm of Rio's heartbeat.

It was her palm, pressing into Rio's sternum, weighed down by something warm.

Agatha's breath hitched as she gaped at the second hand atop hers. With darker skin and slightly calloused fingertips, heavier than her own. Holding her in place like an anchor, fingers curled slightly around the edge of her palm as if letting her move away wasn't an option.

They had held hands before, during the dinner with Evanora or at the gala, but that was a choice, a calculated move to ensure credibility. Here, in the soft light of the morning, with the air still heavy with the warmth of sleep and their shared breath, there were no witnesses, expectation, or contracts.

Just Agatha subconsciously reaching out to feel Rio's heartbeat in her sleep. To make sure the woman was safe and alive, while dreaming about losing her.

Moving seemed impossible. The weight of Rio's hand over hers rooted Agatha to the spot, a quiet insistence that she stay. But it wasn't just their hands.

Sometime during the night, the cautious canyon Agatha had left between them had vanished, swallowed by the gravitational pull of shared warmth and unconscious trust. Her right leg - the one she'd stubbornly planted outside the blanket like a tether to rationality - had traitorously wormed its way beneath the covers, slipping between Rio's calves as if it had every right to.

The contact jolted her out of the surprised stupor.

Shorts. Rio was wearing shorts, or at least pants short enough to uncover her lower legs. Her skin was smooth, warm, and entirely too enticing.

Agatha tensed her leg, wanting to remove it as quickly as possible, when she felt her knee press further into a warm thigh. She'd stopped mid-sling, as if her sleeping body had been moments away from climbing on top of Rio.

Her cheeks burned from the realization, her muscles going slack, refusing to cooperate as she wrestled with what she wanted and should do.

She should move.

She should absolutely fucking move.

This was wrong on so many levels, she couldn't even focus on one.

A soft grunt cut through the silence, and she turned her head on the pillow, just enough to catch a glimpse of Rio's profile. Her brow was relaxed in sleep, lips parted slightly, hair partially loosened from its ponytail. The bandage still hugged her forehead, but didn't blend in with her skin anymore, the color returning to her face. She looked peaceful. Vulnerable in a way Agatha wasn't used to seeing.

The heat pulsed against her palm, the unmistakable thrum of life accompanied by the regular rise and fall of Rio's chest that now matched Agatha's breath for breath. That steady, silent rhythm crawled into her bones and demanded she acknowledge what she had been trying so hard to ignore.

The warmth wasn't just physical. It was emotional. Dangerous.

She could feel the faint flutter of Rio's heartbeat under her hand, the same pulse she had clung to in her nightmare, silently begging it not to stop.

Now, in the soft hush of early morning, with golden light leaking through the blinds and painting the room in gentle tones, the truth Agatha's mind had uttered reluctantly in the dead of night gained inescapable weight.

Not just a passable desire she could stifle down.

Not a product of the dry spell, tricky lighting, and simple biology.

This, this was bone-deep.

The possessiveness, the trust, the fucking worry hadn't sprouted from something as flimsy as attraction. They weren't passing symptoms of proximity. No, they were rooted in the deepest crevices of Agatha's chest, places she hadn't even known existed until Rio had slipped through the cracks in her armor like sunlight through old blinds.

She had barged into Agatha's life with puppy-like eyes and infuriating calm. With gentle teasing and careless touches that meant everything. With her quiet understanding, her maddening patience, and that uncanny, dangerous ability to see through every defense Agatha had spent years reinforcing.

And Agatha just... let her.

Let her fit into the life she'd built to be impenetrable. Into her heart that was now raw and uncovered, drowning in the hardest of truths.

She had feelings for Rio.

Complicated, unwanted feelings she could not write off as lust or loneliness.

Because when had desire ever made her feel safe?

When had wanting someone ever come with trust?

Agatha's throat tightened, something traitorous clawing its way up. She wanted to laugh, or cry, or maybe bury herself deeper into the bed and never face what this meant. That her carefully constructed plan, built on logic and strategy, had been undone by the very person she'd chosen to ensure distance.

By Rio, who kept breathing steadily beside her, blissfully unaware.

She stayed frozen in the moment, her mind struggling to carry the importance of the realization that couldn't be softened even by the gentle lighting. The weight pressed into her chest, heavy with meaning. Terrifying in its clarity.

Fuck the yoga and martial arts. How was she supposed to survive ten months of this sharp-edged tenderness twisting in her? How could she look at Rio again, painfully aware of what she felt and unable to do anything about it?

How the fuck did one move on from something like this?

The first logical step was to disentangle herself from Rio and flee the room. Possibly the country.

With the precision of a neurosurgeon, Agatha maneuvered her leg away from Rio's. The room remained motionless, cloaked in silence, yet the relentless pounding in her temples magnified every rustle of fabric until even the smallest movement felt deafening. She cringed as her knee separated from the lean heat of Rio's thigh, the absence immediate and aching.

Ridiculous, she scolded herself, burying the longing before it could unfurl. Her focus narrowed to her hand, still splayed across Rio's chest, still anchored. Slowly, deliberately, she unclenched her fingers, releasing the soft fold of Rio's shirt caught between them. Her hand moved back, inch by inch, until it slipped free from under Rio's with reluctant finality.

Rio didn't so much as stir.

Agatha sat up, careful not to let the shifting mattress betray her, and rubbed her hands over her face as if she could wipe away everything she'd just felt.

Get up, move, focus.

She rose to her feet and padded out of the room, each step mechanical and grounding, the cold floor expelling the warmth clinging to her like smoke. The familiar routine took over - check the emails while the coffee maker whirs to life, prepare Nicky's lunch before making sure he got up.

The ache didn't leave. It just tucked itself neatly beneath the surface again, into the vault where Agatha had kept it sealed for weeks until the night pried the door open, destroying the lock. It took on the shape of a warm hand resting atop hers and a heartbeat that wasn't her own.

By the time she had snapped Nicky's Minecraft lunchbox shut - courtesy of Rio, of course - the familiar movements lulled her into a false sense of security. In the kitchen, she could pretend she hadn't spent the night coming to earth-shattering conclusions about her fake wife. She could pretend she didn't know what Rio looked like in the dim lighting of the early morning.

She could pretend she didn't want to see it ever again.

The house roused slowly, the soft patter of feet on the stairs urging her out of the stupor and back into the present, where she stood with fingers clenched around her favorite mug, the coffee sloshing unsteadily from her trembling hands.

"Hi, Mama," Nicky muttered, still rubbing the sleep out of his eyes as he rounded the island. His bleary gaze slid over her robe and tousled hair. "You're not dressed."

"I'm working from home today," she explained, unfurling her fingers before her grip could shatter the ceramic.

Nicky perked up at the words. "To take care of Rio? Is she okay? Can I see her?"

Agatha flinched under the onslaught of questions, handing him a plate with scrambled eggs. Breakfasts were usually toast or cereal, the morning rush leaving little time for anything more complicated, but she needed something to keep her hands busy. The eggs were a necessary sacrifice.

"She's still asleep," she ignored the churning in her gut, reminding her of the inevitable, and followed Nicky to the dining table, coffee in hand. There was no way she could stomach anything solid with the nausea gripping her throat.

Nicky dug into his breakfast, clearly not sharing her anxiety. "Do you think she'll feel better for my game?"

Shit, she forgot about that. The topic had resurfaced a few times since their prolonged stay at Wanda's, eventually leading to Nicky taking matters into his hands and inviting Rio without considering his mother's sanity.

Rio, to her credit, had immediately checked in with Agatha to make sure she was on board, but under the scrutiny of Nicky's best puppy dog eyes, Agatha had no choice but to agree. The only good thing that came out of the arrangement was that they could treat it as one of the 'dates' they had decided were necessary, but hadn't gotten around to discussing yet.

In light of recent revelations, Agatha was thankful for her son's insistence. Sitting across from Rio in a candle-lit restaurant was the last thing she needed. The bleachers were much safer.

"I'm not sure," she said, choosing her words carefully. "The cheering can get intense, and she's not supposed to be in loud places."

"But the game's on Sunday," Nicky noticed quickly. "You said two days."

Agatha sighed, drumming her fingers against the mug. "Two days without screens, not to heal entirely," Nicky's mouth snapped open again, another retort forming on his tongue, but Agatha kept talking. "I know you're excited about Rio seeing you play, I'm sure she is too, but we have to think about her health, alright?"

Nicky jabbed his fork into the eggs more forcefully, an upset frown pulling at his lips.

"There will be other games," she added gently, relieved when the stubborn tension in Nicky's shoulders lessened.

He chewed in silence for a moment before muttering, "I just wanted us to go together."

Agatha's fingers stilled around the coffee mug.

"You know," he looked up from his plate, eyes thoughtful. "Like a family."

The words hit Agatha harder than he probably meant them to. There was no accusation in his voice, no malice, just plain honesty only children could produce.

"Nicky..." she said, unsure of what she should say. Her heart and mind pulled her in two painfully different directions, tearing her in half.

"I know it's different," he added quickly, like he hadn't meant to open the floodgates but decided to go with the flow. "And I know Rio's not like, technically, my family. You know, blood or something. But she kinda is, and we never do things just the three of us. I thought it'd be nice."

Agatha stared at him blankly, her mind almost caving under all the implications.

Just the three of us. Like a family.

The words echoed in her mind, cruel in their innocence. Since the day Rio and Nicky had built the raised bed, Agatha hadn't let her thoughts stray in that direction again. Thinking in those categories was dangerous. Imagining permanence could be damning.

Because Rio wasn't with them to stay.

The deal was temporary and transactional: Rio needed money, and Agatha needed to win against her mother. Simple on paper, manageable in theory.

But Nicky didn't know that.

All he knew was that there was another adult in his life, helping him with homework, teaching him new things, and listening to his ramblings about video games with an enthusiastic smile. Somebody who looked at him with the kind of softness he associated with care.

It was dangerous.

Not just for her heart, which, if she were honest, had already folded in ways she didn't know how to manage, but for Nicky's. He was a child. He couldn't suspect the quiet devastation that would follow Rio's leaving. He wasn't ready for the ache that would ripple through their home like a fault line splitting the foundation.

Truthfully, neither was Agatha.

Her eyes slowly traveled back to his face, her lower lip trembling.

She couldn't tell him. Rio was a temporary fixture in their lives, but Nicky was already too attached to understand.

And Agatha was too attached to say it out loud.

So, like a coward, she nodded.

"You're right. We don't do things together often."

She didn't say as a family. The word felt too loaded, too fragile on her tongue. Like naming it might make it real, even though it wasn't.

Nicky gave her a small, hopeful smile before popping another bite into his mouth, unaware of the grenade he'd just dropped at the center of her chest.

Agatha stared down at her coffee, the smooth surface contrasting against the chaos swirling in her chest. She felt unmoored, adrift in a sea of feelings she couldn't name, much less control. Affection. Guilt. Fear.

Rio had never asked to be a part of this.

She'd agreed to play a role, to step into Agatha's world, help her fight a battle, and then step back out once the curtain fell with quiet finality. But now, she was woven into everything: Nicky's routines, Agatha's evenings, the warmth of shared silence, and the pull of something deeper than she dared to admit.

And when she left, when she had to go-

Agatha didn't know how to unspool that. Didn't know how to teach her son how to stop loving someone who had never promised to stay to begin with.

She offered Nicky a gentle smile, the kind that stretched the skin around her mouth uncomfortably and didn't reach her eyes, and shoved the feelings aside. "We can have a movie night," she said softly. "Once Rio's allowed to look at screens. Just the three of us."

Nicky brightened again, and the sight of his eyes, wide and trusting, hit her like a gut punch.

She should have predicted the outcome. She should have realized Nicky would get attached to Rio, leading to inevitable heartbreak once the deal expired. But, at the same time, she knew she couldn't have. She couldn't have known how well Rio would fit into their lives or how easy it would be to get attached to her.

If she had, she would have pulled the plug on the arrangement before it could come to life.

Agatha stood, gathering her half-finished mug and his empty plate, the motion automatic. She put them in the dishwasher with trembling hands, listening to Nicky's voice as he hummed a tune under his breath, a song Rio had been playing around the house nonstop for the past three days.

She pressed her fingers against the edge of the counter and breathed.

Ten months.

Ten months of pretending, of proximity, of everything Rio had become. And after that?

She didn't have an answer.

She only knew that when Rio left, it wouldn't just be one heart breaking. It would be two.

When Wanda came to collect Nicky, announcing her arrival with a short honk, Agatha didn't bother to walk out of the house to greet her. She kissed the crown of her son's head, helped him with his backpack, and held the door open as he skipped down the porch steps toward Wanda's car. All she could muster was a brief, uncommitted wave in her best friend's direction, paired with a fake smile that made Wanda look at her through the side window questioningly.

Agatha ignored the look, retreating into the house and closing the door with a tired sigh. Another long, dreadful conversation was brewing, but she didn't have the mental capacity to think about it. She would worry about it later, after she got through the next forty-eight hours of being trapped in the house with Rio.

Speaking of-

She glanced toward the staircase.

A part of her hoped she wouldn't have to face Rio yet. That she could drag her feet and avoid pretending she hadn't realized something enormous and terrifying in the middle of the night for even an hour longer. It wouldn't change anything. The knowledge would still sit heavy on her chest, inescapable like Rio's presence for the next two days. Rio couldn't know. The feelings couldn't go anywhere other than another lockbox shoved to the back of her mind.

Still, she found herself moving toward the guest room, quiet in her approach. Rio's well-being was her responsibility now, handed over to her in the form of a cheerful, too-bright pamphlet, complete with bold fonts and a cartoon brain that grinned beside words like concussion protocol and risk of hemorrhage. She'd read it twice the night before, memorizing warning signs.

She hovered at the door, fingers pausing on the handle a beat too long, caught in the limbo between duty and the urge to lock herself in the office until everything returned to normal. Then she pushed it open and stepped into the dim stillness of the room.

Nothing had changed. The curtains remained drawn, casting faint ribbons of light across the wooden floor. They crept forward like delicate fingers, stretching toward the bed and spilling over the folds of the green covers, over the shape of Rio's sleeping form.

She had moved since Agatha left - turned to her side, one arm extended across the mattress as if reaching for something lost in sleep. Or someone. The sheets were tangled, creased in the outline of absence, and the quiet intimacy of it nearly made her turn around, but her eyes caught on the bandage, making her stomach churn.

It had shifted slightly, a few black strands of hair curling over the edge. A small, rust-colored dot had bloomed through the gauze, faint but undeniable. Right over the place where the skin had been split open and sewn shut.

Agatha took an involuntary step forward, the protective urge roaring in her chest like a second heartbeat. Not just duty or concern, but something else. Something dangerous.

She crouched by the bed, eyes scanning Rio's face, searching for pallor, for strain, for any other sign that things had turned quietly, fatally wrong in the hour she'd been gone. But Rio looked the same, warm under the hush of sleep, her breath steady, lashes casting shadows on her cheekbones. Safe, healing, and alive.

Still, Agatha stared at that single dot of blood like it had whispered betrayal. Like it was proof she hadn't done enough. Had Rio moved too much? Pulled the stitches in her sleep? Was that thin dressing hiding a slow, silent bleed?

She leaned closer, heart knocking against her ribs. Her hand trembled as she reached for the edge of the gauze, unsure what she would do once her fingers touched the material.

And then, a flicker of movement.

A soft fluttering of lashes accompanied by a twitching brow before two bleary brown eyes blinked open, unfocused and confused, landing on Agatha's hovering hand before moving to her face.

Agatha didn't move, caught and exposed in a moment she couldn't lie her way out of.

Rio squinted, her voice thick with sleep. "...Did I die?"

Agatha blinked. "What?"

"You look like you're about to cry," Rio murmured, frowning faintly. "Or say last goodbyes over an open casket."

Agatha rose from the awkward position, relief washing over her in a calming wave. If Rio's questionable sense of humor was still intact, she had to be fine.

"You're bleeding," she said quietly, gesturing toward the bandage.

Rio hummed, closing her eyes as if the news didn't matter. "It could be from yesterday."

It wasn't. Agatha knew that because she'd spent most of the night staring at the bandage and having epiphanies about the conflicting feelings that resurfaced at the stark reminder of Rio's condition.

But she couldn't say that.

Instead, she cleared her throat and stepped away from the bed, keeping her voice even as she spoke. "I'll bring you the meds and some breakfast. I can rewrap the wound before I start work."

That seemed to get Rio's attention. Her eyelids fluttered open again, her eyes sharper than before as she took in Agatha's robe and pajamas peeking out from between the lapels.

"What time is it? Shouldn't you be on your way already?" she asked, hand automatically reaching toward the nightstand.

"No screens," Agatha reminded her, pointing toward the other side of the bed where Rio's phone remained throughout the night. "And it's a little after eight. I'm working from home for the next few days."

Rio frowned, carefully maneuvering her body to lean against the headboard. "You didn't have to do that."

"Lilia's orders," Agatha shrugged as if she hadn't planned on staying home anyway, inching toward the door. Her movements felt rigid, her spine too stiff, and her muscles too tense. She needed distance, breathing room to handle the emotions coiling in her chest like hissing snakes.

Her hand brushed the doorway, feet carrying her out of the room like a rat abandoning a sinking ship, when Rio's soft voice stopped her.

"Agatha."

It shot a bolt of electricity down her spine, effectively freezing her in her place. Her brain ricocheted the word until it shifted, no longer said in the steady voice but a faint whisper.

"Agatha. Please. Stay."

Said like a prayer. Like a plea.

She turned despite herself, eyes falling into warm pools of brown. Rio tilted her head, studying her with that quiet thoughtfulness she had when she suspected more than she let on.

Agatha hated that look. It never failed to make her feel exposed.

"Thanks," Rio said, taking Agatha by surprise. She expected an argument, another back and forth of I don't need your help and I don't care, I'm still helping. Somehow, the easy surrender felt worse. It meant Rio had stopped resisting her - had decided to accept the help, probably realizing the fight was futile in light of Agatha's stubbornness.

Agatha nodded, already halfway out the door. "I'll be right back."

Then she slipped out of the room, feeling Rio's eyes at the back of her neck like burning lasers.

The tray wasn't heavy, but Agatha carried it like it might tip under the weight of implication. She balanced a mug of tea, a glass of water, toast with a thick layer of butter - enough to clog an artery, just how Rio liked it - and a small bowl of sliced fruit. The painkillers sat in a neat pile beside the plate, accusing her with their silence.

She nudged the door open with her shoulder.

Rio looked up from where she was still propped against the headboard, her gaze sharper, more awake, but soft at the edges. The room smelled faintly of her perfume and eucalyptus.

Agatha moved silently, setting the tray on the nightstand and taking a step back under Rio's watchful gaze. The quiet lingered, making her hands move uselessly at her sides, itching to do anything. She didn't want to hover, didn't want her actions to reflect what she had realized during the night.

"Eat first," she said evenly, pointing toward the food. "You shouldn't take the meds on an empty stomach. Then I'll change the bandage."

Rio obeyed without complaint, reaching for the plate and biting into a piece of toast with her eyes still trained on Agatha. Like she knew something. Like she could sense it.

Agatha turned on her heel again, wordlessly walking out of the room to fetch the small first aid kit she had learned to keep around after one too many scraped knees. Nicky was an overall cautious child, not very prone to injuries, but whenever the twins were around, the carefulness flew out the window, leading to bruises and cuts she had to tend to.

When she rejoined Rio, the woman was nibbling on an apple slice, the toast and meds gone from the tray, and the cup of tea half-empty. Her eyes were trained on her phone, still lying on the nightstand, occasionally lighting up with new notifications. Agatha had put it on silent the night before, almost driven mad by the amount of texts Rio had been getting.

"I know it's against the doctor's orders," Rio said slowly as if testing the waters. "But I need to check my phone. Billy promised to let my abuela know I'm fine, but..."

Agatha's face twisted with anger before she could help it, the dread from seeing Rio squint at the screen the night before resurfacing.

She quickly reminded herself she had no right to tell Rio what to do. She was an adult, capable of making her own decisions, and Agatha was - what? Her fake wife? Somebody harboring an unwarranted crush? Neither of those things gave her the privilege of telling Rio what was best for her, even if it came from a place of care.

Wordlessly, Agatha moved to the other side of the bed and retrieved the phone, handing it to Rio without looking at her face. Then, just as silently, she started fiddling with the first aid kit, unzipping it and rummaging through the contents with more concentration than necessary.

She almost jumped when Rio's voice sounded in the room, warm and light.

"Hola, abuela."

Agatha focused on laying out the essential items, cramming them on the bedside table next to the tray. The steady flow of Spanish filled her ears, but her knowledge of the language wasn't remotely enough to make out more than a few buzzwords, one of which was her name, thrown into a long sentence she couldn't understand.

It dawned on her that she'd never asked Rio what her family thought of the sudden marriage. She didn't even know if Rio had told them about it. She must have said something, though, right? Otherwise, Agatha's name wouldn't come up in the conversation so effortlessly, as if she'd been a recurring topic during those calls.

But how much did Rio's grandmother know? Could Rio have told her about the deal, the money, and the temporality of the agreement? Or had she convinced her family that they were in love and married for a reason as simple as wanting to share a life?

Rio's impatient voice snapped her out of the spiral. "No, eso no hace falta. ¿Por qué? Porque estoy bien. ¿Le vas a creer más a una desconocida que a mí?"

There was some mumbling on the other end of the call, and Rio clenched her jaw, looking up at the ceiling as if praying for patience. "Está bien. Se lo voy a preguntar," she grumbled, eyes snapping to Agatha. "She wants to talk to you."
