Rio laughed, the sound warm and unbothered in a way that made the stone in Agatha's stomach shift, soften. It didn't disappear - she doubted it would be that easy - but it became more manageable to carry with Nicky's insistent tugging as he clung to them like he belonged right between them, fitting in like a small puzzle piece.

The balloon man looked like he'd stepped straight out of a circus or a carnival - bright vest, suspenders, and a grin that was far too wide for a morning spent around screaming children. Nicky bounced on his toes as he pointed at a sword, then changed his mind three times before finally deciding on a hat shaped like a coiled snake.

Rio crouched down beside him, chin propped on her hand, giving each option a gasp of awe like it was the most impressive creation in the world. "That's ferocious," she said gravely as the balloon snake was secured on Nicky's head. "No one at the park will dare mess with you now."

Nicky puffed out his chest, pulling at the hat with pride. "You better watch out too," he warned her, narrowing his eyes dramatically.

"Oh no," Rio said, staggering back with a hand over her heart. "That glare is lethal. You really are your mother's son."

Agatha pressed her lips together, stifling a laugh, and dropped a couple of bills in the man's tip jar - while pointedly ignoring the soft smile he was sending all three of them - before steering them back toward the open grass. The balloon hat bobbed dangerously with every bounce of Nicky's step, but his joy was magnetic, tugging them both along.

"Can I have a real snake?" he asked, looking at Agatha with his best pleading eyes as Rio busied herself with spreading out their picnic blanket.

Agatha sighed, reaching out to straighten out his newest wardrobe addition before it slid sideways off his head. "No."

"I'd take care of it!"

"Still no, baby."

Nicky huffed, chewing on his lower lip before smiling slyly. "Rio, can I have a real snake?"

Rio glanced up from where she was shaking out the blanket, eyes flicking between them. Her grin was equal parts wicked and indulgent. "That depends. How big a snake are we talking here? Tiny and cute, or the kind that eats your mom's shoes?"

Agatha shot her a sharp look, but Nicky's eyes went comically wide, his mind no doubt spiraling through visions of a snake rampaging through their house. "Shoes?" he whispered, scandalized.

"Oh yeah," Rio said seriously, tossing the backpack onto the blanket before plopping down next to it. "First, it'll take one. Then two. And then, before you know it-" She widened her eyes dramatically, pointing at Agatha's feet. "Barefoot. Forever."

Agatha pinched the bridge of her nose, torn between exasperation and the laugh threatening to burst out of her. "Rio..."

Nicky looked between the two women, studying their expressions before crossing his arms. "Snakes don't eat shoes," he said firmly.

"Well, not in the wild, of course," Rio agreed, nodding slowly. "There are no shoes there to eat. But here? In the city? Leather shoes are it for snakes."

Nicky squinted at her in suspicion, though his voice came out slightly concerned. "What about my shoes?"

"Hm," Rio hummed, scratching her chin in thought. "I suppose they'd be safe for a while. Your mom has enough to feed a snake for months, but once they're gone..."

She trailed off, staring at Nicky's sneakers pointedly. He squealed, tugging at his mother's arm. "Mama, we can't get a snake!" He said urgently, his face a mixture of horror and concern. "We wouldn't have any shoes left!"

That did it. Agatha barked out a laugh before she could stop herself, quickly trying to cover it with a cough. "Baby, no. Snakes don't eat shoes. That's not how they work."

Nicky blinked, his eyes sliding back to Rio. "They don't?"

Rio lifted both her hands in surrender, a guilty smile tugging at her mouth. "Okay, okay, I might've exaggerated a little. They don't eat shoes."

"Rio!" He exclaimed in a way so eerily similar to Agatha that both women froze for a fraction of a second. It was her exact cadence, her exact tone, like her own voice had been tossed back at her through a smaller, higher-pitched speaker.

Nicky, of course, didn't notice. He stood his ground, pointing an accusing finger at Rio. "You tried to trick me!"

"I mean, it kinda worked, didn't it?" Rio laughed, entirely unrepentant as she crossed her legs and leaned forward. "And you have to admit - it was a pretty good story."

Nicky tried to keep his glare, but it wobbled. His lips twitched once, twice, before laughter burst free, his body folding as he collapsed against the blanket. He nearly landed square in Rio's lap, and she moved without thinking, one hand bracing the back of his head while the other adjusted the precarious balloon hat.

"Yeah, it was," he admitted between giggles, his gaze tilting up toward his mother. "But I don't want a snake anymore."

Agatha caught the triumphant curve of Rio's mouth, a smirk just this side of smug, and she rolled her eyes. Still, her chest softened against her will. Rio's methods were always a little unorthodox, half-tease, half-chaos, but damn if they didn't usually work.

And looking at the two of them, tangled together on the blanket with the balloon bobbing between them like a flag of victory, Agatha couldn't quite decide whether the warmth in her chest was relief, affection, or something much, much more dangerous.

Before she could focus on it too much, Nicky popped back up like a spring, the hat falling onto the blanket, quickly forgotten. He scanned the wide lawn like he had a dozen new plans brewing in his head.

"Soccer!" he shouted, lunging for his backpack before either of them could even react.

"Careful with the-" She bit back the automatic lecture as he fumbled the ball against his knee and nearly tripped over the edge of the blanket. She pressed her lips together instead, settling for a quiet exhale. It wasn't as though he'd listen.

"Yeah, let's play," Rio said easily, rising to her feet in a single fluid motion. "We'll go two on one. Me and your mom against you."

Agatha shot her a sharp look. "I'm not participating," she said before she could stop herself. Her tone wasn't biting, not exactly, but she smoothed the edge down the moment it left her mouth, adding quickly, "You two are the soccer pros. I'll only slow you down."

Rio tilted her head, studying her with an expression that was far too perceptive for comfort. "It's not a championship game. Just a bit of fun."

"Yeah!" Nicky agreed quickly, passing the ball over to Rio, who trapped it under her foot with the ease of someone who'd done it a hundred times. "Lotta fun!"

Rio juggled the ball lazily against her foot, her smile tugging sideways. "Besides, if you're not out there, who's going to keep me from showing off too much? I have to live up to all the stories."

Agatha folded her arms, arching an eyebrow but biting back the automatic retort about Rio's already overinflated ego. Instead, she settled for a careful, "Nicky can keep you humble. He's very good at that."

"True," Rio agreed, glancing down at the boy beaming up at her. "But he's not half as good at heckling me as you are." She shifted her gaze back to Agatha, a spark of mischief lighting her eyes. "I think you're the only person alive who can make me feel like I'm losing when I'm winning."

The words made something shift in Agatha's chest. Was that a positive thing? The look in Rio's eyes said it was, but how could bringing somebody down be good? How could anybody want a partner who did that?

She shook her head as if it could stop the comment from lodging itself somewhere deep in her mind and turned toward the blanket. "Then Nicky will have to make sure he wins."

The boy groaned, tugging on her wrist to stop her from sitting down. "Mama, come on! Just a little bit?"

Agatha smoothed his hair, but the balloon had left it unruly and electrified, making it jump right back up. "You and Rio can run circles around me, baby. You'll have more fun without me tripping all over the place."

Rio's chuckle drifted over. "Don't tell me the great Agatha Harkness is afraid of looking silly."

Agatha's throat tightened at the phrasing - half a dare, half a tease - and she had to look away before her expression betrayed the flood of conflicting thoughts it stirred up. She reached for the picnic blanket instead, lowering herself onto it with forced ease. "I'm just practical," she said, plucking up her water as though that ended the matter. "Someone has to keep an eye on the snacks and Nicky's new hat."

For a second, she thought Rio might push further. But then Nicky kicked the ball out from under her foot, and her attention pivoted back to him, the game sparkling to life between them with effortless energy.

Agatha rested her back against the tree, taking a slow sip of the water as she watched the pair dart across the grass, the morning sun bathing them in its warm rays.

It struck her that she'd never seen them like this. Rio had been present in Nicky's world for months now, but in more measured ways. In the kitchen, where she hovered close enough to steady his small hands before something landed on the floor. In the garden, where Nicky took his duties far too seriously to allow much room for chaos. Even the movie nights had a certain structure to them - laughter, yes, but framed within the walls of their house and its routines.

This was different.

Here, the rules fell away. Rio wasn't guiding or supervising; she was chasing, dodging, laughing like a kid herself. And Nicky, wild and unrestrained, sprinted after her without a care in the world. Whenever Rio got too far, her long legs an obvious advantage, he shrieked in protest that mixed with a giggle as the woman slowed enough to let him catch up.

Agatha's chest tightened, watching them. It wasn't that joy had been absent from their lives before - Nicky had never lacked for laughter or affection. But this was a different kind of lightness, the kind Rio seemed to carry in her stride and then spill into the world around her.

Agatha had never seen her quite like this.

At home, Rio's presence often came with a steadiness that balanced Agatha's sharper edges: attentive in the kitchen, thoughtful in conversation, reliable in ways that had rooted themselves into their routines. But here, out on the grass, that steadiness gave way to something freer. She was running with abandon, letting out a triumphant whoop when she stole the ball from Nicky, collapsing into laughter when he managed to slip it past her a moment later.

The shift startled Agatha. She hadn't realized how much Rio held herself back until she wasn't doing it anymore. There was a looseness in her posture, a boyish grin stretched across her face, and - God help her - an ease that made Agatha's throat tight. It was the kind of sight she'd never been allowed to imagine wanting: Rio happy, radiant, unburdened by expectation.

And worse - it was the kind of sight she could get used to.

Her eyes tracked the movements, sliding to Rio more often than she'd admit.

The athleticism didn't surprise her - after all, she'd gotten her hand injured because of Rio's distracting physique - but the utter lack of self-consciousness did. Rio was all motion and grin and flushed cheeks, hair plastering itself to her forehead as if the summer air couldn't quite keep up with her.

And Agatha just... stared. Long enough that her water went warm in her hand. Long enough that Nicky scored two more times, crowing his victory. Long enough for Rio to notice.

Shit.

Even mid-laugh, Rio's eyes cut toward the tree, finding Agatha instantly, like she'd been aware of the gaze on her all along. The grin softened into something slower, more dangerous.

Agatha's stomach plummeted. She straightened too quickly, her mouth, which had been embarrassingly hanging open, snapping shut as she forced her eyes down to the patchy grass at the blanket's edge.

When she glanced back up, Rio was already jogging toward her, Nicky lagging a few steps behind and protesting loudly about needing a rematch as if he hadn't won. She came to a stop in front of Agatha, cheeks flushed, chest rising with quick, shallow breaths, her grin still firmly in place.

"You know," Rio said, brushing damp hair off her forehead with the back of her wrist. Agatha followed the movement like a cat following a laser beam. "You'll burn holes in me if you stare any harder."

Agatha's lips parted, a sharp retort ready on the tip of her tongue, but she caught herself again, the words sticking in her throat. Instead, she reached for the safest ground she could find. "I'm brushing up on my soccer knowledge."

It came out flatter than intended, and she instantly hated how careful she sounded. Like she was weighing every syllable before handing it over.

Rio tilted her head, eyes narrowing the barest fraction. But she didn't tease back. Not immediately. Instead, she bent down, bracing her hands on her thighs so she was level with Agatha. "You could do that by participating," she said, her voice low. "Because something tells me you're not admiring my technique."

Heat clawed its way up Agatha's neck, and she glanced over Rio's shoulder where Nicky was staring at them impatiently.

She cleared her throat, tilting her chin in his direction. "He's waiting," she said, voice steady despite her burning cheeks. "Better go before he physically drags you back onto the field."

Rio raised her brows, but before she could say anything, Nicky's patience ran out.

"Rio!" he groaned, tapping his foot against the ball. "You promised a rematch!"

Brown eyes lingered on Agatha for a second longer, sliding across her face as if cataloging every microexpression for later. Their weight was almost tangible, like a steady hand gently touching her skin and feeling every tense muscle.

Just as the scrutiny started becoming too much, Rio straightened up, redirecting her attention back to Nicky.

"Yeah, yeah, I'm coming," she said, her grin returning full force as she jogged back to the boy.

Agatha let out a breath she didn't know she was holding, watching her girlfriend easily steal the ball from Nicky and sprint toward the imaginary goalposts.

For a moment, she allowed herself to just watch. To memorize the picture of Rio sprinting across the grass, her hair coming loose from its tie, her smile brighter than the sun.

Then something caught her eye.

It was subtle at first - so subtle that Nicky didn't notice, too caught up in defending his side of the field. But Agatha's gaze was sharp, honed over the years of cataloging the smallest details and searching for weaknesses. When Rio pivoted too quickly on her right leg, she didn't spring forward the way she had before. Her stride hitched, the motion jerky, followed by the tiniest wince that flickered across her face before she masked it with a laugh.

Agatha's stomach clenched.

She sat forward instantly, her pulse quickening with an urgency that had nothing to do with the game. Her eyes tracked Rio's movements now with precision, no longer the indulgent stare of a smitten girlfriend but the sharp focus of someone waiting for confirmation of what she already knew.

And there it was again. A fraction of hesitation every time Rio put weight on her right side. A limp so fleeting it would've been invisible to anyone else.

"Fuck," Agatha muttered under her breath, pushing herself to her feet before her brain could catch up with her body.

By the time she reached the edge of the makeshift field, Rio had just stolen the ball again, triumph flashing across her face. But Agatha wasn't looking at the joy anymore. She was looking at the way Rio shifted her weight, trying to disguise the strain.

"That's enough," Agatha called out, her voice sharper than she intended.

Both Rio and Nicky froze.

"But, Mom," Nicky complained, already sensing she was about to end the fun. "We were just-"

"Break time," Agatha cut in, firm but not unkind, her eyes never leaving Rio's. She crossed her arms, narrowing her gaze like she dared Rio to argue. "Now."

Rio straightened, the grin slipping, replaced by something more guarded. She brushed a hand across her damp forehead, then glanced at her leg as though surprised Agatha had noticed.

Nicky looked between them, clearly confused, but Agatha didn't waver. Not when she could see through every mask Rio tried to put up.

"Water," Agatha added, softening her tone deliberately for Nicky's sake. "Both of you. Come sit down."

Rio's eyes flicked from Agatha to Nicky, the familiar spark of defiance already igniting in her expression. She bent to scoop up the ball, twirling it in her hands with exaggerated nonchalance.

"I'm good," she said, casual but a little too quick. "It's only been like forty minutes. I can go for longer than that."

The double meaning was clear, punctuated by the small smirk stretching her lips, but Agatha refused to let it get to her. Not when the brightness didn't quite reach Rio's eyes and the edges of her smirk were fraying.

"Don't do that," Agatha's tone remained measured, toeing the line between ordering and coaxing. "Don't pretend nothing's wrong when I see it plain as day."

Nicky frowned, glancing between the two women. "What's wrong?"

"Nothing's-"

"Rio's knee is bothering her," Agatha cut in smoothly, shooting her girlfriend a warning look before turning back to her son. "Remember when she told you she hurt it back in high school?"

Nicky nodded, his face quickly clouding with worry.

"Well, sometimes when you get hurt like that, even if it's really old and healed, it can still ache once in a while," Agatha explained, softening her tone. "Kind of like when you scrape your knee, and even after the scab's gone, it still feels sore if you bump it. That's why breaks are important."

Nicky's mouth turned down as she shuffled closer to Rio, gently taking the ball out of her hands as if afraid she'd buckle under the weight. "You need a break," he said earnestly, grabbing onto Rio's hand to steer her toward the blanket.

The embers of protest fizzled out in the woman's eyes, giving way to begrudging acceptance as she followed him. Agatha suspected the objections would've been much fiercer and more vocal had it not been for Nicky's obvious concern, which immediately subdued Rio's instinctive need to pretend everything was fine.

Still, Agatha saw a fraction of that instinct in Rio's steps - measured but certain as if she wanted her body to communicate what her mouth couldn't. It only made the limp more evident.

Rio lowered herself onto the blanket with a muttered, "Traitor," aimed at Nicky, though the boy didn't catch it - or if he did, he chose to ignore it. He plopped down beside her, eyes glued to her knee like he expected it to show signs of injury.

"It looks okay," he said slowly, glancing up at Rio. "Will you tell me how it happened now?"

The question surprised Agatha. With the amount of time they'd spent talking about soccer and what Nicky had dubbed 'Rio's glory days', she expected her son to know the story inside out - the weather, humidity, and the opposing team's name included.

But it did make sense. Rio had a way of skimming past the parts of her life that didn't fit neatly into a funny anecdote or a motivational line. She never outright lied, but she also didn't linger on things that carried weight. Especially around Nicky.

"Guess I never told you, huh?" Rio said, her tone easy but a shade too practiced. Her hand fiddled with the water bottle Agatha had handed to her, unscrewing the cap a little slower than usual.

Nicky shook his head, already hanging onto her every word. "Just that it was an accident."

Rio tipped the bottle back for a long drink, buying herself time. When she lowered it again, her smile was there, quick and crooked, though Agatha didn't miss the flicker of hesitation in her eyes. "Well," she began, stretching her legs out in front of her, "it was during a game. I was running fast, as fast as I could, chasing the ball. Then someone came at me from the side, and-" She snapped her fingers, the sound sharp enough to make Nicky flinch. "Knee went out. Just like that."

Nicky's eyes widened. "It just... broke?"

"Not broke, exactly," Rio corrected gently. She leaned back on one palm, tracing a circle in the blanket with her other hand as though she needed to keep it busy. "But it tore. Which meant a lot of doctors, a lot of ice, and a lot of being told to sit down when all I wanted to do was get up and play again."

Agatha's chest tightened at the way Rio's voice softened on that last part. It wasn't the full story. Rio might have never told her the details of her accident, but she knew enough to realize the woman had glossed over some important parts. Like the months of grueling rehab that had surely followed and the crushing blow of having her trajectory derailed right when it mattered most. She wasn't hiding it for her own sake, though. She was shielding Nicky.

The boy's face scrunched, lips pressing together as though he were trying to absorb every detail. "Does it still hurt?"

"Sometimes," Rio admitted with a shrug, flashing him an easy grin to undercut the truth. "But not enough to stop me from running circles around you."

That earned a small laugh from Nicky, though the worry didn't completely leave his eyes as he kept glancing between Rio's injured knee and her face.

"That's why stretching is important," Rio added, sensing his unease. "And paying attention to the other players on the field. If I'd seen the girl coming in, I could've tried to avoid the collision."

It was an empty reassurance. Agatha might not have known much about soccer, but she knew stretching wouldn't have saved the ligament from tearing. Especially not when somebody had plummeted into it.

But Nicky didn't know that, and he nodded quickly, absorbing the words like a sponge. "We should've stretched before playing," he said solemnly.

Rio patted his hand sympathetically, offering a crooked smile. "A lesson for next time. One I should've learned years ago, considering my advanced age."

Nicky let out a small laugh, though his brows still pinched together. He reached for the ball, holding it protectively against his chest. "You shouldn't play anymore," he muttered. "I'll... I'll play with the other kids for now."

Agatha raised her brows at the sudden concession, hiding her surprise behind a sip of her own water. Nicky's gaze already strayed toward a group of children chasing each other near the swings, the itch to join them written all over his body.

"Go on, baby," she encouraged him softly, brushing a hand over his hair when he turned back to ask for permission. "Make some friends. We'll watch from here."

That was all it took. Nicky shot to his feet and bolted across the grass, the ball tucked securely under his arm like he was already mid-game.

Agatha watched him for a moment, making sure he didn't topple anyone over in his excitement, before letting her shoulders sag with a quiet exhale. The park seemed louder suddenly, kids shouting and parents chatting, but their little corner on the blanket felt like its own pocket of quiet. She settled back into her spot, back against the tree, while Rio lay down fully, head propped on Nicky's backpack as she stared up at the leaves swaying above them.

It felt peaceful, but Agatha could sense the undercurrent of something tenser. Something unsaid.

She let the silence linger for a moment before it became impossible to ignore. "He'll probably make you stretch before you do anything now," she mused, but the words came out too careful, too restrained for the joke to land.

The only reaction she got was a half-hearted hum.

Agatha's eyes flicked sideways at the sound. Normally, it meant contentment - satisfaction after a good meal or seeing something bloom in the garden. But this one was different. Flat. A placeholder more than a response.

She shifted against the tree trunk, fighting the urge to smooth her shirt just to keep her hands occupied. "You don't agree?" she asked lightly, like they weren't walking straight into a minefield.

Rio rolled her head to the side, looking at her from where she was sprawled on the blanket. Her eyes narrowed the faintest bit, like she was studying a problem she couldn't quite solve. "I'd agree if you meant it as a joke," she said plainly. "But that sounded like... a line out of a parenting manual."

"I was joking," Agatha bristled, caught between the urge to defend herself and the deeper prickle of embarrassment that Rio had noticed.

"Right." Rio turned her gaze back to the canopy above them, exhaling through her nose. "I guess you've been 'joking' all morning. But it doesn't sound like you."

Agatha's chest tightened. She stared at the blanket, picking at a loose string just to have something to do. "Maybe I'm just having a day."

Rio let out a soft laugh, but it wasn't amused. "No, Agatha. You're holding back. Like you're worried I'll break if you so much as tease me."

A part of her wasn't even surprised that Rio had clocked her restraint after a mere few hours. It was a clear disruption in their dynamics, even though Agatha had tried to play it off as best as she could, and she should've realized it was a matter of time before Rio brought it up.

But there was something else under her tone too, simmering beneath the irritation. Agatha replayed the moment on the field - the hitch in Rio's step, her immediate brush-off, the way she would've kept going if Agatha hadn't stepped in.

"You're annoyed," Agatha said slowly, testing the waters.

Rio's jaw ticked. "I don't like being pulled out of a game when I didn't ask to be."

Agatha frowned. "You were limping."

"I was fine."

"You weren't."

That finally earned her Rio's full attention. She pushed up onto her elbows, dark eyes sharpening. "Well, that's not up to you to decide, is it?" she asked firmly. "You don't get to choose what I can and cannot handle, and step in or withdraw whenever you feel like it."

Agatha's breath hitched. For a moment, they just stared at each other, silence taut between them. Around them, kids shrieked and laughed, the sounds of the park clashing against the tension sitting heavy in the space mapped out by the blanket.

It was clear Rio wasn't just talking about the soccer field.

Her tongue pressed against her teeth, words coiled and ready - snide, dismissive, safe. It was the kind of retort she'd been avoiding all morning. The kind sharp enough that she was sure it would cut Rio deep enough to make her rethink their entire relationship.

So, she held it back, settling on a slow exhale as if it could rid her mouth of the venom poised on her tongue. "Well," she muttered, tearing her eyes away from Rio to check on Nicky, running around the field with a few other kids without a care in the world, "forgive me for not wanting to watch you get hurt when it's avoidable."

Rio sat up fully, tucking her left leg while the right remained stretched out. "I'm not fragile, Agatha." Her tone wasn't cruel, but steady - unyielding. "I've lived with this injury long enough to know my limits. And I've lived with you long enough to not shatter when you roll your eyes too hard."

Agatha's head snapped up, temper prickling even as her chest squeezed tight. "So what? You'd rather have me cut you down every other sentence? Make you feel like you're losing when you're winning? Because I may not be a relationship expert, but having your girlfriend treat you like an opponent to spar with seems fucked up."

The word girlfriend slipped out sharper than she meant, like it was too new, too fragile to sit on her tongue without bristling.

Rio's eyes softened the slightest fraction, though the set of her jaw didn't. "I already told you that I like your sharp edges."

Agatha blinked, breath catching, every retort scattered by the sheer steadiness in Rio's voice. She wanted to argue, to tell her she was wrong, that those edges ruined things, drove people away. That they weren't something anyone should like.

But Rio was still staring at her like she meant every word.

Agatha scoffed, waving her hand dismissively. "You keep saying that, but-"

"No, Agatha." Rio interrupted, leaning in close enough that Agatha felt the warmth of her knee brush against her own. "There's no but here. It's up to me to decide what I can handle. It's up to me to know that sanding yourself down isn't what I want."

Agatha's throat tightened as the words sank past every defense she'd spent years perfecting. She opened her mouth, then closed it again, fingers curling into the blanket like it could anchor her.

Rio didn't let up. "I don't want the careful version of you. I don't want the polite edits. I want you. All of you. Sharp edges, bad jokes, messy moods. That's who I chose." Her gaze softened, but her voice stayed unshakably certain. "So stop trying to sell me this... sanitized version. Because I'm not going anywhere."

Agatha swallowed hard, but her chest still felt too tight, her body still locked in place like any wrong move would send her shattering. She hated how much she wanted to believe her. How much she wanted to reach for Rio, to let the words soak in instead of ricocheting off the old scars that told her nothing good ever stayed.

She shook her head, forcing a brittle laugh. "That's like holding onto a blade and hoping it won't cut you," she said, eyes locked on the grass, on anything but Rio's face. "And I can be good. I can dull the blade. Change. If you just give me time-"

"Stop. Just... stop."

The warmth of a hand settled firmly on her knee, grounding her, though Agatha kept her eyes stubbornly ahead. She didn't dare look, not when she knew that warmth was in Rio's gaze too, patient and steady enough to undo her with one glance.

"I've never asked you to do that," Rio said, her voice softer now, but edged with a conviction that left no room for argument. "What makes you think I'd ever want that?"

Agatha let out a short, humorless laugh that scraped raw in her throat. "Every single relationship I've ever had? People say they don't mind the baggage, but everybody has a breaking point, and I-" She faltered, had to force the words out past the lump in her throat. "I don't want to reach yours."

Her jaw clenched, and she kept the rest buried - kept back the admission that she'd never wanted anyone enough to even consider changing. Never thought anyone was worth rewriting herself for. Until Rio. And that thought terrified her more than anything.

Her body screamed at her to run, to tear herself free from the blanket, from Rio's touch, from the slow unraveling she hadn't expected to happen in the middle of a public park of all places.

But before she could move, Rio shifted closer, her presence steady, the grip of her hand tightening on Agatha's leg. A quiet anchor. A subtle challenge.

"Do you know why I like you the way you are?"

Agatha's lips twitched, reflexes snapping back into place before she could choke them down. "Because you're a masochist?" she huffed, shutting her eyes like slamming a door, already regretting the sharpness in her own voice. The joke was bitter, too much, a shard meant to deflect.

So much for dulling the knife, she thought grimly.

But Rio only chuckled. The sound was warm, unhurried, completely unbothered by the barbed edges Agatha had flashed like warning shots.

"There she is." The hand on Agatha's knee gentled, sliding into slow, absent circles against the fabric of her slacks. It was tender in a way that made Agatha's chest ache. "But no. That's not the reason."

Rio leaned in, just close enough that Agatha could feel the steady hum of her presence. "I like you the way you are because you're real. You don't fake it. You don't hide behind sweet lies or half-smiles when you're upset. You give the world the raw version of you, even when you think it'll scare people off. And it doesn't scare me. It makes me trust you."

Agatha's breath snagged, her eyes squeezing tighter shut against the burn behind them.

Trust.

Of all the words Rio could have chosen, that was the one that cut deepest - and yet, somehow, didn't hurt at all.

"Besides," Rio added, voice lighter but no less firm, "it's nice to have a - what did you call it? A sparing partner? Especially one that can keep up with me."

Agatha almost managed a huff of amusement, but it dissolved before it reached her lips. The burn in her chest hadn't faded, not with that one word still lodged inside her like a glowing ember. Trust.

But when she finally dared to look at Rio again, she didn't find the teasing ease that usually followed the jabs. Her girlfriend's eyes were sharp, steady in a way that made Agatha's stomach twist.

"And since we're being real here..." Rio's tone softened, but the edge underneath didn't go away. "We agreed to talk things through. No leaving each other guessing. Remember?"

Agatha stiffened. She did remember, though, like so many times before, she hadn't promised Rio anything solid that night in the living room. Just that she'd try.

"You told me I don't have to tell you everything right away."

The fingers on her knee paused as Rio shifted. "That's true," she said slowly. "But don't you think it's worth mentioning if it affects your mood that much? If it makes you change your entire personality?"

Agatha's jaw flexed, a protest scraping its way up her throat. "You're one to talk," she said tightly. "What about your knee? You were limping, I called you out, and you tried to brush me off. Isn't that the same thing?"

Rio blinked, her expression unreadable for a moment, before her lips pressed into a thin line.

Agatha pushed on, too unsettled to stop herself. "You're asking me to bare it all the second I feel off, but when it was your turn, you didn't want me to know. You wanted to pretend everything was fine. So forgive me if I don't see the difference."

The silence that followed was taut enough to snap, the sounds of the park not enough to penetrate it. Agatha braced for a sharp retort, but Rio just studied her, eyes dark and searching, and it made her want to squirm.

Finally, Rio's voice came, insistent like she was trying to break through a wall brick by brick. "The difference is that I was being stubborn. You-" She paused, leaning in the smallest bit. "You were being scared. And those aren't the same thing."

Heat crawled up Agatha's neck again. It sounded preposterous. She was Agatha fucking Harkness. Fear wasn't something she felt, let alone allowed to dictate her behavior.

But there was nothing else that could explain the shift, the sudden urge to adjust her personality.

Because she was afraid that Rio would leave.

And she hated herself for it, just as much as she hated Rio for seeing it.

Her throat bobbed with the swallow she forced down. The admission clawed at her ribs, raw and jagged, and she refused to let it out. Not here. Not while Rio was watching her like she could peel back every layer with nothing more than patience and persistence.

"I'm not scared," she finally said, the words clipped, unconvincing even to her own ears. "I was... being careful."

Rio's brow knit, the faintest crease between them, like she was weighing the word and finding it hollow. "Careful," she echoed. "Or controlled?"

"Controlled is better than reckless," Agatha said tightly, eyes drifting away from Rio's face to focus on a group of kids chasing bubbles in the distance. "At least it doesn't ruin things."

Rio let the silence stretch just long enough to sting before answering. "Or it keeps you from ever really having them in the first place."

Agatha's breath caught, sharp and uneven. The words landed like a stone in her chest, sending ripples out to every part of her that she'd tried to keep calm.

She almost snapped back, almost let the familiar venom coat her tongue. But when she glanced sideways, Rio wasn't gloating. She wasn't smirking. She was just looking at her - open, intent, like she was daring Agatha to stop running circles around herself and finally say it.

Agatha sighed, gaze sliding down to the blanket. "What if I do ruin it?"

Rio's hand disappeared from her knee, but before the sudden absence of warmth could register, it grabbed her chin, gently guiding her to look into two pools of warmth and understanding.

"Then you tell me," Rio said simply, as if it were the most obvious thing in the world. "Not the blanket. Not the grass. Me."

Agatha frowned, though her hand hung a little heavier, leaning into the touch. "After I ruin it? That doesn't make any sense."

"It does if you'll be willing to fix it," Rio replied simply, her thumb grazing Agatha's cheek. "We'll both make mistakes in this. We'll stumble and argue and try to find our footing again. That's inevitable. What matters is how we handle it."

Agatha's lips pressed together, her chest tightening at the certainty in Rio's tone. It was too easy for her, too simple, like she'd already made peace with every possible disaster.

Agatha, on the other hand, lived in disasters. They were familiar. Predictable. People left, trust broke, things burned. And now here Rio was, saying it wouldn't be the end of the world if Agatha tripped and dragged her down with her.

Her jaw flexed under Rio's fingers. "You make it sound like it's not a big deal. Like everything can... just be patched up with tape."

Rio's gaze softened, but her hold didn't waver. "Not tape," she said gently. "Work. Patience. Wanting to try again. That's what makes it last. Not pretending mistakes don't happen."

"There's a good chance that I won't know how to fix it," she pointed out, though her voice came out more tired than confrontational. "That I won't even know something's broken until it's too late."

"You won't be fixing it alone."

The words settled between them, so simple and so terrifying that Agatha didn't know whether to laugh or cry. Her instinct screamed at her to pull away, to retreat before Rio saw the cracks splitting wider across her composure. But her body betrayed her, leaning that fraction closer into the touch, her heart hammering so hard she was certain Rio could feel it through her palm.

"You really believe that?" she asked, voice low and almost disbelieving.

"I wouldn't be here if I didn't."

Agatha swallowed hard, her pulse skittering under Rio's thumb. The heat in Rio's gaze held her tighter than her hand, steady and insistent, like she could anchor Agatha through sheer will alone.

"Rio..." Her voice was rough, caught somewhere between warning and plea.

"Agatha," Rio murmured back, leaning in just slightly, just enough for Agatha to feel the brush of her breath against her lips. Her hand slid from her chin to cup her cheek, and Agatha's defenses trembled, faltering under the weight of everything she hadn't dared to want.

She should've stopped it. Should have remembered the boy only a few yards away, the promise they'd made to keep this secret. But in that moment, with Rio's warmth seeping into her skin, she wanted nothing more than to close the distance.

Her eyes fluttered shut, a fraction too ready, when-

"Mama! Rio!"

Both women jolted apart like guilty teenagers, Rio's hand dropping as Agatha snapped her gaze toward the field. Nicky came tearing back across the grass, the ball tucked under his arm.

"I scored!" he shouted, breathless and beaming. "Did you see?"

Agatha forced her lips into a smile, her heart still racing for a very different reason. "Of course, baby. You were amazing."

"Yeah, great form, buddy," Rio added quickly, subtly shuffling back on the blanket until she was at the very edge.

Nicky threw himself into the space between them, grabbing for the water bottle as though he hadn't just almost caught them doing something he wasn't supposed to see. He launched into an animated retelling of his victory, arms waving and words tumbling out too fast to catch.

Agatha nodded along, listening with half an ear, though her pulse hadn't settled. She could feel Rio's presence even with Nicky separating them, the space between them suddenly charged in a way the boy would never notice - but she would. Every second.

And as she tucked an arm around her son, pulling him closer while he chattered, she couldn't shake the phantom of Rio's touch lingering against her skin.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! Not much to say, just thanks for reading, and keep in mind that the next chapter(s) might be late.

Chapter 34: Lonely in a full house

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

In hindsight, deciding to start a relationship with summer just around the corner wasn't the best idea.

School was out, which meant Nicky was around more than ever. Not all the time - Agatha had made sure of that by signing him up for a day soccer camp that would occupy most of his mornings and early afternoons. It gave her peace of mind while she was at work, knowing he wasn't cooped up at home with too much energy and not enough outlets.

But camp ended long before her workday did.

Before Rio, Agatha would have had Sharon step in during those long, empty hours. It had never been ideal - shockingly, Sharon had a life of her own, and was sometimes unavailable, and Wanda, while more than willing, had her own children to wrangle - but it was a system. A patchwork of favors, babysitting fees, and careful schedule-juggling that, while imperfect, had kept their summers afloat.

This year should have been no different. Agatha had braced herself for the same logistical nightmare, ready to endure the headaches for the sake of stability.

But Rio had upended the system with quiet stubbornness.

With her newfound reluctance to leave Nicky in Sharon's care when there were other options - although she'd cleared up the misunderstanding about Agatha's infidelity and Sharon had apologized for assuming - Rio had volunteered herself for the gaps. She'd rearranged her life with an ease that made Agatha unsettled: picking up extra shifts but scheduling them for late evenings, moving her own academic work to early mornings, and carving out her afternoons specifically for Nicky.

Agatha hadn't asked her to do it. In fact, she'd vehemently argued against it. But Rio had insisted.

And so the rhythm of summer shifted, not for Agatha but for Rio.

Agatha told herself she wasn't worried about competence - Rio was more than capable of driving Nicky home, making sure he ate something with actual nutritional value, and soaking up his post-camp energy with soccer drills or garden work. The problem wasn't whether Rio could. The problem was that she did.

Because Nicky wasn't her responsibility.

And yet, every evening when Agatha returned, she was met with the same scene: her son glowing with delight, tugging Rio into yet another round of one-on-one, while Rio's laptop sat abandoned on the dining table, a half-finished sentence staring at Agatha accusatorily.

It wasn't that Agatha didn't love it. She did. She loved the way Rio threw herself into Nicky's games, laughing as if every feint were worthy of a highlight reel, cheering him on with a fervor that made him puff up with pride. Agatha could watch them for hours - and often did.

But beneath the warmth, the guilt gnawed. Rio was supposed to be writing her dissertation, not sacrificing her focus to play stand-in summer counselor.

And if that weren't enough, the arrangement had carved their relationship into something lopsided. Between Nicky's endless energy, Rio's stacked bar shifts, and the dissertation work she shoved into whatever hours remained, there wasn't much left for Agatha herself. They hadn't had an evening - or even an hour without the possibility of Nicky barging in at any given moment - alone since the date.

Which was another reason why starting a relationship just before summer started had been a major miscalculation. Everything felt suspended - their new connection, the delicate balance they were trying to build, the chance to learn what 'them' actually looked like when it wasn't wrapped in the trappings of shared obligations.

Mornings in the kitchen, scarce even before the summer, were entirely gone now. Agatha left the house shortly after sunrise, herding her overeager son towards the car in silent defeat while the rest of the house remained quiet. By the time Rio even made it downstairs, Agatha was already on her second meeting at the office.

Weekends weren't much better. Rio worked late on Friday and Saturday nights, and her footsteps didn't sound on the stairs until well past midmorning. By then, Nicky had already demolished half the pantry and dragged Agatha into two board games she only half-paid attention to. Rio would eventually wander down, hair mussed, voice hoarse from exhaustion, looking apologetic before being immediately pulled into whatever adventure Nicky had going.

Evenings had turned into their own kind of ache. Some nights, Rio wasn't home at all, swallowed by the bar until last call. Others, she slipped in with shoulders sagging and eyes glassy with fatigue, collapsing on the couch for no more than thirty minutes before excusing herself for bed. If Nicky wasn't already asleep, she gave him her last scraps of energy - a brief story, a quick round of Mario Kart - before disappearing upstairs. By the time Agatha went to bed, Rio's room was dead silent.

It left Agatha caught in the in-between: not alone, not together, suspended in the strange limbo of being someone's girlfriend and wife in theory, but not in practice. Their stolen moments - a shared look over Nicky's head, fingers brushing as they reached for the same plate, a quick kiss when the boy wasn't in the room - felt less like steps forward and more like reminders of what they weren't having.

And the worst part was that Agatha couldn't blame her. Rio was stretched thin between Nicky, the bar, and the deadlines that loomed over her head. The little time she did carve out was for Nicky, not her. Which, rationally, made sense. Which, rationally, Agatha should have been grateful for.

Rationality, however, took a backseat in light of the quiet ache that had settled somewhere between Agatha's ribs and refused to budge - the ache shaped like missing someone despite seeing them every day.

They'd talked about communication. Rio had told her to be more forthcoming and not let doubts eat at her without voicing them. But could she really raise the issue without sounding selfish? Without sounding jealous of her own child getting more of her girlfriend's attention than her?

She told herself she should be proud of the bond between them. After all, Nicky was the most important person in her life, and although he didn't know their relationship had turned into something more than a partnership, it warmed her heart to hear their shared laughter echo through the backyard when she returned home. But it didn't erase the hollowed-out part of her, the one that noticed when Rio used the last bits of her energy to play video games with Nicky instead of saving them for her.

She'd even tried once - tiptoeing toward the subject like the ground beneath her might crumble if she pressed too hard. She'd hinted at another date night, something simple, safe. A movie at home, a dinner without interruptions, anything that wasn't tagged with the words babysitting duty or research.

But the moment she'd mentioned Wanda had offered to pick Nicky up from camp and keep him overnight, Rio's eyes had lit up - not at the thought of an evening alone together, but at the opportunity to catch up on field notes. Agatha hadn't corrected her, and by the time Rio had returned - too tired even to see straight, much less hold a conversation - she'd merely pecked her cheek before turning in, the ache growing with every step toward her empty bedroom.

She hadn't brought it up again.

Agatha told herself it was unreasonable, mostly because there wasn't much to miss. The honeymoon phase of their relationship ended before it could have truly begun, cut short somewhere between their visit to the park and the start of exam season. They hadn't had the string of stolen evenings alone that other couples took for granted. They hadn't even shared a bed since before they got together. Their 'relationship' so far had been pieced together from conversations stolen between responsibilities, a kiss here, a touch there, never long enough to build momentum before duty tugged one of them away.

And yet, the absence of those moments only made her long for them more.

Sometimes, when she returned to an empty house and a garden filled with laughter, Agatha would catch herself pausing at the window, watching from inside like she had so many times before. She knew she could invade the space now, knew Rio wanted her in the garden, but the obnoxious staring was easier from the shadows.

So, she stood and watched as Rio kneeled between the raised beds, dropping ripe tomatoes or cucumbers into the bowl in Nicky's hands, laughing at something he'd said.

It was an ordinary sight, but it gnawed at Agatha's composure like a rampant beast. Because she wanted to brush the streak of dirt from Rio's face and kiss her until her hands shook from more than just exhaustion. She wanted to grab one of her uncovered, lean arms and drag her inside.

But instead, she stayed by the window for a moment too long to be anything but desperate, convincing herself she had no right to feel frustrated when Rio was already giving so much of herself to their little household.

No right to crave her time.

No right to crave her touch.

Even if the craving coiled tighter in her chest with every unspent glance, every missed chance to reach out.

Besides, her own hunger was the least of her worries. Agatha had perfected the art of pushing down her own needs for those she cared about, and she cared about Rio more than she was ready to admit. Which meant she could see the exhaustion etched into the slouch of Rio's shoulders, the way her smile at Nicky grew thinner by the end of the day. Still, Rio never turned him down when he bounded up with a ball in hand or begged to show her the newest addition to his Minecraft world.

Agatha saw it, but couldn't do anything to stop it. Not when Rio shut down her attempts at intervening with a dismissive wave of her hand or a soft but tired - always tired - smile tossed over her shoulder when Nicky dragged her away. The limited time they had together barely sufficed for a few murmured sentences and a chaste kiss, let alone a lengthy conversation about Rio's responsibilities around the house and Agatha's growing worry.

Still, she knew it was only a matter of time before the strain showed in something clearer than thin smiles and weary sighs. She just didn't expect it to be so small, so ordinary, when it finally did.

It was a Wednesday evening, the lingering rays of the sun still stubbornly barging into the house through the windows, when the breaking point came. Nicky, sticky with popsicle juice, tugged at Rio's arm the moment she dropped her bag on one of the chairs by the dining table.

"Come on, Rio, just five minutes! You promised you'd show me that spin again when you came back!"

"I know, I know, just-" Rio scrubbed a hand over her face, her laptop bag sliding off her shoulder with a thud. "I just need a second, Nicky. Please?"

The words weren't harsh, but they carried a weary edge, one Rio had made sure to smooth out whenever she talked to the boy before.

Nicky blinked, his grin faltering like a balloon losing air. He let go of her arm slowly, staring up at her as if she'd just grown three heads. "But... you said-"

"Nicky," Agatha interrupted, her tone low and even as she closed her own laptop and stood. The crack in Rio's composure was small, but it was enough - her opening. "How about we let Rio sit down and eat something? You can show me what she's already taught you."

He frowned, suspicion flickering across his features. His eyes flicked back to Rio, waiting, clearly unconvinced. "But she'll come later?"

Before Rio could summon the answer - Agatha could already hear the guilty concession in her head - she stepped in again. She rested her hand against the back of his neck, smoothing down the tufts of hair he'd begged her to cut short for summer. "Rio's not made of the same stuff you are, baby," she said with a small, coaxing smile. "She doesn't have endless batteries like you do. If you run her too hard, she'll break, and then we'll never get our spin back. So we've got to cut her some slack, don't we?"

Nicky's mouth pulled sideways, his brain clearly weighing whether or not this counted as betrayal. Finally, he sighed with all the gravity of an old man. "Okay. But you have to promise to look the entire time I show you. No blinking."

Agatha chuckled, giving him a light squeeze on the shoulder. "I promise." She tipped her head toward the backyard. "Go set up. I'll be right there."

The boy darted off, the bounce in his steps as cheerful as ever.

Agatha waited until the screen door banged shut before turning back. Rio stood where she'd dropped her bag, jaw tight, eyes full of guilt she hadn't tried to hide fast enough.

"Agatha-"

"Not now," she said quietly, not unkindly. "We'll talk later, after he's in bed."

She knew she'd won when Rio merely nodded without any word of protest, but the victory felt brittle in her hands. The quick surrender only spoke of how tired Rio was, and it made Agatha's heart heavy when she walked out of the room to join her son.

The house had settled into that heavy hush that came only after Nicky's bedtime - quiet but not quite still, like the walls themselves were holding their breath. Agatha had settled in the living room - the furthest they could get from Nicky, though he slept like the dead - a half-finished glass of wine perched on the coffee table beside her as she scrolled through emails she wasn't really reading.

When Rio padded in, changed into sweatpants and a t-shirt, her hair was damp around the edges like she'd splashed water on her face in an attempt to wash away exhaustion. She sank into the other end of the couch with a groan, stretching her legs out but not quite meeting Agatha's gaze.

"I'll make it up to him tomorrow," Rio muttered after a beat, rubbing her temple with the heel of her hand.

Agatha closed her laptop and set it aside along with her reading glasses. "He's already gotten over it."

Rio let out a low, humorless laugh. "The look he sent me when he came in to grab water said otherwise."

Agatha studied her - tired eyes, drawn shoulders, the tension that never seemed to leave her lately. Her voice was fragile, heavy with guilt and the exhaustion clinging to her like smoke. "He's just not used to you saying no."

Rio winced like the words had landed harder than intended. "I didn't mean to disappoint him like that."

"Technically, you just told him you needed a second," Agatha pointed out, tucking in her right leg to shift enough to look at her girlfriend properly. "I was the one to pull the plug. And, from experience, I know he'll survive. Probably won't even remember it in a few days."

Rio's head fell back against the couch with a groan, her hand sliding down her face. "You make it sound so simple."

"Because it is," Agatha shrugged, the corner of her mouth twitching upward. "He's a kid, Rio, not the president. Half the things he declares 'the end of the world' are minor inconveniences that barely last two days."

"Still," Rio muttered, lowering her hand again. "I hate letting him down."

"You didn't let him down," Agatha countered, sharper this time. "You asked for five minutes. Establishing boundaries isn't a crime."

"It felt like one, though."

Agatha stayed quiet, studying Rio's profile while the woman stared at the wall above the TV. With the concealer washed off, the dark bags under her eyes were prominent and unmissable, adding to the exhaustion edged into every line of Rio's face. Her fingers tapped slowly against the armrest, a soft but steady pattern like she needed to keep moving to stop the weariness from consuming her completely.

"You've been running yourself into the ground," Agatha said slowly, weighing each word carefully before letting it settle in the space between them. "Between him, the bar, and whatever's living in your laptop. Even when you go to bed early, you don't go to sleep. I'm starting to wonder if you even do that."

"Sleep's overrated," Rio grumbled.

"You're fighting not to fall asleep right now."

Rio blinked, as if only now realizing her eyelids had been drifting shut through the conversation. She sat up straighter, spine snapping taut like a puppet tugged on its string. "I'm fine," she insisted, though the way her neck strained to keep her head upright betrayed the effort it cost her.

"Except you're not," Agatha countered, her voice firmer than she felt. "You're not a machine, Rio. It's been three weeks, and you already look like a shell of yourself. How long do you think you can keep this up before you collapse from exhaustion?"

"Please," Rio scoffed, leaning into bravado like a shield. "If you think a bit of running around with Nicky can take me down, then you don't know me very well."

The bravado might have worked on anyone else, but Agatha could see the cracks - how the cocky grin didn't quite fit with the shadows under her eyes, how her tapping fingers faltered mid-rhythm before forcing themselves back into sync.

Agatha clenched her jaw, refusing to rise to the bait. That was what Rio wanted: a sparring match, a distraction dressed up as banter. If they circled the ring long enough, they'd never have to touch the heart of the matter.

Not this time.

"What about when you add the bar into the mix?" she pressed, her voice quiet but razor-edged. "Or squeezing in your research into whatever slivers of time you find? Would that take you down?" Her gaze locked onto Rio's, unyielding. "Because from where I'm sitting, it looks like it already is."

For a beat, Rio didn't answer. Her smirk twitched, faltered, like it couldn't quite hold its ground under the weight of Agatha's words. She dragged a hand through her hair, leaving it mussed, and finally let her eyes drop to her lap.

Agatha watched her, the silence stretching until it pressed heavy in her chest. Her instinct was to let it go, to step back before she pushed too far. But then she remembered the look on Rio's face from earlier - the exhaustion, the guilt bleeding through her forced grin when Nicky had tugged at her sleeve.

This wasn't about them. It wasn't about how Rio would see her at the end of this conversation or how their relationship would suffer from it. It was about Rio. About her obvious exhaustion stemming from her stubbornness and Agatha's silent acceptance.

That ended now.

She exhaled slowly. "I'll call Sharon tomorrow morning, make sure she's available to watch Nicky at least three times a week."

Rio's eyes snapped back to her instantly. "No."

"Rio..."

"It's wasted money," Rio insisted, more animated than she'd been since the start of their conversation. "I'm perfectly capable of watching Nicky."

Agatha raised her brows at the heat behind the words, but decided not to focus on it. Not yet. "Money's unimportant when your health is at stake. We've been over this already."

After you had a fucking chair thrown at your head, she added silently, flinching at the memory of seeing Rio in a hospital bed, bruised and bleeding. The last thing she wanted was to relive that nightmare when Rio collapsed from overexerting herself.

"And," she continued, when her girlfriend opened her mouth to argue, "if it's Sharon that you have a problem with, I can find a different babysitter. It's summer, half the neighborhood teens are searching for a job."

Rio clenched her jaw, her brow furrowing. "So, what, you'd trust a random stranger with Nicky? Pay them to watch him when I'm available to do it?"

"You're not a live-in babysitter, Rio," Agatha pointed out, shifting in her seat like it could help her shake off the weight of Rio's stare. "Being available doesn't mean you should have to do it. And you have a life of your own. Responsibilities and needs you've been neglecting for him. I can't keep agreeing to that."

A comment about her own needs being neglected as well simmered on her tongue, hot and bitter, but she forced it back down. This wasn't about their half-formed relationship, about her missing Rio in the small, private ways she would never admit aloud. Mentioning it would only make Rio feel guiltier.

Rio's mouth pressed into a thin, displeased line. "You're doing it again."

Agatha blinked. "Doing what?"

"Deciding what I can and cannot handle," Rio scoffed, her voice edged with steel. "I am living my life."

"Are you?" Agatha snapped before she could rein herself in, anger rising too fast to control. "When's the last time you had some downtime? The last time you went out with Alice and Billy? Did anything that doesn't revolve around this house, your research, or the bar?"

The words landed between them with more force than she'd intended.

But Agatha already knew the answer. She'd known since a few days ago, when Billy had knocked nervously on her office door and asked - more carefully than usual - if Rio had seemed busier recently. Normally, she would've snapped at him for dragging personal matters into work, but his question had rung alarm bells in her head. Especially when a few quick follow-ups revealed he hadn't seen Rio in weeks. Not once since Agatha and Rio had crossed that line from pretending to something real.

It was a worrisome timeline. And it left an uncomfortable, leaden guilt in her gut. Guilt that made her wonder if she was holding Rio back - not just from her friends, but from the parts of her life that existed outside this strange little bubble.

Rio crossed her arms, bristling. "I see Alice regularly at the bar. And Billy doesn't need me right now. Nicky does."

"That's not your call to make." Agatha's voice cracked like a whip, sharper than she intended, but she didn't take it back. "You don't get to decide that my son should take precedence over everything in your life."

Something in Rio's face faltered. Her arms tightened across her chest like she was trying to hold herself together. For a long moment, she said nothing. The silence stretched taut, her jaw working, her eyes flickering toward the floor before finally finding Agatha's again.

"It's my life," she said firmly, but her voice was frayed at the edges. Whether from exhaustion or something else, Agatha couldn't tell. "I'm the only one who gets to decide about it. If you don't want me around Nicky or something, then just say that instead of hiding behind some half-assed excuses."

Agatha inhaled sharply, trying to steady the flare of irritation clawing at her chest. "That's not what I said."

"Sure sounded like it." Rio's laugh was sharp, brittle. "You're talking about paying someone to do something I'm willing to do for free. Something I want to do. It's been great these past three weeks, and now - what? You've decided I'm spending too much time with him?"

"Great?" Agatha repeated, her voice rising slightly at the blatant lie. "Look at yourself! You're overworked, overstimulated, and exhausted. I've seen murder victims look more alive than you." She took a steadying breath, even as her hands clenched against her thighs. "And you want me to keep pretending it's sustainable?"

Rio's chin tipped up, the spark of defiance flaring. "I'm handling it."

"No, you're not."

"Yes, I am," Rio snapped back, her voice tense and sharp. She dragged a hand over her face, exhaling through her teeth. "Jesus, Agatha, not everything has to be a crisis for you to handle. So what if I'm tired? Everyone's tired. You think you're the only one who comes home burned out?"

Agatha stiffened, caught between the sting of the remark and the exhaustion that had driven it. "Don't you dare make this about me," she warned, low and cutting. "I'm not the one running myself into the ground for the sake of appearances."

Rio flinched, shoulders bunching like the words had struck a bone. She opened her mouth, then closed it again, throat bobbing as if forcing the words back down. When she finally spoke, her voice was quieter, but still carried an upset edge.

"Appearances?" she scoffed, shaking her head. "You think I'm doing this so the neighbors don't gossip about why you're hiring a babysitter when you have a wife at home?"

Agatha clenched her jaw at the incredulity in her girlfriend's tone. "Well, forgive me that I can't read your mind," she said, prickly. "You don't talk to me. What else am I supposed to think?"

Rio's jaw worked, teeth grinding, but no reply came immediately. Instead, she turned her face away, staring hard at the turned-off TV as if it might hold the answers. The silence stretched until it was nearly unbearable, every second weighted with the heaviness of what neither of them had said yet.

"It's not about appearances," she finally said, each word clipped, quick, like she didn't want to hold onto it for longer than necessary. "I just... want to do right by him. That's all."

It wasn't the full truth - Agatha could hear it in the way Rio's voice thinned, in the way her gaze wouldn't settle - but it was all Rio was willing to offer. And the lack of anything more only made Agatha's chest tighten further, caught between wanting to push harder and knowing that doing so might shatter what little steady ground was left underneath their feet.

For a moment, Agatha thought Rio might dig her heels in further, argue until they were both too drained to keep going. But then the fight seemed to leak out of her, leaving her posture sagging against the couch cushions.

"But... fine," she muttered, voice laced with defeat. "Call Sharon. Or whoever. As you said, it's not my call to make. You should do what you think is best for Nicky."

Agatha blinked, the sudden change almost giving her whiplash. The quick surrender felt like a slap across the face, like Rio would rather wave the white flag than let her in. "That's not what this is about."

"Okay."

The word sounded so hollow that Agatha wouldn't have believed it came from Rio if she weren't staring at her.

"It's not," she insisted, not liking the emptiness in Rio's eyes. "It has nothing to do with your ability to look after Nicky."

"I believe you," Rio said, leaning back and pinching the bridge of her nose. "I don't have the energy to argue about this anymore. So, you win."

Agatha's throat tightened at the resignation lacing her tone, but she held her ground. "It's not about winning, either."

Rio's hand dropped from her face, her eyes cutting toward Agatha like she expected to see her cross her fingers while she said it. "Alright," she shrugged.

Agatha ground her teeth, feeling her ire rise. "Can you stop with the nonchalant bullshit? Just tell me what about not wanting to see you collapse is so upsetting."

Rio's jaw worked, the muscle ticking as she looked away, eyes fixed on some far-off corner of the room. Her shrug this time was slower, heavier, more of a stall than a dismissal. "Because it feels like a backhanded way of saying I can't handle it," she admitted finally, her voice thin but still laced with stubbornness.

Agatha blinked, caught off guard by the honesty buried under the prickles. "Rio-"

"You asked," Rio cut in, lifting a hand like she could swat the conversation away. "That's your answer. I'm tired, sure. Maybe I'm stretched a bit too thin. But I am handling it. And you're benching me in the middle of the game."

Her chest rose and fell too quickly, like she was trying to out-breathe her own admission.

Agatha leaned forward, biting back the urge to argue further and instead softening her voice. "I'm not benching you. I'm bringing in a substitute to let you catch your breath."

"But you do think I can't handle it," Rio pointed out bitterly, apparently forgetting her reluctance to keep arguing.

"If by 'it' you mean the crazy schedule you forced upon yourself," Agatha shifted again, this time shuffling closer to the woman as if physical closeness could bridge all the other hollows between them. "Nobody could handle that alone. And I refuse to watch you bend over backwards just to prove that you can."

There were only a few inches of space between her knee and Rio's thigh now, but neither moved to close the distance further.

Rio's jaw clenched, her gaze fixed on the coffee table like she could burn a hole straight through it. "You make it sound like I'm killing myself for fun," she muttered. "Like I don't know when to stop."

Agatha's reply came sharper than she wanted, cutting through the air between them. "Do you?"

Rio flinched, just barely, but enough for Agatha to see. The edge in her eyes dulled, leaving something rawer, more uncertain. Her arms tightened across her chest, fingers digging into the fabric of her sweatshirt.

"I just..." Rio exhaled hard, the sound shaky. "I want to help. In any way I can. Show that..." She trailed off, as if her brain caught on to what she was about to say and decided against it. But it was enough for Agatha.

She resisted the urge to reach out, to bridge those last inches of space between them with touch instead of words. "You don't have to prove anything, Rio. Not to me. Not to Nicky."

The bitterness drained from Rio's expression, replaced with something more fragile - uncertain, almost lost. Her eyes flicked toward Agatha, wide and searching, but only for a moment before she leaned back, pulling the nearest throw pillow against her chest like armor.

"Fair enough," she murmured.

Silence stretched, heavy but no longer sharp. Agatha let out a quiet breath, deciding not to push her further, not tonight. Instead, she reached for her phone on the coffee table, punching in a reminder for the morning. "I'll call Sharon tomorrow."

Rio nodded once, curt, but her knuckles tightened against the pillow like she wanted to argue and couldn't summon the strength.

Agatha sank back against the couch, the space between them aching more than she'd ever admit, knowing the truce they'd struck was only temporary. That the conversation was still far from over.

Rio rubbed at her temple again, then set the pillow aside as if she couldn't stand the feel of it anymore. "I'm done for the night," she muttered, standing with more stiffness than usual. "I'll... see you tomorrow."

Agatha almost called after her - an apology, a plea, anything to close the space Rio left behind - but the words tangled on her tongue. She watched as Rio padded toward the hallway, shoulders hunched, hair messy from her own restless fingers. The bedroom door clicked shut a few moments later, quiet but final.

The silence settled in the living room like a heavy fog as Agatha stayed on the couch, staring at the dark TV like it might light up with an answer.

She hated how unfinished it all felt. There were still words sitting heavy in her chest, pressing against her ribs until she couldn't breathe. Words about how their relationship wasn't moving anywhere, about how much she missed Rio, even when she saw her every single day.

And worse: words about how afraid she was that this was all they'd ever have. A half-life. Domestic on the surface, hollow underneath.

Agatha rubbed at her eyes, a bitter laugh escaping her throat. Of course she hadn't said any of it. Of course she'd swallowed it down, like she always did when the feelings turned too sharp to name. Better to leave things unresolved than risk pushing too hard and watching Rio walk away for good.

But the ache stayed, right where it always did, like a permanent hole in her chest. Missing someone you lived with was ridiculous. And yet, here she was, sitting in a quiet living room, staring at the hallway Rio had disappeared into, feeling lonelier than she had in years.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! Thank you for reading to those who are still keeping up with the story (especially those who comment because it's honestly giving me life, and I've noticed there are fewer comments under each chapter).
I know this is kinda another chapter where they're arguing, but I really wanted Rio to be the one who needs an intervention for once. Also, it's shorter, and the following might be shorter too (meaning not 8k but 5k of words), just an fyi. My writing's still wrestling with me for every word and every sentence, so what I said about chapters possibly being late still stands (sorry!)

Chapter 35: Keys and wounds

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The sound of the door opening echoed through the house like a judge's gavel, making Agatha flinch. Nicky darted past her before she could even stand up from the table, his face split in a wide grin, shining with excitement.

"They're here!"

Agatha merely hummed, silently wishing she could share his enthusiasm. Inviting Wanda and the twins over had been prompted by Nicky's insistent pouting - a suspicious display, considering he saw them more often than she did. But she had no proof that Wanda had somehow convinced him to demand a playdate, and so she'd bent to his will, hoping it wouldn't bite her too hard in the ass.

That hope died the moment Wanda sauntered into the dining room, a conniving smile already plastered across her face.

"Well, well, well," she said, slinging her bag over the back of one of the chairs. "Who do we have here?"

Agatha rolled her eyes. "Were you expecting someone else in my house?"

Wanda lowered herself into the seat opposite, neatly folding her hands on the table like a detective ready to interrogate her prime suspect. "No. I wasn't even expecting you, to be honest. Thought you'd pull off another disappearing act."

"I was busy."

"Right." Wanda hummed, disbelief dripping from every syllable. "Years of friendship, and you still think that line works on me. It's almost insulting, really."

Before Agatha could fire back, the three boys thundered through the room, Tommy tossing a quick 'hi' over his shoulder before vanishing again toward the backyard, Nicky hot on his heels. Billy skidded to a stop beside her, flashing her a toothy grin before wrapping his arms around her waist.

"Hi, Aunt Aggie!"

She'd never been more grateful for her godson. "Hi, kid," she said, softening as she returned the hug. "How's your summer been?"

"Fun," he shrugged, stepping back from her and glancing around the room. "Is Rio here?"

Traitor.

Agatha's smile didn't falter, though she felt something twist beneath her ribs. "She left to work on her research," she said evenly. "Which means she probably won't return until late in the evening."

Billy's face fell slightly. "Oh."

"He read a book about dinosaurs," Wanda explained, tone too mild to be casual. "And Rio's his go-to expert on the subject."

Agatha didn't like the way her friend was looking at her - that quiet, knowing glint in her eyes that said she already knew there was more to this. "Well," Agatha said coolly, "maybe his mother should read the book too, so he has someone to talk to."

Billy shook his head solemnly. "One book isn't enough. Rio knows everything." He sighed, sounding far too dramatic for his age. "It's okay. But Tommy's gonna be mad. He keeps talking about that spin Rio taught Nicky. He wants to learn too."

"Can't Nicky just teach him?" Agatha asked, pointedly avoiding Wanda's gaze.

"Tommy says he's explaining it wrong." Billy leaned in conspiratorially, lowering his voice. "I just think he can't do it. Even Rio won't help."

Agatha forced a laugh - a brittle, hollow sound. "Well, we all have our limits."

Billy just grinned, oblivious, and darted after his brother.

The house fell quiet again, save for the distant thud of sneakers against the back porch. Wanda waited a beat before reaching over and tapping her nails lightly against the table. "Who knew a few pick-ups and drop-offs were enough to build a friendship, huh?"

Agatha sent her a flat look. "I don't think your children should be considered Rio's friends. It's weird."

"They certainly don't think so," Wanda shrugged, her manicured fingernail tapping out a steady rhythm. "And neither do I. She can actually keep up with them, which is impressive."

The dark circles under Rio's eyes flashed in Agatha's mind, and she clenched her jaw to stifle the guilt. Her girlfriend could keep up with three rowdy pre-teens, but the cost of it was too great to ignore.

"Actually, that reminds me," Wanda said casually, far too innocently for Agatha to believe the segue had been unintentional. "She hasn't come by to pick up Nicky in like a week. What's up with that?"

Agatha raised her brow. "What's up with that? You turning back into a college kid?"

"Well," Wanda leaned back in her chair, sending her a knowing look, "I could have asked if everything was alright, but you would've clammed up. It's called knowing your audience."

"And you think I'll tell you everything now that you've told me your master plan?"

"No. I've known you long enough to realize talking to you is like pulling teeth," Wanda said, a smirk tugging at her lips. "But you didn't immediately fight me on the 'something's wrong' comment. Which leads me to believe that I'm right."

"Detective Wanda strikes again," Agatha grumbled, pushing herself up from the chair. "Coffee?"

"Coffee won't distract me."

Agatha rolled her eyes again, already heading for the kitchen. "Jesus, not everything is a power-play. I'm being a good host."

"Please," Wanda scoffed, following her. "You'd sooner poison me than play hostess."

"Don't tempt me," Agatha grumbled, busying herself with the mugs, spoons, sugar, anything that kept her hands occupied. Wanda waited patiently in that deceptively casual way of hers - still, silent, watching her with eyes that didn't miss a thing. And finally, with a sigh sharp enough to rattle the spoon in her hand, Agatha sighed.

"We fought."

Wanda raised her brows, not judging but genuinely surprised. "About Nicky?"

"In a way." Agatha pressed a mug into her hand before reaching for her own and steering them back to the living room.

They sat, the aroma of coffee weaving between them, grounding and bitter. Wanda watched her over the rim of her mug, eyes soft but knowing. "You asked her not to spend so much time with him?"

Agatha frowned, shoulders tensing. "Where did you get that from?"

Wanda drummed her fingers against the ceramic, weighing her words. "It's just something Nicky said the last time he came over. About Rio not being around as much," she said slowly. "But he didn't mention your involvement. I just... put the two and two together."

"You're shitty at math," Agatha muttered, though her tone lacked its usual bite. "Rio was exhausted. Between Nicky, the bar, and her research, she was running herself into the ground. I stepped in. Got Sharon to help."

"That explains why I've been forced to interact with her."

"Please. You like Sharon. Her gardening tips kept your peonies from dying."

"Rio actually helped, too. She-" Wanda caught herself when she saw Agatha's expression tighten. "Unimportant."

Agatha gave her a flat look. "No, that's part of the problem. Rio's set on helping everyone to the point she doesn't see it hurting her. She was pale, snappish, sleeping maybe four hours a night. I could practically hear her bones creaking."

"That's a nice, clinical way of saying you were worried sick," Wanda said gently.

Agatha ignored her. "She wouldn't listen. Said she wanted to do it. Like it was her responsibility."

"Maybe because she wanted to help?"

"She said that too." Agatha's voice wavered, betraying the undercurrent of guilt she'd tried to smother for days. "And she's been helping. More than she should've. More than I asked her to."

Wanda sipped her coffee, green eyes sharp and unwavering. "And yet, you sound more hurt than relieved."
