Agatha froze. If Rio was a master at reading her, Wanda was a close second - a rather unremarkable achievement, considering the number of years they'd known each other. Still, combined with her pathological need to solve Agatha's every problem and help her grow emotionally, it was an inconvenience.

Wanda set her mug down with a soft clink. "The last time I heard about your relationship with Rio was after the date-"

"Because you forced me to tell you every detail," Agatha chimed in, not liking where this was going.

"And it's been radio silence since then. You don't mention her unless somebody else brings her up. You change the subject whenever I ask how things are going. I think this is the most we've talked about her in a month."

"Your point?" Agatha drawled with an eye roll.

"You don't have much to talk about," Wanda said, conviction clear in her voice. "Combine Rio's exhaustion, your attempts at making her schedule easier to manage, and the fact that you sound hurt about her spending so much time with Nicky, and the conclusion's clear." She leaned forward slightly, her tone softening. "You miss her."

Agatha blinked, slightly surprised by the clear showcasing of the inner workings of her brain. Somehow, Wanda had managed to hit the nail right on the head after fifteen minutes of conversation and weeks of quiet observation.

Annoying, sure, but undoubtedly impressive. Not that Agatha would ever admit it out loud.

"You're wasting your potential as a kindergarten teacher," she said, fighting to keep her tone even as she raised her mug again, the bitter taste of coffee far more pleasant than that of defeat. "It's not too late for a career change, detective."

Wanda chuckled, shaking her head. "All I'm hearing is that I'm right."

Agatha's mouth opened, then closed again. She wanted to argue, to latch onto the narrative that she'd merely been worried about Rio's health. That Wanda had imagined the hurt in her voice. But the words wouldn't come.

Wanda smiled faintly, but not unkindly. "You talk about her like she's a coworker who ignored a safety memo, not your girlfriend."

Agatha exhaled through her nose, staring into her coffee like it might offer a way out. "She's always busy," she said finally. "I thought it'd get better after I enlisted Sharon's help. But it didn't change much for us. Just that she has more time when I'm at work."

Wanda hummed, stirring her coffee lazily, though her eyes never left Agatha's face. "So, let me get this straight. You took something off her plate - leading to an argument - and she filled that space with more work?"

Agatha frowned, setting her mug down a little too hard. "That's not-" She stopped herself, because it was. "She said she needed to make up for the hours she was spending with Nicky. Her advisor's demanding, and summer is the time for field work and research."

"Right," Wanda said slowly, like she was translating Agatha's words into something sharper. "And where does that leave you?"

Agatha's answering laugh was low and humorless. "Somewhere below all the plants and whoever keeps scheduling her late shifts."

"Have you told her that?"

"Of course not." Agatha's tone snapped like a frayed wire. "What would that even sound like? 'Hey, Rio, could you please stop working so hard on something you're really passionate about and spend more time with me, your demanding girlfriend who doesn't even know what a normal relationship looks like?"

Wanda's lips curved, amused but sympathetic. "Something like that, yeah. Maybe with fewer self-inflicted insults."

Agatha didn't dignify that with an answer, settling on a withering glare that made Wanda sigh.

"Okay, listen," her friend leaned forward again, like it could somehow make Agatha understand her words better. "You may not have much experience in relationships, but even you know communication is important. Just talk to her."

The word 'communication' rang out in her ears like an alarm.

"Now you sound like her," Agatha grumbled, quickly patching up her shaken foundation with petulance.

Wanda tilted her head to the side. "Is that right?"

"Don't look so smug. It doesn't suit your whole therapist vibe."

"Therapists get paid. I'm doing this out of the goodness of my heart."

"Good, because this session isn't worth a single penny," Agatha dragged a finger along the rim of her mug, staring into the liquid. "Rio's big on communication until she has to be the one communicating. The argument I mentioned? I tried to tell her she's taken on too much, and she kept getting defensive. Then she just... gave up. Told me I'd won."

The silence stretched for a beat, enough to make Agatha look up at her friend. Wanda kept watching her, a mixture of curiosity and thoughtfulness etched into her expression.

After another few seconds, Agatha rolled her eyes with a sigh. "What?"

"You're one of the hardest people to communicate with that I know," Wanda noticed, not unkindly. "If Rio's so big on communication, she must've figured out a way to get you to do that."

"You want me to call her so she can give you some pointers?" Agatha drawled.

Wanda hummed, tapping her chin. "That's not a bad idea, actually. But for another time," she looked at Agatha again. "What about Rio makes her easier to talk to than everybody else?"

Agatha froze, turning the question over in her head a few times like a sea otter that had just acquired a new rock. She'd never thought about that before because she didn't think opening up with Rio was easy. It was still an internal fight every time she tried to be vulnerable. But it was easier than with other people.

Her finger stilled around the mug, narrowing her eyes as if the question were an elaborate trap.

"What do you mean, what about her?"

Wanda arched a brow. "Exactly what I said. You're not an open book, Ags. You've built an entire fortress around yourself, and most people give up before they even move a single stone. But Rio-" she gestured vaguely with her mug. "-she got further than anyone else. Maybe she figured out a way, but you still had to let her. So what makes her different?"

Agatha didn't answer right away. The air between them filled with the muffled sound of the boys in the garden, filtering through the house like a reminder that life outside still existed. Her gaze drifted toward the hall as she briefly entertained the idea of outrunning the question.

"She... pushes," she finally said, sounding too shy for her own taste. "But not in a way that makes me want to bite her head off. She asks questions, and then she waits. She doesn't fill the silence, doesn't try to fix me, doesn't... pity me."

Wanda said nothing, but the look on her face softened, inviting her to continue.

"She listens," Agatha admitted, almost grudgingly. "Really listens. Like she's trying to understand what I'm not saying. And somehow makes me say more than I mean to." She huffed a humorless laugh. "It's infuriating, honestly."

A small smile curved Wanda's lips. "You sound like someone who actually enjoys being seen for once."

Agatha's head snapped toward her, ready to argue, but the words caught somewhere in her throat.

Seen.

It had always scared her how clearly Rio could see her, how she could decipher her emotional Morse code by just looking at her. At first, it made her feel exposed, like somebody prying bandages off her wounds and peeking underneath without her consent. Now, it led to genuine fear that, at some point, Rio would see too much and leave. That the bloody, jagged wounds would eventually become too ugly for her to look at.

But it hadn't happened. Every sliver of vulnerability she had offered, Rio took like something precious, holding it close and making Agatha feel like she was worth looking at.

So, Wanda was right. For the first time in her life, Agatha was enjoying being seen.

She shook off the warm feeling blooming in her chest, her jaw setting. "What's the point of this, exactly? We're talking about Rio, not me."

Wanda took a slow sip of her coffee, still watching Agatha with that infuriatingly patient expression she always wore when she was about to say something annoyingly perceptive.

"People have different keys," she said at last, setting the mug down. "Communication is about figuring out which key actually turns the lock. And Rio clearly found yours, made from gentle persistence and reading between the lines."

Agatha frowned. "What's that supposed to mean?"

"It means," Wanda said, leaning forward slightly, "that different people respond to different ways of getting them to open up. Finding the key is crucial."

Agatha narrowed her eyes. "So what you're saying is that I don't know my girlfriend well enough to get her to talk to me."

Wanda shook her head with the patience of a saint. "I'm saying you used the wrong key for that particular lock. Has Rio ever had trouble communicating with you before?"

Agatha hesitated. She sifted through memories - both from before and after they'd admitted they wanted something real - and one thing stood out glaringly clear.

"No," she admitted. "Rio's an open book. Usually, I'm the cagey one, and she has to pry the answers from me."

"Then maybe this wasn't a communication problem," Wanda said, gentle but pointed. "Maybe it was an exhaustion problem."

Agatha frowned, but Wanda didn't let up.

"You said yourself she looked like she was running on fumes. People usually aren't up for a hard conversation when they can't keep their eyes open."

The observation landed heavier than Agatha expected. She stared at a grain of the table, tracing it with her thumb, feeling her stomach twist with something uncomfortably close to guilt. She'd thought about that before, about Rio being too tired to delve deeper into the topic. But a part of her decided that it had been a week, and Rio still hadn't brought it up again, which meant she didn't want to talk about it.

And Agatha, well, she never had to be the one to push. Not when Rio wore her heart on her sleeve with her.

"So the metaphor about keys is something along the lines of timing is key?" Agatha scoffed. "That's uninspired. I expected something better."

Wanda took a slow sip of her coffee as if giving Agatha a chance to rethink her words. When the older woman kept looking at her impatiently, she sighed. "Timing is a part of it, yes. But how you handle the conversation is also key."

When she lapsed back into silence, Agatha clenched her jaw, fighting the urge to throw her mug at her best friend. She refrained from doing so, mostly because it was her favorite mug, and grit out: "Is there any version of this where you don't speak in fucking riddles?"

"It's more fun that way," Wanda teased, then grew serious again. "Ags, I love you with all my heart. But you're not exactly... straightforward in showing that you care. As you said, Rio knows how to decipher all the hidden messages you send, but people tend to be less perceptive when they're tired."

"The point, Wanda. Before you lose your coffee privileges."

Wanda wrapped her hands around the mug protectively. "Did you actually tell Rio that you were worried?" she asked, her tone indicating that she already knew the answer. "Or did you just hide behind logistics and platitudes about taking on too much?"

Agatha blinked, the conversation from a week before flashing through her mind. She had told Rio that she was worried, right? The words had to have left her mouth at some point.

Except... they hadn't.

"Shit."

Wanda nodded. "Maybe Rio got defensive because the conversation felt like her boss telling her she couldn't handle something instead of her girlfriend showing her worry."

Agatha's mouth opened, but no argument came. Because it wasn't wrong.

Wanda sat back, letting the words sink in. "Different keys, Ags. Your motivation was good, but you used the wrong phrasing for her lock."

Agatha exhaled slowly, rubbing a hand across her jaw. "You make it sound like I should've handed her a poem instead of a lecture."

"Wouldn't hurt," Wanda teased, then softened again. "Just... talk to her. Not as the head of this house or the person whose son she's been babysitting, but as someone worried about her. As someone who misses her."

The last line lingered in the air, its echo mixing with the boys' laughter drifting in from the garden.

Eventually, Agatha drummed her fingers against the table, her expression tight. "That feels manipulative. Using my feelings to influence her behavior."

Wanda looked at her, eyes wide with surprise. "Damn."

"What?"

"Agatha Harkness talking about not wanting to be manipulative?" Wanda shook her head. "Never thought I'd live to see the day."

Agatha glared at her. "You know, for my friend, you sure talk about me like I'm the worst person on the planet a lot."

Wanda laughed, lifting her mug to her lips. "One of the reasons you went into law was because you like manipulating people. I'm stating facts," she put the mug back down, folding her hands around it as her smile grew softer. "It's not manipulative to tell her how you feel. You won't be using it as leverage in an argument or to guilt-trip her into changing her behavior. Just to make her see the situation through your eyes."

Agatha's jaw tightened, but she didn't fire back. Honesty had always been her sharpest tool, but only when she could wield it like a weapon, not when it felt like baring a part of herself she wasn't quite comfortable looking at.

"You've already done the hard part," Wanda added, her tone firm but soft. "You let her in, let her see you. And she stayed."

Agatha looked away, eyes finding a window just as the twins and Nicky darted past it, shrieking with laughter. The late afternoon sun made their shadows stretch long over the grass, and for a moment, she envied them - their easy joy, their ability to just be without analyzing it to death.

"Did she, though?" she asked, surprising herself. "I see her less now than before we decided to give something real a shot. Our schedules are a mess, sure, but it feels almost... purposeful. Like she's pulling away."

Wanda's gaze softened. "Maybe she's just trying to figure it out. Or maybe she's afraid she's letting you down."

"That's ridiculous," Agatha scoffed.

"Is it?" Wanda tilted her head. "You have a high bar. For yourself, mostly, but for other people too. Maybe she thinks the only way to keep up is to never stop running."

Irritation rose in Agatha's chest like a tidal wave. "Except I told her to slow down," she argued, working her jaw.

"Ags, I'm not claiming to understand how her mind works," Wanda said softly, though her voice remained firm. "And I'm not choosing sides. But try to see it through her eyes. You get a new girlfriend - she's got a son, she runs a tight ship, expects the best from everyone around her. She trusts you enough to watch the kid while she's at work, three weeks straight. Then one day she looks at you and says you look half-dead, that she'll find someone else. You try to fight it, because of course you do, but she's a wall and you're already exhausted. So you surrender the fight."

"And then," Wanda continued, her tone steady, "you wake up the next morning, and everything feels... off. Things are seemingly the same, maybe even better, but all you can focus on is that you're not needed in the same way you were before."

Agatha's lips pressed into a thin line, but Wanda didn't give her the chance to interrupt.

"Your girlfriend doesn't try to talk to you about it again. Or maybe she would if you gave her a chance, but you're afraid of what she would say because, well," Wanda shrugged, though her expression remained serious, "maybe the problem wasn't that you overworked yourself, but that you overstepped. So you keep busy with other things - the bar or the research - to keep the conversation away and to show her that you can handle things."

Agatha took in a steadying breath before she shook her head. "That's not-"

"Your version of the story, I know," Wanda said gently. "But what if it's hers?"

The question lingered, quiet but heavy.

"Ags, you don't know what it's like to try and prove your place in someone else's already-built life. She's still trying to figure out what space she takes up - as your partner, as Nicky's... whatever she is to him, as someone who wants to belong but doesn't want to overstep. And then you pull her back, thinking you're helping her rest, and maybe she just hears: you're doing it wrong."

The familiar guilt settled like a stone in Agatha's stomach, chasing away the residual irritation from Wanda's words.

Her first instinct was to argue - to say that Rio had been a part of her life for months now, that she knew the rhythms of their house, the quiet creaks in the floorboards, even the shape of Agatha's silences.

But the protest caught in her throat, because Wanda wasn't wrong.

Knowing how the house functioned before they'd started dating didn't carry the same weight after the fact. Agatha wanted to believe they had slipped into each other's lives seamlessly, but the truth was more complicated.

Hadn't she herself spiraled the day after their first date, overanalyzing every word and every gesture because she'd been convinced her sarcasm would drive Rio off? Hadn't she tried, however briefly, to blunt her edges only for Rio to call her out on it, looking at her with that maddening certainty and telling her she didn't have to change a thing?

The memory stung, mostly because it made Wanda's point for her.

Agatha had been so preoccupied with her own fear of breaking something fragile that she'd failed to see that Rio might be afraid, too - afraid of doing too little, of not fitting into a life already full of structure and history and people who mattered.

It was easy to forget that when Rio moved through the world with that steady, unflappable confidence. She carried herself like calm water, all reflection and control, but Agatha knew how deceptive stillness could be. She'd been so busy testing the surface - throwing in her doubts, her jabs, her rules - that she hadn't stopped to wonder what might be happening beneath it.

Maybe Rio wasn't as unaffected as she looked. Maybe every stone Agatha tossed rippled farther than she realized.

Agatha swallowed thickly, draining the last of her coffee to ease the tightness in her throat. Her hand shook as she set the mug back down. "It wasn't about punishing her," she muttered, small and weary.

"I know it wasn't," Wanda said, her tone softening again. "But intentions don't always land the way you want them to. You said it yourself - she's tired. Running on fumes. People don't think straight when they're burnt out; they read everything through the lens of failure. So maybe she heard your concern, but what stuck was the part that sounded like disappointment."

Agatha looked away, staring into her empty cup like she could read the answer to her every question from the dregs. Wanda's words hit too close, peeling back the protective layer of logic she'd been clinging to all week.

"I really fucked up, huh?"

Wanda contemplated the question. It was one of her traits Agatha valued most - the honesty. Any other person would've automatically disagreed, but she could see her best friend genuinely consider her answer before offering it.

"No, I wouldn't say so," she said eventually. "There's no pointing fingers in this situation. You could've been more forthcoming, sure. But so could Rio. Blaming yourself or her for how everything played out won't change anything."

Agatha sighed, feeling a fraction better. "I guess I should talk to her next."

Even the thought of that conversation tied her stomach into knots, but she'd been avoiding it for a week, half-expecting Rio to come to her when she was ready. Hoping that Rio would always be the first one to reach out and mend the gap was wrong, and if the past few days were anything to go by, unsustainable in the long run.

For once, Agatha had to be the open one.

"You should," Wanda agreed, studying her carefully before her eyes softened. "Rio's not your mother. She won't accuse you of being manipulative just because you have feelings or call you needy for missing her."

The words gripped Agatha by the throat, wrapping around it like an unintentional noose. Even the softness in Wanda's voice couldn't lessen the impact - it hit her with the sharp precision of a blade sliding between her ribs.

Her mother.

She hadn't heard from her in weeks - if walking into the house to find her speaking to Rio even counted as hearing from her. But she'd thought about her more than she cared to admit. More than she could control. More than was remotely healthy.

And it wasn't even about the deal, not really. Though the PI still lingered like a vulture at the edge of her life - a shadow slipping past her office building, a silhouette pausing too long across the street from the house. And yes, sometimes when Rio stumbled through the door looking like exhaustion personified, Agatha had considered bringing it up - suggesting they arrange another public outing, play the married act again to throw her mother off the scent.

But even she knew that would be crossing a line. Using the fake marriage to prop up the real relationship felt like poisoning the well and pretending the water was still clean.

No, Evanora didn't haunt her thoughts because of the contract.

She haunted them because of the relationship. Because Agatha was already messing it up, barely a month in.

Barely a month, and the real part of their connection was already shaking like an unsteady house of cards, pushed by an invisible hand.

Agatha knew whose hand it was.

It was the same hand that once clamped around her elbow and yanked her back when she skinned her knee as a child - when she'd made the mistake of reaching out for comfort instead of keeping her composure. The same hand that used to hover in the air mid-lecture, palm raised just enough to make her flinch, just enough to teach her that tears were an invitation, not for comfort but for punishment.

That hand had never truly let go. It simply changed shape - from flesh and bone to instinct and fear. Now it lived inside her, curled around the part of her that wanted to reach for Rio and whisper I miss you, please come back to me - squeezing until the words died on her tongue.

Wanda's fingers stilled around her mug, no longer tapping, and the lack of sound made Agatha blink, like the silence woke her from a stupor inflicted by memories.

"I-" Agatha forced a breath past the tightness in her chest, willing her voice to steady. "I suppose everything goes back to her."

The bitter laugh that escaped her didn't make Wanda flinch but smile sadly. "The wounds our parents leave are always the deepest."

Agatha nodded, knowing her best friend was speaking from experience. They stared at each other for a beat - one with a mother incapable of showing warmth, the other an orphan with a parent-shaped hole in their heart - before Wanda sighed quietly, abandoning the mug to lean back in her chair.

"The wounds are deep, but they don't bleed forever," she said, running a finger over her wedding band as the boys' cheerful shouts filtered through the house.

Agatha followed the motion with her eyes, letting the silence settle between them like dust. Wanda had a knack for sentimentality - a trait that used to unnerve Agatha to no end. But she'd learned to appreciate the way she looked at things, that she could see the light in the darkest situations.

"They don't heal," Wanda added after a moment, softer but steadier. "People love talking about healing. Like everything just... closes up if you wait long enough or love hard enough. But some wounds don't. They scar over, sure, but they ache when the weather changes. And if you hit them the wrong way..." She shrugged, but there was something raw in her eyes. "They split right back open."

Agatha's grip tightened around her mug.

"The right people don't make them disappear, either," Wanda continued, gaze flicking toward the garden, where Tommy and Nicky shrieked over something undoubtedly stupid. "They just-" she hesitated, searching for the right wording, "-they learn where not to press. And sometimes, if you're really lucky, they find a way to hold you without ever touching the hurt."

Agatha looked away too quickly, like the words struck something she didn't want seen.

Wanda softened even further. "Rio isn't here to fix what your mother broke. Just like Vis isn't here to patch up the hole my parents had left. It's not their job. But," she leaned forward again, elbows on the table, "it is their job to care. And from what I've seen... Rio does. She cares about you, even if sometimes she gets it wrong."

The acknowledgment - that Rio could care and still mess up, that care wasn't the same as precision - settled in Agatha's chest like a weight and relief all at once.

Wanda gave her a long look, eyes warm but unyielding. "Talk to her. Tell her where it hurts - not so she can fix it, but so she knows where not to press."

Chapter End Notes

Hi! Thank you for all the comments under the last chapter (honestly, I didn't mean what I said in a whiny way, just an observation, but seeing so many of you still following the story gave me the boost to finish this and the next chapter on time). Also, the story's passed 3k kudos, so thank you!!!
Now, I wanted to include the conversation with Rio in this chapter (because I know the story's been feeling like they're not moving forward, I hear you guys, really), but when I started writing it, that conversation alone came out almost 10k words long, so I had to split it. That being said, they will figure their shit out next chapter and finally stop arguing over everything. I know it's annoying, but considering the type of people they are and the situation they're in, I couldn't really imagine them jumping from something fake to something real without any issues.
And finally, I saw a tiktok today about how excruciating this slow burn is, so Ally, if you got this far, I hope it was worth it hahaha

Chapter 36: Missing each other

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The garage door whirred open at precisely 10:12 PM, the low mechanical groan cutting through the quiet of the house like a blade. Agatha jolted upright from the couch as if someone had yanked a string tied straight to her spine. She caught herself gripping the armrest and slowly peeled her fingers away, flexing them in an attempt at nonchalance.

"Honesty and feelings," she muttered like a curse and a reminder all at once.

Her thumb found her wedding ring - habit, anchor, tell. After the date, the gesture had lost a part of its calming ability, but it had quickly regained it as the only tangible proof of her connection with Rio. Fake or not. She rolled it once, twice around her finger, then forced herself to stop before she wore a groove into her skin. She smoothed out her sweats like they were courtroom attire, spine straightening instinctively as if she expected to be cross-examined.

The quiet clicked back into place. Then-

The garage door shut. A car door. The muffled thud of Rio's boots on concrete. Each sound landed in Agatha's chest with the precision of a metronome, steady and unhurried, while her own heartbeat tripped over itself like it was trying to catch up.

She took a breath, then another. She's just Rio. Except tonight, that felt like saying it's just a scalpel before performing open-heart surgery for the first time.

The interior door finally opened with a soft metallic clack.

Agatha stepped out of the living room shadows like she'd been waiting backstage for her cue, pulse hammering in her throat. The hallway light flicked on, spilling warmth across the floor, and Rio stepped into it, shoulders slumped, eyes tired in a way that didn't just speak of exhaustion but of someone who's been holding herself with fraying thread.

Agatha swallowed down the reflexive urge to greet her with humor, with something deflective and sharp. She stood still instead.

"Hey," she said softly, like a word placed gently on a wound instead of pressed into it.

Rio's head snapped toward her instantly, eyes widening like a deer caught in unexpected light. For a heartbeat, something raw flickered across her face - surprise, maybe even alarm - like she'd been counting on a few more seconds to collect herself before anyone saw her.

Her expression smoothed out almost immediately, practiced composure sliding back into place. Almost. The exhaustion clinging to her bones made it slower this time, less seamless, like a coat thrown over a fire instead of a door quietly closed.

"Did something happen?" she asked, pausing just inside the threshold but not stepping closer. Her gaze swept over Agatha with that unnerving accuracy that always made her feel too visible. "You look like-" She stopped, brows drawing together. "-like you've been waiting to go to war."

Agatha almost smiled. Almost. "Not war," she said, voice steadier than she felt. "But we need to talk."

Rio's shoulders dipped a fraction lower, as if she'd been expecting that exact sentence all day, maybe even all week, but hoped she might outrun it. She nodded once, slow and resigned, shifting her grip on the bag like she was debating whether to put it down or use it as an excuse to retreat.

"Can it wait until I at least take my shoes off?" she asked softly, not irritated but tired. So tired.

Agatha took a measured breath. She knew the timing wasn't perfect, but would it ever be? Without this conversation, Rio would remain drained. Nothing would change.

"I know you're exhausted," she said, voice low, careful. "And I don't want to tear into this like we're picking a fight. But I need to say it."

For a long moment, Rio stood perfectly still. Then she nodded again, smaller this time, and set her bag down by the wall without breaking eye contact.

"Okay," she murmured, kicking off her boots with slow, deliberate movements. "Then talk to me."

The house felt strangely quiet around them, like even the air was bracing itself.

Agatha studied her girlfriend for a beat, noting the slight tremble in her hands as they fidgeted near her hips and the shadows dancing over her sunken cheeks. Guilt ripped through her chest like a knife.

"I will," she said, more to convince herself that she wouldn't chicken out than Rio. "But go change first. I'll reheat dinner since you probably haven't eaten anything since lunch."

Rio blinked, something complicated flickering across her face - relief tangled in reluctance. She looked like she wanted to argue, to insist she was fine and that they should just get it over with, but the weight in her shoulders said otherwise.

"...Okay," she conceded quietly, the word barely more than a breath. She hesitated before turning toward the stairs, her fingers flexing like she was grounding herself. "I'll be quick."

As she disappeared down the hallway, Agatha released a breath she hadn't realized she'd been holding. The silence that followed wasn't peaceful - it buzzed with everything unsaid. She moved into the kitchen on autopilot, opening the fridge and pulling out the covered plate she'd prepared earlier like a woman performing a ritual instead of a domestic task.

The microwave hummed to life. She stood in front of it, staring at her own blurry reflection in the glass door as the timer counted down.

You can still walk away from this, the old voice whispered - sharp, familiar, poisonous. Keep it light. Ask how her day was. Pretend nothing's wrong. It's safer that way. Easier.

Her fingers curled tight around the edge of the counter.

No.

Not this time.

Her body moved independently of her mind, preparing two mugs of tea and carrying them to the table before returning to the kitchen for cutlery. Her steps were hurried, purposeful, as if she were a waitress running between tables, catering to fussy guests during peak hours.

As long as she kept moving, the voice couldn't catch up to her.

As long as she kept moving, it felt like a semblance of running without actually running away.

The timer landed on one, and she opened the microwave, freezing it a second before it would beep. She stared at the number, wishing she could stall her own life the same way. Give herself just a few more minutes to go over what she would say, how she would navigate the minefield that would be the conversation waiting for her in the dining room.

Steps sounded on the stairs, and Agatha blinked, urging her body to move again. She grabbed the plate through a dish towel, the steam curling over her head like a smoke signal, and took a steadying breath.

Just Rio, she thought as she stepped out of the kitchen. It's just Rio. Put yourself together.

Her girlfriend was already by the table when she emerged, face damp from a quick wash, loose shirt hanging off one shoulder like she'd pulled it on without looking. She smelled faintly of soap and exhaustion.

Her gaze flicked from the food to the tea to Agatha's face, and something in her posture shifted, shoulders tensing ever so slightly.

"You set the table," she said slowly, like the sight alone reminded her that it wasn't just a quick dinner before bed.

Agatha shrugged, a gesture too sharp to be unusual. "You haven't eaten."

Rio's eyes lingered on her longer this time, searching her face. The tiredness didn't leave her features, but something more alert flickered behind her eyes - caution, maybe.

The urge to abandon it all - to force a smile, slide the plate across the table, pretend this was just another tired evening with too much silence and not enough touch - rose like a wave in Agatha's chest.

But she kept her jaw steady, even if her fingers tightened around the edge of the plate.

"Sit," she said, quieter than she'd meant to.

Rio didn't move. Her eyes dropped briefly to the plate, then back up. "You're pale," she observed suddenly. "And your hands are shaking."

Agatha froze, fingers still around the dish towel. "So are yours," she said, noting the slight tremble in Rio's palms, probably caused by low sugar.

Another beat passed, their eyes meeting over the table, before Agatha sighed, breaking the contact to put the plate down. "Just sit, please. Eat."

Rio's brows drew together, not in annoyance, but in that soft, infuriating way she got when she was worried. She looked at Agatha for a long moment - then nodded, slowly, like she was accepting something heavier than a meal. She pulled out the chair and sat down, tired but present, hand reaching for the fork.

Her shoulders relaxed slightly as she finally looked at the dish, a soft hum escaping her lips. "You made the risotto."

Agatha slid into her own chair, immediately reaching for the scalding tea to have something to ground her. The ceramic burned her fingers, but she ignored the sting, pulling the mug closer. "I did," she said, not trusting her voice to say more without cracking.

Rio dug her fork into the meal slowly, almost cautiously, like she was expecting a grain of rice to jump out at her. "Thank you." The words must have sounded stiff even to her own ears because she cleared her throat, trying again, "Really. I was ready to go to bed on an empty stomach, and you cooked one of my favorite meals."

Agatha made a small, dismissive sound, eyes firmly fixed on the rising steam from her mug. "You would've woken up at three in the morning and eaten cereal straight from the box like a raccoon. Consider it a preventative measure."

Rio huffed a quiet laugh, but it didn't last. The amusement faded almost as quickly as it appeared, leaving something tentative in its wake - gratitude still tangled in caution.

The scrape of her fork against the plate sounded too loud in the stillness of the room. She took a bite, chewed, swallowed, then set the utensil down again instead of continuing. Her eyes lingered on the food, like she was trying to decide if she was allowed to enjoy it.

She glanced up. "It's good," she said softly. "Even better than the last time you made it."

"Yes, I remember the pointed complaints about salt content."

"I was being a brat," Rio admitted with a small, tired smile. "This one's perfect."

The compliment landed heavier than it should. Agatha's fingers tightened around her mug. The warmth seeped into her palms, but it did nothing to untie the knot in her chest.

She could feel Rio watching her again. So carefully. Like she was trying to read a message written in a code only she knew how to translate.

"Agatha."

It wasn't a question. It was a name spoken like a knock on a locked door.

Agatha drew in a slow breath, steadying herself. "Eat," she said quietly. "You need it."

Rio reached for the fork again, but didn't move any further.

"I can eat and listen at the same time," she pointed out, her eyes unwavering. "You wanted to talk. And something tells me you didn't mean regular dinner conversation."

The words were gentle. But they landed like a challenge and an invitation all at once.

Agatha's fingers tightened around the mug until her knuckles stood out, bone-white against ceramic.

No more circling the truth. No more waiting for 'the right moment'.

Her mother's voice rose like a phantom at the back of her mind - don't be needy, don't cling, don't want - and Agatha shoved it down so hard she could almost feel it bruise.

She didn't look at Rio when she spoke. She stared at the table instead, at the faint water ring left by her tea, and forced the words through her clenched jaw.

"I miss you."

The silence that followed was so complete it felt like the entire house inhaled her sentiment and held it with its breath.

For a moment, Agatha regretted everything. She wished she could snatch the confession back and swallow it, choke it down with sarcasm and carefully constructed distance. Armor was easier. Cold was easier.

But the words were out, hanging between them like something fragile and painfully alive.

The fork rattled slightly against the plate, and Agatha finally lifted her gaze.

Rio was staring at her like she'd just said something she didn't believe she was allowed to hear.

Her voice, when it came, was small. "You... miss me?"

Agatha's throat tightened. "You're here," she said, struggling to keep steady. "In the house. Every day. We talk, technically. You're around Nicky. You eat and sleep here. But I feel like-" She exhaled, breath sharp. "I feel like you're passing through me instead of being with me."

Rio's lips parted, as if to respond, but no words came out.

Agatha swallowed hard. "You were right. You said we'd fall back into the old patterns if we didn't do anything to make our relationship work, and you were right. We've been together for a month, and I can't remember the last time I talked to you about something other than this house or logistics. I can't remember the last time I kissed you for longer than five seconds. We haven't even-" she stopped herself, deciding that bringing their non-existent sex life into the conversation would be too much.

"And I know you're exhausted," she continued, the words leaving her mouth like a waterfall. "I know your schedule's a mess. I know adding Nicky to that made it worse. That's why I-" Her jaw flexed. "That's why I pushed for Sharon. Not because I didn't trust you. But because I was losing you in the process of having you here."

Her voice cracked on the last word, but she didn't look away.

Rio set her fork down with a care that felt almost reverent, like any sudden movement might shatter the moment. Her fingers rested beside the plate, trembling just faintly, and when she lifted her gaze, it was wide and unbereably gentle, like she was afraid Agatha might bolt if she blinked too hard.

"I didn't..." Her voice caught, quiet but raw. She wet her lips, trying again. "I didn't know you were lonely."

Lonely.

It wasn't a dramatic word. It wasn't even an accusation. It was simple, a perfect description of the feelings coiling inside her, and it made Agatha's lungs burn.

Rio's brows pinched, not in guilt exactly, but in something more painful - realization. "I thought I was... doing what you needed - keeping everything running. Showing up. Doing right by Nicky. By this house. By you." She let out a breath that barely counted as one. "I thought... if I just held everything together, it should be enough."

Her gaze flicked down to Agatha's hands around the mug, then back to her face. "But I didn't stop to think about how I was showing up. I thought being present was the same as being with you."

"What about this past week?" Agatha asked, pointedly keeping accusation out of her voice. It wasn't about pointing fingers. It was about learning the truth. "After I got Sharon to help?"

Rio hesitated, her shoulders squaring up like defenses pulled back into place. But just as Agatha readied herself for another argument, the walls fell back down, uncovering the raw vulnerability. "I've... been afraid."

The admission landed like a pin dropping in a silent room - delicate, but impossible to ignore.

"When you asked Sharon to help, I..." She swallowed, her voice thin. "I know you said it was because I was tired. That it didn't have anything to do with me not doing enough. But I couldn't stop hearing it that way."

She let out a shaky breath, eyes fixed on a point somewhere near Agatha's hands like she was afraid to look her fully in the eye. "I can't help you with money. I know I'm not-" Her throat bobbed. "I know I'm not on your level. Not even close. You have a stable job, a house, a life you built. And I came into it with a bartender's salary and a stack of textbooks."

Her fingers toyed with the fork without picking it up. "Taking care of Nicky... it felt like the one thing I could give you that mattered. Like I could contribute to your life instead of just... being allowed to be in it."

She pushed the words out slowly, like each one scraped on its way up. "So when you brought Sharon in, I thought... Right. Of course. You don't need me for that either." She let out a humorless breath, almost a laugh. "The thing I told you about my research wasn't a lie: I have been neglecting it to look after Nicky. This past week was mostly me trying to get everything back on track. But it was also a way to, I don't know, show you that I wasn't just some extra weight."

Her thumb pressed into the table, leaving a faint crescent mark on the wood before lifting. "I thought that if you saw how hard I worked, you'd... think that I could bring something to the table that feels worthy of the life you've let me be a part of."

Her shoulders curled inward slightly, not in defeat, but in quiet admission. "I didn't realize that in trying so hard to do that... I stopped actually being in your life."

Agatha stared at her, feeling a throbbing ache pulse in her chest as if Rio's every word created a small fracture in her heart.

For a long moment, she didn't speak. Couldn't. Her fingers tightened around the hot mug until the heat finally registered, forcing her to set it down before it slipped from her hands.

"Rio," she said, and her voice came out so soft she almost didn't recognize it. "You don't have to... prove your worth to me. I already know it. I already know you're irreplaceable in my life."

She exhaled, slow and uneven, like steadying herself before stepping off a ledge. "Sharon can look after Nicky. She's good at it. She's paid for it. But she's not replacing you because you were never filling a role. You're not a nanny or a housekeeper or a cook. You're-" her jaw worked, searching for the words, "-you. And that's exactly who I need. That's exactly who I want."

Her fingers twitched on the table, desperate to reach across but too hesitant to do it. "You didn't fail me by being tired. You didn't lose points. There is no invisible scale where I'm weighing your worth against how many chores you do or how much income you bring in." Her voice dropped, quiet but steady. "You don't have to earn your place here every day."

Her breath hitched, but she met Rio's gaze anyway. "You already have it."

Rio's eyes shimmered with something raw - pain, maybe, or relief so intense it bordered on grief. Her fingers tightened around her fork like she needed the pressure to keep herself present. She didn't speak right away, and Agatha let the silence sit without rushing to fill it. Let it breathe between them instead of letting it choke.

When Rio finally inhaled, it sounded like the first breath she'd taken all evening.

"I think," she began, voice small and careful, "I kept telling myself I was doing it for us. That if I just pushed a little harder or picked up one more shift, I could walk into this house and feel like I'd earned the right to-" Her voice faltered, and she swallowed. "-to touch you without feeling like I was stealing your time."

Agatha flinched, almost imperceptibly.

Rio's gaze dropped. "Before you start blaming yourself, you never said anything that could even hint at that. But in my world... you have to earn everything. You have to work for it. You've shared so much with me - your home, your family, yourself - and I..." Her brows knit, as if she were fighting with herself. "I wanted to match you. Wanted to give back at least a fraction of that. But I focused too much on certain things and lost sight of what really mattered."

Her eyes found Agatha's again, the message clear in them.

You.

You're what really matters.

The unsaid words hung between them, tangling with the smells of the cooling dinner and the untouched tea.

Rio's thumb traced the edge of her plate, a nervous, looping motion. "But I didn't tell you any of that," she admitted, guilt dripping from every syllable. "I just... disappeared into work and told myself it was the right thing. That you'd understand without me saying it."

The vulnerability in her eyes made her look impossibly young. "You shouldn't have to guess. You shouldn't have to feel me slipping and wonder if you imagined it. You shouldn't have to miss me because I let fear get the best of me."

Her voice broke on the next inhale, but she pushed through it. "I should've talked to you, told you I was scared. And I'm truly sorry that I didn't."

Agatha's fingers drummed once against the table, a contained gesture, but her voice - when it came - was steady. "I don't need you to be fearless," she said quietly. "I just need you to be here. Even if you're scared."

Rio let out a shaky breath. "I thought being scared made me less worthy of being here."

"And disappearing made you more worthy?" Agatha countered, not harsh, just tired. "Because from where I was sitting, it looked a lot like you choosing everything else over us."

"It wasn't-"

"I know," Agatha said, not letting her spiral. "But that's how it felt."

Silence stretched - thick, but not hostile.

"You're right," Rio relented softly, earnestly. "I made decisions for us without including you in them. I won't do that again."

Agatha studied her for a moment, eyes sharp, searching. "We promised to talk about our issues, fears, everything. You were the one to stress how important communication was."

Rio remained silent, guilt flickering over her features as she nodded.

"Remember the day after our date, when I tried to figure out how to be softer because I thought if I fixed the parts of myself that might be too much, you'd stay?"

Rio's expression cracked, something like pain flashing across it. "Yeah."

"You had to confront me back then, too," Agatha pointed out, her voice deceptively even. "The same way I had to confront you about this."

Rio swallowed hard. "We keep trying to preemptively fix things we see as an issue without even giving each other a chance to decide if they are one."

"It's like we take one step forward and three steps back," Agatha murmured. "Because we assume instead of just... saying it. Or letting it run its course. We adjust ourselves in silence and call it effort." Her tone tightened, frustration laced through with something startingly gentle. "And I hate talking like this. You know I do. But I hate the quiet between us more."

Rio's eyes shone, raw and unguarded. "Then let's stop leaving each other to guess in the quiet."

Agatha's lips pressed into a thin line. They'd stood in this place before - on the edge of something honest, promising each other clarity and ending up in the same loop. Words that sounded good in the moment but dissolved the second life demanded anything of them.

"We've said that before," she noticed, voice low. "Both of us. We've said we'd talk, that we'd do better. And then we don't. We pull back and wait until it festers. We let it rot between us just long enough for it to turn into a fight." Her gaze flicked up, sharp even as her lips trembled. "I don't want to keep doing this just to end up in the same place every time."

Rio didn't flinch or argue. She just breathed in slowly, like she was taking the weight of those words into her lungs.

Then, instead of speaking, she moved.

Her hand reached across the table, tentative at first, like she expected Agatha to pull away. Her fingertips brushed against Agatha's knuckles, a question written in the gentle contact.

Agatha didn't retreat.

Rio's fingers slipped fully over hers, warm and steady despite the exhaustion lingering in her bones. "We're not in the same place," she said quietly, grounding the words with the pressure of her palm against Agatha's. "We're miles away from what this conversation would've looked like a few months ago. The fact that it even happened speaks of how much has changed."

Her thumb brushed over Agatha's skin, a small motion, reverent. "I know it might feel like we're not making any progress, but we are. We're moving forward."

Agatha stared at their connected hands for a moment, letting herself bask in the warmth seeping from Rio's skin into her own. It was almost pathetic how such a trivial touch made her feel giddy - like she'd been wandering around cold for weeks and had only now realized it.

Her thumb twitched, almost involuntarily, brushing the side of Rio's hand like she was confirming something solid was really there. Her voice, when it came, was quiet. Too careful.

"Are we, though?" she murmured, though there was no bite in it. Just tired hope disguised as skepticism. "Because this feels like history repeating itself."

Rio didn't let go. If anything, her fingers curled more firmly around Agatha's, grounding. "If this were history repeating," she said softly, "you wouldn't have waited by the door for me. You wouldn't have made tea. You wouldn't have looked me in the eye and said you miss me."

Agatha's breath caught, subtle but there.

Rio's gaze held hers, unwavering despite the fatigue webbing the corners of her eyes. "A few months ago, you would've stayed quiet and pushed me away - not because our relationship was different, but because you wouldn't even consider talking about whatever bothered you."

Agatha opened her mouth to protest, but the words died in her throat. Those weren't some made-up accusations Rio used to validate her point; they were real-life examples of how Agatha had acted after realizing her budding feelings for the woman - she clammed up and drew a line between them, leading to weeks of heartbreak and confusion.

A conversation of any kind had been out of the question back then, mostly because the idea of vulnerability made her skin crawl.

"And yet," Rio continued, tracing another line over her girlfriend's knuckles, "here you are. Talking. Naming the ache. Pushing through your instincts and reaching out first because you know how important it is for me to hear."

Her lips curved, soft and achingly sincere. "That's not a loop, Agatha. That's breaking one."

Silence settled again as Rio let the words sink in, let Agatha make her own sense of them.

"It still took me a week," Agatha finally said, her voice trembling slightly despite her best attempts to smooth it out.

Rio's fingers didn't stop moving, tracing purposeful lines across Agatha's skin. "It did."

"And it was really fucking hard to do."

Rio's smile lingered, gentle but steady. "I know," she said, and there was gravity in the simple admission - respect, not reassurance. "And you still did it."

Agatha looked down, as if eye contact suddenly felt dangerous, but Rio kept going. "You were so afraid you weren't built for relationships. That I'd have to bend over backwards to make this work. But this? Here?" The hand around Agatha's tightened again. "You made this conversation happen. I was spiraling, letting my fears get to me, and you pulled me back."

Agatha's throat constricted at that, something unbereably tender hooking behind her ribs.

Rio's voice dropped, low and sincere. "And I know what it cost you to reach out. I know you were just as afraid when bridging the gap as I was while accidentally creating it."

For a moment, Agatha forgot how to breathe.

"But you still did it," Rio squeezed her hand again, this time more demanding, urging Agatha to look at her.

Blue eyes hesitantly met brown, and Rio's smile widened enough to show the small gap between her front teeth. "And I'm really fucking proud of you, querida."

Agatha's breath hitched involuntarily - both at the pet name and the honesty dripping from every word. Her lips quivered slightly, but she eventually pulled them into a fragile smirk, blurred at the edges.

"You're giving me too much credit," she murmured, trying to shift the focus away from herself like it burned. "I didn't... come to that on my own."

Rio's brows drew together slightly. "What do you mean?"

Agatha exhaled through her nose, a little tense, a little embarrassed. "Wanda came over today. The twins had a playdate with Nicky." She hesitated, like admitting she'd talked to someone else about this felt like crossing some unseen line. "She helped me make sense of things, I suppose."

Rio didn't interrupt. Her thumb just kept moving, slow and steady, encouraging.

Agatha's mouth twisted, somewhere between a grimace and a reluctant smile. "She used this metaphor about keys and locks, which almost made me stop listening, but she had a point. Different people respond to different approaches when it comes to getting them to open up. And I-" she flicked her gaze up, meeting Rio's eyes for a brief second before looking away again. "-I didn't use the right key with you. I came at you like your exhaustion was a problem to manage. Like I was your supervisor reallocating your workload. And that wasn't-" She sucked in a breath. "That wasn't what I meant."

Her fingers curled slightly, restless. "I honestly thought I'd said the words I'm worried about you at some point. That I'd made my intentions clear. In my head, it was there. But apparently, I just... handed you a schedule adjustment and then couldn't understand why you were drifting away."

She huffed, faint and bitter. "I knew about my tendency to... hide everything important inside a logistical decision. It feels safer that way. Makes me feel less exposed. But I didn't realize what I was doing until Wanda pointed it out."

Silence pulsed between them. Rio's thumb didn't waver, tracing steady circles over Agatha's hand like she was creating a map only she could see.

"I learned to translate wanting into control a long time ago. If something felt like it might slip away, I tightened my grip. Rephrased it. Made it practical," Agatha bit the inside of her cheek, gaze focused on the wall behind Rio. "It's a coping mechanism. A way to seem less-" her jaw tightened, like the next word tasted wrong, "-needy."

The next words came out quieter, raw around the edges. "Needy was... never received kindly, growing up. Showing want, asking for something - attention, time, softness - it came with consequences. Always."

Rio's grip tightened again, her eyes softening even though the tension in her jaw betrayed the anger simmering underneath. Not at Agatha, but at the person responsible for the pain.

"I know you're not my mother. I know that," Agatha added quickly, like she needed it on record. "Which is probably why I didn't even realize what I was doing until Wanda looked me in the eye and told me you wouldn't call me manipulative for having feelings. And then..." she offered a half-shrug, the motion jerky and tired. "...everything fell into place."

Her eyes found Rio's again. "Telling you to slow down was easier than admitting I was scared of losing you to everything else in your life. To the bar. To your research. To everything you deem important." She forced out a breath, harsh and shaky. "It was easier than saying I miss you, and I don't know how to ask for you without feeling like I'm doing something wrong."

The confession hung in the space between them, impossible to ignore.

She let out a quiet laugh, tired and brittle. "Wanda said different keys open different locks. I think I've been using the only one I know. The one that keeps me from looking like I'm asking for too much."

Rio didn't speak right away.

She just looked at her - really looked at her - eyes dark and unbearably gentle in a way that made Agatha want to flinch and lean in at the same time.

When she finally spoke, her voice was quiet but unwavering. "You're saying I'm giving you too much credit," she murmured, her thumb slowing its pattern over Agatha's skin. "But Wanda's not the one sitting before me, voluntarily laying down her armor to let me see underneath."

Agatha's breath stuttered in her chest.

Rio's fingers tightened, deliberate. "Even the fact that you've talked to her about this speaks volumes to me. And I know you'll probably say something along the lines of Well, she made me and wouldn't let me leave until I told her everything, but I know you. I know she could've put a gun to your head and you still wouldn't tell her anything unless you wanted to."

Agatha's lips parted, a protest poised on her tongue, but it caught on her teeth, unable to escape.

"And as for everything you said..." Rio exhaled, a soft huff. "Talking to me about how you're feeling isn't manipulative, it's brave. This," she raised her free hand to gesture between them, "is you being brave. And the fact that you needed someone's help to get here doesn't change anything. Doesn't diminish how far you've come."

Rio's eyes slid down to the table, her breath stuttering. "Presence isn't something you should have to ask for. Not in any kind of a relationship. It should be a given, a cornerstone, and I'm sorry for putting you in a position where simply wanting me to be with you instead of just existing next to you felt like asking for too much."

Agatha exhaled slowly, the rawness of Rio's voice settling somewhere deep in her chest, taking root.

"But," Rio looked up again, her eyes glinting in the dining room's soft light, "I need you to know that your wants and needs could never be too much for me. Whenever you decide to put them in my hands, I will never close my fists and treat them like a weapon. I need you to believe that. Not just understand it - believe it."

Agatha's throat worked, something fragile flickering behind her eyes. "Belief is... slower," she admitted, barely more than a breath. "Understanding is easy. Belief feels like-" Her mouth trembled, but she steadied it. "Like stepping somewhere without checking if the ground will hold."

Rio nodded once, accepting that without argument. "Then I'll stand there next to you," she said simply. "And if it gives, then we fall together. You don't have to measure your steps alone anymore."

For a moment, neither of them spoke.

Agatha blinked once, slowly, like her body needed time to catch up with the fact that nothing catastrophic was happening. No alarm. No snapback. No punishment.

Rio's hand caressed hers again, the touch grounding without being suffocating. Agatha stared at the delicate movement of her fingers, feeling the warmth of Rio's skin like an anchor tethering her to the present moment. Her voice, when it finally emerged, sounded like it had been dragged across glass.

"I don't want you to just stand next to me," she said. "I want you with me."

Rio exhaled shakily, something like relief and grief tangled together in a sound. "Then that's where I'll be," she said, and the words felt like a vow. "I've been tired. Overwhelmed. Scared. But none of those things are excuses to stop choosing you."

Her thumb stilled over Agatha's pulse. "So I'm choosing you. Right now. And I'll keep choosing you, even on the days I'm too tired to do it perfectly."

Agatha's lips parted, a sound catching at the back of her throat that could've been a laugh or a sob. Her hand shifted, fingers trembling as they slowly, hesitantly, intertwined with Rio's.

A deliberate, conscious act of staying.

"There's something else Wanda said," Agatha murmured, her voice softer now, as if she were shedding the last of her defenses. Her gaze drifted from their intertwined fingers to Rio's face again. The weariness was still there, etched into the slope of her shoulders and the faint tightness around her eyes, but beneath it, something had shifted. Rio looked present. Awake. Like someone finally surfacing for air after being underwater for too long.

"She talked about... the things our parents leave behind," Agatha continued, her tone careful like she was handling something delicate. "How the wounds they leave eventually stop bleeding, but they never really heal. They close over, but the skin remains tender. Easy to break."

Rio's expression flickered, something quiet and aching settling behind her gaze. Agatha knew why. Just like Wanda, Rio was moving through the world with a parent-shaped hole in her heart. A wound that would never heal.

"Wanda said that the right people eventually learn the map of you," Agatha said, a shaky breath catching on the way out. "They figure out where the fragile places are. Where the old bruises lie. And instead of pressing on them, they learn how to hold you around them. How to be careful without treating you like you're breakable."

Her lips twisted into something that wasn't quite a smile. "I think that's what we're doing. Or trying to. Learning how to care about each other without stepping on landmines we didn't plant but have to live with."

She inhaled slowly, jaw working around the truth until she let it spill. "You probably don't even realize how much it means to me that you chose me. That you're saying you'll keep choosing me. It's like you instinctively know where not to press sometimes, and I find it both terrifying and exhilarating, the fact that you already know me so well," she allowed herself a small smile, running her thumb along Rio's.

"But every situation is new. Every time, we're figuring it out from scratch," her face sombered again, but her voice remained soft. "And sometimes we get it wrong. We press where it hurts or we use the wrong key. But it's not about being perfect." Her eyes looked into Rio's with a steady kind of certainty. "It's about trying. So... even if you're too tired to do it perfectly, don't let fear stop you from doing it altogether."

The silence settled again. Rio didn't look away, studying Agatha in something akin to reverence, like she wanted to soak in the moment before speaking.

When she finally opened her mouth, her voice was low and warm like embers rather than flame. "You're right," she said, fingers curling around the hand in hers. "It doesn't have to be perfect. It just has to be ours."

Rio's words lingered in the air like the last warmth of a flame before it gentles into a glow.

It doesn't have to be perfect. It just has to be ours.

Something in Agatha eased at that - a loosening in her shoulders, a quiet unclenching behind her eyes. The heavy conversation had left a soft exhaustion between them, but it wasn't the kind that hollowed like after Agatha's first unsuccessful attempt at getting Rio to slow down. More like the kind that followed after a storm, when the air felt cleaner, even if everything still carried the signs of rain and wind.

She looked at Rio for a long moment, taking in the subtle aliveness there - the alertness that hadn't been present when the evening began. The tiredness was still there - Agatha suspected it wouldn't disappear until at least a few nights of restful sleep - but it no longer felt like something swallowing her from the inside. More like something she could rest in.

Agatha's gaze dipped to the plate in front of Rio. The dinner lay untouched, probably already cold around the edges, even if the center still carried a semblance of warmth.

Her thumb brushed over Rio's once more, slower this time. "So much for listening and eating at the same time," she said quietly, the shift in topic a bit sudden but not dismissive. More like an offering. A way to ground all the words they'd just spilled into something tangible. Real.

She glanced back up, a faint, almost rueful softness curving her mouth. "Eat before your stomach digests itself. No more hard conversations for tonight."

Rio blinked, then huffed a soft, almost disbelieving breath - somewhere between a laugh and a sigh. "You can't expect my multitasking skills to remain intact when your emotional growth is happening right in front of me."

Agatha gave a scoff, but felt her cheeks grow warmer at the hidden compliment. Because Rio knew how much starting the conversation took. She recognized the effort. "I suppose I'll keep my emotional growth at bay until you're done eating next time."

Rio shot her a look - a tired but amused one - and finally reached for the fork with her free hand. "Don't you dare. I'll gladly starve if it means having you like this."

The fingers around Agatha's tightened, and she rolled her eyes even though the back of her neck felt unbearably warm. "You're prone to unnecessary sacrifices, you know that?"

Rio chewed, swallowed, then pointed her fork at her. "Now who's psychoanalyzing who?"

"At least I waited until you started eating. You usually do it before breakfast."

"Touché."

The air between them softened further, settling into something warmer, quieter. Rio kept eating, and Agatha let herself watch for a moment. The tension from earlier had melted into something gentler, something that felt dangerously close to peace.

When Rio set her fork down, only half the plate gone, she looked up - steady, intentional. "After I'm done," she said, voice low but no longer heavy, "we should sleep together tonight."

Agatha's breath short-circuited.

There was a full half-second where her mind threw itself into a spiral of imagery she immediately wanted to set on fire. Her heartbeat lurched into an unreasonable tempo, and she could feel her expression threatening to betray her in real time.

She cleared her throat. "You-" she started, and cut herself off before the sentence could spring straight into disaster. Her voice came out controlled, only barely. "You're exhausted, Rio. And Nicky's in the house. I don't think-" I could control myself enough to keep quiet "-that's a good idea."

Rio blinked once. Then twice. And then, with excruciating calm: "Agatha."

Agatha stared back, defensive without fully knowing why. "It's not that I don't want to. I-" have been fighting with myself for the past month not to rip your clothes off "-just don't think it's good timing."

Rio's lips twitched, caught between amusement and fond exasperation. "I mean literally sleep. As in horizontal unconsciousness. In the same bed. Because I've missed you too and don't want this to end, but-" she gestured vaguely toward her own face, "-I'm tired and probably won't stay awake long enough to appreciate cuddling on the couch."

A silence.

Then Agatha made a sound that could only be described as a quietly imploding oh.

Rio arched a brow, slowly, deliberately. "But," she added, tone deceptively casual, "that's not what you were suggesting, huh?"

Agatha's brain promptly burst into flames, painting her face red. She opened her mouth, closed it again, then worked her jaw before scoffing with fake nonchalance. "I wasn't suggesting anything."

Rio didn't look convinced in the slightest.

"Maybe," she hummed, drawing out the sound as she gathered another bite onto her fork, entirely too casual for someone who had just detonated Agatha's entire nervous system. "But you were thinking about something else."

Agatha lifted her chin a fraction, summoning as much dignity as possible in this situation. "Since when are you a mind reader?"

Rio didn't take the bait. She tilted her head slightly, studying her with that infuriatingly gentle, all-knowing expression. "If I were actually suggesting what you're thinking," she said thoughtfully, "I'd like to think I'd be a little more romantic than 'oh, yeah, we should sleep together tonight.'"

Agatha blinked. A protest formed on her tongue - because she was not about to admit Rio was right - but it died when the rest of the sentence registered. Something she hadn't even realized was coiling unpleasantly in her chest loosened a fraction.

Rio's voice softened, but there was a spark beneath it, quiet and warm. "Just so we're clear," she continued, "the fact that I'm too tired to keep my eyes open doesn't mean I don't-" she paused, eyes sliding over Agatha's form before meeting her gaze with steady intent, "-find you very, very worth appreciating when the timing isn't two minutes before I faceplant into a pillow."

Something hot and traitorous spiked low in Agatha's stomach. The way Rio's eyes bore into hers without even an ounce of doubt or hesitation, like she'd been thinking, imagining, how exactly she'd appreciate Agatha when given the chance, made her heart stutter. She glanced down at their palms, the contact feeling far too electric for something as simple as hand-holding, and she briefly considered brewing Rio an entire pot of coffee to chug down before subtly shaking her head against the absurd idea.

"You-" Her voice came out too high-pitched, too wrecked, and she exhaled sharply before continuing, "-can't just say things like that."

Rio flashed her a grin, and Agatha's gaze snagged on the small gap between her front teeth.

Her mind, traitorous and newly unshackled, immediately conjured the image - Rio beneath her, that stupid, charming gap-toothed grin pressed against her skin, laughter muffled against her collarbone. It was ridiculous. Reckless. Entirely inappropriate considering they had just spent an entire evening talking about wounds and trauma and emotional honesty.

And yet.

Now that the air between them wasn't tight with unspoken fear - now that Rio had said I choose you and meant it - Agatha felt space inside her chest that she didn't even know had been occupied open up. For weeks, every brush of Rio's hand, every moment of closeness, had come with a sharp edge. Don't want too loudly. Don't reach too fast. Don't seem needy.

But Rio hadn't called her needy. She hadn't recoiled at the simple I miss you.

And now, maybe for the first time, it didn't feel dangerous to want.

And fuck did she want that woman.

"Why?" Rio's teasing voice brought her back, but did little to extinguish the flames of realization burning in her stomach.

Because now that Agatha had been granted the silent permission to want more than careful touches and chaste kisses, her mind wouldn't stop imagining what it would feel like to have Rio's panting breaths echo in her ears. How she'd sound, taste, feel.

"Is the great Agatha Harkness having trouble controlling herself around me?"

Agatha inhaled slowly through her nose, as if oxygen might restore her dignity. It didn't.

She fixed Rio with her best unimpressed stare, only mildly compromised by the fact that her pulse was doing cartwheels. Even worse, Rio could probably feel it against her palm. "Congratulations," she said dryly, voice mostly steady, "you've cracked the case. Over a year of celibacy has finally rotted my brain."

Rio tilted her head, brows scrunching faintly. "It's only been six months."

"Of the arrangement," Agatha grumbled. "I had more important things than getting laid going on."

Her mistake became clear when Rio's smile curved, slow and delighted. "Until now, yeah? Because this feels like a roundabout way of admitting it."

"I admit," Agatha replied, enunciating each word with dangerous precision, "that I am a woman with blood in my veins and a very pretty girlfriend who keeps saying things like appreciate you when the timing is right with full eye contact."

Rio hummed, pleased. "Sounds like your problem, querida."

"Oh, it absolutely is," Agatha agreed, tone deceptively calm even as the word fanned the flames burning low in her stomach. "And I'm coping admirably, all things considered."

"You mean considering you're imagining - what was it? Me under you?"

Agatha froze.

Rio's grin went feral. "You made a face."

"I did not." Agatha reached for her cold tea as if the gesture could rebuild her crumbling dignity.

"You absolutely did."

Agatha's eye twitched. "Finish your dinner," she said through her teeth, tone clipped but eyes undeniably bright. "Before I decide to redirect this energy into murder."

Rio picked her fork back up with the serenity of someone very aware she had just won a battle Agatha would never admit occurred. "You can redirect it wherever you want," she said casually, "when the timing's right."

Agatha swore her soul left her body for a moment. "Eat. Your. Food."

Rio smiled into the plate and, with infuriating ease, obeyed.

The silence lasted for less than a minute before Rio interrupted it again. "You shouldn't feel embarrassed, you know?"

Agatha clenched her teeth, eyes raised to the ceiling as if some God could save her from the conversation.

"About the whole wanting to jump me thing."

"I did not say that," Agatha bristled.

Rio tilted her head, a soft smile tugging at her lips. "That you're embarrassed or that you want to jump me?"

"Rio, I swear to-"

Rio lifted the hand holding her fork in mock surrender, but her eyes were shining with something softer than mischief - something that made Agatha feel far too seen. "Alright, alright," she said lightly, then scooped up another bite just to keep Agatha from combusting on the spot. "Though for the record, my brain is equally rotten."

Agatha rolled her eyes. "Yes, I remember how devastated you were when I told you about the no sex rule at the beginning of our arrangement. The celibacy must've been hell."

"It was," Rio said, voice deceptively calm. "But not for the reasons you think." She hesitated, as if considering whether she should continue. "Every time I walked into this house and saw you with your hair down and those stupidly large reading glasses that shouldn't look good on anyone but somehow look amazing on you-" she gave an incredulous shake of her head, "-I had to remind myself that this was a professional arrangement and I couldn't pounce on you in the middle of the living room."

Agatha's brain blanked. "My... glasses?"

Rio nodded solemnly. "The ones you wear when you're working or reading. You'd just sit there with your hair all messy, frowning at your laptop or some book like it personally offended you, and I'd feel..." She trailed off, shaking her head again. "Do you have any idea how hard it is not to walk across the room and kiss the annoyance off your face?"

Agatha stared at her, at a complete loss for words. Her heartbeat thudded in her ears like a warning siren. She watches me. She wants me.

Then, another detail registered.

"Wait, you said professional arrangement. You mean..."

Rio leaned in slightly, her voice dropping into something low and charged with electricity. "If you think your thoughts these past few weeks have been... unwise enough to be embarrassing, let me free you from that burden." She held Agatha's gaze, unwavering. "I have been mentally irresponsible about you for months, gorgeous."

For a heartbeat, all Agatha could do was stare, like her brain was rifling through every memory of the past six months and forcibly recontextualizing it.

The contract. The flirty remarks. The blurred lines. The desperate logic she'd been using to make sense of it all.

"You..." Agatha's voice came out strangled. "You've been wanting me since-?"

Rio didn't flinch. If anything, she looked relieved to finally say it. "I already told you I wanted you at the bar. It just never really... disappeared."

"But you acted-" Collected. Calm. Normal. "-so unaffected."

Rio pursed her lips. "I acted like someone who entered a legally binding partnership with a woman who made it very clear it was strictly business. I wasn't going to throw my attraction at you like a grenade."

Agatha's stomach swooped. Because the thing Rio wasn't saying - but Agatha felt deep in her bones - was that Rio had been protecting her. Giving her time to figure everything out at her own pace. Trying to stay within the lines Agatha had drawn for them.

"And the glasses," Rio added after a beat, almost mournful. "Those were unfair. Cruel, even."

Despite herself, Agatha's lips twitched. "You mean to tell me," she said slowly, "that you've spent six months suffering in silence because of my eyewear?"

Rio met her eyes with the solemnity of someone delivering a eulogy. "And the messy bun that you pretend isn't intentional." A beat. "And the robe. The satin one with a flower pattern."

Agatha's mouth felt dry. That robe. The one she'd walked around countless times, thinking nothing of it. "You," she said faintly, "are ridiculous."

"I," Rio corrected, far too composed for someone confessing to six months of quiet torment, "am very, very patient."

Agatha looked at her. This woman she had married to prove her mother wrong. This woman she had developed genuine feelings for between sideways glances and stupid, slow-burning longing that had felt like a secret she had to keep even from herself.

Something warm and dangerous uncurled in her chest.

Six months. They'd been orbiting the same want for six fucking months.

She exhaled, something close to laughter catching in her throat. "Well," she managed, "considering you suffered through my glasses and robe with such grace, I suppose I can forgive your... mental irresponsibility."

Rio's grin was slow and devastating. "Generous of you."

Agatha held her gaze, pulse thrumming. "I expect compensation for my leniency."

"Of course," Rio said softly, fork forgotten, eyes dark with something that made Agatha's skin prickle. "Just you wait."

The air between them had changed, the promise lingering over the table like traces of smoke. But it wasn't heavy. No, heavy had been earlier, when every word had risked a wound. This was something else. Something alive, humming low beneath the quiet.

Rio set her fork down with a soft clink, her meal mostly gone, and wiped her mouth with deliberate calm. It shouldn't have felt like a loaded gesture. It did.

Agatha stood before she could overthink it, palms pressed briefly to the edge of the table to steady herself. The phantom feeling of Rio's hand in hers lingered on her skin even as it pressed against the cold wood. "You're done," she said, more to say something than because it needed saying.

Rio arched a brow. "Observant."

Agatha made a point of ignoring her, slipping into a practiced sort of composure as she gathered the plate. "You should shower before bed. You look like you've fought God in a parking lot."

"Honestly, that'd probably be easier than having to talk to my advisor," Rio laughed, grabbing the half-empty mugs before Agatha could. "You cooked. I'll clean up."

"You're exhausted," Agatha argued, sending her a pointed look. "Go to bed."

Rio relinquished her hold on the cups, but her eyes remained on Agatha, watching her with a focus that made her skin feel too tight. "I remember somebody promising to join me in said bed."
