Agatha stilled for a moment, the sentence playing in her mind on a loop before she swallowed. "Your memory's malfunctioning. There were no promises."

Rio stood, moving with that familiar kind of certainty that always made Agatha's breath stutter. "Maybe," she murmured, leaning into Agatha's space and tucking an unruly strand of hair behind her ear with maddening care. "But there were no objections either."

Her hand brushed against Agatha's temple first, a fleeting touch that felt more like a question than contact. Then it drifted down, tracing the line of Agatha's cheekbone with the kind of unhurried reverence one would reserve for most precious things. Sparks shot along Agatha's nerves with humiliating ease, and her fingers slipped slightly against the plate she was holding, suddenly clumsy.

Rio's palm found her jaw, thumb barely ghosting over the corner of her mouth. There was precision in every motion, but no calculation. No performance. Rio wasn't teasing her now. She was listening to something wordless, primal, guiding her hand like instinct had finally been allowed to speak after being shoved aside for too long.

Agatha's pulse roared in her ears, loud enough that she was half-certain Rio could hear it.

Then Rio looked at her, and in her eyes was something unguarded, something dark and hungry and painfully honest - a wanting so clear it rooted Agatha to the spot.

Before she could assemble a single coherent thought, Rio moved.

Her forehead brushed Agatha's, breaths mingling, warm and steady. She paused there for a heartbeat, giving Agatha every chance to pull away, but distance was the last thing on the older woman's mind.

Rio's mouth found hers a second later, like a seal set on their conversation.

The kiss was soft at first, similar to the ones they'd shared even when drifting apart. But beneath it, coiled and waiting, was something deeper. Something that said I have been holding this back for too long.

Agatha made a sound - quiet, involuntary, almost startled against Rio's lips.

Rio answered it by tilting her head, deepening the kiss just enough to make it real, to remove any doubt that it was merely a kiss goodnight.

Every thought Agatha had about restraint, about timing, about exhaustion dissolved under the heat of it.

Without meaning to, without thinking at all, she responded.

Her fingers tightened around the plate to keep it from slipping out of her grip as she surged forward, foregoing gentleness as she kissed Rio back. Her free hand lifted, gripping the back of Rio's neck like she needed proof that she was real and wouldn't go anywhere. The kiss shifted, gained heat - her mouth parting against Rio's, a rush of something hungry spilling through the moment.

Rio made a low sound in response, caught between surprise and satisfaction, and Agatha felt it more than she heard it - vibrating against her thumb, humming against her lips.

The soft thud of Rio's body aligning flush against hers stole the rest of Agatha's breath. That low sound Rio had made still echoed between them, and now there was an urgency to her movements that hadn't been there before - controlled, but only barely.

Rio's hand slid from Agatha's jaw down the line of her throat, lingering at the rapid pulse fluttering there, before trailing to her waist, where her other hand was already pressing into Agatha's lower back. The grip sharpened, growing directive, a silent instruction that made every nerve in Agatha's body stand at full attention.

Then, with agonizing steadiness, Rio guided her back.

Agatha didn't even register the movement until the edge of the dining table pressed against the backs of her thighs.

Her breath stuttered.

Rio followed, crowding into her space until Agatha was braced between her body and the solid wood, the plate still uselessly clutched in her hand. The heat radiating off Rio was dizzying, her thigh between Agatha's just enough to make the air turn molten. The table behind her suddenly felt too high, too convenient, like all it would take was one move for Agatha to be sitting on it with Rio between her knees.

And for a heartbeat - just one traitorous second - she almost let it happen. Her fingers twitched, halfway to setting the plate down to free her hand and pull Rio closer, when the fork scraped against the ceramic, almost slipping from under Agatha's thumb.

Reality cut through the haze like an unwelcome splash of cold water.

Agatha's eyes shot open, her spine straightening to put a few inches of space between their kiss-bitten lips. Her breath came out short, ragged, and she didn't know if it was from the kiss itself or the sheer willpower it took to end it.

Rio's eyelids fluttered, slowly uncovering the darkened irises. There was barely any brown left, the color swallowed by the hunger lingering in every line of Rio's face.

That look alone almost made Agatha lean in again, but she held onto the fraying thread of control with a white-knuckled grip.

"Fucking Christ, Rio," she muttered, loosening her hold on the back of her girlfriend's neck. Her nails had probably left crescent-shaped imprints near Rio's hairline. She ran her fingers over the skin to soothe the sting. "You really like testing the limits of my self-control, don't you?"

Rio leaned back into the touch, her unbridled hunger giving way to something a fraction softer. The hands on Agatha's waist gentled, holding instead of pressing now, fingers tracing slow lines along her spine. She hadn't even noticed when Rio's hands slipped under her shirt.

"Would you believe me if I said it wasn't about testing?" Rio asked, voice low like she didn't want to disrupt the moment by speaking too loudly. "I just... couldn't help myself."

The words sent a shiver down Agatha's spine that she didn't even try to hide.

She leaned in again, placing a chaste kiss on Rio's lips before letting her hand slide down her arm and fall to the side. "Go shower," she ordered, tone strained in a way that absolutely ruined her attempt at sounding strict. "Before we do something stupid."

Rio didn't argue, and Agatha found herself torn between gratitude and regret. But it was for the best. She knew one word from her girlfriend would likely end with one of them splayed over the table.

Rio's thumb traced once last circle against the knobs of her spine before her hands withdrew, readjusting the t-shirt with slow precision.

When she stepped back, the imprint of her body lingered like a permanent mark.

"I'll be waiting upstairs," Rio said, voice steady despite the flush still painting her cheeks and the sparks lighting up her eyes. There was no innuendo in the words, just a silent promise that hung in the air after she'd turned towards the stairs.

Agatha watched her go, heartbeat thudding unevenly against her ribs. She stood alone in the dining room for a breath. Then another.

The fire burning low in her belly seemed to thrive on the supplied oxygen, the flames licking her ribs and spreading across her entire body. She ran her tongue over her lips, jaw clenching as she fought off the urge to follow the woman upstairs and into the shower.

When the timing’s right, she thought reluctantly, pushing herself off the table. And that better be fucking soon.

For now, she’d have to settle for curling up with Rio under the covers. Because as much as she loved to push her girlfriend’s buttons and keep her guessing, there was only one way this evening was ending - with them in the same bed.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! As always, thanks for all the comments, kudos, everything. Safe to say, we'll be taking a break from them arguing every other minute now because writing (and reading) that shit is depressing, but as I said, I kinda couldn't imagine their relationship without some sort of a rocky start. Anyway, hope you enjoyed and see you next week!

Chapter 37: Domesticity, unscripted

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The house had settled into that late-night hush - the kind that made every sound feel deliberate. The faint hum of the heater, the creak of old wood shifting as the temperature dipped, her own breathing - shallow, measured - filled the quiet like a confession.

Agatha lingered by the sink longer than necessary, fingertips resting against the cool marble. The mirror reflected a version of her she wasn't sure she recognized - shirt slightly askew from Rio's hands, lips tinted from a kiss she'd deepened before she even realized she'd moved.

You almost let her put you on that table, a treacherous voice whispered. You wanted her to do it.

She uncapped her cleanser, smoothing it across her skin with calm, practiced motions. Routine. Familiarity. Things that steadied her pulse instead of making it thrum in her temples.

She rinsed with cold water, hoping it'd chase away the warmth in her cheeks. It didn't. If Agatha didn't know better, she'd think the water started evaporating the second it touched her heated skin.

As she pressed a towel to her face, the quiet became muffled, giving her a momentary illusion of stillness. She let herself breathe into the fabric before pulling it away.

The conversation. The touch. The kiss.

They had cracked something open inside her that she'd been holding shut with unforgiving hands. A craving she'd kept locked at the back of her mind sprang out and was now stirring beneath her skin, warm and restless.

To be near Rio. To feel her breathe in the dark. To fall asleep with the steady rhythm of her heartbeat within reach.

It wasn't new. Ever since they'd shared a bed after Rio's accident, Agatha had spent countless nights lying awake, painfully aware of the emptiness of her bed as her mind brought up the smallest details of those two unforgettable nights.

The smell of Rio's shampoo haunted her. The phantom feeling of her heartbeat against Agatha's palm pulsed in sync with her own. The memory of their legs tangled under the sheets had her tossing and turning, like her limbs couldn't find the right position without another body beside her.

So yeah, Agatha had spent an embarrassing number of nights staring at her bedroom door. Before they'd gotten together, the urge to get up and march into Rio's room was wishful thinking - an itch she knew she'd never get to scratch.

Then, after the date, it had become more painful. Because logic told her that she could knock on Rio's door and slip into her bed. That it wouldn't be weird to want to sleep next to her girlfriend. But wanting had felt dangerous - like reaching too quickly would cost her everything.

So she hadn't, spending her nights staring at the door until sleep took pity on her and let her stop imagining scenarios that wouldn't come to life.

But tonight was different. Wounds had been named. Fears dragged into the light. And for the first time in weeks, she didn't have to brace for Rio to pull away. She wasn't rationing her affection like it might run out.

Rio had offered closeness. Had asked her to stay. Not by accident. Not as a casual afterthought.

She knew Agatha would want to be near her tonight. More than that, she had admitted she wanted it too.

A month ago, Agatha would have dissected every syllable, searching the shadows of Rio's words for a loophole, a condition, a trap. She would have convinced herself that affection had terms, that wanting too much would break whatever fragile peace they'd built.

But tonight, for the first time, there was no fear waiting beneath the want.

Just Rio.

Rio, who had kissed her like she'd been holding back too long.

Rio, who had said I choose you as if it were the only right option.

Rio, who had confessed to missing her.

And suddenly, that - more than any breathless thought of being lifted onto a table and kissed senseless - was what made Agatha's pulse stutter.

She met her own eyes in the mirror. Dark. Unmasked. Bruised and wanting, yes, but also allowed to want.

It wasn't about sex, though desire simmered beneath the surface, hot and steady. It was about something simpler. Something she'd never dared to claim for herself.

To fall asleep in the circle of steady arms without counting down the minutes until she'd be alone again. To lie beside someone and not feel the urge to pull away before they do.

To be kept.

A steadiness settled low in her chest at the thought that would've sent her running for the hills a few months before.

She exhaled. Turned off the bathroom light.

Her gaze caught on her bed in passing - unmade in that effortless way lived-in things tend to be, the quilt thrown carelessly across a tangle of sheets and pillows. It was a California King, selected years ago, not out of necessity but symmetry. The room was too large, too empty, and she'd filled it with a bed that promised space. Space to stretch, to sprawl, to breathe without brushing against anyone else.

Space she had once valued.

She thought briefly of all the nights she'd woken in the exact center of it, limbs outstretched like a starfish claiming territory she no longer remembered how to share. No edges. No warmth to bump into. Just silence and fabric and the luxury of isolation.

Her eyes flicked to the door, in the direction of Rio's room. The bed there was a queen - big enough for comfort, small enough to guarantee proximity.

There would be no drifting to opposite ends. No accidental distance. If she fell asleep with Rio, she would feel her there, in every shift, every breath, every brush of skin under shared blankets.

The thought didn't scare her. On the contrary, it made her almost giddy with anticipation.

Without letting herself linger another second, she flicked off the light and stepped into the hall, almost bumping into a solid body.

Rio stood outside her door, barefoot and damp-haired from her shower, dressed in a loose shirt long enough to cover the tops of her thighs. If she had shorts on, Agatha couldn't see them, and her eyes snagged on the long, muscular legs before traveling back up. The soft hallway light drew a faint glow across her tan skin, catching on her collarbone and the hint of the tattoo stretching over it.

For a heartbeat, neither of them moved.

Then Rio's lips curved slightly. "Searching for someone?"

Agatha rolled her eyes, if only to disguise the way her pulse immediately jumped. Her gaze flicked briefly down the hall, toward Nicky's room, like she was making sure every door stayed shut, no audience to witness whatever this was. "What are you doing? You said you'd wait."

Rio tilted her head, glancing at the master bedroom's closed door before refocusing on her. "Figured I'd wait in the bed I'll be sleeping in."

"We're not sleeping in my room."

The amusement draining from Rio's face was subtle, but Agatha felt it like a physical shift in the air - like she'd just slammed a door Rio hadn't even known she wanted to walk through. "But... your mattress probably feels like angels hugging you," she said slowly, brows drawing together. "And I'm sure you have, like, silk sheets or something."

"Egyptian cotton," Agatha corrected automatically, then immediately regretted giving that much away. Rio's mouth twitched. "Not silk. And-" she cleared her throat, posture straightening, "-I have work tomorrow, and you need sleep. I'm not risking waking you up while getting ready."

The logic sounded perfectly reasonable. Responsible, even.

It was also only half the truth.

Because, yes, she didn't want to wake Rio with her morning routine. And she didn't want to sleep in a bed big enough for them to drift apart in the middle of the night.

But the real reason was a bit more pathetic than that. If Rio fell asleep in Agatha's bed and her scent seeped into Agatha's sheets, Agatha knew herself well enough to understand one brutal, humiliating truth:

She wouldn't be able to sleep in that bed alone again.

For fuck's sake, she had a problem with it even without knowing what it would be like to have Rio curled under her covers. Before they'd gotten together. Before she'd learned it wasn't a fantasy but a real, tangible possibility to wake up beside the woman.

She could only imagine the torture that would follow the night she finally found out.

Rio watched her, expression unreadable for a moment. Then she shrugged, the motion slow and easy, like a small surrender. Either she was too tired to argue or she trusted that Agatha - after everything tonight - would speak up if it truly mattered.

And she would. She absolutely would. If it were a real issue. If it weren't just her being pathetic. If Rio seemed hurt by the refusal.

But her girlfriend didn't look hurt. Didn't even look mildly inconvenienced. Instead, she stepped forward and slid her fingers through Agatha's, warmth blooming easily between their palms.

"My room it is," she murmured, voice low but laced with something that felt like quiet victory.

Because, apparently, Rio didn't care about Egyptian cotton sheets or angels hugging her. She cared about falling asleep next to Agatha.

Before Agatha could swoon at the implications, Rio was already tugging her down the hall, their bare feet slapping against the wooden floors. The way she moved was purposeful, decisive, like the short conversation had stripped away the last thin layer of patience she'd been clinging to all evening.

Agatha let herself be guided, her mind flickering between awareness of Rio's hand and the faint citrus-and-cedar scent of her shampoo still clinging to the air. Every step seemed to pulse with the leftover electricity of that kiss - the one that had nearly landed her on the kitchen table.

By the time they reached the door to the guest bedroom, her heart was a steady, too-loud drum in her chest.

Rio pushed the door open, the soft light from the hallway spilling across the bed made with an almost military precision, the only disruption a faint indentation on one side of the mattress where she'd probably sat earlier.

Agatha hadn't paid much attention to the room the last time she'd crossed the threshold, too focused on the hurt clawing at her chest to notice the details. But now, standing in the doorway, her eyes catalogued everything with sharp clarity.

The space wasn't just cluttered - it was uncharacteristically disordered. Piles of papers and books covered nearly every flat surface, spilling onto the floor like they'd multiplied overnight. A sweatshirt hung from the closet's open door, an inch away from falling onto the heap of clothes underneath. A small graveyard of mugs covered the nightstand on the side where Rio slept - one of which, Agatha realized, she'd written off as devoured by the dishwasher over a week ago.

The sight startled her, not because it was repulsive, but because it wasn't her.

Agatha had only been in the room a handful of times, but she knew how her girlfriend operated. Rio was the kind of messy that made sense - the kind where chaos was contained within invisible borders, where every misplaced item had a reason and a rhythm. This was different. This was the kind of mess that came from exhaustion. From someone who'd been surviving instead of living.

Now, the room looked like a battlefield she'd been losing for weeks.

"Thinking about changing your mind?" Rio's voice came from beside her, edged with something brittle despite the humorous lilt.

Agatha tore her gaze away from the cup on the windowsill, one she now suspected was cultivating its own ecosystem, and looked at her. Rio still hadn't dropped her hand, but her expression had shifted - uncertain, a touch defensive.

Agatha's chest softened despite herself. "No," she said firmly. Then, because her mouth always seemed to outrun her better judgment, she added, "But I could let Ana know to come in here next Friday."

The reaction was immediate. Rio's shoulders went taut, the muscles in her jaw ticking. "I don't need a housekeeper to clean my room." Her tone wasn't sharp, but it carried that quiet stubbornness Agatha had come to recognize - the one that hid shame under practicality.

Agatha opened her mouth, unsure what she'd say, but Rio beat her to it.

"I just..." She sighed, dragging a hand down her face, leaving a faint smudge of tiredness in her wake. "Cleaning's been the last thing on my mind. I'll get to it tomorrow."

Something in the way she said it - flat, almost apologetic - made Agatha's chest constrict painfully.

Wanda's words echoed in her mind before she could block them out.

Try to see it through her eyes. You get a new girlfriend - she's got a son, she runs a tight ship, expects the best from everyone around her.

Agatha's grip on Rio's hand tightened.

Expects the best from everyone around her.

This wasn't Rio's best. Agatha knew that. The room was a picture of depletion - the kind that seeped into everything, even small, mundane acts like putting away a mug. It was a cry for help if she'd ever seen one.

But Rio - her stubborn, proud, overworked Rio - stood there thinking Agatha was judging her for it.

The realization hit like a physical blow.

She reached up, gently tucking a damp lock of Rio's hair behind her ear. "Hey," she said softly, fingers brushing the woman's chin to urge her to look up without demanding it.

Rio did, eyes dark and startled under the low light.

"I wasn't judging," Agatha continued, her voice quieter now. "It just caught me off guard."

Rio's mouth parted slightly, as if she wanted to argue, but the fight had left her. She just looked at Agatha, eyes careful, searching.

"I didn't expect your room to reflect your exhaustion so clearly," Agatha added softly. "It got me worried."

Rio glanced around the room again, taking in the chaos like she was seeing it for the first time through Agatha's eyes. Her thumb rubbed absently over her knuckles, a nervous tell. "Sorry," she muttered after a beat. "The more cluttered my mind gets, the harder it is to declutter... anything else."

Agatha's expression gentled. "Don't apologize." Her fingers tightened around Rio's hand, grounding the words with touch. "Just-" she drew in a quiet breath, searching for the right phrasing, "-tell me when the clutter becomes too much next time. And I'll do whatever you need to help manage it. Even if it's just... sitting in the same room while you figure it out."

The offer hung in the air, soft but certain.

Rio's eyes lifted to hers, something unspoken moving through the space between them. For a long moment, neither said a word. The silence felt warm now, weighted with understanding instead of unease.

Then Rio's shoulders loosened, tension draining from her like air from a punctured tire. "Okay," she murmured, her voice almost childlike in its exhaustion. A small, sheepish smile followed. "Can we sleep now?"

Agatha's lips curved into a faint smile, fond and tired. "Of course, darling."

Their fingers slipped apart as they lifted the covers, the simple act feeling strangely intimate after everything they'd said tonight.

The bed dipped under their weight, sheets cool against warm skin. The faint smell of Rio's shampoo - something citrusy, edged with cedar - hung in the air cooled by the air conditioner buzzing softly in the corner.

Agatha sank back against the pillow, turning just enough to catch Rio settling beside her. In the half-light, Rio looked softer somehow - edges blunted by fatigue, lashes brushing her cheeks, her hair falling messily over her temple.

"The lights, Rio," she muttered, noticing the woman's eyes already fluttering shut, her breathing slow and steady in that unmistakable pre-sleep rhythm.

"You get 'em," Rio mumbled, voice slurred by exhaustion.

Agatha exhaled a long, put-upon sigh, the kind that belonged more to habit than annoyance. Her gaze flicked toward the bedside table - the one nearly buried under a precarious arrangement of mugs in varying degrees of decay. In the middle of the chaos stood the lamp, its warm amber glow painting Rio's face in soft gold.

It was pretty.

Pretty inconvenient.

Agatha briefly weighed her options. Lean over Rio, or get up. The thought of standing, of peeling herself away from the enveloping warmth of the bed, was enough to make her want to declare defeat and sleep in the light.

Another sigh escaped her. "Fucking unbelievable," she muttered under her breath, half to herself.

Propping up on one elbow, she leaned across Rio's body, stretching for the switch. Her arm trembled slightly under the awkward angle, her fingers fumbling through the obstacle course of ceramic handles and cold coffee rings.

The move brought her closer than she'd intended - her front brushing against Rio's side, the soft give of her body a stark contrast to the sharp edge of the bedside table. Agatha's breath hitched; she could feel the slow rise and fall of Rio's chest beneath her, the steady rhythm of it, like the sea at low tide.

Finally, her fingertips found the switch, and she pressed it harder than necessary. The light vanished instantly, plunging them into soft, velvety darkness.

She barely had a second to celebrate before Rio let out a low, contented hum - a sound so deep and unguarded it sent a shiver up Agatha's spine - and then an arm snaked around her waist.

"Rio-"

Too late.

Even half-asleep, Rio's grip was strong, instinctive, dragging Agatha down into her like she was claiming a stuffed animal rather than a person. Agatha's arm gave out under the pressure instantly, making her land squarely against the younger woman with a surprised grunt.

Her cheek collided with the warm curve of Rio's collarbone, the scent of her shampoo invading her senses with even more force. Her arm, the one that had just waged war with the lamp, came to rest across Rio's stomach in a clumsy attempt at balance, while the other lay trapped between them, half-pinned under Agatha's own weight.

For a suspended second, Agatha didn't move.

She could feel Rio's heartbeat under her ear, steady and unbothered, as though this - her sprawled across her, face buried in her neck - was the most natural thing in the world.

And maybe it was.

Agatha swallowed hard, unsure what to do with her hands, her breath, her entire existence.

Then Rio shifted slightly, murmuring something incoherent against her hair. Her arm tightened imperceptibly, drawing Agatha closer, tucking her in without ever waking.

Agatha froze, the thoughts of pulling away ringing in her mind like alarm bells. But the warmth, the softness, the sheer comfort of it all - God, she hadn't realized how much she missed this kind of touch. Not sex, not lust, just being held.

She exhaled, long and shaky, letting that warmth thaw her defenses. This was what she wanted. This was what she'd hoped for.

Her muscles relaxed in increments until she finally let her full weight settle comfortably against Rio's body, adjusting her arms until she was fairly certain her circulation wasn't cut off.

As Rio's breathing evened out again, deep and rhythmic under her cheek, Agatha found herself thinking she could get used to it.

And, to her surprise, the thought didn't scare her.

Agatha woke before the alarm.

For a moment, she didn't move, too aware of the weight draped over her waist and the steady warmth claiming her body. It took her fogged mind a few seconds to piece the details together - the slow rise and fall of the surface under her cheek, the all-encompassing smell of Rio's shampoo, the unfamiliar sheets in a muted shade of green.

Then it came back to her, not in pieces but all at once.

The dinner. The kiss. The short conversation. The tangle of limbs that had ended with her half-sprawled across Rio's body in the dark.

Now, the early light seeped in through the narrow gap in the curtains - a single stripe of gold slicing through the dimness, crawling across the sheets until it settled on Rio's hand. The fingers were slack, half-curled against the dip of Agatha's lower back, the wedding band glinting faintly where the sunlight caught its edge.

Agatha's gaze lingered there, conflicted.

The ring had always been a prop - a gleaming lie born out of necessity, bureaucracy, and a single desperate idea that somehow became a contract. It was meant to stand for something that didn't exist then.

But in the quiet morning light, with Rio's hands holding her like they had every right to, it didn't feel false. Not anymore.

In the past month, with the distance between them widening, Agatha had started to think of it differently. The ring wasn't just evidence of deceit. It was a beginning. A strange, accidental one, sure, but a beginning nonetheless.

And maybe that was what she needed. Proof that Rio was here. That, for now, they had time - six more months to figure out what after looked like.

The thought soothed her in a way she wasn't proud of.

She exhaled softly, letting her eyes wander upward. Rio's face was just above hers, close enough that Agatha could count her eyelashes.

They hadn't moved much during the night, just enough that their legs had tangled and stayed that way. Agatha could feel the warmth of Rio's bare thigh pressed against her own, the faint brush of her breath against her temple, the soothing rise and fall of her chest.

She lay there, watching as best as she could without stirring too much.

It wasn't the first time she'd seen Rio asleep up close - they'd shared a bed in the aftermath of the accident, after all. But that had been different. Then, Agatha had been too startled by her own feelings to linger, too terrified that paying too much attention would only fan the fire she was already struggling to smother.

Now, she didn't even try to look away.

Her gaze softened of its own accord, tracing the contour of Rio's face with something dangerously close to reverence. The faint shadow of her lashes against her skin. The curve of her mouth, slightly parted. The slow, steady rhythm of her breathing - the kind that could lull Agatha right back to sleep if she let it.

And she wanted to.

The temptation to stay, to melt back into the pool of warmth and pretend the world beyond this bed didn't exist, settled on her like a weighted blanket. Just a few more minutes, she reasoned. Work wasn't that important. After all, it only paid for the house and the groceries and-

Her eyes flew open.

Nicky.

Her son's name hit like cold water, and she immediately scanned the nightstand for a clock. Of course, Rio didn't own one. Fucking younger generation and their stupid dependency on phones.

Still, judging by the angle of light already spilling across the covers, Agatha could tell she was cutting it close.

Which meant Nicky would be up soon.

And she definitely wasn't starting her morning by explaining to him why she was sneaking out of Rio's bedroom.

She drew in a slow breath, trying to commit the moment to memory before reality dragged her back into it - the faint smell of Rio's shampoo, the residual warmth where their bodies touched, the quiet, effortless peace that came with being beside her. Then, with all the precision of a surgeon, she began to shift, inch by inch, trying to free herself from Rio's hold without waking her.

That plan lasted all of three seconds.

Rio murmured something incoherent - a soft, sleepy sound that vibrated against Agatha's cheek - before her fingers tightened, curling into the hem of Agatha's shirt under the covers.

Agatha froze.

Rio's brow furrowed slightly, her breathing steady, even as her body pressed closer. Her head tilted to the side, nose brushing against Agatha's hair before settling there, the motion so unguarded, so tender, it sent a jolt straight through her chest.

"Rio," Agatha whispered, amusement bleeding into her voice.

"Mm," came the muffled reply, thick with sleep.

"Let me go."

Rio's grip tightened another fraction, her face burrowing further into the crown of Agatha's hair. "Stay," she mumbled. "S'warm."

Agatha sighed. She was not strong enough for this.

Before she could come up with a reply, Rio let out another small noise, something between a sigh and a groan. "You smell nice."

The words landed like an ambush, and if Rio didn't sound seconds away from falling back asleep, Agatha would have thought she was making this more difficult on purpose. "You're dreaming," Agatha murmured, gently prying Rio's fingers from her shirt one by one.

"No," Rio grumbled, eyes fluttering open just enough to catch a blur of Agatha's face as she sat up. "You're... leaving."

Her voice cracked faintly on the last word, and the sleepy vulnerability in it almost made Agatha consider getting her driver or an Uber for Nicky so she could spend the rest of the day enveloped in Rio's warmth.

But as tempting as that thought was, she quickly cast it aside, brushing a strand of hair off her girlfriend's forehead.

"I have work," she said softly, not sure if it was more to remind herself or inform Rio. "And you need rest. I'll see you later."

Rio's lips curved downward in an adorable pout. "Work sucks."

Agatha couldn't agree more. "It does," she nodded, tucking the covers closer around her. "Sleep, darling."

Rio's hand fell back to the mattress, her body relaxing almost instantly. Within seconds, her breathing evened out again, but the faintest traces of a pout remained on her face as she drifted back under.

Agatha lingered for a moment, watching her with an affection she didn't dare name. Then she leaned down, pressing the lightest kiss to Rio's temple - so soft it barely disturbed a single hair - before slipping out of the bed and into the cool air of the hallway.

The door clicked shut behind her with a quiet finality.

By the time Agatha reached the office, she'd managed to convince herself she was fine.

Mostly.

The first half of the drive had been tolerable. Despite the early hour, Nicky had seemed more energetic than ever, chattering about some new drills the camp coaches had promised to teach the group. Agatha had let the words wash over her, occasionally humming or adding a comment at just the right time to reassure him she was listening.

But once she'd dropped him off, the silence hit - and the drive turned into an exercise in restraint.

She knew the route to the office by heart, every lane change and every traffic light, but today, she had to focus on every turn, every stop sign, every breath. Because if she didn't, her traitorous hands might steer her right back to the house, back to the warmth, back to Rio's bed.

The pop playlist Nicky had insisted on - undoubtedly Rio's influence - did little to drown out the memory of her girlfriend's sleepy voice saying stay.

By the time Agatha parked, she already knew the day was a lost cause.

Now, sitting in her glass-walled office twenty stories above the city, surrounded by neatly stacked case files and the distant hum of conversation, she looked every inch the picture of composure. Tailored navy suit. Perfectly aligned pens. A calm expression honed through years of boardroom politics and courtroom warfare.

Her body was there.

Her mind wasn't.

It was still buried somewhere under Rio's sheets, clinging to the fading warmth that lingered against her skin.

"-Mrs. Harkness? Is everything alright?"

Agatha blinked. Her assistant was standing in front of her, laptop in hand, eyes wide with concern.

Shit, when did he even come in?

Her scowl formed before the thought did. "Is that a personal question, Teen?"

Billy straightened immediately, the laptop wobbling in his arms. "No, ma'am. Just making sure you, um, heard me?"

"I did," she lied, snapping her attention to him. "So what about this..."

"Filing," he supplied quickly. "For the nonprofit incorporation. The literacy group in Dorchester? You said you wanted to review the draft before we send it to the Secretary of the Commonwealth."

Right. That one. The teachers' initiative.

Agatha's memory clicked into place. "Yes. What about it?"

His Adam's apple bobbed as he swallowed nervously. "Ms. Ruiz says they're hoping to file by next week, but your schedule's already-"

"Squeeze it in."

"But-"

"I said, squeeze it in." She didn't raise her voice, but the tone was enough to make him nod quickly.

"Of course. Anything else?"

Agatha almost scoffed. She may not have remembered him coming in, but she was fairly certain he had done so uninvited. Certainly not because she needed him for something.

"No," she said briskly. "That'll be all."

Billy made a hasty retreat, muttering something about sending a calendar invite on his way out.

The moment the door clicked shut, Agatha dropped her shoulders and let out a quiet sigh. She fixed her bun, adjusted her jacket, and glared at her laptop screen. Unread emails stared back - over a hundred now - multiplying like a virus. The open case file hadn't moved an inch since morning, and the text of a deposition blurred in front of her eyes every time she tried to focus.

It was infuriating. She didn't lose focus. Not over anyone, least of all someone she'd already kissed - and slept beside - without combusting.

You're being ridiculous, she thought, mentally hitting herself over the head. This isn't high school. You're a fucking partner at this firm, not a blushing intern.

Her phone buzzed.

The screen lit up with a text.

Rio [12:04 PM]

just woke up

Three words. Casual. Effortless. Utterly devastating.

Agatha could almost hear them in Rio's voice - the lazy lilt, the scratch of sleep still clinging to it, the faint hint of mischief undercutting her exhaustion.

Her pulse tripped over itself.

For a full minute, she just stared at the message, thumb hovering over the screen, her mind offering a dozen responses, each worse than the last.

Wish I were there.

Jesus, what was she, a heroine in a romance novel?

I haven't slept that well in weeks. Can we make it a regular thing?

Okay, yeah, that sounded desperate even as a thought.

I can't focus on work because of you.

Technically true, but she wasn't admitting it to anyone, especially Rio.

Finally, her mind graciously supplied a reply that didn't make her want to chuck the phone across the room.

Me [12:07 PM]

Good. You needed the rest.

Clinical? Maybe. But still infinitely better than her other options.

Rio's reply came a second later.

Rio [12:07 PM]

ah so you really are in a mood

good morning to you too, querida

Agatha frowned, eyes darting toward the glass walls, where Billy sat unsuspecting at his desk, probably updating her calendar.

Narc.

Me [12:09 PM]

Should I start searching for a new assistant? Preferably one that doesn't know you?

Also, my day started six hours ago, but sure, good morning.

Rio [12:10 PM]

you like him too much to fire him

and besides, I need someone to keep me posted on when you're too busy to text me back

Agatha exhaled sharply through her nose, the beginnings of a smile threatening her composure. She straightened in her chair, glancing once more at Billy, who was blissfully unaware of the threat looming over his head.

She typed slowly, carefully, forcing her mind to come up with a response other than I'm never too busy for you.

Me [12:12 PM]

I tolerate him. Which can change very quickly if he keeps helping you with your espionage.

Three dots appeared instantly.

Rio [12:12 PM]

romantic espionage

arguably the best kind

Agatha felt the corners of her mouth twitch before she could stop them. "Unbelievable," she muttered under her breath, turning slightly toward the window so no one would notice the rare crack in her expression.

The last thing she needed was for people to see her blush like a teenager texting with her crush.

Her phone buzzed again.

Rio [12:13 PM]

also, I miss you

That one hit harder than it should have. No teasing, no deflection, just plain, unguarded truth.

Agatha stared at it for too long, her throat tightening, fingers hovering uselessly over the screen.

She could lie - say she had to go, make up a fake meeting, and threaten Billy with bodily harm if he said anything to Rio. She could ignore it altogether, bury herself in work until the moment passed.

But lying felt cruel.

And ignoring felt worse.

Finally, she typed:

Me [12:15 PM]

You saw me this morning.

Rio [12:15 PM]

I know

doesn't change anything

Agatha blinked at the phone, her professional resolve cracking like a faulty foundation.

She shouldn't have checked her phone. She knew this would happen - that every word from Rio would feel like a small gravity well tugging at her, pulling her thoughts out of orbit.

Her phone buzzed again, sending a jolt up her arm.

Rio [12:16 PM]

we need to do it more often

Agatha frowned at the message.

Me [12:16 PM]

Text in the middle of my workday?

Rio [12:18 PM]

sleep together

Agatha's pulse kicked up immediately, the memory of warm skin and tangled sheets flashing too vividly behind her eyes. She straightened in her chair, spine stiffening like that alone could save her composure.

Rio [12:18 PM]

but preferably on days when you don't have to abandon me at the crack of dawn

you're really not helping the vampire allegations btw

Agatha rolled her eyes at that, imagining the sly smirk on Rio's face.

Me [12:19 PM]

There are no allegations. Just your own conjectures.

Rio [12:19 PM]

you're suspiciously pale and avoid sunlight, it's the only valid explanation

aaand you're rich, ridiculously attractive, and have great hair

those are like the cornerstones of being a vampire

Agatha huffed a quiet laugh before catching herself, glancing at the office space beyond the glass walls. She lowered the phone slightly under the desk as if anybody could see the screen.

Me [12:21 PM]

You're impossible.

Rio [12:21 PM]

and yet you like me anyway

Agatha typed, then deleted three different responses before settling on the least incriminating one.

Me [12:22 PM]

You're bold in the morning.

Rio [12:22 PM]

you would've found out just how bold i can be if you didn't leave

Agatha froze, her mouth going dry. Her mind supplied the images before she could stop them - Rio in the bed, hair mussed, eyes darkened by the desire she'd seen the night before. Hands grabbing and pulling at clothes, sheets tangling and coiling around them like snakes, muffling heavy breaths and low gasp.

She crossed her legs.

Me [12:23 PM]

I'm at work, Rio.

Rio [12:23 PM]

my problem exactly

also, i meant cuddling in the morning

what were YOU thinking?

Me [12:24 PM]

Cuddling isn't bold. You know what you're doing.

Rio [12:25 PM]

mmmm, maybe

you gonna do something about it?

Agatha shifted in her chair again, the air stiffling despite the top two buttons of her shirt being undone.

She should end the conversation. She needed to end the conversation before she did something stupid like jump into her car and drive home.

Me [12:27 PM]

Yes. Put down my phone and get back to work.

Rio [12:27 PM]

you would've done that 10 minutes ago if you wanted to

still, you keep replying, smiling at your phone, crossing your legs...

Agatha's head shot up, ready to glare at Billy and rip his head off, but he wasn't at his desk anymore. In fact, he wasn't anywhere near her office.

"What the fuck?" she muttered, quickly tapping out her response.

Me [12:28 PM]

Rio, I swear to god, if you somehow installed cameras in my office, I'll fire teen for conspiring with you.

Rio [12:28 PM]

oh, querida, that was almost too easy

thank you for the confirmation though

Agatha exhaled through her nose, her cheeks burning with embarrassment. She could practically hear Rio's voice - smug, teasing, drenched in victory.

Me [12:29 PM]

Asshole.

Rio [12:29 PM]

interesting way of admitting i know you so well

but before you put your phone down just to prove a point, i was thinking movie night? you, me, Nicky

Agatha blinked at the screen, the abrupt turn catching her off guard. For a moment, she'd braced for another flirtatious retort or a teasing remark, not... this.

Especially when one detail didn't quite fit the question.

Me [12:30 PM]

Movie night? It's Friday, don't you have work?

Three dots appeared instantly, lingering on her screen for longer than before.

Rio [12:31 PM]

i changed my schedule two days ago

my abuela threatened to call you if i didn't sound more alive

she also yelled at me and called me stupid in the most loving way possible about how i've been handling things

Agatha's brows lifted slightly, amusement warring with something warmer, quieter. She could almost hear the older woman's voice - sharp, no-nonsense, and utterly fearless in her affection.

Me [12:32 PM]

I'm glad she put some sense into you.

Rio [12:33 PM]

it helped, but not as much as our conversation yesterday

Agatha felt warmth spread across her chest at the words. Before she could type out her answer, another message came through.

Rio [12:33 PM]

so, movie night?

Agatha glanced at the mountain of files looming over her desk. Her digital calendar flashed a migraine-inducing grid of meetings and check-ins she didn't care for, while new emails kept multiplying like rabbits in her inbox, the number inching toward triple-digits.

But the image that surfaced - Nicky tucked under a blanket, Rio stealing all the popcorn, the faint sound of laughter echoing through the living room - made the decision for her.

Me [12:34 PM]

If you don't fall asleep within the first fifteen minutes, sure.

Rio [12:34 PM]

i was gonna let you pick the movie but you just lost that privilege

hope you like hotel transylvania

at least you'll be able to point out the inaccuracies, vampire

Agatha rolled her eyes, but couldn't help the smile tugging at the corners of her mouth.

Me [12:35 PM]

The last time we watched it, Nicky spent three days ending every sentence with blah-blah-blah. I hope you're prepared.

I'll pick up the snacks on my way back.

Rio [12:36 PM]

great. i've got dinner covered

Agatha's laptop dinged with another notification, reminding her that she had a meeting in four minutes. She sighed, standing up from her chair.

Me [12:36 PM]

I have to go. See you at home.

Rio [12:36 PM]

aren't you forgetting something?

Agatha rolled her eyes again, gathering her laptop as she headed for the door.

Me [12:37 PM]

I'm not ending messages with blah-blah-blah.

Rio [12:37 PM]

you're a terrible vampire

see you at home🖤

She barely contained the smile threatening to overtake her face as she walked toward the meeting room.

Agatha balanced the grocery bag on her hip as she pushed the door open with her shoulder. The smell hit her before the sounds did - warm, rich, savory, with that faint sweetness that clung to the air whenever Rio cooked something from home.

Her heels clicked against the hardwood as she stepped inside, greeted by the soft hum of music playing from the kitchen and the rhythmic clatter of utensils.

"Smells like bribery," Agatha called out, locking the door behind her.

From the kitchen, Rio's voice floated back, light and unbothered. "Smells like dinner, actually. Bribery comes later."

Agatha allowed herself a small smile, tossing her keys into the bowl by the door and kicking off her heels before walking further into the house. She set the bag down on the kitchen counter, rolling her shoulders as she shrugged off her blazer. "What are you making?"

"Reheating, actually. You took longer than I thought," Rio said without turning from the stove, her voice light. Baby hairs clung to the back of her neck, curling from the heat as she stirred the pot with lazy precision. "Arroz con gandules and tostones. We already ate, though. I wanted to wait, but Nicky kept stealing everything when I wasn't looking, and..."

Agatha waved her hand at the apologetic tone, even though Rio still wasn't looking at her.

"It's fine," she said. "The last meeting ran longer than I expected, and then the interns created a metaphorical fire I had to put out."

She shook her head, not wanting to relieve the nightmare, and reached up to tug the elastic from her hair, freeing it with a quiet sigh. The instant release made her jaw relax, the ache at her scalp easing as dark waves spilled over her shoulders. She ran a hand through the loosened strands, eyes fluttering shut for one long, exhausted breath.

"Where's Nicky?" she asked, the soft music stopping her from hearing any other sounds in the house.

The stove clicked off, but no answer came.

Agatha opened her eyes, blinking through the haze of her own fatigue to find Rio staring at her.

Not glancing - staring.

Her gaze was slow and deliberate, sweeping from the tips of Agatha's hair to the open collar of her blouse, where the two undone buttons revealed the faintest glimpse of skin. Her throat bobbed as she swallowed, and Agatha could see the way her fingers flexed around the wooden spoon, grip tightening slightly.

The sight sent a spark through her blood.

"Rio?" she said quietly, half a question, half a warning.

No response. Just another step forward, almost subconscious, like Rio was being pulled closer by gravity alone. The distance between them shrank to two feet, the scent of sofrito and heat and Rio herself curling around Agatha until she could almost taste it.

Rio's lips parted, as if she was about to say something, but no sound came out.

Agatha tilted her head, the corner of her mouth twitching upward. "Rio," she repeated, slower this time, savoring the way the name lingered in the thick air.

That did it.

Rio blinked hard, like she'd just woken from a daydream, and froze mid-step. "I-" Her voice caught. She coughed once, rubbing the back of her neck. "Sorry. You were saying?"

Agatha arched a brow, arms crossing in a careful mix of authority and amusement. It only seemed to fluster Rio more. "I was asking about Nicky. Where is he?"

"Uh - right. Nicky." Rio nodded a little too quickly, eyes darting anywhere but at her, as if proximity itself had become dangerous. "He's in the living room, adding, um..." Her voice trailed off again. Her gaze dropped helplessly to Agatha's collar, to the small triangle of bare skin between two undone buttons.

Agatha chuckled, snapping her fingers in front of Rio's dazed face. "Really?" she drawled, though her own pulse betrayed her calm tone. "You've seen me come home from work hundreds of times. Can't you focus for two seconds?"

"You let your hair down," Rio said immediately, as if that explained everything. Her eyes flicked back to Agatha's, equal parts defiance and surrender. "And I'm only human. You can't expect me to pay attention when you look like that." She pointed the wooden spoon at Agatha as though she were delivering a closing argument.

There was nothing particularly daring about Agatha's clothes - fitted navy slacks, a crisp white button-up, bare feet. But Rio looked at her like she was seeing something indecent, something private she wasn't supposed to want as much as she clearly did.

Honestly, Agatha was kind of surprised she'd managed to hide that for months. Or maybe she hadn't - Agatha just didn't want to read into every look and give herself false hope.

Now, she tilted her head, the corners of her mouth curling in quiet victory. "What do I look like?"

Rio didn't even hesitate. "Hot."

The single word landed like a spark to dry kindling. Agatha felt the heat climb up her neck, but she met Rio's gaze steadily, refusing to let it show. "Romantic," she murmured, tone feigning innocence while her smirk betrayed her. "Now, am I going to find out what my son is doing in the living room, or will you combust before you share that detail with me?"

"I change my answer," Rio groaned, tossing the spoon into the sink. It clattered uselessly, the sound punctuating her frustration. "You look mean."

Agatha laughed softly - low and warm, the kind that made Rio's expression flicker between hunger and exasperation.

"He's adding finishing touches to his surprise," Rio said finally, eyes narrowing playfully as if daring Agatha to pry.

"Surprise?"

"Can't tell you. I pinky promised," she replied, her grin returning full force. "But he's occupied. And I banned him from the kitchen before he inhaled your food."

The mischievous gleam in her eyes was all it took for the spark between them to surge again, a crackling pulse of tension neither could fully disguise. Agatha blinked once, realizing her upper hand was slipping fast. "Oh?"

"So," Rio drawled, taking a slow, deliberate step forward, "how about a 'welcome home' kiss?"

Agatha's heartbeat tripped. "I was at work, not war."

Rio waved her hand, closing the last of the distance between them, her eyes fixed - hungrily, intently - on Agatha's mouth. "Semantics."

She didn't wait for a reply.

Her hand found the edge of the counter behind Agatha, caging her in with an easy, practiced confidence that made Agatha's pulse jump straight into her throat. The smells in the air lingered, spices she couldn't name mixed with garlic, but all she could focus on was the warmth of Rio's body pressing close.

Then Rio leaned in.

It was soft at first, like she was testing whether Agatha would let her. When Agatha didn't pull away, Rio deepened the kiss, her hand sliding up to cup the side of her neck, thumb brushing lightly against her jaw.

Agatha exhaled sharply, her body instinctively arching closer. The residual heat clinging to Rio's skin from working at the stove seeped into her clothes, spreading a fire down every nerve until Agatha forgot where she was, why this was a bad idea, the fact that she was supposed to win this game that-

Her stomach growled, and the noise broke through the haze like a slap.

Rio froze mid-kiss, then pulled back just enough to look at her, eyes blinking open in disbelief. For half a second, there was silence.

Then her lips curved into a slow, dangerous smile.

"Wow," she said, voice low and teasing, breath brushing against Agatha's cheek. "Guess you're starving for something else at the moment."

Agatha groaned, covering her face with one hand. "Shut up."

"A moment longer and you would've eaten me, gorgeous," Rio murmured, grin widening as the blush across Agatha's cheeks deepened.

The last thing she needed was the mental image of Rio on the counter, staring down at her as Agatha-

"Go change before I lose my mind completely," Rio interrupted her train of thought, giving her hip a playful squeeze before stepping back toward the stove. "I'll plate the food."

Agatha straightened her shirt - mostly to give herself something to do - and shot her a glare that wasn't nearly as sharp as she wanted it to be. "I hate you."

Rio glanced over her shoulder, spoon in hand, utterly unbothered. "You have an interesting way of showing it."

She didn't dignify that with a response - mostly because she couldn't come up with anything that wouldn't give Rio even more ammunition.

The scent of arroz con gandules still lingered in the air as Agatha rinsed off her plate and slid it into the dishwasher with a sigh. Rio's exquisite cooking was synonymous with comfort food, even though Agatha had never had Puerto Rican cuisine before meeting the woman, and it always left her warm and sleepy.

She almost regretted teasing Rio about falling asleep during the movie - right now, she was more likely to doze off on the couch before the first scene even began.

She closed the dishwasher with a soft click and scanned the rest of the kitchen lazily, more out of habit than necessity. The snacks had already been transferred to bowls and carried out by Rio, who had been called away by Nicky before Agatha even sat down. The urgency in her son's voice had made Agatha frown, but Rio merely sent her an apologetic smile, pressing the full plate into her hands and saying something along the lines of "you'll see".

That had been twenty minutes ago. Maybe thirty.

Long enough for her to start getting suspicious. Because as much as she trusted Rio with Nicky, she knew the woman tended to entertain the craziest of the boy's ideas for the sake of what she called 'science' and Agatha dubbed 'inability to say no."

She wiped her hands on a towel and headed toward the living room, calling out, "If you two have turned my furniture into an obstacle course again, I swear-"

Her voice trailed off as she rounded the corner.

The living room looked nothing like it had before she left for work. Every blanket and pillow in the house had been repurposed into an elaborate fort that sprawled across the rug like a miniature kingdom. The couch cushions had been turned on their sides to form makeshift walls, fairy lights strung across the top like a canopy. A faint glow spilled out from the interior, along with the unmistakable smell of popcorn.

And there, right in the middle of it all, stood Nicky - hands on his hips, a plastic hard hat on his head, a grin so wide it was almost comical.

"Ta-da!" he said, throwing his arms to the side. "Surprise!"

Agatha blinked. "What... exactly am I looking at?"

"A stroke of Nicky's genius!" Rio's voice came from inside the fort, muffled by blankets and enthusiasm. She crawled out, hair a little mussed, cheeks flushed from effort. "And you're just in time. It's officially not a construction site anymore."

Nicky nodded, yanking the hat off his head and throwing it to the side. It clattered against the floor, and Agatha followed it with her eyes - where did he even get that?

"I see," she said, crossing her arms and surveying the chaos with the kind of skeptical expression that only came from years of parenting. "And how long has it been a construction site?"

"Since right after dinner!" Nicky said proudly. "Rio told me about movie night after Mrs. Hart left, so we used Rio's lights and blankets from every room-"

"Mine included?"

"-Don't worry," Rio cut in quickly, grinning, "Egyptian cotton remained untouched. We made sure to use things that won't leave us in ruin if we get juice on them."

Agatha sighed, gaze sliding across the fort's roof that looked suspiciously like Rio's bedspread before settling on her son, who kept grinning at her proudly. "Great job, baby," she said, offering him a soft smile. "It looks very cozy."

Nicky's grin widened somehow - the kind of proud, toothy smile that made his eyes scrunch up and his chest puff out like a tiny general admiring his troops.

"You haven't even been inside yet!" he declared, grabbing her hand to pull her closer toward the fort.

The entrance was unobstructed, the blankets that had been fashioned into doors pushed to the side and secured with the string lights to leave a clear view of the TV.

When Agatha bent down, she blinked at the sight, momentarily speechless. She'd helped Nicky build her share of pillow forts, but not one came close to this. Her creations had always been wobbly, one wrong move away from collapsing, and fit for only one person - two if they squeezed together.

But this construction was sprawling, intricate in a way that spoke of practice and patience. The fort wasn't built; it was engineered, with specific types of pillows chosen for each wall, blankets laid out like a foundation, and fairy lights used partially to add elegance and partially to tie it all together.

"You did all this?" she asked, her voice gentler than she intended as she crouched a little closer to inspect the setup.

"Team effort!" Nicky explained immediately. "Rio made sure it wouldn't fall, and I made sure it looked pretty!"

"I handled structural integrity," Rio chimed in from behind him, grin wide and shameless. "You'd be surprised how much physics goes into keeping couch cushions upright."

Nicky nodded solemnly, like he was confirming something of grave importance. "Rio's a pro. She knew where to put everything, and it didn't even fall when I pushed one of the pillows!"

Rio's smile twitched into a glare that wasn't fooling anyone. "Which I told you not to do."

"We needed to test it!"

"We could've tested it without risking hours of work, mi científico loco." Rio pointed out before turning to Agatha, who was watching the exchange with a mixture of amusement and disbelief. "For the record," she added, noticing the small crease between the older woman's brows, "I have a long and decorated history with pillow forts. Not to brag, but I was undefeated among all my cousins."

Agatha huffed out a quiet laugh despite herself, her gaze sweeping over the structure again. Of course Rio had a history with this. That would explain why she'd managed to produce this architectural marvel, while Agatha's forts always looked more like condemned buildings.

Before Nicky, she'd never built one at all. Probably hadn't even sat in one. And now, staring at this glowing, blanket-draped fortress that looked straight out of a dream, she was beginning to realize what she'd been missing.

A tug on her hand snapped her out of her thoughts as Nicky urged her to get inside. "Come on, Mama! We've already waited forever for you."

"Yes, the horrors of letting your mother eat before movie night," she mused, crouching down to fit through the opening. The fairy lights brushed softly against her hair as she ducked beneath the edge of a blanket and crawled into the fort.

It was spacious, big enough to fit three people without feeling crammed, but Nicky still threw himself into the spot right next to her, his side pressed tightly against hers.

"Lights off!" he declared, waving the TV remote like a scepter.

Rio rolled her eyes, but dutifully walked over to the light switch, leaving the room bathed in the fairy light's soft glow.

"Here, your highness," she mused, reappearing in their line of sight as she crouched down to fit beside Nicky.

Agatha watched her maneuver her long limbs to fit into the space with the kind of careful precision that shouldn't have looked as graceful as it did. She steadied a bowl of popcorn with one hand, bracing the other against a pillow as she crawled into place beside Nicky, somehow managing to avoid kicking either of them in the process.

The fairy lights caught her as she moved, tiny reflections winking across her skin like starlight scattered on warm bronze. They traced the elegant curve of her neck, the slope of her shoulders, and lingered in her hair, creating a soft, golden glow.

She looked entirely at ease, void of the late-night exhaustion Agatha had gotten used to seeing. Her dark eyes shimmered with something gentle and unhurried - a quiet happiness that made Agatha's chest tighten.

There was something about the way Rio fit into the space, into this over-the-top fort made of blankets and snacks that put a small smile on Agatha's face.

Because Rio fit in like she belonged there. Like she was supposed to fill the quiet corners of Agatha's home with warmth and steadiness.

And as Agatha watched her settle in, she found herself thinking - not for the first time - that she could get used to this.

To her.

The thought lingered, quiet but insistent, as Rio leaned back into the pillows, stretching out her legs with a sigh.

"Okay," she said, throwing a blanket over the three of them and putting a bowl of popcorn in Nicky's lap. He stuffed a handful into his mouth before Agatha could even react. "Everyone ready?"

Nicky nodded hard enough to make the popcorn bowl wobble, and Rio fished out the remote from the heap of blankets, pressing play.

Agatha eyed the TV suspiciously as the Columbia Pictures logo came into view, quickly followed by familiar animated bats swooping across the screen. "You really went with Hotel Transylvania?" she asked, arching a brow.

"As promised," Rio replied with an easy smile. "And it was a democratic decision. Right, bud?"

"Totally!" Nicky agreed quickly, even though Agatha suspected he didn't really understand what democracy was.

Agatha rolled her eyes, but the soft curve of her lips betrayed her. "I'm not sure I like you two ganging up on me."

Rio clicked her tongue, shaking her head in mock-disbelief. "You're trying to tell me you don't like democracy?"

"I doubt it was in the room when you decided to make me suffer through a movie about a vampire hotel."

"Defensive," Rio hummed. "Almost like you're afraid it'll expose you or something."

Agatha opened her mouth to fire back when Nicky groaned. "You're missing all the important stuff!" he complained, gesturing to the screen as if they were watching the movie for the first time and not the hundredth. "No talking in the fort."

Rio glanced at him, undeterred by his attempt at a stern look. "I thought we decided on no rules."

"I'm the king of the fort," he replied confidently, puffing out his chest. "And the king changed his mind."

"And does your highness know that he is the one talking?"

"Just to shush you!"

Rio smirked, leaning closer to Nicky. "Selective enforcement of the law. You'd make a great politician someday."

Nicky eyed her suspiciously. "Can I still be king?"

"Sure," Rio said with a wink. "As long as I'm in your inner circle, you can be as corrupted as you want."

Agatha bit back a smile at the ease of their conversation and reached for a handful of popcorn from Nicky's bowl. "If you two are done establishing your new, highly corrupted government, can we watch the movie before bedtime?"

"Yes, ma'am," Rio said with exaggerated deference, earning a snicker from Nicky.

They refocused on the TV, shifting into more comfortable positions, which led to Nicky being essentially squished between them despite the fort's size. He didn't seem to mind, though, sinking into the warmth with a content hum, his eyes never leaving the screen as he began mouthing along to the lines.

The fort filled with sounds of laughter and cartoon chaos, blending with the occasional rustle of blankets or crunch of snacks. Nicky's head eventually moved to rest on Rio's arm stretched behind his pillow, his legs thrown over Agatha's knees as he predictably occupied more space than he needed.

Agatha didn't mind. She relaxed into the comfortable bubble they'd created, letting go of the day's stress and letting her eyes drift closed.

At first, she thought she'd imagined it - the faintest brush of something against her hair. It was enough to force her tired mind back into gear, eyelids fluttering open as she half-expected to see the makeshift ceiling caving in.

But then the feeling reappeared, making her realize the touch was far too gentle, too subtle, to come from a faulty construction. Rio's fingers traced the loose ends of Agatha's ponytail, thoughtlessly curling and uncurling a few strands she'd managed to reach.

Agatha didn't move. She only exhaled slowly, pulse skipping, eyes trained on the TV while her focus slipped further and further from cartoon monsters.

Rio readjusted, careful not to jostle Nicky, and the touch came again - a slow twirl, a featherlike graze against her neck that made her skin prickle with awareness.

And then, with a tiny, silent motion, Agatha reached up and tugged the tie off.

Her hair fell over her shoulders, soft and loose, catching faint glimmers of the fairy lights. Rio didn't miss a beat; her fingers slid deeper, tracing lazy patterns just below the hairline, like she'd been waiting for that exact moment.

The rest of the world faded into a hum. The movie, Nicky's giggles, even the flicker of light from the screen, became background noises as Agatha leaned further into the touch, savoring every brush of Rio's fingertips against her skin.

It was such a simple thing, almost trivial, but it made something in Agatha unwind, thread by thread.

She hummed contentedly before she could stop herself, then glanced at Rio to see if the woman had noticed the reaction. Dark eyes flicked over to hers, warm and soft in a way that made something in Agatha's chest tighten, a small smile dancing at the corners of those lips Agatha had spent most of her workday thinking about.

They stared at each other for a few beats, their eyes communicating everything their mouths couldn't before Rio finally broke the contact, turning back to the screen. Her fingers never stopped twirling the strands, though, slow and gentle - a way to show presence without making it obvious.

To anyone else, it would've looked casual. Innocent.

But to Agatha, it felt like everything.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! As always, thank you for the comments, kudos, and just sticking with this story in general.
There was a question about whether I know how many chapters this will have (thank you for the long comment, I really enjoyed reading it), and the truth is, I have no idea. This story proved to me that planning and executing are two very different things, and at this point, I can't even give you a ballpark number. All my plans went to shit about fifteen chapters ago because I keep writing scenes that are more detailed than I expected, needing to split chapters, and ending up with far too many words. Sorry!
Also, this chapter is over 10k because I have no self-control, but it might mean that the wait for the next one will be longer than a week. Not necessarily, but you know how it is.

Chapter 38: Not enough

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

It was slowly getting ridiculous.

Or, more accurately, fucking excruciating.

Because Rio had kept her promise.

She wrote when Nicky was at camp, went out for research right before Sharon drove him home, and cut down on her late-night shifts. The dark circles under her eyes faded day by day, replaced by color and light. There was laughter again, the quiet kind that slipped out mid-sentence, and that familiar spark when Rio started talking about something she loved.

It was good. Healthy. Stable.

And utterly unbearable.

Because what truly tested Agatha's composure wasn't Rio's improved schedule - it was the fact that she was home most nights. So when Nicky was asleep, and the house had gone still, it was the two of them.

The new routine started innocently enough. Agatha would settle into her favorite chair with her laptop balanced on her knees, half-reading through contracts she'd already redlined twice or flagging down emails she'd have to circle back to. Rio would sprawl across the couch, barefoot and utterly relaxed, the glow from the TV washing over her as some sitcom rerun played in the background.

Sometimes they talked about little things - work, Nicky, a book Rio had just finished, a case Agatha couldn't quite let go of. Other nights, they didn't bother with conversation at all. It was enough to just be there, in the living room's stillness punctuated by the TV's hum and the soft clack of keys.

And then, like clockwork, Rio would put down whatever she was working on. She'd stretch, arms over her head, shirt riding up just enough to test Agatha's self-control, and disappear into the kitchen.

She always came back with something: two glasses of wine, mismatched mugs of tea, a bowl of cut-up fruit. She'd set them on the coffee table, just out of Agatha's reach - a silent challenge, a wordless invitation.

Move.

And, inevitably, she did.

It became a quiet ritual, familiar and dangerous all at once.

The first two nights, it was harmless. They'd sit side by side, knees brushing as they worked or read or pretended to watch whatever sitcom Rio had put on. Agatha nursed the offered drinks, rereading the contracts and letting herself relax into the moment.

But then came the small shifts - the casual touches that weren't so casual anymore. They grew bolder, evolving into something far less innocent.

Sometimes Rio's hand would settle on her thigh and stay there, heavy and warm, thumb stroking idle patterns against the fabric of her slacks. Other times she'd lean in close under the pretense of showing Agatha something on her phone, her breath fanning over Agatha's neck, the scent of coffee and cedar wrapping around her like a trap.

And every time, Agatha felt her pulse stutter, the air around them thickening until it felt like breathing took effort.

They both knew what they were doing.

They also knew what they couldn't do, not with Nicky sleeping under the same roof in a house that carried every sound.

It was fucking torture. Sweet, exquisite, self-inflicted torture.

Because once their lips found each other, there was no stopping it.

It was almost clumsy the first time it happened, a collision of suppressed wants rather than a kiss. It left them stunned, heads resting together in silence, their heartbeats trying to catch up.

The second time, there was no hesitation.

And now it had become a pattern.

Nicky went to bed. They settled in the living room. Rio stretched and left to bring something from the kitchen. Agatha moved to the couch. Then they collided.

They'd end up tangled on the couch, the low light from the TV flickering over them as Rio pressed her mouth to Agatha's, one hand buried in her hair, the other gripping her waist like she needed the anchor. Agatha would respond with equal hunger, fingers sliding beneath the hem of Rio's shirt, feeling the heat of the skin that made her dizzy.

It wasn't gentle anymore. It was urgent. Needy in the best way.

Agatha would try to keep quiet, biting back sounds that might carry up the stairs, while Rio's breath hitched against her mouth, their rhythm messy and desperate.

The most recent one left her completely wrecked.

It started innocently, like all the others - a shared glass of wine, some rerun they weren't really watching. Rio's gaze snagged on one of the plants littering the living room - a philodendron, one of the few Agatha could actually name - and she started talking about soil and light and everything that should not have made Agatha's stomach tighten the way it did.

But Agatha was only human, and Rio's enthusiastic babbling paired with the gleam in her eye was - God help her - hot.

"You're such a fucking nerd," she grumbled, already reaching for Rio's jaw.

She greedily swallowed whatever protest Rio was about to vocalize, her world narrowing to the warmth of her girlfriend's mouth.

The kiss seemed to deepen the moment it started, the familiarity of each movement stripping it of hesitation. Agatha's fingers gripped Rio's face more firmly while her other hand curled into the back of her shirt, pulling her closer until Rio was practically in her lap, one knee pressing between her thighs. The position sent a shiver up Agatha's spine, sharp and electric, and she barely registered Rio's hands on her shoulders until they were pushing against her, severing the contact.

The whine that left her throat was so pathetic that she would've curled up and died from mortification if she were capable of feeling anything other than want.

"Agatha-" Rio panted out, voice torn between a warning and a plea.

The logical part of her brain knew this was a bad idea - a tremendously bad idea, if she were being honest - but that part took a back seat when Rio shifted slightly, accidentally pressing her thigh right between Agatha's legs.

Her lips moved to Rio's neck. "He's asleep," she murmured against the soft skin, grazing the fluttering pulse point with her teeth before sucking on it gently.

Rio let out a low sound, something between a groan and a moan, as her grip on Agatha's hair tightened, tugging her away only to crash their lips together.

Agatha could taste the wine on Rio's tongue, feel the low hum of stifled moans vibrate between them when she gasped into the kiss. It was simultaneously too much and not enough, the slow, subconscious grind of their hips fanning the flames they both knew they'd have to put out by the evening's end.

Agatha didn't want it to end.

She was actually about a minute away from testing just how quiet they could be when Rio broke the kiss again, pressing their foreheads together. "We should stop," she said softly, struggling to catch her breath. "While I still have the mental capacity to do so."

It was the right thing to do. The sensible thing.

Agatha still fucking hated it.

"We're technically the furthest from Nicky's room," she said, trying for casual. It didn't work. "And he's a heavy sleeper."

Rio pulled back, fingers playing with the baby hairs at the nape of Agatha's neck. She looked just as wrecked as Agatha felt - eyes dark, hair mussed, lips red and swollen. Her voice was hoarse when it came again, thick with self-restraint. "You're the one who insisted we wait until he's out of the house for the night, mi alma."

Agatha almost groaned. God, past her could be so utterly stupid sometimes. "Can't a woman change her mind?"

"She can," Rio agreed, a teasing smile stretching her lips. "But if she waits, she can also be as loud as she wants."

Well, that was just cruel.

Regrettably, it also worked well enough for her brain to finally look past the lust-laden haze.

Agatha's head fell against the backrest with a defeated thud, her hands lessening their hold on Rio's hips. "You're enjoying this too much."

"Enjoying?" Rio repeated with a laugh, shaking her head. "I'm dying, Agatha. Slowly combusting on the inside. Suffering from blue balls."

"That's fake."

"Yeah, and I also don't have balls, but you get the gist."

Agatha huffed out a laugh, quiet and breathless, still half-pinned beneath her. "That suffering is self-inflicted."

Rio's grin softened, the humor fading into something almost tender. "It is," she said, brushing her thumb along Agatha's jaw. "But I meant what I said about timing."

Her touch lingered, tracing the corner of Agatha's mouth, the edge of her chin, slow and reverent, like she was memorizing her by feel.

"I want to appreciate you," Rio murmured, the words a whisper that skimmed over Agatha's lips. "And I need time to do that."

Agatha swallowed hard, pulse hammering. "We have time now."

Rio shook her head with a smile. "Not enough. And you deserve better than rushed. Better than quiet."

The honesty in her voice hit harder than the restraint itself. Agatha's breath caught. There it was again - that careful way Rio handled her, like she was something precious and not a woman in her forties with a kid and a life built around control.

Like she was worth being undone properly.

Rio leaned forward, pressing a slow, open-mouthed kiss to her throat, the kind that was more promise than act. "When it happens," she said softly, "I want you loud. I want you unthinking. I want all of you."

Agatha's fingers flexed against Rio's hips, nails dragging lightly through the fabric of her sweats. "You're mean."

"And that's usually your thing, huh?" Rio mused, though her voice was low and rough. "Patience, mi vida. The time will come."

Agatha bit back a remark about how she'd much rather come, knowing that Rio was right.

The waiting was torturous, and Agatha had never been above a quick, messy hook-up, but this was different. Rio wasn't some woman she'd forget the next morning. She wasn't a warm body Agatha could use to relieve tension. She was her girlfriend, which meant a whole new level of intimacy.

It scared her, to a certain degree - not just how much she wanted Rio, but how much Rio seemed to want her. How every time they pulled apart, Rio looked ruined, seconds away from throwing caution to the wind and devouring her whole. It was more than a simple craving, more than lust.

Agatha figured that was what truly wanting someone looked like - bone-deep, all-consuming, raw.

A part of her also didn't know why Rio looked at her like that - didn't think she deserved it - but she tried not to focus on those thoughts too much.

Rio slid off her lap and onto the cushion beside her, snapping Agatha out of her thoughts. The sounds of fake laughter from the TV filled the silence as their fingers intertwined, resting against Rio's thigh.

Rio's thumb traced slow, lazy circles over the back of her hand, the kind that soothed and burned at the same time. Agatha stared at their joined hands, almost smiling at the sight. Compared to Rio's tan skin, her own looked pale, almost transparent, with the blue veins peeking through like tangled roads on a map.

No wonder Rio called her a vampire.

"We should probably stop torturing ourselves," Rio murmured after a long moment.

Agatha huffed out a strained laugh. "You started it."
