"I was literally just talking about the philodendron," Rio said, the corner of her mouth lifting. "You're the one who pounced."

"That's not how I remember it."

Rio grinned, but the tension under it didn't fade. It wasn't awkwardness - more the ache of wanting that had nowhere to go.

Agatha tilted her head back and stared at the ceiling. She didn't want to say it, didn't want the moment to end, but the clock on the wall was merciless. "We should probably head to bed," she murmured.

"Yeah," Rio said after a beat, her voice low, reluctant. She didn't move, though. "My room?"

It was almost enough to make her cave.

They'd talked about the sleeping arrangements before, after Agatha had spent the night in Rio's bed. They'd discussed it, debated it, even pouted about it - mostly Rio - until they came to an agreement that neither of them liked but both understood: it couldn't be an every-night thing.

It wasn't about temptation, not really. They were adults. They had restraint, or at least enough of it to stop every time things teetered too close to indecent for a house shared with a ten-year-old.

No, it was about what it meant.

Waking up beside Rio was a slippery slope - the kind of comfort that crept in quietly, then refused to leave. Agatha had already struggled to fall asleep without the steady warmth of her body beside her, and she couldn't let her mind learn that dependency. Not when there was a child in the house who still sometimes crawled into her bed after bad dreams.

And there was always the risk - the sound of small feet padding down the hallway, a sleepy knock on her door, or worse, catching her sneaking out of Rio's room at dawn. It wasn't worth the questions, the explanations, the confusion.

But God, it didn't make it any easier.

Rio was watching her now, eyes soft and patient, a little understanding mixed with something that looked too much like longing.

"Not tonight, darling," Agatha said finally, her voice gentler than she meant it to be. It still came out sounding like regret.

Rio's lips quirked into something resembling a smile. "Didn't think so," she murmured. "Had to try, though."

"You always do."

"Because," Rio said, standing and stretching with a quiet groan, "sometimes you say yes."

Agatha's gaze followed her, the familiar ache stirring low in her chest. "Moments of weakness."

Rio smirked faintly, leaning down to press a kiss to her temple. "My favorite moments," she whispered into Agatha's hair before pulling away. "Goodnight, querida."

"Goodnight," Agatha echoed, watching her disappear around the corner and wondering how much longer she could keep pretending that a few stolen evenings would ever be enough.

By noon the next day, Agatha's desk looked like a crime scene.

Contracts, post-its, and half-drunk coffee cups formed an unholy alliance across her workspace, the result of a morning that seemed determined to test the limits of her patience. Her inbox overflowed, three different paralegals were waiting on her signature, and the opposing counsel in her current case had apparently decided to redefine incompetence.

For some reason, the universe had chosen today to remind her that life outside of Rio existed.

Agatha didn't appreciate the reminder.

Still, the sheer amount of work kept her distracted - something she needed more than she cared to admit. Because when she wasn't buried in paperwork or chewing through emails, her mind wandered to places it absolutely shouldn't.

Falling asleep thinking about Rio - about how good it would feel to have her pressed up close, warm and flushed and whispering things that should not be echoing in Agatha's head during business hours - was one thing.

But daydreaming about that while sitting in her glass-walled office, surrounded by junior associates who were supposed to see her as an unfeeling machine? That was unacceptable.

She had a reputation to maintain, damn it.

So, when the door to her office opened without a knock, she didn't even look up. "I said no interruptions, Teen. Are you incapable of following direct orders?"

"Okay, that explains why Billy looked at me like I had a dead wish or something."

Agatha froze. The voice - familiar, amused, and far too casual for her office - snapped her out of her irritation. Her head jerked up so fast her neck protested with a crack.

Sure enough, there she was.

Rio stood in the doorway like she'd just walked into a coffee shop, not one of the most prestigious law firms in the city. Her left hand pushed the door closed behind her while her right held up a takeout bag emblazoned with the logo of Agatha's favorite salad place - the one that charged absurd prices for something made of leaves and air.

She looked utterly out of place in the sterile, wood-and-glass office. Her jeans were cuffed and faded in all the right places, her Red Hot Chili Peppers T-shirt was soft and wrinkled, and her hair was pulled into a messy bun that somehow looked artful instead of rushed.

And yet, she moved like she belonged there. Like she could walk through this firm full of steel nerves and sharper tongues and make the entire floor bend to her rhythm.

"Special delivery," she said, waltzing across the office as if Agatha's name on the door made it hers by association. She dropped into one of Agatha's expensive leather chairs with the same ease she had when sinking into their couch at home and held out the bag. "I come bearing greens and overpriced protein."

Agatha blinked, trying to remember how to form words. "You... brought me lunch?"

Rio shrugged, a smirk tugging at the corner of her mouth. "I figured you forgot that was a thing people do between coffee IV drips."

Agatha's eyes darted to her assistant's desk, but Billy was nowhere in sight. Convenient.

"He didn't rat you out," Rio laughed, reading her mind. "I actually had to get Lilia to let me in because he's too scared of you. There was a lot bitching and moaning about getting fired involved."

Honestly, Agatha would've preferred Billy to go behind her back and let Rio in instead of Lilia. Now she'd probably have to endure knowing little smiles from the older woman, paired with off-handed comments about how she always knew something real would come out of it.

Lilia's intuition never failed, and Agatha hated her for it.

"You couldn't break in like the last time?" she asked, accepting a container as Rio held it out to her.

"I didn't break in," Rio argued, setting the empty bag aside. "I just looked furious enough for the security to escort me to your floor. They probably would've dragged me out if you started screaming bloody murder."

Agatha chuckled, expertly tearing off the lid and suppressing a smile at the sight of the Greek Salad waiting for her. Her stomach grumbled in appreciation, reminding her that she couldn't survive on coffee and spite alone.

As she reached for the fork, her gaze drifted up to Rio's face, a thank you on her tongue, but something gave her pause.

There was a faint tension around her girlfriend's mouth, not quite matching the teasing words that were probably supposed to mask it. Her smile was genuine, but strained, like she was fighting to keep it in place.

Something was off.

She leaned back in her chair, momentarily forgetting about the salad. "This isn't just you making sure I don't starve, is it?"

"Damn," Rio chuckled, but it came out strained, her smile wobbling. "Nothing gets past those lawyer instincts, huh?"

"Rio."

The tone of her voice was enough for Rio's amused mask to falter again before it cracked completely, its fall punctuated by a sigh.

"Something came up when I was on my way here."

Agatha straightened, the casual posture she'd been forcing herself to maintain dissolving. "What happened?"

Rio's fingers tightened around the takeout fork, turning it absently between her fingers before she glanced toward the glass wall that separated them from the rest of the office.

It was technically lunch hour, which meant the floor had thinned out - half the staff were out or in the kitchen, making use of the break. Still, a few junior associates lingered near their desks, all pretending very hard not to look toward the corner office where the firm's most feared partner was being visited by a woman in cuffed jeans and a faded band T-shirt.

Agatha didn't need to look to know they were watching.

People always watched.

Especially when someone like Rio - warm, vibrant, unapologetically genuine - stepped into a place designed to suffocate personality.

"The room's soundproofed," Agatha said, impatience threading through her tone. She could tell Rio was hesitating, and that made something uneasy stir in her gut. "Just tell me."

Rio turned back to her. Her usual spark was gone, replaced by sharp, unsettled focus. "Alice called," she finally said. "She worked the closing shift at the bar last night. Said some guy came up to her - about six feet, white, brown hair, nothing remarkable except..." She paused, her brow furrowing. "She said his eyes were almost black. The kind that makes you feel like they're swallowing you whole."

A cold, familiar knot formed in Agatha's stomach. She knew those eyes. They'd stared at her from the witness stand more times than she cared to remember.

"The PI."

Rio's jaw tightened, and the sigh she let out was confirmation enough. "Yeah. That's what I thought. Figured you'd recognize him from the description."

Agatha took off her glasses and set them neatly on the desk, the motion deliberate. Her pulse had quickened, but her voice stayed even. Controlled.

"Let me guess," she said. "He wasn't there for a drink."

Rio's mouth quirked humorlessly. "Not even close."

"What did he want?"

Rio hesitated only long enough to gather her thoughts. "He asked Alice a couple of questions. She shut him down immediately, but she did some digging after he left. Asked the bartenders, a few of the regulars."

Agatha already knew where this was going, and she hated it.

"Turns out," Rio continued, "this was the third time he's come by. Always during shifts when I wasn't around. And since my schedule is almost identical to Alice's-"

"She didn't see him there either," Agatha finished for her, the words clipped. "Why didn't anybody else mention a strange man asking about you? It seems like cause for concern."

Rio twirled the fork between her fingers, a restless movement that betrayed her frustration. "They probably thought it was some dude with a crush. Trying to get information so he could work up the courage to ask me out."

Agatha's eyes narrowed. "That sounds like the beginning of a harassment case."

"Yeah, well," Rio sighed, "he only talked to men. Straight men. So I doubt the 'creepy stranger' alarm bells ever went off. If they even have those."

Agatha drummed her fingers once against the desk, jaw tightening. "What did they tell him?"

"Most regulars barely remember the conversation since he always caught them on the right side of drunk," Rio said. "But the ones that do remember said it was small talk, stuff like how long I'd been working there, whether I was single, if I flirted with them while pouring their drinks. The usual."

Agatha arched a brow. "That's not usual."

"Not for us," Rio agreed, lips pressing into a thin line. "But people usually don't think about espionage between cocktails. And I don't talk about my private life on shift, so he didn't get much."

"And the staff?"

Rio leaned back in her chair, rubbing her hand against her jaw. "The questions got more personal, focused on my... romantic life. That's why they thought he was just a guy with a crush."

Agatha withheld from commenting on just how moronic that reasoning was. If she'd seen a strange man ask about a married coworker twice, knowing that same coworker had been attacked before at her place of work, she certainly wouldn't have entertained his delusions.

"Don't they know you're my-" she stopped herself, rephrasing the question. "Don't they know you're married?"

The word felt weird on her tongue, like it didn't belong there after everything real that had grown between them.

It seemed to have the same effect on Rio, whose mouth tightened slightly as if to suppress a frown. "He chose people I'm not close with," she admitted, her voice measured. "I'm not a detective, let alone a lawyer, but I think it was purposeful. A way to test if those I consider more coworkers than friends know about the marriage."

Agatha leaned forward slightly. "He asked them about it?"

"In a way that seemed more like small talk than interrogation," Rio said. "Questions like if I wear my wedding ring at work, if I talk about my wife, if she's ever come by the bar. Nothing too direct or provoking."

Agatha worked her jaw, keeping her voice calm. "So he's searching for gaps. People who'll say they didn't even know you were married, or that they've never seen me."

"Which they haven't," Rio pointed out, not accusatory, just matter-of-fact. "They know I'm married, though. I never leave the house without the ring."

At the mention, Agatha's eyes dropped to the gold band circling Rio's finger. Despite being only six months old, it already bore the marks of wear - tiny scratches and soft dents that caught the sterile office light. It was well-loved now, molded to Rio's hand. Proof that she wore it not for show, but out of habit.

Agatha tapped a finger against her desk before looking back up. "He's been watching us for two months, give or take. My mother must be pressing for proof."

Rio frowned, her expression thoughtful. "You think Evanora's getting impatient?"

"I know she is." Agatha leaned back in her chair, expression darkening. "She thought showing up at the restaurant would shake us. It didn't. Then she tried paying you off and walked away with a bruised ego. Both those stunts happened while the PI was following us, which means he didn't deliver the results she wanted."

"So now he's escalating. Moving on to a more hands-on approach," Rio said, nodding. "Wouldn't starting with our closest friends make more sense, though?"

"Theoretically, yes," Agatha allowed, tilting her head. "But remind me - how exactly did Alice react when he tried asking her questions?"

Rio's face lit up with recognition before the corners of her lips curved upward. "Fair point. Nobody we actually know would give him the time of day."

"Exactly." A faint smirk tugged at Agatha's mouth. "My mother might be a manipulative, cold-hearted bitch, but she understands people. She knows loyalty makes them tight-lipped. So she's counting on strangers - the acquaintances, the coworkers, the people who see us from a distance but don't know us."

Rio twirled her fork idly between her fingers, thoughtful. "So what do we do now?"

Agatha considered it for a moment, her tone turning strategic. "We close the gaps. If he's talking to people who don't know about me, then we fix that. Subtly, naturally - no sudden changes, nothing that looks like a cover-up."

Rio tilted her head, a mischievous glint forming behind her eyes. "You want me to stand on the bar and declare my undying devotion to everyone listening? Because I will."

"Subtly, Rio," Agatha repeated, though a reluctant smile crept into her voice. "It can be as small as dropping by each other's workplaces, being seen in the right places, at the right times. A lunch delivery here, a casual check-in there."

"Which just happened," Rio noted, catching on. "Did my romantic gesture just inspire your devious plan?"

Agatha rolled her eyes, but the fondness was impossible to miss. "There's hardly anything devious about it. Just... pragmatic."

Rio laughed softly, but the tension didn't leave her shoulders. She fiddled with the fork again, expression sobering. "He pissed me off before, but now it's different. He's not just prying - he's trying to erase what we've built. To make it look like we're still pretending." She hesitated, her tone dropping lower. "We're not pretending anymore. There's nothing to prove."

Agatha didn't answer immediately.

She wanted to agree - to echo it, to let it stand as the only truth - but she couldn't. Because while their feelings weren't pretend anymore, the marriage still was. A paper construct with real consequences. And her mother wouldn't stop until she tore it down.

Letting the real part of their relationship influence their commitment to keeping up the lie created room for error. They couldn't relax into believing the authenticity of their feelings would protect them from Evanora. Not when Agatha was certain the woman would try to discredit the marriage even if she didn't think it was fake.

She swallowed the thoughts, studying Rio instead. "Which just means he's not going to find what he's looking for," she said at last, voice steady but softening around the edges. "Because it doesn't exist anymore."

Rio held her gaze, something shifting in her expression - understanding, maybe, or affection tempered with frustration. Then she exhaled, her lips quirking into that small, cooked smile Agatha could feel in her chest.

"You know," she said lightly, "I could get used to this. Eating lunch in your office while you tell me romantic things."

Agatha arched a brow. "Eating is a bit too generous, don't you think?" she asked, gesturing to the full containers before finally picking up her fork. Lunch hour had technically ended about five minutes ago, but her stomach didn't care about schedules - or optics.

Rio mirrored her movements, finally spearing a piece of lettuce with exaggerated care. "I honestly didn't mean for this to turn into a strategic briefing," she said. "Or a part of our anti-Evanora contingency plan."

"Neither of those things makes me appreciate the gesture less," Agatha replied, voice smooth as she methodically assembled the perfect bite. "But next time, no conspiring behind my back. I know Teen's your informant when it comes to my schedule, but it changes by the hour. Just text or call before you decide to surprise me."

Rio chuckled, shaking her head. "You do realize that defeats the purpose of a surprise, right?"

"It's the only way to ensure I'll be all yours for more than five minutes."

The words slipped out before Agatha could stop them - unfiltered, quiet, too honest.

And the way Rio's mouth curved in response was nothing short of dangerous.

"All mine, huh?" she said slowly, tasting the words like something decadent. "I like the sound of that."

Agatha rolled her eyes, maintaining her composure despite the familiar spike of warmth traveling up her spine. "That's hardly news. We've been together for over a month."

"Still," Rio leaned forward, elbows resting on her knees, her tone dipping into something low and warm, "you should be careful saying things like that, querida. Especially in places where it could end with an HR violation."

Against her better judgment, Agatha's gaze flicked toward the glass wall.

Most of the staff had trickled back to their desks, but the air outside her office seemed thick with gossip. Associates and paralegals clustered in pairs, pretending to read documents while their eyes occasionally darted toward the glass. The ones who thought they were being discreet were, as usual, the worst offenders.

She turned back to Rio, unimpressed. "Behave, then. The last thing I need is Marcy from HR barging in here with her fake smile and that voice that could crack glass."

Rio's laugh was quiet, low in her throat - the kind that lingered. "Sounds like you and Marcy go way back."

Agatha let out an unamused huff, gathering another bite. "It's not my fault people get offended when I point out their incompetence. I'd be doing society a disservice by keeping quiet."

Rio grinned at that, her eyes bright with amusement. "No wonder everyone thinks you're terrifying. Do they know you have a soft side?"

"I don't."

"Mhm," Rio hummed, unconvinced. "Hard to believe when you literally offered to sleep in a chair because I had a bump on my head."

"A concussion, Rio," Agatha corrected, tone clipped. "You had a concussion, and observation was one of the doctor's first instructions."

"Right." Rio's smirk deepened. "Just doctor's orders. Certainly no worry or affection involved."

Agatha gave her a look that was supposed to be stern but landed somewhere closer to fond resignation. "Eat your lunch. Before I remember I'm actually at work."

Her girlfriend chuckled again, a low, satisfied sound that said she knew she'd won. Still, she obediently turned back to her food, though the exaggerated concentration she applied to chewing was pure performance.

For a few minutes, the only sounds in the office were the muted scraping of forks and the distant hum of the air conditioner. It was domestic in a way that felt almost ridiculous in the sterile office used to clipped voices and forced politeness.

Then Rio tossed her fork into the empty container with a clatter and leaned back in her chair, stretching her long legs out with a satisfied sigh. "You know," she said, glancing toward the glass wall, "I'll never understand why big firms have this obsession with transparency. What about privacy?"

Agatha dabbed her mouth with a napkin, her expression dry. "Privacy is secondary to control. People work harder when they know they might be watched."

"Sure, but that means you are being watched, too."

"Yes, I'm sure they're riveted - watching me glare at paperwork and mutter obscenities under my breath."

Rio tilted her head toward the glass again, raising an eyebrow. "They seem pretty riveted watching you right now."

"Us," Agatha corrected crisply. "They're watching us, because your visit is going to be the most exciting thing to happen in this office all week."

"They already saw me at the gala," Rio reminded her. "You'd think my existence wouldn't be headline material anymore."

Agatha resisted the urge to sigh. Maybe if she hadn't built an entire career around being the kind of woman whose emotions were a rumor rather than a fact, the office gossip mill would've died down by now. But no - half her colleagues still believed Rio was just a pretty plus-one, and the wedding ring was another power accessory.

"Some people," she finally said, glancing at her watch, "are harder to convince than others. Unfortunately, I have a meeting in ten minutes, and I'm already late preparing for it."

That was an understatement. She was incredibly late: the kind of late that left no room for preparation other than reading one email and hoping for the best. But Rio didn't have to know that.

Her girlfriend, however, didn't move toward the door. Instead, she rose slowly, gathering her empty container and stretching her arms with deliberate languor. When she looked at Agatha again, there was a glint in her eyes that was far too dangerous for office lightning.

"Well," Rio said, stepping around the desk, her tone casual but her movements anything but. "We wouldn't want those people talking, would we? This is about mending the gaps, after all."

Agatha blinked. "Rio-"

But she was already circling the desk, slow and sure, one hand brushing the smooth surface as if tracing invisible lines of permission. Agatha's pulse quickened with every step she took closer.

"This is not what I meant," Agatha managed, though her voice came out thinner than she intended.

"Relax," Rio murmured, stopping beside her chair and reaching across her desk to grab the other container - the one Agatha had been eating from. "Just helping you clean up. Don't want to be an ungrateful guest."

Her hand brushed against Agatha's wrist in the process - warm, deliberate, lingering just long enough to make the air between them shift.

It was supposed to end there. It didn't.

When Agatha turned to admonish her, Rio was closer than she should've been, her face inches away, her breath carrying a faint trace of dressing and mint.

"Rio," Agatha said again, more pressing.

"Yes?" Rio's voice remained quiet, innocent in the way that made it so much worse.

"You're-"

"Not close enough?"

"Too close."

Rio smiled. "Then maybe you should tell me to step back."

Agatha's throat tightened, the words tangling somewhere between logic and want. "I'm at work."

"Let this be your incentive to get some blinds."

And before Agatha could fully summon her professional outrage, Rio leaned in and kissed her.

It wasn't deep - just a brush of lips, soft and tasting faintly of a dare. But it felt like a crack in the marble armor Agatha spent decades perfecting. The kiss lasted no more than a heartbeat, maybe two, but when Rio pulled back, she did it with infuriating slowness, her eyes still fixed on Agatha's.

Agatha inhaled sharply, the sound catching in her throat. "If Marcy from HR comes knocking at my door, I'm giving her your number to deal with it."

Rio smiled, unrepentant. "Bring it on. I'll go into a detailed retelling of how irresistible I find you."

"You're impossible," Agatha muttered, feeling her cheeks redden.

"And you still like me," Rio said, stepping back just enough to give her space. "I wasn't kidding about the blinds. You have a private, soundproofed office. Imagine what you could do here if your colleagues couldn't see your every move."

Agatha exhaled through her nose, torn between exasperation and the inconvenient ache low in her stomach. The last thing she needed was to imagine that. "Go. Before I do something that'll land me in a disciplinary meeting."

Rio winked, leaning close enough to murmur, "Just think about it," before walking to the door - her stride unhurried, confident, hers.

And Agatha did.

She thought about it long enough to forget about the meeting until her laptop shrieked with the sound of an incoming call.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! Have I accidentally posted this chapter in a different story for an entirely different fandom that I haven't interacted with for months? Perhaps. Anyway, sorry for the delay, still wrestling with writer's block (the fucker's winning, tragically), but the next chapter should be on time. Maybe. Hopefully. Thank you for reading, kudos, and comments (they really help me find the motivation to stare at a blank page until I figure out how words work). See you when I see you!

Chapter 39: Not wandering alone

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

For once, Agatha had to admit Rio was taking her plan seriously.

Not that she'd ever doubted her girlfriend's commitment - Rio had proven herself more times than Agatha could count, playing the role she'd been cast in with conviction, even when the performance hurt or felt unfair. But now, there was no performance. No role. Rio wasn't acting anymore; she was enjoying herself.

And she seemed to delight in the newfound excuse to invade every corner of Agatha's meticulously separated life.

It started small: Rio stopping by the office to deliver something Agatha had supposedly forgotten at home - a folder, a pen, a reusable water bottle that Agatha had never seen before. Or waiting for her in the firm's marble lobby at the end of the day, cross-legged on a bench, a paperback in hand, a lazy grin breaking across her face the second Agatha appeared.

Nothing grand enough to raise suspicion. But also not irrelevant enough to be ignored.

And considering Rio stood out like a sore thumb in a room full of crisp white shirts, polished shoes, and ties pulled tight enough to cut off circulation, people noticed. They noticed fast.

Whispers followed Agatha down corridors like static: half-curious, half-awed, always quick to die the moment she appeared. The firm's most ruthless lawyer - the woman who'd made partner with a kid on her hip and negotiated settlements like she was performing surgery - apparently went home with someone who laughed too loud and wore scuffed sneakers.

It should have irritated her.

It didn't.

Her whole career, she'd guarded her private life like it was a state secret. No one knew where she lived, who she saw, or what she did after hours. It came from a place of caution, caused by years spent scrutinized as an influential politician's daughter. Nothing good ever came from people poking their noses into her business, and the boundaries kept her untouchable.

But now? Now she didn't mind people knowing that Rio existed. That someone was waiting for her at home.

The rumors spread much like after the gala, fueled by Rio's insistence on chatting up people in the elevator, in the halls, anywhere that would warrant her casually mentioning that, yes, she was Agatha's wife.

And Agatha didn't really care. Because after years of hiding behind walls and composure, she found visibility didn't scare her. Not when it meant being seen as Rio's.

Of course, the effort went both ways.

Since their plan had been born out of the PI's sudden interest in Rio's workplace, Agatha couldn't keep their public appearances limited to the firm. If Evanora's hired spy was widening his net, then so would she.

So, she began stopping by the bar.

She always arrived near the end of Rio's shift, still wrapped in the sharp polish of her day: tailored suits, heels that clicked with quiet authority against the worn wooden floor, and the faint scent of perfume cutting through the smell of liquor. She'd slide onto a stool at the far end of the counter - the same one she'd sat in the first time they met - and pull out her laptop as if she belonged there.

Rio never made a scene when she showed up. No dramatic greetings, no affectionate displays meant to announce Agatha's presence. But she didn't need to. Their small gestures spoke louder than words ever could - the quick, conspiratorial grin Rio threw her way when she caught sight of her, the way Agatha's lips curved in response despite herself, the subtle touches when their hands brushed as Rio passed her drink. Every exchange felt deliberate but unscripted, like they were doing it more out of habit than for show.

Agatha never ordered the drink; that wasn't why she came. Still, Rio always poured her one, choosing by instinct. Whiskey on the days when exhaustion settled into Agatha's bones, when her shoulders sagged and her jaw refused to unclench. Dry white wine when the tension was sharper than fatigue, when her mind hummed too loud to rest.

She'd nurse the glass, laptop open in front of her, the blue glow painting her face in cold light to disguise what she was actually doing.

Waiting for Rio to finish.

Technically, Rio could have driven herself - her beat-up Toyota had survived more miles than Agatha cared to count - but the ritual had to make sense. Agatha's visits couldn't feel like a box ticked for the PI's benefit. If they drove home separately, it would look hollow, transactional.

So they'd found a rhythm. Rio took an Uber to work, claiming - truthfully - that her wife didn't trust her car to drive too often without combusting spontaneously and that driving to her closing shifts was already asking for trouble. After clocking out, she'd leave with Agatha, sliding easily into the passenger seat, smelling faintly of citrus and gin and warmth.

It became its own quiet ritual: Agatha watching from her seat as Rio wiped down the counter, offered her staff a final joke or two, then disappeared into the back to grab her things. When she returned, she always wore the same tired but radiant smile. Their fingers would find each other on instinct as they left, the weight of staring eyes barely registering.

Because yes, the point was to be seen. But more often than not, it didn't feel like a performance at all.

Aside from the bar, Agatha also found herself popping by Rio's lab.

It happened only once because Rio's department was far less forgiving of outsiders wandering in. The building was all glass panels and filtered air, with access requiring ID scans and safety clearance. On her visit, Agatha had to sign in at the front desk, surrender her handbag, and wait until Rio came down to collect her in a lab coat, badge clipped to her chest, and a grin already in place.

They weren't allowed inside the main lab - safety protocols, Rio explained apologetically - but Agatha didn't need to see petri dishes or plant tissue cultures to understand the gravity of the place. Even standing in the corridor, Rio seemed brighter, more grounded, her hands animated as she talked about her experiments in a low but enthusiastic voice.

Agatha found herself listening, not because she understood the scientific jargon, but because Rio spoke about it the same way she argued in court - with precision, passion, and a kind of joy that made everything around her hum.

She also looked unfairly attractive in that lab coat. The crisp white fabric framed her tan skin, the faint streak of ink on her wrist peeking from under her sleeve, the goggles forgotten in messy hair. It quickly turned Agatha's active listening into absentminded nodding as she didn't even bother to hide her staring.

When it came to leave, Agatha kissed her in a manner entirely inappropriate for a university hallway - slow, deliberate, slightly devastating. It fanned the flames building in her stomach for what felt like months, but Rio ended the kiss far too quickly, sending her an amused look.

"This is a professional setting, Mrs. Harkness," she said, smoothing her hands over Agatha's hips before stepping back. "Behave."

Agatha scoffed, grabbing the empty coffee cups from the windowsill to dispose of them on her way out. "Like you behave in my office?"

The words alone sent a spark down her spine. They hadn't done anything scandalous in her workplace - anywhere, for that matter, which was frankly getting unbearable - but Rio liked to push her limits every time she visited. Her flirty comments, casual touches that weren't so casual, and goodbye kisses always left Agatha's head swimming, buried in thoughts that were far from appropriate.

Rio laughed softly, the sound low and unbothered. "You don't get to complain until Marcy gets involved. Plus, I told you to have blinds installed."

"And I told you that it would look suspicious," Agatha argued, glancing at her watch. "I have to be in court soon."

"Yeah, I should probably get back to it too," Rio said, nodding toward the main lab. Her eyes softened as they found Agatha's, a small smile tugging at her lips. "See you at home?"

Agatha nodded, pecking her lips one last time. "See you at home."

As she left the complex, the charade was the last thing on her mind. Because whatever they were building wasn't a performance. Not anymore.

On Friday, the bar was more crowded.

The weekend's beginning drew in post-work rush, college stragglers, and couples that mistook dim lighting for romance, making the air feel thicker. The smell of liquor and sweat clung to the wooden floors, layered over with stale beer and the faintest trace of cigarette smoke that slipped in through the perpetually open door. Every few seconds, another burst of laughter or a raised voice cut through the low thrum of music, pushing against Agatha's already frayed patience.

Still, her seat was there. It always was.

Through the handful of her visits, Agatha had never seen it taken. The first two times, she thought it was pure luck, but now she knew Rio kept it unoccupied purposefully - a secret shared with her by a very amused Alice after a disgruntled man had told Agatha 'not to get comfortable because the seat was reserved for someone special'.

When she'd asked Rio about it, her girlfriend shrugged.

"If you're sitting at the bar, waiting for me to finish work, you're sitting somewhere I can stare at you every chance I get," she'd said, like it was the most obvious explanation.

Agatha didn't argue with the logic because the benefits were clear: if Rio could watch her, she could watch Rio. And the ease with which her girlfriend moved behind the bar never failed to make heat pool in her stomach.

Now, she slipped into the stool like it was her birthright, setting her bag down beside it and trying to tune out the noise pressing against her senses. Her gaze swept the length of the bar automatically, searching for Rio's familiar figure to catch a glimpse of the welcoming grin that never failed to tug something loose inside Agatha's chest.

But instead, she found Alice.

The woman caught her eye and offered a small, knowing smile - one that looked equal parts greeting and amusement - before turning back to the row of beers she was pouring. The group of rowdy college kids crowding the counter buzzed with excitement, eyeing the pints hungrily and visibly trying to hurry the bartender up with their impatient glances.

Agatha's lips pressed into a thin line at the ruckus before she leaned back, accepting that Rio was likely in the backroom wrestling with kegs or whatever else. She'd wait. She always did.

Still, she wasn't above having a drink while she did.

Before she could wave Alice over, another bartender appeared in front of her - one she hadn't seen before.

She was young, probably early twenties, with bright blue eyes and a black ponytail that swung when she moved. The girl leaned forward on her elbows, smiling with an openness that felt far too casual for Agatha's liking.

"What can I get you tonight?" she asked, tone light, voice pitched just loud enough to carry over the music and overlapping conversations.

"Chardonnay," Agatha said firmly. "Dry. Whatever you have that isn't from a box."

That earned her a laugh and a glimpse of a dimple visible in the woman's left cheek. Agatha could swear she was angling her head specifically to show it off. "You sound like someone who knows what she wants."

Agatha tilted her head slightly, unimpressed but polite. "It's a rare skill."

"Bet you use it often." The bartender's grin widened as she poured. "We don't usually get people like you in here - too classy for this joint." Her eyes flicked down, lingering on Agatha's left hand for a fraction of a second before they returned to her face, unbothered. "Though you wear the chaos well."

"You probably shouldn't judge your customers based solely on looks."

The woman set her drink down with a glint in her eye. "Let me get to know you, then. How about-"

"Don't even finish that sentence, Becky."

Alice's voice cut clean through the noise, sharp enough to make the younger bartender blink.

Agatha glanced up to find her standing just a few feet away, an empty tray tucked under her arm. Her expression fell somewhere between amusement and warning.

"Why?" Becky asked, still smiling. "There's nothing wrong with a little-"

"She's Rio's wife."

Becky froze mid-sentence, color blooming high on her cheeks before spreading across her entire face. "Oh shit." Her eyes darted to Agatha like she'd suddenly become radioactive. "Shit. I'm so sorry. I didn't-"

"Notice the ring?" Agatha interrupted, reaching for her glass with deliberate calm. "Or care about it until you learned you're stepping on your coworker's toes?"

The questions lingered in the air, making Becky squirm uncomfortably. Alice took pity on her and pushed the empty tray into her chest with more force than necessary. "Go collect glasses. And stop flirting with married customers."

Becky scrambled away before Alice even finished the second sentence, her shoulders stiff and her steps hurried, ponytail swishing like a white flag.

Agatha didn't bother following her with her eyes; instead, she turned to Alice, who looked mildly amused. "You're like sapphic catnip, aren't you?"

Agatha snorted into her wine at the question, shaking her head with a wry smile. Her interactions with Alice had been few and far between during her messy entanglement with Rio - even after it had turned into something real.

Still, she'd always liked Alice. She was sharp, steady, and fiercely protective - the kind of friend everybody wished for. And she liked her even more for dating Jen, whose softer moods had made her marginally less unbearable during partner meetings.

"It's the clothes," she said with a shrug. "Thanks for the save."

It was Alice's turn to laugh. "I wasn't saving you," she corrected, lazily wiping the counter. "Not that I'd mind watching Rio bash Becky's head against the bar - girl needs to learn what marriage is - but we’re already short on staff."

"Rio wouldn't-"

"Oh, she absolutely would."

The interruption came from behind her, warm and teasing, the sound of it so familiar that it sent a shiver down Agatha's spine before her brain even caught up.

She turned.

Rio stood just to her right, framed by the amber light spilling from the shelves behind the counter. Her hair was pulled into its usual ponytail, her worn leather jacket hugged her shoulders perfectly, and her well-loved backpack hung from one arm. She looked ready to leave.

"You're early," Agatha said automatically, trying to sound unimpressed as her eyes lingered a second too long. The outfit was one she'd seen countless times before, but somehow, Rio managed to make denim and a black T-shirt look like sin wrapped in nonchalance.

It wasn't the clothes. It was the person wearing them.

And everything that waited underneath.

Rio smiled, offering a small shrug. "Pulled a few strings."

"She asked Becky to come in earlier," Alice explained with a smirk. "Bet you're regretting that now, huh?"

Rio scoffed, leaning over to press a quick kiss to Agatha's cheek, lips brushing warm against her skin. The casual intimacy of it sent a ripple of warmth through her chest, softening the edges of her composure.

"Please," Rio scoffed, straightening again, voice full of smug affection. "Becky can try all she wants. This one’s all mine."

Agatha arched a brow, pretending not to melt. "You just admitted you'd bash her head into the bar."

Rio tilted her head, eyes glinting. "I said she could try," she murmured, tone dripping with implication. "Not that there wouldn't be consequences."

Before Agatha could fire back, Rio nudged her shoulder playfully, nodding toward the wine glass in her hand. "Come on, gorgeous. Chop chop. We've got places to be."

"You did not just-" Agatha started, then narrowed her eyes. "What places? Sharon's only watching Nicky until seven."

Rio's grin was pure mischief, lips curving as she leaned in close enough that Agatha caught the faint scent of her shampoo.

"Unless somebody told her to drive him to Wanda's," she whispered, her breath brushing against Agatha's ear, "for a sleepover."

Agatha froze.

For a heartbeat, she could practically hear the implications slotting together in her mind.

A sleepover.

Which meant an empty house.

Which meant-

Oh.

Her pulse skipped, composure cracking. She downed the rest of her wine in one, inelegant gulp, the glass clinking sharply against the counter as she set it down.

"Let's go," she said briskly, grabbing her bag and Rio's hand.

Alice's laughter followed them as they moved toward the door. "Have fun, lovebirds!"

The warm night air hit them the second they stepped outside. A small group of smokers loitered near the entrance, their conversation faltering as the two women swept past them - Agatha in her fitted suit, heels clicking decisively against the pavement, Rio trailing beside her with an amused, fond look in her eye.

Agatha didn't even look at them, just tightened her grip on Rio's hand and tugged her toward the car. She'd deny it if asked, but anticipation hummed beneath her skin - quiet, coiled, alive.

Just as she was about to round the car toward the driver's seat, the keys were snatched clean out of her hand.

"Rio!" she protested, fingers flexing around empty space. "The hell are you doing?"

Rio grinned again - infuriating, lopsided, the kind that made her both want to roll her eyes and kiss it off her face.

"I'm driving," she announced, opening the passenger's door with a small, mock-formal bow.

Agatha didn't move. She leveled her with a look that could've reduced lesser mortals to dust. "You drive like a grandma. It'll take you ages to get us home."

"We're not going home."

That made Agatha blink. Not home?

It took every last bit of her willpower to hold back an exasperated groan. "What? But you said-"

"Places, plural," Rio said calmly, one hand coming up to rest on Agatha's shoulder as if she could gently steer her into compliance. "We have a stop to make first."

Agatha locked her muscles, unmoving. "A stop?"

There was not a single place she could think of that could compete with their house - empty, quiet, private. A night without interruptions, without the constant hum of responsibility or the sharp edge of restraint that kept her from pulling Rio in just a little closer, kissing her just a little longer.

Rio sighed, her hand slipping off Agatha's shoulder when it became clear she wasn't winning this particular standoff. "It's been a while since our last date," she said, voice softening. "And we have time. Wanda won't drop Nicky off until I give her the all-clear tomorrow."

Agatha's brow furrowed, the logistics finally cutting through the haze of surprise. "Wait a minute. She's supposed to be on some family trip."

Since she and Rio had reconciled after their rocky start, the universe seemed determined to make alone time an unaffordable luxury. Every attempt at a child-free night had fallen through: cancelled plans, sick friends, last-minute changes. Nicky had turned into an immovable constant, always at home, always around.

And Agatha loved her son to the death, but there was only so much they could do with him upstairs.

This weekend was supposed to be no different - the Maximoffs off on some little family getaway, and Agatha already resigned to another night of making out on the couch like a teenager with a curfew.

Rio's fingers drummed lightly against the top of the car door, a quiet tell. "Something came up at Vision's work. They had to cancel."

Agatha narrowed her eyes, suspicion creeping in. "And why is this the first I'm hearing about it?"

"Because Wanda told me yesterday when we ran into each other during pickup."

"So you decided to pawn Nicky off," Agatha said, folding her arms, "to whisk me away on a date?"

For once, Rio hesitated - just for a heartbeat - before nodding. "I... yes?" she admitted, voice lifting slightly at the end, as if hoping phrasing it like a question might soften the crime.

Agatha held her gaze, lips twitching despite herself. She wanted to look annoyed - should look annoyed - but Rio's face, open and earnest and just a little nervous, made that impossible.

Something about Rio taking the initiative and creating an opportunity for them to be alone made her chest clench fondly.

"Unbelievable," Agatha muttered, failing to suppress the warmth threatening to curl through her tone. "You went behind my back to organize a date night."

Rio's mouth quirked, sensing the shift. "We've already established I'm opportunistic. Wanda served me the chance on a silver platter."

"And you just had to take it."

"An entire night just to ourselves? She wouldn't pry it out of my cold, dead hands," Rio grinned, opening the door wider. "M'lady."

Agatha raised a brow. "You're assuming I'm saying yes to this."

Rio leaned in slightly, her voice dipping into that familiar tone that always wrapped around Agatha's nerves and tugged. "I'm assuming you're curious."

Fucking Rio.

Of course she was.

Agatha sighed, more for show than anything, and finally slid into the passenger seat, muttering, "If this ends with a hiking trail, I'm killing you somewhere your body won't be found."

"Noted. No hiking. Promise," Rio said, shutting the door with a victorious grin.

As she rounded the car and slipped into the driver's seat, she shot Agatha a quick sidelong look - the kind that made her heart give an inconvenient little flutter. "Seatbelt, mi alma. You're in for a ride."

The ride, as Rio had gracefully put it, turned out to be more of a crawl, her careful, law-abiding driving leading them through the city at a sloth's pace.

Agatha squirmed in her seat, eyes flicking to the signs in search of clues. Longwood Avenue slid by in a wash of neon and taillights, the air outside carrying the faint scent of rain that had poured until early afternoon.

"Once again," she began, glancing sideways, "the speed limit is a suggestion, not a divine commandment."

Rio grinned, keeping her eyes on the road. "And yet, I've never gotten a ticket. Funny how that works."

"Because everyone's too busy pitying your passengers," Agatha muttered, crossing her legs and drumming her fingers against her knee. The slow procession carried them past the dark outline of the hospitals, then east along Huntington Avenue, where the streetcars rattled by like restless ghosts.

When they merged onto Massachusetts Avenue, Agatha was fairly certain she could walk faster than Rio drove. She leaned back, resigned. "If you just told me where we're going-"

"Nope," Rio interrupted, popping the 'p' with smug satisfaction. "You're not getting behind the wheel. Just enjoy the ride."

Agatha huffed again as the car turned with the speed of a tugboat. "More of a fucking stroll," she grumbled, watching the rows of brownstones slide past, their windows glowing with early-evening light.

Rio didn't answer, just hummed along to the soft music filling the car as if the complaints were more endearing than irritating.

Agatha turned to the window again, feigning disinterest but tracing their route in her mind. Beacon Hill ahead, maybe. Downtown. Possibly something on the waterfront, if Rio was feeling dramatic - which she usually was.

They passed the Esplanade a few minutes later, where the lush trees reflected the glow of the lamps. Joggers and groups of young people assembling for a night out mixed, creating an interesting picture of a city that refused to rest.

"We're going downtown," Agatha said, almost a challenge.

"Maybe."

"Meaning yes."

Rio didn't answer, just reached across the console, her fingers brushing against Agatha's wrist, thumb grazing her knuckles. The touch was brief, casual, but it sent a small jolt of warmth up Agatha's arm.

As Rio's hand returned to the wheel, Agatha let out another irritated huff. "Is the quarter-to-three thing essential? We're barely moving."

"It's the recommended position."

Agatha rolled her eyes. "I can think of better ones."

The right corner of Rio's lips quirked up, even though her eyes never strayed from the road. "Something tells me those won't be suitable for a car."

"It's a big car," Agatha said flippantly. "But that's not what I meant."

The car curved toward Charles Street, where the storefronts glowed softly - florists, antique shops, a closed bakery still smelling faintly of sugar. The narrow road climbed slightly, winding into the heart of Beacon Hill, where the cobblestones began to appear under the tires.

Agatha barely noticed the scenery anymore. She'd found a new purpose: making this drive every bit as drawn-out for Rio as it felt for her.

"And what did you mean?" Rio asked, steering carefully through another turn.

Agatha didn't answer. Instead, she reached across the console, catching Rio's wrist with a deliberate, unhurried touch.

Rio's eyes flicked toward her, quick and warning. "Agatha, I'm-"

Before she could finish, Agatha guided her hand away from the steering wheel and rested it on her own thigh.

"See?" Agatha said smoothly. "Much better."

Rio's breath snagged - a sharp, almost imperceptible hitch - and every muscle in her body locked for a tense fraction of a second. The shock was momentary, though, immediately replaced by movement. Rio's fingers strayed and then settled, slipping between Agatha's crossed thighs, resting inches above her knee.

Agatha probably should've fully considered the catastrophic repercussions of that position. Namely, the way the smoldering heat radiating from Rio's palm seemed to instantly penetrate the fabric of her slacks, creating a searing brand on her skin.

Her jaw tensed when Rio's thumb began tracing slow, maddeningly soft circles. The movement was so small, so absentminded, that Agatha felt almost embarrassed by how quickly it fanned the flames consuming her already strained composure. The light fraction was a precise undoing - one she'd brought on herself.

Still, she didn't move away from the touch, keeping her hand on top of Rio's as if its weight didn't make stringing a sentence together taxing.

Finally, Rio spoke, her voice tinged with amusement, but more strained than usual. "And to think you wouldn't even hold my hand while driving to our first date."

Agatha stared out the window, refusing to give Rio the satisfaction of seeing how tightly she was wound. The lights of Beacon Hill flickered across the windshield in soft gold.

"Yes, well, my driving actually requires keeping both hands on the wheel," she said, biting down on her lip to stifle a yelp when Rio squeezed her thigh playfully. She sent her a warning look. "Don't start something you won't finish."

Rio's mouth curved, slow and dangerous. "Oh, I'll finish. Just not here."

The words hung tantalizingly in the air - a promise etched in heat and silk. Once again, Agatha found herself wondering why Rio wouldn't simply give in to what they both wanted and drive them straight home.

Not that the anticipation wasn't exhilarating, in its own, excruciating way, but they'd had plenty of it already.

Enough to last a lifetime, if Agatha was being honest.

"You might want to step on the gas, then," she scoffed, eyes still forward as if one look at Rio would undo her completely. "At this rate, we'll still be driving by tomorrow morning."

Rio's laugh was soft, even warmer than the touch of her hand. "We're almost there, don't worry."

Outside, the street began to narrow even further, the glow of gas lamps washing over red-brick facades and black wrought iron. The car slowed to a crawl as Rio searched for a spot, one hand still resting comfortably on Agatha's leg as though it belonged there.

When the car finally eased to a stop along Mount Vernon Street, Rio put it in park and glanced over, eyes gleaming under the dashboard light.

"End of line."

Agatha tilted her head, assessing her surroundings - the steep hill, the stately brownstones, the quiet elegance of the street. "You dragged me through half of Boston for... this?"

"Don't sound too excited," Rio mused, lifting her hand. The sudden absence of contact was sharper than the initial touch, leaving Agatha's entire thigh cold and tingling.

Before Agatha could properly mourn the loss, Rio leaned back to retrieve her backpack and pulled a pair of sneakers out of it.

Or, more accurately, Agatha's favorite pair of sneakers that she usually opted for on their excursions to the park or quick grocery runs.

Rio handed them to her with a mischievous grin. "Here. Wouldn't want you breaking an ankle in those heels."

Agatha's eyes narrowed suspiciously as she accepted the shoes. "What exactly do you have planned?"

Rio just smiled - that infuriating, unreadable little curve of her mouth that always meant you'll see.

"Nothing too dangerous," she said, which did absolutely nothing to reassure Agatha.

The street outside was hushed, wrapped in the kind of stillness that only came after rain. The lamplight hit the wet cobblestones, making the entire slope shimmer faintly gold. Somewhere down the block, a window was cracked open; faint jazz floated out, the notes curling through the chill.

Agatha sighed, unbuckling the seatbelt with deliberate slowness. "If this turns out to be one of those immersive theater things, I'm walking home. Which will probably be faster than your driving."

Rio laughed, shoving the door open and stepping into the damp air. "I'd make sure to give you more than just one glass of wine before that."

"Right, silly me," Agatha muttered, slipping off her heels. She frowned at the sneakers in her lap before finally conceding - she wasn't about to clatter down Beacon Hill in fucking Louboutins. A twisted ankle would be cheaper than a broken heel.

As she laced the shoes up, she felt Rio watching her, and the knowledge alone made her movements slower, more deliberate than necessary. When she looked up, Rio was already on the sidewalk, backpack slung casually over one shoulder, hands in her jacket pockets. She looked perfectly at ease in the cool night air - a little smug, a little too proud of herself.

"Come on," she said, nodding up the hill. "It's not far."

Agatha joined her with a quiet click of the door and a sigh that was equal parts resignation and curiosity. "You know, there's a fine line between mysterious and irritating."

"And I love living on that line," Rio replied with a grin, lacing their fingers together.

They started up Mount Vernon Street, their footsteps echoing softly in the empty corridor of brick and gaslight. The rain had left everything gleaming: the iron railings, the slate steps, even the trees that seemed to bow down from the droplets adorning their leaves. Every few seconds, a window flickered with a TV illuminating the inside of some beautiful, elegant townhouse.

After a moment, Agatha spoke again, her voice quieter than she intended. "You picked this for a reason."

Rio didn't answer right away. She glanced over, the earlier grin softening into something smaller, almost private. "It's one of my favorite places in the city. Every street feels haunted, but not in a bad way. Just... lived in. Like the walls remember things."

Agatha raised a brow. "So we're searching for ghosts?"

"History," Rio corrected gently, giving her hand a brief squeeze.

They turned a corner onto one of the narrow lanes, where the cobblestones looked uneven enough to twist an ankle, and Agatha immediately understood the sneakers.

"Why history?" she asked after another beat of silence.

Rio smiled, her eyes warm and steady, that soft shade of brown that always reminded Agatha of melted chocolate. "My dad used to say you can learn a lot about a person just by looking at their bookshelf. Get to know them through the stories they choose to surround themselves with." Her tone dipped, threaded with that quiet nostalgia that always crept in when she spoke about her parents. "The books are the first thing I notice when I visit someone's home - how many, what kinds, the ones they hide or leave out. All of it says something."

"You must have found my collection of law textbooks rather uninspiring."

"I look for books that people chose to have," Rio said, steering them around a puddle. "Not the ones they own because they have to. So I was more interested in the ones you keep everywhere but your office."

Agatha tilted her head, curiosity piqued. "And what did you find?"

Rio's laugh was soft, carrying in the damp air. "That I was wrong about you. You're not nearly as into romantic novels as I thought. Certainly not the knight-in-shining-armor kind."

It took a moment for Agatha's mind to catch up, pulling the memory from some deep corner - the first dinner Wanda had forced her into, the one she'd left considering marrying Rio for the inheritance. Rio had sat across from her then, smirking over candlelight in that infuriating blazer as she made her first attempts at scaling Agatha's walls.

"But," Rio continued, "your collection of classic literature is impressive. And-" she threw her a teasing glance, "I think you already know where this is going - history books."

Rio's words hung between them, soft and teasing, carried along by the faint sound of their footsteps over the cobblestones. A group of people passed them, their laughter echoing off the brick buildings towering over the street.

Agatha brushed a stray curl away from her face. "You can learn a great deal from the past."

Rio shot her a knowing glance, the kind that said she wasn't buying it for a second. "Sure. Except half the ones you have are about murders, haunted estates, witch trials-"

"-case studies," Agatha interrupted smoothly.

Rio laughed. "Mhm. The Salem Witchcraft Papers seem like a valuable source of knowledge for your line of work."

"They are," Agatha argued, feigning offense even as a smile tugged at her lips. "The fascinating insight into mass hysteria might come in handy the next time the economy crashes."

"You dog-eared the parts about spectral evidence," Rio countered.

Agatha opened her mouth, then closed it again. Finally, she groaned. "Okay, fine. My fascination with witches didn't die with my dream of becoming one. What does that have to do with this?"

She gestured toward the hill that sloped upward, the windows above them glowing like watchful eyes. Everything smelled of wet brick and earth, the kind of scent that hinted at the city's age - something preserved in the cracks.

"It's not just witches, though. Right?" Rio asked, her smile softening. "You like the stories that linger, that haunt the places where they happened, refusing to die."

Agatha slowed her pace as they turned onto Acorn Street. Small clusters of tourists littered the uneven cobblestones, slick from the rain, and pressed against the old brick houses in search of the perfect Instagram post.

"You make that sound far more poetic than it is," she said, watching her footing. "It's just a childhood interest that grew instead of dying."

Rio rolled her eyes fondly, sidestepping a group occupying the middle of the street. "Then treat this as a playground for your inner child."

They passed a row of shuttered windows, each dark and gleaming with reflected lamplight. Somewhere farther down, a door creaked open, spilling warm light into the night before closing again. The sound of their footsteps - hers light, Rio's steady - seemed to echo back at them, slightly out of sync, as though someone else were walking a beat behind.

Rio noticed it too. "Tell me you heard that," she whispered, more playful than afraid.

Agatha chuckled at the shenanigans. "This street is crowded with people; you'll hear footsteps."

"Unless it was a ghost."

Agatha's lips twitched. "And if it were?"

"Then you'd have to deal with it," Rio replied without missing a beat, her tone solemn. "I don't fuck with ghosts."

That pulled a laugh from Agatha before she could stop it, sharp and genuine. The sound carried down the narrow street, bouncing off the brick until it softened into the night.

"You probably should've thought about that before planning our date in haunted alleys, my hero," she teased, bumping their shoulders together.

Rio squeezed her hand, looking pleased with herself. "I did. Figured getting haunted until the end of time was worth watching you enjoy yourself."

Agatha's breath stuttered in her chest at the ease with which Rio had said it - like it was the most obvious thing in the world to subject herself to an eternity of suffering for Agatha's sake.

"And don't try to tell me you're not having fun," Rio continued. "Your face says it all."

Agatha didn't comment, letting the silence answer for her.

They continued down the hill, leaving the clusters of tourists behind. The chatter faded with every turn until the city grew quieter again, hushed under the weight of its own age.

Rio kept their pace unhurried, their hands still loosely joined. She didn't talk much, only occasionally pointing things out - an old carriage lamp, a brick archway barely tall enough for modern doors. Agatha half-listened, her attention snagging less on the words and more on the rhythm of Rio's voice - low, even, comforting in its certainty.

Her gaze kept drifting. To the curve of Rio's jaw in the lamplight. To the faint damp curl of her hair at the nape of her neck. To the easy, deliberate confidence in her movements - the kind that made Agatha's stomach tighten with a sharp, familiar ache.

They passed an old church, its steeple looming pale against the navy sky. The clock hands glimmered faintly, frozen at half past eight. Rio tilted her head toward it. "Even time's taking the night off."

Agatha hummed in agreement, pretending to study the architecture, though she was very aware of the way Rio's fingers brushed over her knuckles with each swing of their hands.

For someone who prided herself on composure, she was beginning to feel dangerously unraveled.

"I don't think I've ever taken the time to walk these streets," she said as they walked on, soft enough not to disturb the quaint air between them. "Can't even remember the last time I was in this part of the city."

"I was obsessed with it when I first moved here," Rio admitted with a small smile. "Everything's so different - the architecture, the history, even the air. It feels real. Like it stayed true to itself even when the world around it changed."

Agatha glanced at her out of the corner of her eye, and something in Rio's expression tugged unexpectedly at her chest. There was no teasing smirk, no attempt to impress, just raw honesty. The kind of sincerity that would've made her walls shoot up a few months ago.

Now, it made her stomach twist with the intensity of how much she wanted to preserve that honesty between them. To protect the unguarded, almost melancholic look in Rio's eyes as she studied the old facades and uneven cobblestones.

"Real," Agatha repeated softly. "Is that what you like about it?"

Rio shrugged one shoulder, but the gesture didn't feel dismissive. More like a silent surrender. "I appreciate the rawness of real things. Their unfiltered beauty."

Agatha's pulse misfired, a quiet betrayal. She turned her head toward a nearby balcony veiled in ivy, pretending the shadows held her attention. But she wasn't looking at plants or wrought iron. She was looking for steady ground.

Real things.

Unfiltered beauty.

Words she'd spent half a lifetime running from.

She thought about every mask she'd crafted: sharp, polished edges designed to impress, manipulate, survive. The versions of herself curated like armor that had protected her from weakness, from being cracked open and seen for the fragile, bloody pieces beneath.

Over the years, that armor had fused to her so tightly, she'd forgotten what her skin felt like without it. Removing even a single plate had become a delicate, painful process.

And yet...

Rio.

Rio had somehow coaxed the armor loose with nothing more than stubborn warmth and unnervingly perceptive eyes. She hadn't pried or demanded. She'd just been there, steady and patient, making it feel safe to set each mask down and walk away from it.

Agatha dared a glance at her and saw a pair of soft brown eyes looking back at her. Rio's appreciation for real things didn't end with cobblestones or ivy-draped balconies. She knew. She saw her. The unguarded pieces. The messy ones. The delicate ones.

And she valued them.

Agatha's breath wavered. She tightened her hold on Rio's hand - a small gesture, but one that carried the weight of a confession. Rio's answering squeeze was gentle, grounding, as if she understood exactly what was being said without words.

"I think..." Agatha began, voice hushed as if afraid the night might overhear. "I think I'm learning to appreciate that beauty as well."

Not the beauty of facades.

Not the beauty of perfection.

But the terrifying, thrilling beauty of choosing honesty over armor. Of trusting someone enough to be soft in their presence. Of building something that didn't require masks or careful choreography.

At least when it was just the two of them.

The thought lingered for a beat, bitter in its truth, but Agatha cast it aside. The night wasn't about proving a point to her mother or making sure the PI got her good side on his invasive mission to disprove their relationship.

It was about them. About the steady press of Rio's hand in hers, guiding her through the seemingly haunted streets with the unwavering confidence of someone who wouldn't let go. About spending time together on the strangest and yet the best date Agatha had ever been on.

They slowed as the black iron gates of Granary Burying Ground emerged ahead, framed by the glow of nearby streetlamps. The cemetery stretched beyond like a pocket of stillness carved out of the city - old stones leaning into each other, dark earth holding centuries of history.

"That's our next stop?"

Rio pushed the gate open, letting the long creak echo through the quiet before answering. "Nothing screams romance like a date with a few hundred dead people."

"Not afraid of ghosts anymore?" Agatha mused, letting herself be tugged inside. "This place is supposedly riddled with them."

The moment they crossed the threshold, the rest of Boston seemed to face. The world shrank down to shadows, lamplight, the whisper of wind through branches, and the comfortable brush of their shoulders as they walked side by side.

"I'm not afraid," Rio argued lightly, lowering her voice out of instinctive respect for the dead. "Just don't like them. And honestly, the one here is more pitiful than scary."

"Oh?"

"Yeah, James Otis Jr."

Agatha tilted her head, impressed. "You actually researched ghost stories for this?"

"Obviously," Rio shot her a wink. "It's a guided tour. I expect a five-star review."

If only she knew the things Agatha planned to do to her once they returned home.

Far more gratifying than anything Yelp allowed.

Agatha cleared her throat, dragging her thoughts back to the present. "So? What about this James?"

Rio squared her shoulders, slipping effortlessly into storyteller mode. "Picture it," she said dramatically, "Colonial Boston. A stormy night. A tavern packed with rowdy men and terrible life choices."

Agatha lifted a brow. "Did he tell you this himself?"

"Creative liberties," Rio sniffed, nudging her. "Now hush. You're ruining the ambiance."

She slowed her pace, guiding them deeper between ancient stones. "So. James Otis Jr. - brilliant lawyer, fierce patriot, total menace to British authority. One night, he's in a tavern, minding his own business, maybe overindulging a little-"

"Maybe," Agatha echoed, amused.

Rio ignored her. "-when a fight breaks out. A real disaster. Fists everywhere, tables flipping, bottles flying. And someone - a guy who could use a class on anger management, probably - breaks one over his head."

The detail sparked a hazy memory somewhere deep in Agatha's mind - a page from a book on Boston's history, one she'd read a few times. She knew this story, she realized. Had read it a few times.

Then again, she'd never heard it told by Rio, on a date, in the middle of a haunted cemetery.

So maybe she'd never really known it at all.

"The accident changed everything," Rio continued. "He survived, but he wasn't the same. Mood swings. Fits of rage. Deep depression. He went from fiery political legend to... lost."

The night breeze drifted between them, cool and restless, tugging at Agatha's coat as Rio guided her along the path. The lamplight painted Rio's cheekbones in gold and shadow, lending her an almost spectral quality herself.

"One day, he wrote a letter to God. Said he was tired. Asked to be struck down by lightning."

Agatha's breath hitched - not from fear, but from the way Rio told it, her voice low and steady, threading mourning into the air like a spell.

"And then," Rio said, stopping them in front of a weathered stone Agatha barely glanced at, "during a storm, he stepped outside... and a bolt of lightning killed him. Just like he'd asked."

The silence that followed wasn't heavy, but still in a way that made the city outside feel impossibly distant.

Rio's voice softened. "Some people say they've seen him here, wandering between the graves in the clothes he was buried in. Not frightening. Just searching. Like he's still trying to find his way out."

Agatha studied her girlfriend instead of the graves - Rio's dark eyes reflected lamplight, her breath curling in the cool air, her expression a mixture of reverence and wry humor.

"As I said," Rio finished, a small smile tugging at her lips, "more pitiful than scary."

"I wouldn't agree."

Rio met her eye. "No?"

"It's pitiful, sure. Maybe a lesson on 'be careful what you wish for,' but..." she shrugged, glancing at the headstone bearing the name of James Otis Jr. "The idea of being lost in life and then in death? Realizing it doesn't offer the reprieve you wished for? That's scary."

Rio's expression softened, the wry amusement ebbing into something quieter. She followed Agatha's gaze to the headstone, the inscription barely legible in the dim light.

"Yeah," she murmured, "I guess it is scary when you put it like that."

They stood there for a moment, listening to the faint hum of traffic beyond the cemetery walls - modern life rushing past a man who had never found peace of his own.

Agatha exhaled slowly. "Being trapped in something you thought would save you? That's the kind of fear that sticks."

Rio shifted beside her, the motion subtle but unmistakably tense. When she looked at Agatha, there was something unreadable in her eyes, like uncertainty wrapped in worry.

"But you don't think that's you, right?" she asked quietly.

Agatha blinked. "What?"

Rio's gaze flicked away, skimming over the dark silhouettes of headstones as if searching for a safer place to land. "You know... the marriage." Her voice came out careful, almost hesitant. "The thing that was supposed to save you. You don't feel trapped, right?"

Agatha stared at her, stunned as her mind tried to make sense of the words.

"I don't... what on earth are you talking about?"

Rio swallowed, eyes darting around as though making sure no lurking PIs could overhear - or maybe just avoiding looking at her entirely. "Just... you married me to outmaneuver your mother's plans. To prove her wrong. And I don't want you to feel, I don't know, chained to me. With the contract and-"

"Don't." Agatha's voice cut through the air, sharp and immediate. "Just don't."

Rio froze.

"Have you forgotten that I asked you to be my girlfriend?" Agatha pressed, stepping closer. "Or that you accepted?"

Rio still wasn't looking at her, so Agatha lifted her free hand and gently cupped her chin, coaxing her head up. The moment their eyes met, the irritation in her voice softened, but the intensity didn't.

"You are one of the best things that's ever happened to me, Rio Vidal. Why the hell would I feel trapped when being with you is the freest I've ever felt?"

The slight hitch in Rio's breath got swept away by the wind, but Agatha still heard it, felt it against her palm.

The words settled between them, not heavy but unmistakable in their raw truth. Shadows shifted as the branches overhead stirred, but neither of them moved.

Agatha let her hand drift, fingers sliding from Rio's chin to her jaw, thumb brushing a slow, reassuring path along her cheekbone. Rio leaned into the touch, seemingly without even realizing it.

"I was lost when I found you," Agatha said, voice low, steady. "And I was lost when all of this began. Hell, I'm probably still a little lost now."

Her forehead dipped closer, the faint warmth of Rio's breath mingling with hers.

"But I know," Agatha's lips hovered a whisper from Rio's, "I'm not wandering alone anymore."

The cemetery held its breath. And so did Rio.

She didn't move at first, just stared at Agatha as if trying to memorize every word that had just been said, every ounce of sincerity.

Then, gradually, the tension bled from her shoulders.

"You can't just say things like that," Rio whispered, her voice hoarse in a way Agatha had learned to associate with their evening rendezvous on the living room couch.

"Why?" she asked with faux-innocence, already seeing the answer in Rio's eyes. Her thumb traced a slow line along her girlfriend's cheekbone.

"Because," Rio leaned in closer, their lips a whisper away, "seeing you like this makes me want to do things entirely inappropriate for a graveyard."

Agatha tilted back as a small crease formed between her brows. "Like this?" she repeated, confused.

"Unguarded. Honest," Rio murmured, using her free hand to press against Agatha's lower back, pushing their hips together even as their upper bodies remained a few inches apart.

The single point of contact struck like a flint, creating sparks that promptly set Agatha's skin on fire. Her grip on Rio's jaw tightened, unsure whether she should push or pull.

"That's what does it for you?" she asked, her voice not as steady as she'd hoped it would be. "Honesty?"

Rio nuzzled into her hand - a rather obvious attempt at closing the gap. The distance shrank another inch. "Unfiltered beauty or real things," she corrected, eyes dark in a way that made Agatha's stomach clench with want. "Your unfiltered beauty."

Agatha swallowed hard, gaze darting down to Rio's lips that looked entirely too inviting for the place they were in.

Another inch.

The lips came closer, enough to make their breaths tangle, hot and immediate.

Well, she thought, the rational part of her mind dissolving, maybe James won't mind.

Agatha pressed forward, meeting Rio halfway in a hungry, demanding kiss that probably made half the silent bodies in the graves around them sit bolt upright.

The thought was immediately pushed to the back of her mind when the hand on her lower back curled possessively into her blazer, the firm grip urging her impossibly closer. Rio's lips parted in a silent, intoxicating invitation that Agatha would never refuse.

Everything around them shattered. The entire world narrowed to the taste of Rio's mouth - deep, consuming, familiar - the steady press of her body against hers, and the way her hand gripped and anchored Agatha, making her feel suddenly and fiercely found.

Rio's grip shifted, letting go of Agatha's hand in favor of exploring her back, sliding beneath the hem of her jacket and untucking her shirt to settle just above the curve of her tailbone. The kiss became less of an embrace and more of a claim, a desperate collision of urgency. Agatha pressed back, a low sound trapped in her throat, arching into the heat of Rio's touch. Her own hands tore into the silk of Rio's hair, ruining her ponytail, pulling her in deeper, the angle of the kiss growing more insistent.

When Rio's hand moved again, sliding down her spine and brushing the edge of her slacks, a final, cold spark of self-preservation fired through Agatha's mind. Not here.

With a sudden, profound effort, she pulled her head back, breaking the seal with a gasp that was ragged and loud in the absolute quiet of the night. Her hands slid down Rio's shoulders, landing on her collarbones to hold her at arm's length.

Rio's eyes, dark and heavy-lidded, were blazing. "Agatha," she breathed, her voice a low vibration that promised utter ruin.

Agatha forced herself to speak, her voice trembling slightly. "We're in a fucking cemetery, Rio," she managed, fighting to re-anchor herself in reality. "And we're not fucking in said cemetery."

Rio blinked, like her sight needed readjusting to understand where they were standing. Her gaze flicked to the grave just a few feet away from them, lips quivering as if she was fighting the pull of a smile. "Sorry, dude," she said earnestly to the headstone. "Don't haunt us."

A snort slipped past Agatha's lips, short and unguarded, before she grabbed Rio's hand that was still stuffed under her shirt and pulled it away. "He would've burned us at the stake," she pointed out, tangling their fingers together. "Don't apologize to him."

Her heart kept beating unnaturally fast, especially when Rio turned to look at her again, eyes softer than they had been a second ago but still carrying that searing want that made Agatha's self-control fray at the edges.

A beat passed, the silence comfortable but charged, before Rio lifted their connected hands to her lips, pressing a chaste kiss to Agatha's knuckles.

"You're one of the best things that's ever happened to me, too," she muttered against the soft skin, gaze never straying from Agatha's.
