Agatha froze, not because of the words, but because of how Rio said them. Soft. Certain. Without the air of someone returning a sentiment out of obligation, but with the disarming honesty of someone who'd been holding onto the truth for too long.

It punched the breath right out of her.

It was one thing to say those things, especially when she'd been so blindsided by the insecurity in Rio's expression.

It was something else to hear them. To feel them wrap around her heart like a warm hand that holds without squeezing.

They made her feel wanted. Worthy of everything they were building.

"This," she swallowed, her voice raw around the edges, "is getting too sentimental for a place filled with dead patriots."

Rio smirked, shrugging. "Better that than heated, right?" she asked teasingly, lowering their hands to let them hang freely between them. Before Agatha could fire back, her expression softened again. "You'll never have to wander alone as long as I'm in your life. I hope you know that."

Agatha let out a choked sound, startingly close to a sob, but she pushed it down. Her fingers caressed the hand in hers, eyes never straying from Rio. "I'm learning to believe it."

It was the best she could offer, the closest she could get to breaking through the walls of unhealthy independence she'd spent years building.

"Good," Rio muttered, leaning in for a quick, reassuring kiss. When they pulled apart, she rested their foreheads together, letting them breathe the same air. "Very good. Because I-"

Her voice cut off as a sudden gust swept through the cemetery, rattling the branches overhead. Rio flinched, then narrowed her eyes up at the trees.

"Okay, I know that was the wind," she said, "but it felt judgy."

Agatha barked a laugh. "Maybe James disapproves of lesbians canoodling near his final resting place."

"I'd give him a reason to be mad if you didn't stop me," Rio muttered, tugging Agatha gently back the way they came. "Come on. Before we get hexed by a Founding Father."

Agatha let herself be pulled along, raising a brow. "You've been telling me for literal weeks that you won't fuck me on the couch, but a graveyard is fine?"

"I'd rather have judgy Founding Fathers hear us than Nicky."

Yeah, Agatha had to agree with that sentiment.

They walked in silence for a moment - quiet, but not empty - before Agatha finally registered the familiar turns, the slope of the sidewalk, the way Rio's hand tugged with unmistakable purpose.

"Wait," Agatha said slowly, "this is the way back to the car."

"Correct," Rio replied, brisk as a soldier on a mission.

"Are we driving to the next stop?"

She tried to sound neutral, but God, if they got back into the car and Rio insisted on driving again, she might actually die of old age in the passenger seat.

"Nope," Rio said, not missing a step as she led them toward a shortcut. "We're going home."

Agatha's head snapped toward her so fast she almost worried about whiplash. "Home? After only two stops? I thought you had a whole tour planned out."

"I did."

"And you researched ghost stories for this."

"Yup."

Agatha stopped dead in her tracks, pulling Rio to a halt mid-stride. Her eyebrows climbed. "And you're abandoning something you've prepared for so extensively?"

Rio's mouth twitched, but she didn't look away. "We'll do it another night."

That was when it hit her - slowly at first, then all at once.

The shortcut.

The clipped answers.

The determined pace.

A smirk unfurled across Agatha's face like a cat stretching in a sunbeam.

"Oh," she breathed, delighted. "Oh, I see."

Rio's suspiciously neutral expression faltered. "No, you don't."

"I do," Agatha sing-songed, stepping closer. "Somebody got impatient."

"No."

"Somebody kissed her girlfriend in a graveyard," Agatha continued mercilessly, "and then immediately decided her carefully constructed plans could go fuck themselves."

"It's called adjusting the schedule," Rio argued, cheeks warming unmistakably. "Efficient people do it all the time."

"Mhm. I'm sure this is all about efficiency."

Rio narrowed her eyes. "I don't like that tone."

"Yes, you do," Agatha said, leaning closer as her voice dropped just enough to make Rio's breath hitch. "You like it when I'm mean."

Despite the teasing, something about the situation warmed her heart. She knew Rio didn't cut corners, didn't skip steps, didn't abandon plans. Not unless something mattered more.

Unless someone mattered more.

And the realization did things to her. Dizzying, sinful things.

"Agatha," Rio breathed out, eyes unapologetically glued to her lips. The space between them shrank again, like they were two magnets unable to stay away for long. "Unless you want our first time together to be in an alley, I suggest we move."

The raw want in her voice was almost enough for Agatha to start searching for the nearest dim-lit street not riddled with tourists. It was almost enough to press Rio against the closest wall and finally take what she'd been so rudely denied for weeks.

But the last functioning neuron in Agatha's mind rang the alarm bells, helpfully reminding her that she'd much rather do this somewhere she could get Rio naked.

"Give me the keys," she rasped out, suddenly lightheaded under Rio's dark gaze. "I'll get us home faster."

Rio didn't object. Just pressed the keys into her palm and dragged her toward the car.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! I honestly didn't mean the kinda cliffhanger (kinda because I think we all know where this is going), but this is almost 10k words long, so yeah. Had to split it. Also, I've never been to Boston, so everything's based on research (James' story is real btw), Google maps, and hoping for the best. As always, thank you for reading and see you (I think) next week!

Chapter 40: The count

Chapter Notes

You know where this is going: smut ahead. For those who want to skip it, pretty much stop reading around the time they pull up to the house.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

"That's three, Agatha. We're not-"

"Are you seriously counting how many traffic laws I've bent to my will?" Agatha asked, whipping the car into a sharp turn that earned them an outraged honk from someone who clearly wasn't in as much of a rush.

"Broken," Rio corrected, gripping the door like she expected it to detach and fly off into the night. "You're actively breaking the law, and I'm not spending the night in jail. Or in a fucking morgue."

Agatha only scoffed, her foot steady on the gas as the city blurred around them. "Dramatic, aren't we?" she drawled. "Relax. I always drive like this when Nicky's not in the car."

Rio turned a slow, deeply unimpressed stare her way, the kind that suggested she was mentally updating her will. "That's not as comforting as you think it is."

"It should be," Agatha countered, a wicked little curl to her lips as she let one hand slip to the side, drifting toward the warm denim of Rio's thigh. "I'm still alive after all."

Before her fingers could make contact, Rio's hand shot out, firm but not unkind, circling her wrist. She guided Agatha's hand back toward the wheel and released it only once it was hovering obediently at the ten-and-two position.

"Both hands on the wheel," Rio ordered, voice low with a mix of authority, exasperation, and something else that made Agatha's pulse dance. "Now."

Agatha huffed, but the grin she wore was incorrigible. "You know," she said, eyes flicking toward Rio, "I would've expected fewer protests about my driving, considering your begging to go home early."

"There was no begging," Rio grumbled, looking out the window. "Oh, come on, that light was red!"

"Yellow at best," Agatha said flippantly. "And I proceeded with caution."

Rio let out a noise between a groan and a prayer for survival. Then, unexpectedly, her voice softened, a gentle hand running up Agatha's arm - not enough to distract her from the road ahead, but enough to make her skin tingle despite the barrier of her clothes. "We have all night, querida. You don't have to drive like you're running from the cops."

Agatha's mouth twitched with a smile she didn't bother trying to suppress. "We're not," she said, glancing at Rio just long enough to catch the soft look in her eyes. "Running from the cops, I mean."

"Yet," Rio muttered, but her touch lingered - warm, steady, sliding down Agatha's arm in a way that made her breath catch. Not distracting, exactly. More like an anchor. The kind of touch that meant to say I'm here and I'm not going anywhere without the words.

The car slowed a little, almost involuntarily.

Agatha glanced at their joined shadows reflected on the windshield - their silhouettes fitting together even in distortion - and cleared her throat. "I already told you: I always drive like this," she said to cover up how Rio's verbal and non-verbal assurances hit somewhere close to her heart. "It has nothing to do with," she waved her hand before returning it to the wheel, "everything."

Rio hummed, and Agatha could feel her eyes on her as firmly as a touch of a hand. "Right. So nearly getting T-boned has nothing to do with being horny?"

Agatha choked on air. "That's not- I-"

Rio didn't let her finish. "Agatha," she said, suddenly soft in a way that made the rest of the world dim a little. "We'll get home. And we'll have the whole night to do anything we want. Whether you drive like a maniac or a law-abiding citizen."

Agatha swallowed hard. "Yeah, but driving like a maniac will get us there faster," she pointed out, not even caring about admitting her driving style wasn't the safest. "And don't act like you don't want that."

"Oh, I do. Trust me," Rio admitted, her voice dipping into something that went straight between Agatha's legs. Her fingers traced one last line along Agatha's biceps before moving away. "If I had a nickel for every time I thought about this, I'd probably be richer than you. But to do everything I want to do to you, I need both of us alive."

For a second, Agatha genuinely considered pulling the car over.

Rio must have sensed it, because she added lightly, "Don't even think about it. If we're not doing it in a graveyard, we're not doing it on the side of the road either."

"Those two are not comparable," Agatha argued, readjusting her grip on the wheel. Another intersection appeared, the red light shining mockingly, and she slowed the car to a begrudging stop with a sigh.

The silence stretched for a few seconds, interrupted only by the soft hum of the radio and the impatient tapping of Agatha's fingers before she spoke again. "I really enjoyed the date," she said quietly, eyes glued to the traffic light. "It was... different."

Rio shifted beside her, tilting her head. "Good different?"

"Obviously," Agatha rolled her eyes, pressing on the gas when the light finally turned green. She worked her jaw, deciding that focusing on a conversation would be better than sitting in this stifling tension. "I haven't been on a date like that since college. Maybe not even then."

"You mean," Rio hesitated, searching for words, "low budget?"

Agatha shook her head, glancing at her out of the corner of her eye. The woman seemed tenser than before, her shoulders tight, fingers gripping the door handle, but Agatha knew it had nothing to do with her artful driving anymore.

"Thoughtful," she corrected gently. "Catered to some obscure interest nobody's ever paid attention to."

Rio went very still at that - so still Agatha could practically feel the breath she wasn't taking. Then, slowly, her death grip on the door eased, fingers sliding away to rest lightly on her own thigh.

"Oh," Rio said, so quietly it might've been lost under the hum of the engine if Agatha wasn't tuned to her like a radio frequency. "Well. Good. That's... good."

Agatha's mouth twitched. "How incredibly articulate of you."

"It's hard to be articulate when you're going fifty in a thirty."

"It's forty-five."

"We passed a school," Rio stressed.

"It's night. The children should be asleep."

Rio groaned, but it quickly turned into a laugh, warm and genuine. When she shifted again, her eyes focused on Agatha's profile, her expression soft and open - no teasing, no bravado.

"I like paying attention," she admitted. "To you. Especially to the parts you don't show often or talk about to just anyone."

Agatha swallowed, her throat unexpectedly tight. The road ahead blurred for a moment before she blinked it back into focus. "I only told you about wanting to be a witch as a kid. You deduced the rest from studying my bookshelves."

"True," Rio agreed, voice low. "But it wasn't just the books. I notice everything about you. How curious you were when I brought you to that bookstore-slash-bar. The way you always stop to read the plaques on historical buildings. How you look at old houses like you're trying to see who lived there."

Agatha chanced a glance at her. The streetlamps slid over Rio's face as they passed beneath them - light, shadow, light again - like she was flickering between all the versions of herself Agatha had come to care about. All real. All hers.

"I used to hate that about you," she said slowly, a hint of a smile in her voice. "The way you notice things other people miss. Or the things I'm trying to hide. That you... care enough to pay attention."

"And now?"

Agatha exhaled slowly, her throat contracting around the words. "Now it's... comforting, I guess," she forced out without meeting Rio's eye. "To know you see certain things and they don't scare you."

Rio nodded in her peripheral vision, looking pleased but not smug. "They never scared me. If anything, they made me want to get to know you more."

Agatha snorted despite herself. "Famous last words."

"I'm still standing, aren't I?" Rio asked, amusement bleeding into her voice like a balm meant to soothe the raw places Agatha had voluntarily uncovered. "And I'm not going anywhere. You're not getting rid of me that easily."

The solid certainty behind the words made something uncoil in Agatha's chest - not the entire twisted knot of uncertainties she'd been tying since she was a child, but a small part of it.

Another part. Because, apparently, all Rio did was unravel her.

Before she could think of a response, the house came to view - windows dark, blinds up, just as she'd left it in the morning.

Except now, it was also blissfully empty.

Her pulse jumped as she guided the car into the driveway, reaching blindly for the remote to open the garage. Her fingers brushed Rio's, who was already pressing the button and reaching to unbuckle her seatbelt.

Under any other circumstances, she would've teased Rio about eagerness and impatience, maybe even purposefully slowed down the car to prolong her torture. But not this time. Not when her stomach clenched with the same hungry anticipation she could see in Rio's profile.

The car stopped neatly beside the old Toyota, the garage door beginning its descent.

Agatha killed the engine, plunging them into sudden silence, interrupted only by their breathing and the sound of the door's motor working on sealing them off from the rest of the world.

The automatic lights flicked on, too bright, too invasive, but Agatha didn't care.

Not bothering to wait for the door to hit the concrete floor, she undid her seatbelt and turned, slamming her mouth onto Rio's. The kiss was no longer about illicit urgency or defiant public spectacle; it was about arrival and consumption.

Rio responded with a muffled sound of relief and fierce possession, her hands immediately finding Agatha's face, anchoring her there. Their mouths met with a familiar, hungry geometry, tongues sweeping together. The lingering tension from the drive - the speed, the red lights, the adrenaline - was instantly channeled into the press of their bodies.

The hands cupping her cheeks slid to the back of her neck, the grip growing more demanding as they urged her forward. Agatha followed mindlessly, her body acting on instinct, until the hard plastic of the center console dug a sharp, painful reminder of the tight space into her hip.  

It was almost absurd, the way they'd spent weeks wrestling with their self-control not to give in, and now couldn't bear to wait five more minutes.

"Not here," Agatha mumbled against the warm lips devouring hers, her own hands tightening on Rio's shoulders, making no movement to sever the contact. "Inside."

Rio hummed, ignoring the request as her teeth grazed Agatha's bottom lip before sucking on it gently, possessively. A low, shaky moan reverberated at the back of Agatha's throat, soft but unmistakable, and was immediately swallowed as Rio adjusted, deepening the kiss again.

Her hands pulled again, and the console dug into Agatha's hip hard enough to elicit a quiet hiss.

The sound seemed to work better than the words, making Rio lean back enough to drag her lips across Agatha's jawline - a slow, maddening trail punctuated with warm breaths. "Let's go," Rio whispered, pressing a kiss against the soft skin below her ear.

Agatha didn't need to be told twice. She whipped around, yanking the car door open and stumbling out with her heart hammering a frantic rhythm in her throat. The moment her feet hit the concrete floor, she was already moving in quick, long steps that screamed urgency.

When she reached the door, warm hands appeared on her hips, easily wrenching her around. Her back slammed against the wooden surface before she could form a coherent thought, and Rio's mouth descended on hers once again, all-consuming and hungry. Agatha responded without hesitation, a ragged breath escaping in a shaky moan when Rio's thigh slotted firmly between hers.

The pressure was maddening - not enough to offer any real relief, but too firm to go unnoticed. Her hips rolled forward in a desperate attempt at satiating the fire consuming her entire body, fingers tearing at Rio's leather jacket like a lifeline as their lips clashed together.

The door rattled when Rio pushed further into her, hands yanking at Agatha's shirt to untuck it and slide underneath. The skin-on-skin contact made them both gasp, momentarily ending the kiss, but Rio didn't waste a second. Her lips mapped out the scorching path along Agatha's jaw until they traveled down her throat, nipping and sucking at the tender skin in a way that made Agatha's hips stutter before picking up their frantic pace.

Her head tilted back, thudding against the door as another moan, raw and unguarded, was ripped out of her throat, echoing through the empty garage.

"So fucking hot," Rio whispered against her throat, voice dripping with lust. "Las cosas que quiero hacerte..."

Agatha's eyes snapped open, the unexpected Spanish blasting through the haze of sensation. Rio didn't usually use it with her, knowing that Agatha's knowledge of the language didn't let her understand more than the basics - the only times she heard Rio speak it were on the phone with her family or when helping Nicky learn.

She'd certainly never heard it spoken like this - low, sultry, a little wrecked, and utterly feral. The sound vibrated against her neck, turning the words into a physical force. With the way Rio's voice changed - the depth, the immediate intimacy, the sheer unleashed hunger - Agatha knew, without translating a single syllable, that Rio was speaking in a language that bypassed logic entirely.

The knowledge went straight to her core.

Agatha choked back another sound, her fingers digging tighter into the leather. She tilted her head back down just enough to look Rio in the eye, the teasing fire instantly returning to her gaze, even as her body still pulsed against the rigid thigh trapped between hers.

"I don't speak Spanish, querida," Agatha managed, her own voice husky and unstable, her breath ragged. She forced a challenging smirk. "But I know enough to understand the tone of promise. And if you're going to make promises like that in a language I barely understand, you'd better be ready to back them up immediately."

She flexed her hips, a deliberate, agonizing movement that drew a sharp, undeniable gasp from Rio.

"And," Agatha continued, pushing the door handle just enough to hear the lock disengaging, "if we're going to get to the part where you follow through on all your grand plans, we need to be somewhere that doesn't smell like fucking motor oil and desperation. Inside. Now."

She pushed at Rio's shoulders, forcing them apart, and hauled the door open with a resounding thud. Rio, momentarily stunned by the sharp shift from raw passion back to Agatha's signature command, was left with no choice but to follow.

Agatha stepped through the doorway and into the dark hallway, kicking off her shoes and leaving them where they landed. She heard Rio do the same, her sneakers hitting the floor with a soft thud, immediately followed by the rustle of leather as she shed her jacket, throwing it onto the hanger.

Hands found her waist again, and just as she was about to oppose being pressed against another wall, they spun her back toward the staircase, forcing her to take the lead. It was a silent, effortless maneuver - a statement that Rio was complying, but not surrendering. Not yet.

Agatha started up the steps two at a time, her adrenaline spiking. The darkness of the house was absolute, guiding them only by memory and the heated connection of their bodies.

One of Rio's hands moved to the banister, but the other remained at Agatha's lower back, not just steering but applying firm pressure that felt less like guidance and more like a brand. The air between them buzzed with anticipation, as days, weeks, months of waiting manifested in quickened steps and ragged breaths that had nothing to do with the climb.

As they reached the top landing, Agatha stopped abruptly, eyes darting between the doors tucked away in the dark hallway.

Which bedroom?

The question ricocheted in her mind, a sudden intrusion of cold logic cutting through the haze of lust.

Rio's room would be the logical, safe choice. It wouldn't leave any indelible memories clinging to Agatha's sheets and pillows after they inevitably separated the next day, exiled back to their respective spaces. Her room was where she kept the pretense of surviving without Rio alive, where she fooled herself into believing she didn't need her to fall asleep.

But tonight, logic felt like a betrayal. Tonight, the urgency demanded something definitive.

Rio sensed her freeze, the subtle clench of muscle under her palm. She leaned close, chest flush against Agatha's back, breath warm against her ear, ready to whisper the obvious suggestion - her room.

Before she could speak, Agatha made the choice. Driven by a sudden, decisive emotional surrender that bypassed all caution, she shook her head, grabbing the hand pressing against her spine and tugging Rio along. Not toward the closed door near the linen closet, but toward the end of the hall - the master suite.

Her room.

Rio followed instantly, fingers curling around Agatha's hand in quiet acknowledgment layered with shock.

"Querida," Rio murmured, the name a question and a promise, spoken in a voice that was suddenly thick with reverence. "Are you sure?"

*starts singing War Is Over*

Chapter 41: The walking gallery

Chapter Notes

Some smut ahead, but not a lot, just an fyi

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Consciousness returned to Agatha not with a gentle nudge but with the distinct sensation of having been run by a steamroller. A very attractive, very enthusiastic steamroller, but a steamroller nonetheless.

She cautiously blinked one eye open, immediately regretting the decision as the beam of light that had woken her assaulted her vision. They hadn't bothered with the blinds last night, and now she was paying the price, lying in the square of light filtering through the window.

Thank God the neighbors decided to plant a massive oak on their side of the fence. Giving them a show was not on her bucket list.

Agatha groaned, a low, hoarse sound that brought back the memories of last night's overuse, and tried to shift.

A catastrophic mistake.

Because her vocal cords weren't the only overworked part of her body. If anything, they were the least of her problems.

Her body protested the movement in a chorus of aches and stiffness that she felt deep in her bones. Her hips felt disjointed, her inner thighs burned with a dull, constant throb, and there was a specific soreness in her jaw that brought memories far more vivid than the state of her raw throat.

Seven times.

Well, they had made it to six before exhaustion - and the sheer physical limits of the human body - had forced a ceasefire around three in the morning.

Agatha turned her head slowly on the pillow, careful not to aggravate the sore muscles in her neck - muscles she didn't even know she had until now.

Rio was dead to the world.

She was sprawled on her stomach, taking up a staggering seventy percent of the enormous mattress. One arm was flung out across Agatha's waist, the other dangling off the edge of the bed. Her face was turned to the side, away from the light and Agatha, but the rhythmic rise and fall of her back indicated deep, dreamless sleep.

She looked messy. Peaceful. Beautiful.

The morning light caught the curve of her shoulders, highlighting the ink of the vines that Agatha had traced with her tongue hours ago. The sheet had slipped down to her waist, letting Agatha finally see the entire piece of art etched into the soft skin.

But nothing was stopping her now.

It was a paradox of ink - chaos and order somehow inhabiting the same space without warring for dominance.

The colors were startingly vivid against the tan skin - emerald greens coiling possessively around blooms of red, orange, purple, and even white.

They looked almost jarringly innocent, a quiet whisper of white and yellow amidst the wilder, sharper blooms surrounding them. They felt significant. Protected. A soft memory planted in the middle of a wild life.

It was a disaster.

Agatha didn't really care for order in her house. After growing up in a place that resembled a pristine office more than a home, she'd learned to appreciate the lived-in feel of the space she'd curated for Nicky and herself. The house was functional and clean, but not immaculate - the walls bore marks of Nicky's curious hands from when he'd been learning to walk, small dents from stray balls or Nerf gun darts, and many other imperfections that she'd always seen as her way of breaking the cycle.

Her room had always been different, though. Since the only times she set foot in it were when she went to sleep, most of it remained untouched, a museum of expensive furniture and unoccupied space. Whatever messes she made were mostly contained to the walk-in wardrobe, and even those were short-lived as Ana brought the space back to pristine condition every Friday.

Nicky's perfectly fine. Stop looking at your phone on your hot date!

On the long, mahogany table - usually littered with contracts, homework, or random scraps of paper - stood a disruption.

Eight small vases arranged in a neat, precise row.

Agatha recognized them from around the house, stuffed in cupboards or gathering dust on the shelves, never used for their actual purpose.

Now they housed a riot of color that cut through the greyscale of Agatha's home.

Each bouquet was different, small and hand-tied, but they all shared a common theme: purple.

There was a vase filled with deep, velvety irises that looked like they'd been bought at a farmer's market. Next to it, a cluster of violets leaned elegantly against the glass. She couldn't really recognize the rest of the flowers, but one thing was clear - the bouquets weren't a florist's perfectly curated arrangements. They were scrappy. Thoughtful. Overwhelming.

"What..." Agatha breathed, her grip on the plates tightening until her knuckles turned white. "Rio. What is this?"

"I said I'd keep up the tradition," she said quietly, scratching the back of her neck. "When we first talked about public outings for the deal? I said I'd keep giving you flowers. And if I wanted to do that for something fake, well, I certainly wanted to do that for something real."

The grand gestures she was familiar with - the impersonal bouquets sent by business partners, the expensive dates at fancy restaurants women would sometimes take her on - never made a dent in her. But this? This row of random flowers lined across the table like a display made especially for her?

"It might be growing on me," she admitted, her voice sounding thin to her own ears. "And I'll make sure to pick a favorite so you don't have to give me eight bouquets every time you decide to spoil me."

Rio glanced at her, a small crease between her brows. "Spoil you?" she repeated, incredulous. "Most of these come from the garden. And the rest is from the farmer's market. It's far less than you deserve, but... I couldn't exactly afford eight dozen roses."

"No, Rio," Agatha said firmly. She put the plates beside the cups of coffee and turned toward her girlfriend, cupping her face. "Any idiot can go to a florist and buy a bouquet," she continued, softer. "But you grew most of these yourself. You took the time to arrange them. "I'm glad you like it," Rio murmured against her skin, her breath warm. She opened her eyes, the dark irises swirling with that fierce, quiet intensity that always made Agatha feel like she was the only person in the room. "Because you're stuck with dirt and time for the foreseeable future."

Dirt and time.

And it was an even bigger luxury for Rio, who was juggling work and studying. Who, just a few weeks ago, almost collapsed under the weight of her responsibilities.

Rio, who spent her morning arranging eight vases of purple flowers just to make Agatha feel special.

The three words scratched at her vocal cords again, insistent and scared. I love you. I love you.

Agatha huffed, trying to mask the pout threatening to overtake her face. "I do not faint."

"You sway," Rio corrected, pulling out a chair for her with exaggerated chivalry. "Sit."

Agatha did.

Rio took the seat opposite her, their eyes meeting over the bouquet of what Agatha was almost sure were azaleas. The flowers Rio had said she'd like.

And she did. She liked the curved, uneven petals. She liked how they seemed messy at first glance, but still held symmetry when you looked closer. Order disguised as chaos.

She took a sip of her lukewarm coffee and nodded her head toward the vase. "I like these. They'll be my favorite from now on."

Rio smiled at her from behind her mug. "That was fast. I was hoping for a bracket. Tournament style."

Agatha rolled her eyes, though she didn't try to hide the genuine smile breaking through. "I can think of better things to do after breakfast than deciding on my favorite flower."

You'll love me by the time our third date rolls around.

And honestly, damn her for being right.

The sound of cutlery clattering onto the ceramic plate snapped her out of her spiral.

"Done," Rio announced, wiping a crumb from her lip with her thumb. She stood up, the chair scraping loudly against the floorboards. "Plate's clean. Coffee's gone. My reward awaits."

"The dishes-" Agatha started, mostly just for the sake of protesting.

The daisies near her spine - the ones Agatha had pegged as innocent earlier - seemed to tremble, as if shaken by their wearer's doing.

The table groaned more insistently under her shifting weight. The bouquets in her peripheral vision wobbled dangerously.

Agatha didn't care. She abandoned the white-knuckled grip on the table to tangle her fingers into Rio's wild hair, pulling her closer, deeper. She stared at the ink on Rio's skin - at the permanent marks of a life she was just beginning to understand - and felt that terrifying pressure in her chest expand again.

It wasn't just lust. It wasn't just gratitude for the eight bouquets surrounding them and the six orgasms she'd already been given.

It was the realization that she wanted to be the next flower on that back. She wanted to be permanent.

"That's a funny way of saying 'oh, Rio, my darling girlfriend, thank you for the incredible orgasm.'"

"Correction," Agatha said, pushing herself forward to sit up and shoot Rio a glare. "You will have to wipe down the entire table later."

Rio smirked, tilting her head. "Later?"

"Yes, later," she grumbled, reaching for the shirt hanging off Rio's frame and ripping it off in a sharp, decisive move. The only done button clattered uselessly to the floor, the sound mixing with her girlfriend's surprised gasp. She peeled the garment off, tossing it over the back of a chair to deal with later.

"The second one," Rio rushed out, leaving the mess of spilled water, fallen flowers, and dirty dishes for their future selves. "Definitely the second one."

Agatha smirked, letting herself be dragged back upstairs.

Her hands maneuvered Agatha toward the bed with a firmness that left no room for discussion, and the second her head hit the pillows, Rio was already crawling up her body.

Her limbs were heavy, her lips were vibrating with numbness, and she was fairly certain that if she tried to stand up right now, her legs would simply fall off.

"You're impossible," she grumbled, refusing to rise to the obvious bait. "I know you have youth on your side, but you have to be at least a little tired."

The hand on her back slid up her spine, tracing each vertebra until it reached the loose strands of hair that had escaped her bun. Agatha's eyelids fluttered shut at the feeling of gentle fingers toying with the ends, untangling a knot with surprising patience.

Rio laughed, her grip on Agatha tightening. "I can live with that."

"You were falling asleep."

"And?"

The dasies.

The subtle callback to losing her parents and being moved to Florida at the age of seven made Agatha's heart constrict painfully. Not for the first time, the memory of her own sharp, suspicious reaction when Rio had first shared that part of her story stung at the back of her throat.

"They symbolize new beginnings," Rio answered with a small, self-depricating smile that tugged at the corner of her mouth. "It's kind of tacky, I know. But I wanted something definitive to mark that new chapter in my life. Something to remind me that change doesn't always come with tragedy. That sometimes it's the beginning of growth."
