Agatha looked at the skeletal rider. The explanation felt terrifyingly relevant. She'd spent years calcified in her own routines, her own defenses, refusing to change for anyone. And then Rio crashed into her life and forced a transformation Agatha hadn't asked for but desperately needed.

"When did you get it?" she asked, stroking the side of Rio's leg.

"After deciding to go for a PhD," Rio said, leaning into the touch with a small smile tugging at her lips. "I figured that even if the symbolism doesn't land, it will be an accurate portrayal of how every doctoral student feels."

Agatha breathed out a soft laugh. "It lands. Both of them, I suppose."

"Good to know," Rio smiled, sitting up to lean against the headboard. "So? What's the verdict? Is the gallery curated to your standards?"

Agatha's eyes traveled back up the length of Rio's body. She looked at the Death card and the wild garden peeking over her shoulder, the tributes to family and friends still vivid in her memory.

Rio had created a crowded, loud, beautiful history map on her skin.

And once again, the quiet urge to be a part of that history settled in Agatha's chest.

"It's beautiful," she admitted, her gaze snagging on the Flor de Maga meant for Rio's late parents. "Even more beautiful with the stories."

Rio grinned, catching Agatha's hand to press a kiss to the center of her palm. "High praise coming from a woman who doesn't know what a thistle looks like."

Agatha rolled her eyes but didn't pull her hand away. Instead, she used the leverage to crawl further up the bed until she was sitting beside Rio, their sides pressed together.

From this angle, she could see the vines curling over Rio's left shoulder to tangle into the masterpiece on her back, but something else caught her eye this time. Too focused on the ink, she hadn't paid attention to the spots devoid of it. And there was one spot in particular, near the base of Rio's neck, that had been left conspicuously bare.

It didn't really make sense - the garden didn't cover Rio's entire back, but this one place stood out with vines coiled around it like they were waiting.

"You missed a spot," Agatha murmured, reaching out to trace the empty area. Her fingertips glided over the warmth of Rio's skin, circling the blank space. "Ran out of inspiration? Or money?"

Rio went still again. She didn't joke, didn't deflect with a comment about student poverty. She turned her head slightly, catching Agatha's eye with a look so intense that it made the air in the room feel thin.

"Neither," she said, her voice dropping to that husky register that did complicated things to Agatha's insides. "I'm saving it."

Agatha's hand stilled. "For what?"

Rio turned fully toward her without breaking eye contact. "Something permanent enough to fill it."

The implication hung heavily between them, terrified and thrilling at the same time.

Agatha swallowed hard, her heart hammering a frantic, traitorous rhythm against her ribs. She looked at the blank canvas of skin, then up into Rio's dark, hopeful eyes. She didn't say the words - those three words that had been trying to claw their way out of her throat all morning - but she didn't pull her hand away, either.

Instead, she flattened her palm against the empty spot, claiming it with her touch.

"Don't rush it," she whispered, the advice sounding more like a plea. "Good art takes time."

Rio let out a shaky, relieved laugh, covering Agatha's hand with her own and pressing it tighter against her skin.

"I've got time, querida," she murmured, leaning her forehead against Agatha's. "I've got nothing but time."

Chapter End Notes

Hi! Once again, my self-control knows no bounds, so that was another 10k chapter. I was torn between including more smut and finally having Rio talk about her tattoo, and you know which one won at the end, hence the jump (don't be mad, I just know that if I decided to write all that, the chapter wouldn't come out for another two weeks because it'd be ridiculously long). Anyway, thank you all for reading, and see you when I see you!

Chapter 42: Broken things

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Reality didn't return with a gentle knock; it barged in like an unwanted guest.

Life resumed on Saturday afternoon - far too quickly for Agatha's liking - the play button pressed by a single text from Wanda to Rio asking if the coast was clear to drop off Nicky. The subtle hint that the boys were growing antsy, remembering the promise of visiting Agatha's house and possibly seeing Rio, forced the two women out of the warm cocoon of the sheets and into the shower.

It was a tactical move to save time and water. Predictably, it had the opposite effect.

The steam, the small space, and Rio's inability to keep her hands to herself resulted in Agatha being thoroughly dismantled against the shower tiles one last time before they actually managed to wash the lingering scent of sex off their skin.

Then came the panic.

There was a frantic, synchronized scramble to deal with the crime scene in the dining room - throwing out the ruined shirt slung over one of the chairs, wiping up the spilled water, righting the fallen vase, and scrubbing the mahogany table until it gleamed innocently.

They had barely finished dressing - Agatha in a soft T-shirt, Rio in a hoodie pulled up high to hide the bruising on her neck - when the front door swung open.

The peace was shattered instantly. Three boys burst into the hallway like a category five hurricane, a blur of limbs, giggles, and shouts. Nicky slammed into Agatha, unknowingly pressing against at least three bruises littering her hips and making her wince, his excited chatter about the sleepover mingling with the twins' own retelling.

Wanda trailed in behind them, looking entirely too pleased with herself as her eyes did a slow, forensic sweep of the couple. Her gaze lingered for a beat too long on the high collar of Rio's hoodie, and then drifted to Agatha's flushed complexion.

"Soccer," Wanda said suddenly, cutting through the boys' tirade, her lips twitching. "Didn't you want Rio to show you some new trick?"

A second later, Rio was being dragged toward the back garden by Nicky, the twins shouting about Ronaldo, leaving Agatha at her best friend's mercy.

The interrogation was surprisingly short-lived. Mostly because Rio's knee - aggravated by their dining table stint - didn't take kindly to another bout of exertion. She had to tap out of the training session after twenty minutes, limping back to the patio with a grimace she tried to hide from the kids.

But even before Rio joined them, resting her outstretched leg on a chair and balancing an ice pack Agatha had wordlessly brought her on her knee, Wanda didn't really ask for details. She didn't joke about the hickey she had definitely seen, or about the way Agatha's eyes seemed to follow Rio around, as if the woman had her own gravity.

No, Wanda seemed uncharacteristically content with a sparse retelling of the date and an easy omission of what followed.

Then, as she was leaving, with the twins already dragging their feet toward the car, Wanda reached out and squeezed Agatha's arm.

"Being happy looks good on you, Ags," she whispered, her voice dripping with sincerity.

She slipped out the door before Agatha could formulate a defense or a denial, leaving the words hanging in the air.

Agatha walked back to the patio, stopping by the window to look at Rio sitting on the steps, rubbing her knee and cheering Nicky on as he dribbled the ball between his feet. As if sensing the sudden attention, Rio turned her head, catching Agatha's eye through the glass, and flashed a bright, unguarded grin.

Agatha felt warmth spread through her chest that had nothing to do with the sun streaming in.

She was happy. It was a foreign, terrifying, fragile feeling, but it was undeniably there.

At least until the night rolled around, the sun set, and the rules of their household snapped back into place like a bear trap.

Nicky was home. The weekend was over.

And that meant Agatha was currently lying in her enormous bed, staring at the ceiling fan spinning lazily in the dark, miserably wide awake.

It was 2:00 AM.

She had been tossing and turning for three hours.

The split-second decision to have Rio in her bed had come to haunt her in a rather spectacular way. She had crossed a line, hoping - praying - that the consequences wouldn't be as severe as her mind made them out to be, only to realize they were even worse than she'd imagined.

The bed felt cold. The silence, usually her sanctuary, pressed against her ears, deafening without the counterpoint of Rio's rhythmic breathing or the grounding weight of her arm draped over Agatha's waist. The sheets, although changed into a fresh set, somehow still smelled like Rio.

Agatha groaned, rolling onto her side and punching her pillow, trying to mold it into a shape that offered some comfort. It didn't work. It just felt like foam and failure.

This is ridiculous, she scolded herself, glaring at the wall. You're a fucking adult. An independent woman. You've slept alone for years and liked it. Remember how to like it again, idiot.

She couldn't.

She couldn't remember why she used to enjoy an empty bed. She couldn't remember why the warmth of another person beside her used to feel suffocating. She couldn't remember why the sound of someone breathing used to be annoying.

Because all those things didn't feel like an inconvenience with Rio. They felt like safety. Comfort.

But the lack of a bedmate wasn't the only thing keeping her up. Wanda's whisper steadily fueled her newfound insomnia, so casual, so easy, and yet so devastating, still echoing in her ears.

Being happy looks good on you, Ags.

Agatha squeezed her eyes shut. Happiness didn't even begin to cover it. The thing taking root in her chest was worse than that. It was terminal.

She thought about the empty space on Rio's back. The way Rio looked at her over the bouquet of azaleas. Rio's touch on her stomach, claiming the soft parts Agatha hated. The way Rio had seamlessly integrated herself into the house, into Nicky's life, into the very foundation of Agatha's existence.

The bile rose in her throat again.

I love her.

Somewhere between the fake marriage license and the eight bouquets lined across her table, Agatha Harkness had gone and done the one thing she promised herself she'd never do: she had given someone the power to destroy her.

And the worst part? She had dragged an innocent bystander into the blast zone.

Agatha rolled onto her back again, rubbing her hands over her face.

Nicky.

Her son still saw their connection as a partnership - a logical, practical agreement between two people who cared about each other but slept in separate rooms and sat two feet apart on the couch.

He didn't know about the breathless kisses in the kitchen. He didn't know about the marks Rio had left on Agatha's being - both physical and metaphorical. He didn't know his mother was falling apart at the seams with want.

The evening had been torture.

They had tried to act normal during dinner. They sat in their usual spots, ate the quick risotto Rio had managed to put together from the scraps from their fridge, and listened to Nicky ramble about the sleepover.

But the air had shifted. Every time Rio passed her something, their fingers brushed, and the electric jolt was so strong that Agatha was surprised the lights didn't flicker. Every time Rio laughed at one of Nicky's jokes, her eyes would slide to Agatha, dark and heavy with a shared secret, and Agatha would have to look away to keep from doing something reckless, like climbing across the table.

If the restraint had been excruciating before, it was now beyond torturous. It felt like wearing a corset that was laced too tightly, restricting her breath, forcing her to be stiff and proper when all she wanted was to be easy and close.

She'd thought scratching the itch would've satiated her enough to make everything easier, that knowing what Rio's touch felt like would've stopped her mind from imagining it.

It turned out to be a massive, catastrophic oversight.

Because now she didn't have to imagine anything. Her mind operated purely on memory, using the silence and darkness to relieve every brush of lips against her skin, every passionate kiss, every earth-shattering touch.

Agatha had never craved another person like this. She'd never felt the absence of their touch or presence like a physical pain prickling her skin. It surpassed the bounds of anything skin-deep and dismissible. The want

wasn't just the byproduct of getting out of a year-long dry spell; it went deeper, taking root in places of Agatha's heart she'd never cared to explore. She didn't just crave Rio's touch or the physical release she knew it could bring.

No, she craved Rio. Every aspect of her. Every version of her. Everything about her.

And it was beyond terrifying.

I love her.

She had tried to ignore the thought for those past few weeks. It remained buried under the budding need to finally get Rio alone and the logistics of working out the plan to throw the PI off. Then she swallowed it down to focus on getting as much out of their time alone as possible.

But here, in the dark, empty room, it was all Agatha could think about.

That, and the fact that she didn't do love. She did contracts. She did mutually beneficial agreements. She did calculated risks with exit strategies already planned out.

Love was none of those things. It was sloppy and unpredictable. It was handing someone a loaded gun, pointing it at your chest, and trusting them not to pull the trigger.

And Agatha didn't trust anyone that much. Or at least, she hadn't until a twenty-seven-year-old grad student with a garden tattooed on her back pestered her into sharing her life story and then refused to leave.

She turned over again, staring at the sliver of moonlight slipping through the curtains.

It didn't feel like the kind of love they wrote songs about - the fluffy, weightless infatuation she used to roll her eyes at. This felt more like a diagnosis. Like she'd been infected months ago - maybe the first time Rio had come with her to one of Nicky's games, or that time she saw them working in the garden together - and now the symptoms were undeniable. There was no cure. There was no going back to the version of herself that existed before Rio Vidal.

And that was the problem. Because Agatha knew how her stories ended.

She was difficult. She was sharp-edged and cynical and stubborn. She drove people away. Every relationship she'd ever attempted eventually buckled under the weight of her armor. People gave up trying to scale her walls. They got tired of cutting themselves on the barbed wire.

Rio was patient, yes. She claimed to like the sharp edges. But everyone had a breaking point.

Eventually, Rio would realize that loving Agatha was hard work. Eventually, the novelty of the chase would wear off, or the age gap would feel too wide, or Agatha would simply say the wrong thing one too many times, and Rio would leave.

And they'd talked about all that. They'd promised each other clear communication and trying and everything else that should make a relationship work.

But what if it wasn't enough? Relationships fell apart every day, and Agatha knew most of them involved people infinitely better at compromise and romance and patience than she was.

She also knew most of those people didn't have a third, innocent person standing in the line of fire.

A child.

Nicky.

Agatha closed her eyes again, biting her lip to stop from screaming into her pillow.

It had always been just the two of them. Agatha and Nicky against the world. She had kept her dating life strictly partitioned, a scattering of casual dinners and nights away from home to never touch their little sanctuary. She had never introduced a girlfriend to him. She had never let anyone get close enough to hurt him.

Until Rio.

She had let Rio in under the guise of necessity, a Trojan horse made of fake marriage certificates and desperation to spite her mother. And Rio hadn't just entered the fortress; she had redecorated.

Nicky adored her. He lit up when she walked into the room. He sought her out for advice on video games. He had started learning Spanish because of her. He looked at Rio with a hero-worship that terrified Agatha because she knew exactly how much it would hurt when the pedestal crumbled.

Agatha squeezed the bridge of her nose, her breath hitching.

If she screwed this up - when she screwed this up - Rio wouldn't just be moving out of the guest room after the deal's end. She would be exiting their lives. And Agatha would be the one left to explain to her son why the coolest, most consistent, most loving person who had entered their orbit in years was suddenly gone.

I can't let him lose her, Agatha thought, a cold sweat breaking out on her palms. I can't be the reason his heart breaks.

But she also couldn't stop. Because it was too late.

She should have stopped in the garden, the day she'd told Rio that all she could do was try. She should have stopped herself from barging into Rio's room after overhearing her conversation with Evanora. She should have stopped the words about wanting something real from ever leaving her mouth.

She should have stopped days, weeks, months ago. But she hadn't. And now putting the genie back in the bottle was impossible. Now, no matter what she did, she'd put them on a path that could only end in heartbreak.

Rio's, hers, Nicky's.

It was too late to protect him from the inevitable fallout. It was too late to try to distance him from Rio. Agatha's selfishness had put them in this place. Her greedy need to have something she'd never imagined being worthy of.

And that very same selfishness would eventually make her the villain in her son's life. The mother who couldn't make it work. The woman who chased away the good thing.

Because crossing the line between fake and real had tarnished any chances at friendship after the deal's end. If Agatha screwed up now, the twelve-month mark would mean the end of Rio's presence in their lives.

Permanent. Irreversible. Heartbreaking.

And she would screw up. She wouldn't be Agatha Harkness if she didn't.

Unlovable and broken. Just as her mother had said.

Agatha threw back the covers, the sudden urge to move unbearable. She needed a glass of water. Or a bottle of wine.

But her feet didn't carry her to the stairs. No, before she could realize it, she was standing in front of the guest bedroom door, staring at the wood in utter surprise.

There was no light filtering into the hallway. As far as she knew, Rio was dead asleep on the other side.

Her hand hovered over the door, everything in her screaming to push it open. Her body ached for the warmth she knew entering would bring. Her mind, usually so disciplined, was supplying helpful images of Rio sleepily tugging the covers back to let her underneath, making room for her without a word.

But the voice in her head - Evanora's voice - was louder.

You're not someone people love. You're a burden, a disappointment, but not someone people want.

If she went in there now, looking like she felt - raw, terrified, completely in love - Rio would see it, even half-asleep. And then what? What if Rio didn't feel the same? What if, to Rio, this was just a really intense, really great taste of domesticity and a family with an expiration date of twelve months?

Agatha looked toward Nicky's door.

That couldn't be true, right? Rio had bent over backwards to prioritize Nicky to the point of utter exhaustion this summer. She'd told Agatha she didn't mind camp drop-offs and spur-of-the-moment soccer matches in the garden. She kept giving, even when nobody asked her to, and it couldn't have been for the sake of pretending or playing house.

Even if Rio didn't love her, she certainly loved her son.

And for now, that was the only comfort Agatha had. Because it gave her a sliver of hope that when she did screw up their relationship, there was a slight chance that Rio would stay. Not for her, but for Nicky.

And maybe that was enough. Maybe it didn't really matter that Agatha was unlovable, because Nicky was lovable enough for the both of them.

With a heavy sigh, Agatha turned back toward the master bedroom, letting the emptiness swallow her once more.

Sunday night was a painful repeat.

The day had been a masterclass in deprivation. Agatha had only seen Rio for a fragmented hour in the afternoon - a chaotic overlap of lunch and homework where Nicky acted as a joyful, oblivious chaperone. They were always too close to the boy to steal a touch, too exposed to risk a kiss, forcing Agatha to survive on glances and the phantom heat of Rio's hand brushing her waist as she passed her in the kitchen.

Then, the reprieve ended. Rio left for her shift at the bar, taking all the oxygen in the house with her.

Agatha had retreated to her bedroom around eleven, going through the motions of skincare and reading like the early-rising professional she was. She turned off the lamp with a soft click forty minutes later, bathing the room in darkness.

But sleep was a foreign country she'd been exiled from.

She lay there, eyes wide open, staring at the shadows shifting across the ceiling, waiting.

At 2:03 AM, she heard it. The soft rumble of the engine in the driveway. The mechanical whir of the garage door opening. The muted thud of a car door closing.

Rio was home.

Agatha held her breath, even though she couldn't make out the sounds of Rio moving across the house. Then, a floorboard creaked just outside her door - a moment of hesitation, a second of weakness - and her heart jumped to her throat.

Please come in. Please don't let me sit in all this alone.

The door to the guest room clicked shut, and Agatha deflated.

The solitude, once her sanctuary, now felt like a cage. The worries she'd managed to keep at bay during the daylight hours descended now, circling her like harpies.

I love her.

The realization was no longer a revelation; it was a heavy, jagged stone sitting in her gut. It remained unexpressed, terrifying in its magnitude.

Five months left.

The passing of time in their fake marriage used to make her feel like a prisoner, marking the days leading up to their release on a cell's wall. Now it felt like a ticking bomb. When the contract expired, when they both got what they initially wanted, and the ink dried on the divorce papers... then what?

Rio had said she wasn't going anywhere. But Rio was twenty-seven, brilliant, and free. Agatha was forty, baggage-laden, and difficult.

The fear wasn't just about being alone again. She knew how to survive alone. She could relearn it.

The fear was that she wasn't enough to make Rio stay once the obligation was gone.

She tried to grasp at the straws of evidence she'd collected over the weekend - at the gravity in Rio's dark eyes when she'd said the blank space on her shoulder was for something permanent. At the way Rio had looked at her across the dining table, like Agatha was the only thing that mattered in a room full of flowers. At the undeniable fact that Rio loved easily, loudly, and without the brakes Agatha constantly slammed on.

It should have been enough. It should have been the antidote. It should have convinced her that Rio was just as far gone, just as hopelessly ruined for anyone else, as she was.

But Evanora's voice kept ringing in her ears, reminding her that she was unlovable, difficult, too much, and the anxiety felt like a physical weight, pressing down on her chest, making the large, empty bed feel suffocating.

Before she knew it, her feet were carrying her down the hall, right to the guest bedroom.

It was the same journey as the night before. The same cool floorboards. The same silent hallway.

But this time, there was a difference. A sliver of golden light spilled from beneath the door, cutting across the darkness.

A beacon. A signal that Rio hadn't gone to bed yet.

Agatha's forehead rested against the doorframe, her body heavy with exhaustion and want. She felt pathetic. She felt forty going on fourteen - standing outside a door, desperate for validation, terrified of rejection.

Needy. Unlovable. Difficult.

Her eyes squeezed shut, her jaw clenching to suppress a sob threatening to escape.

Rio had promised. That night when they'd talked about their fears, she had looked Agatha in the eye and sworn she would never treat Agatha's wants and needs as too much.

But what if this crossed a line?

Rio had just returned from a grueling shift. She was likely exhausted, her knee probably aching. She hadn't come to Agatha's room; she'd gone straight to her own. That was a statement, wasn't it? It meant she wanted peace. It meant she wanted to decompress alone.

She didn't want her needy, spiraling girlfriend barging in, falling apart under the weight of feelings she hadn't even voiced yet. She didn't need Agatha, who felt lost and confused and required Rio's physical presence just to ward off the doubts circling her like vultures.

Leave her alone, the voice - Evanora's voice - hissed. Or don't. Let her see you for who you really are now. Show her the broken, true version of yourself. Watch her realize that not even Nicky is worth dealing with you.

Agatha opened her eyes. She took a shaky breath, placing her hand on the frame to steady herself, and pushed off.

She turned to walk away.

"I can hear you thinking from here, mi vida."

The voice was soft, muffled slightly by the wood, but unmistakable.

Agatha froze mid-step, her heart hammering against her ribs.

"And," Rio continued, her voice drawing closer to the door, "I can see your shadow under the door. You've been standing there for like two minutes."

The door handle clicked.

Agatha didn't have time to run. The door swung open, bathing her in the warm light of the bedside lamp.

Rio stood there. She was still in the black shirt she wore for work - slightly wrinkled, smelling of beer and spirits - and she looked tired. Her head was pulled back into a messy bun, wisps escaping around her face. Her feet were bare.

But she wasn't looking at Agatha with annoyance. She wasn't looking at her with the exhaustion of someone who wanted to be left alone.

She was leaning against the doorframe, arms crossed loosely over her chest, looking at Agatha with a soft, knowing tilt of her head.

"You're spiraling," she stated gently. Not an accusation but a diagnosis.

Agatha opened her mouth to deny it, to make up an excuse about water or a noise she heard, but her throat clicked shut. She just stood there, in her pajamas, feeling small.

Rio sighed - not a sound of exasperation, but of surrender. She reached out, her hand catching Agatha's wrist. Her fingers were warm, the simple touch sending a pleasant wave of tranquility through Agatha's nervous system.

"Come in," Rio muttered, tugging her gently. "Before you convince yourself I hate you or something."

"I don't-" Agatha started, her voice cracking. "You just got home. You're tired. I shouldn't-"

"Agatha," Rio interrupted, stepping forward to bridge the gap. She didn't let go of Agatha's wrist; instead, she slid her hand down to interlace their fingers. "I am tired. My feet hurt. I feel sticky. And the only thing I've wanted since we left the bed on Saturday is to hold you."

She looked Agatha dead in the eye, her gaze anchoring Agatha's drifting soul.

"If you walk away now," she whispered, "I'm just going to follow you. So save my poor feet the trip, yeah?"

Agatha let out a wet, broken breath. The fight drained out of her, leaving only the relief.

"Okay," she conceded.

Rio smiled - small and tired and beautiful - and pulled her into the room, the door clicking shut behind them.

She didn't release Agatha's hand until she guided her to the bed.

"Lie down," she instructed softly, pulling back the covers. "I need ten minutes to shower and change. Otherwise, I'll contaminate the sheets."

Agatha hesitated again, glancing toward the door. "Maybe I should just-"

"No," Rio said, pushing her down onto the mattress and dropping the covers on top of her. "You're mine for the night. And you better be here when I get back."

Rio's scent enveloped Agatha the second her head hit the pillow, and every protest she could have given died in her throat. Her muscles relaxed into it instantly, a soft sigh slipping past her lips.

"Don't worry about falling asleep," Rio added quietly, leaning down to press a kiss to her forehead. "I'll be here when you wake up."

With that, she grabbed her pajamas from the foot of the bed and disappeared into the bathroom, leaving Agatha alone in the lamp's soft glow.

It wasn't the same as being alone in her own room, though. Here, the silence was warmer, more peaceful than suffocating. Agatha's mind didn't bother with conjuring worst-case scenarios, disenheartened by the clear signs that this was Rio's space. That she'd come back and hold Agatha through any nightmarish thought it could produce.

Agatha's eyes took in the room, clinging onto every pile of papers, every stack of books, every trinket littering the shelves. Seeing them was, in some abstract, bizarre way, grounding. The slight clutter reminded her that Rio was real, solid, and flawed, not the idealized savior Agatha had built up in her head, nor the inevitable victim of her destructive nature.

She sank further into the mattress, letting her eyelids flutter shut. Sleep wouldn't come until Rio was beside her, Agatha was certain of it, but the mere smell of her was enough to bring a semblance of peace.

A few minutes later, the bathroom door opened, and she heard Rio tiptoeing towards the bed.

Agatha opened her eyes, tilting her head to look at the woman. Rio had changed into a soft, worn green T-shirt and a pair of boxers, foregoing her pajama bottoms. She looked warm and domestic - a version of her that Agatha had seen numerous times before but would never grow tired of.

Rio switched off the lamp, plunging the room into a soft, grey darkness before the mattress dipped under her weight.

"Okay," she exhaled, sliding under the covers and immediately reaching for Agatha. "Come here."

She didn't wait for Agatha to listen. Her arm hooked around Agatha's waist and pulled her closer, arranging them until Agatha was tucked against her side, head resting on Rio's shoulder, a leg thrown over Rio's hips to anchor them together.

The contact was a balm. The physical weight of Rio's arm, the heat radiating off her skin, the steady thump of her heart - it silenced the static in Agatha's brain better than any bottle of wine she could've found downstairs.

"Better?" Rio murmured, pressing a kiss to the top of Agatha's head.

"Yes," Agatha whispered, closing her eyes. She inhaled the scent of Rio's body wash, mixed with the faint smell of the bar that still lingered in her hair. "I... I thought you'd want space. After you stopped by my door and didn't come in."

"You noticed that, huh?" Rio sighed, her hand rubbing slow, soothing circles on Agatha's back. "I didn't know you were awake. And slipping into your bed without your explicit consent seemed... presumptuous."

Agatha burrowed herself further into her girlfriend. "But you wanted to?"

"God, yes," Rio said without an ounce of hesitation. "I spent most of my day dealing with drunken idiots and clenching my teeth through every other interaction. When I come home, the last thing I want is space. I want my people."

My people.

The possessive plural made Agatha's breath hitch.

"I thought I was being pathetic," Agatha admitted into the darkness, the confession scraping her throat. "Staring at your door for the second night in a row, wanting to be held."

Rio's hand stilled on her back.

"You did that yesterday, too?"

Agatha exhaled slowly to help the words form. They still felt raw as they left her mouth. "I couldn't sleep. But I didn't... I didn't want to be too much. The needy girlfriend who suddenly can't be alone because we had sex."

"Needy," Rio repeated, her voice developing a suspicious edge. "Did Evanora call?"

"She didn't have to," Agatha muttered. "You don't spend your entire life hearing things like that without eventually memorizing them."

Rio shifted, moving her hand to tilt Agatha's chin up until their eyes met in the shadows. Her expression was fierce and tender all at once.

"I am not your mother, Agatha," Rio whispered, the words hitting the center of the wound with surgical precision. "I don't look at you and see a burden. I don't see a project I need to fix or a problem I need to solve."

She brushed her thumb over Agatha's cheekbone.

"I see a woman who has spent forty years holding up the sky by herself," Rio continued, her voice thick with emotion. "And if you need to put the weight down for a few hours? If you need to crawl into my bed to sleep? That doesn't make you needy or difficult. It makes you human."

Agatha felt a tear leak from the corner of her eye, hot and humiliating. She tried to turn away, but Rio held her fast.

"And for the record," Rio added, a small, crooked smile breaking through the seriousness. "I couldn't sleep yesterday either. Apparently, some part of me finds your snoring comforting."

Agatha let out a wet, choked laugh, burying her face in the crook of Rio's neck to hide the fresh wave of tears. "I don't snore."

"You do, but that's alright," Rio said, wrapping her arms tight around Agatha's shaking frame. "I'd much rather lie awake because of your snoring than because I'm missing you."

Agatha clung to her, her fingers bunching in the fabric of Rio's T-shirt as if the cotton were the only thing keeping her tethered to the earth. She didn't say the three words - she was still too terrified they would break the spell, shattering this fragile, beautiful thing they had built - but she poured them into the way she held on.

"Go to sleep, querida," Rio whispered into her hair. "I'm not going anywhere."

Agatha wondered how many times she'd have to hear it before her nervous system believed it.

"Don't let go," she muttered, the plea barely audible.

"Never."

And for the first time in two days, the noise in Agatha's head went silent. She slept.

The next morning, Agatha jerked awake to the distinct click of a door closing down the hall.

For a split second, her brain sputtered, struggling to triangulate her location. The mattress underneath her was firmer than her own cloud-like setup, the sheets were cheap cotton, and the scent filling her lungs was a heady mix of sandalwood and warm skin.

Then the heavy weight of an arm thrown possessively over her waist registered, along with the soft, rhythmic puffs of air hitting the space between her shoulder blades. Her muscles, poised for flight, melted into something dangerously soft.

Rio.

Rio's front was molded against her back, a human heater warding off the morning chill. One of her hands had somehow snaked under Agatha's pillow, long fingers curling near Agatha's face, while the other gripped her waist with a subconscious desperation, as if afraid Agatha would disappear in the dead of night.

Agatha watched the dust particles dance in the sliver of sunlight cutting through the blinds. Everything felt peaceful. Right. Like she could live in this moment.

Heavy footsteps padded down the hallway, and panic cut through the peace like a scalpel, a sharp reminder of why she'd woken up.

Nicky was awake. The previous sound of a door closing had been him leaving his room.

Her eyes darted to the nightstand - empty. She hadn't brought her phone. She had no idea what time it was, but the light suggested it was dangerously close to the time her alarm was set to blare in an empty master bedroom.

If Nicky walked into her room to wake her and found it abandoned...

Adrenaline flooded her system, overriding any lingering tenderness. She grabbed the arm clutching her waist and shoved it off, scrambling to her feet without any grace.

"What the..." Rio mumbled, the mattress shifting as she was rudely dislodged.

Her eyelids fluttered open, heavy with sleep, her mouth set in a confused pout. She looked soft, unguarded, and irritatingly beautiful. "Somethin' on fire?" she grumbled, rubbing a knuckle into her eye.

"I have to go. Nicky's awake," Agatha hissed, her voice a frantic whisper as she strained her ears against the door, trying to track her son's movements like a prey animal tracking a predator.

Rio groaned, the concern evaporating instantly as she flopped back down, burying her face deep in the pillow Agatha had just vacated. "'ave fun at work," she slurred, dead to the world before the sentence was even finished.

Agatha rolled her eyes without dislodging her ear from the door.

Silence. Suspicious, heavy silence.

With her heart thudding a frantic rhythm against her ribs, she turned the handle with agonizing slowness, opening the door a mere crack to peer into the corridor.

Empty.

She slipped out, closing the door with the surgical precision of a cat burglar, and took exactly two steps toward the sanctuary of the master suite.

The bathroom door across the hall swung open.

Agatha froze mid-step, looking like a deer caught in the headlights of a semi-truck.

Nicky stepped out, scratching his stomach. His hair was a bird's nest, his pajama shirt was askew, and his eyes were barely slits. He looked like a zombie in a Snoopy print.

He paused, blinking slowly at his mother standing in the middle of the hallway, shifting her weight like a child caught with their hand in the cookie jar.

"Hi, Mama," he mumbled, his voice thick with sleep.

Agatha's heart hammered against her throat, choking off any articulate response. "Hi," she squeaked out.

Nicky didn't ask why she looked caught. He didn't ask why she was standing in the middle of the hall, barefoot and disheveled. He just shuffled back toward his bedroom, the door clicking shut behind him.

Agatha didn't wait to see if his brain would reboot and process the scene. She bolted for the room, locking the door behind her and leaning against it, gasping for air like she'd just run a marathon.

The alarm shrieked on her nightstand a second later.

The next hour was a blur.

Agatha rushed through her morning routine, scrubbing her skin until it turned pink and avoiding looking in the mirror, as if the sight might offend her.

It wasn't the first time she'd spent the night in Rio's room with Nicky in the house. Nothing about it warranted the sense of shame prickling just under her skin, an irritation and an unnecessary burden. But the reality of almost getting caught followed her around like a dark cloud, hanging over her head as she dressed for the day.

They hadn't done anything scandalous, and yet Agatha felt undeniably dirty as she pulled on her charcoal suit that fit like a second skin. She felt nauseous as she slipped into her four-inch stilettos that clicked a warning on the floorboards. She felt entirely unprepared as she tied her hair into a neat bun at the top of her head and walked out of the room.

Nicky was already at the dining table, munching on his cereal and looking considerably more awake than he had in the hallway.

Agatha gripped her travel mug tighter, her knuckles whitening with the effort of holding herself together. Her mind sifted through the range of excuses she'd prepared in the shower.

I woke up earlier and went to the kitchen to grab some water, baby. That's why you saw me looking guilty near Rio's door.

I didn't hear Rio return from work and wanted to check if she made it back okay. And she did, so no need to think too hard about it.

I heard a noise near Rio's door and was just checking for possible murderers.

Okay, maybe scaring her son with a potential criminal wasn't the best parenting tactic.

She cleared her throat, deciding to play it cool. "You've got everything ready? The bus leaves in thirty minutes, so we'll have to get going soon."

"Yeah!" Nicky said enthusiastically, drinking the remaining milk straight from the bowl before jumping out of his chair. "Rio helped me pack yesterday. She even put some extra Gatorade in my bag."

Agatha stiffened at the name, but forced her feet into motion as she grabbed her laptop and bag. "Of course she did," she grumbled to herself since Nicky had already disappeared into the kitchen to put the dishes away. "She seems to think sugar and electrolytes are the solution to all of life's problems."

"She's not wrong!" Nicky giggled, the sound carrying through the house as he darted past her to the door.

Honestly, it was almost unbelievable that he looked ready to fall back asleep an hour ago.

The drive to the parking lot where the kids were supposed to gather for the buses was agonizingly normal. Agatha gripped the steering wheel a bit too tightly, driving with more aggression than usual, but Nicky didn't seem to care. He sat beside her - a new development he negotiated with a pointed 'I'm almost eleven, Mom' - and filled the suffocating space with chatter.

She waited for the other shoe to drop. She waited for him to ask about the morning. To ask about the hallway. To ask about why she had looked so guilty.

But he didn't. He talked about the trip, about finally playing on a real soccer pitch, even if just for a day, about the new cleats he wanted.

"Rio said she'd practice penalties with me when I get back tonight," he said suddenly, almost buzzing in his seat. "She said I'm good, but I make my target too obvious. I gotta work on my poker face."

Agatha's fingers flexed around the leather. "Rio has very professional insight for someone who hasn't played for years."

"Coaches don't play," Nicky replied immediately, with the absolute authority of someone repeating newfound gospel.

Agatha couldn't help but wonder where he'd heard that one. The answer was probably obvious. The three-letter name seemed to be the answer to most of her questions recently. And the source of all the rest.

"Besides, Rio's cool," Nicky added, looking out the window as his expression turned serious in that unnerving way that usually meant he was thinking harder than a ten-year-old should have to. "I'm glad she's here."

Agatha kept her eyes on the road, jaw set. "I know you like her, Nicky. She's... entertaining."

"No, I mean..." He struggled for the words, gesturing vaguely with his hand while the other picked at a loose thread on his seatbelt. "I'm glad she's here for you."

Agatha slammed on the brakes a little too hard at the red light. The car jerked to a halt, and she mentally wrestled her voice into submission before speaking again, forcing it to stay level and soft. "What do you mean, baby?"

"You're just..." Nicky chewed on his bottom lip, toying with the drawstring on his sweats. "You laugh more now, Mama. Like real laughing. And you don't look so... lonely."

The word hung in the air between them, sharp and suffocating. Lonely.

"I was never lonely, Nicky," Agatha said gently, reaching over to squeeze his knee. "I have you. How could I ever be lonely with such an amazing kid?"

"I know," Nicky said, angling his leg into the touch. "But... when I'm at school or a sleepover, you're just alone. And now... now you have backup. And I have someone to play soccer with. It's nice."

He looked up at her then, his eyes wide and impossibly earnest.

"I liked it when it was just the two of us," he added quickly, as if afraid she'd understand him the wrong way. "But I like us with Rio too, you know? I like how happy we are with her."

The light turned green. Agatha didn't move for a full two seconds.

Horns blared behind her, jarring her back to reality. She pressed the gas pedal, her leg shaking slightly, forcing the car forward through the intersection.

Nicky didn't have to use the word family to get his message across.

He had referred to them as a unit multiple times before - when trying to talk Agatha into inviting Rio to one of his games, while building the raised beds in the garden, and on other, smaller occasions that Agatha couldn't even recall anymore.

But somehow, this conversation hit her the hardest. Even without calling them a family, even without blatantly pointing out all the ways Rio had become a part of their lives, Nicky had made it clear that he didn't see Rio's presence as a fun housemate, but as a solution to his mother's solitude. He had noticed the happiness Wanda had whispered about and said that it extended to him as well.

I like how happy we are with her.

He wasn't seeing romance. He probably didn't think in those categories, or at least Agatha hoped he didn't. But he was seeing a team, a family, and he liked it.

"We're here," Nicky announced, oblivious to his mother's internal collapse, as she pulled to the curb behind the idling charter bus.

He unbuckled his seatbelt and grabbed his duffel bag. He leaned over, staring at Agatha expectantly, and she pressed a quick, automatic kiss to his forehead.

"Bye, Mama. You'll pick me up, right?"

"At six, yeah," Agatha croaked out, clearing her throat to find her voice. "Have fun. Don't break anything - body parts or things."

"I'll call Rio if I do 'cause she won't give me a lecture," he joked, opening the door.

Agatha felt nauseous. "I'll find out either way," she managed, forcing the corners of her lips into something resembling a smile. "Run. Before you get extra laps for being late."

She watched him sprint toward the bus, high-fiving a teammate, looking so light and unburdened.

Agatha waited until he disappeared into the bus before she let her head fall against the headrest. She closed her eyes, but the image of Nicky's earnest face still appeared in the darkness.

You don't look so... lonely.

A few months ago, Agatha would've scoffed at the word. She wasn't lonely; she was selective. She had friends, a son, a thriving career, and a social calendar that required careful management. If anything, she would've laughed and said she wished people would leave her alone more often.

But now, after tasting what her life could look like with Rio by her side, she knew Nicky was right.

Her loneliness hadn't been physical. Her career meant she was constantly surrounded by people, caught in a ceaseless friction of clients, judges, and paralegals. Her days were loud.

But she had been lonely in the way that mattered. It was the specific, crushing solitude of being the only adult in the house. The person who had to check the locks, pay the bills, manage the emotions, and hold up the sky without anyone ever asking if her arms were tired.

Rio had asked. Rio had stepped in and taken the weight without waiting for permission.

I like how happy we are with her.

The sentence replayed in her mind, a looped recording. It was the worst thing he could've said. Because it was true. And because it meant that her happiness was now a load-bearing wall in her son's life. If Agatha did anything to weaken it, if she crumbled, the roof would come down on him too.

The damage wasn't hypothetical anymore. It was done.

Agatha sat there for a long moment, the engine idling, the AC humming against the summer heat. She had a meeting in forty minutes. She had to be Agatha Harkness, the shark who wrangled the most defiant clients into submission.

But all she wanted to do was turn the car around and go home.

Home to the empty house. Home to Rio.

And as the bus pulled away, exhaling a cloud of exhaust, a terrifying, reckless clarity took root in Agatha's chest.

Nicky was gone until six.

Agatha clenched her jaw. She wanted to see Rio. She wanted to feel that peace she'd felt at night again.

Maybe it would offer her enough bravery to utter those three words she'd been trying to hold back all weekend. Maybe the realization that there was nothing she could do to protect Nicky from the repercussions of her feelings - that it was already too late to protect him - was what she needed for the words to form on her tongue without hurting.

Maybe if she confessed, the invisible weight on her chest would lessen.

She sighed, glancing at herself in the rearview mirror. Her makeup was perfect, an impenetrable armor she needed to get through the day.

But the look in her eyes was still lost. Still confused. Like the conversation with Nicky only scrambled her mind more, instead of offering some clarity.

Agatha put the car in drive and steered it toward the firm.

Maybe all she needed was a few more hours to sit with it.

The meeting was a nuisance.

The client wasn't new. The case wasn't even remotely intriguing. Every topic they covered had already been discussed more times than she cared to count.

Agatha sat through it with her back ramrod-straight and a sense that she should be doing something more important as Mr. Finley droned on about an upcoming disposition and how much of an unnecessary hassle this entire thing was.

That Agatha could agree on, though he probably didn't mean the meeting itself.

She wrapped it up in just under an hour, telling Mr. Finley that everything was ready and that she'd get him the win he so desperately wanted before holing herself up in her office.

It took her another two hours to finally crack. The room was stuffy, the light falling through the windows too harsh, and whenever she looked at the glass wall separating her from the rest of the office, she kept hearing Rio's words suggesting she get blinds.

And she still felt lost.

She couldn't really pinpoint the moment she decided to derail her entire day, including a strategy meeting at one and another client meeting at three. Her legs just carried her to the door, laptop and bag in hand, past Billy's desk.

"Cancel my afternoon," she ordered without stopping.

"Mrs. Harkness? But the-"

"Tell them I have a family emergency," Agatha called over her shoulder, heading for the elevator. "Reschedule for tomorrow."

The drive home was a blur of roads and panic. She drove with the radio off, her hands gripping the wheel until her knuckles ached. She was going home to... what, exactly? To confess? To make sure Rio was still there after the night's vulnerability? To search for something that would put her mind at ease?

The plan kept shifting in her mind, dissolving into white noise every time she tried to pin it down.

When she finally entered, the house was quiet.

"Rio?" she called out hesitantly. It was noon. She hadn't thought about the very real possibility that Rio could still be asleep.

There was no answer, but a faint, metallic scraping sound drifted from the kitchen.

Agatha kicked off her heels, leaving them in the hall, and padded down the hall. The floors were cold, and the thin stockings left her skin exposed.

She rounded the corner and stopped dead.

Rio was in the kitchen. She was kneeling on the floor in front of the cabinet under the sink - the one that had hung crooked on its hinges for so long that Agatha had stopped paying it any mind. She was wearing shorts that ended just above her knee and a loose black shirt, her hair pulled into a messy topknot that was slowly surrendering to gravity. A toolbox - one Agatha had never seen before - was open beside her.

As Agatha watched, Rio twisted a screwdriver with practiced ease, her tongue poking into her cheek in concentration. She gave the cabinet door a test swing. It closed silently. Perfectly.

Rio sat back on her heels, wiping her hands on her thighs, and hummed a satisfied little tune.

It was the most domestic, helpful, innocent thing imaginable.

And it made Agatha see red.

The sight of it - Rio fixing the broken parts of Agatha's house, Rio tending to the things Agatha had neglected, Rio making herself useful in a way that implied she planned to be opening that cabinet for a long time - triggered a violent, defensive recoil in Agatha's chest.

It was too real. It was too permanent. It was exactly what Nicky had talked about: You don't look so lonely.

Because Rio was fixing the loneliness, too. And if Rio fixed it, and then Rio left, the house wouldn't just be broken anymore. It would be condemned.

"What the hell do you think you're doing?" Agatha snapped, the words cracking like a whip.

Rio jumped, nearly dropping the screwdriver. She spun around on her knees, eyes wide. "Fucking Christ! You scared me. You're home early."

"I asked you a question," Agatha said, her voice vibrating with a tremor she couldn't control. She marched into the room, stopping a few feet away. "Who told you to touch that?"

Rio blinked, looking from Agatha's furious face to the cabinet door. "The hinge? It was loose and driving me insane every time I went for the trash bags. I just tightened it."

"I didn't ask you to tighten it," Agatha hissed, throwing her expensive bag onto the island with a violent thud. "I didn't ask you to play handywoman! I didn't ask you to fix anything!"

Rio stood up slowly, the screwdriver still in her hand. The relaxed, content demeanor from seconds ago evaporated, replaced by a wary confusion.

"Agatha," she said carefully, keeping her voice low. "It's a cabinet. It took five minutes. Why are you yelling?"

Her calmness only angered Agatha more.

"Because it's not just the cabinet!" Agatha growled, pacing away from her because standing still felt impossible. "It's also the banister outside that used to wobble! The doors that used to creak! You don't get to just- just come in here and start deciding that needs to be fixed! You don't get to make yourself indispensable!"

"Indespensable?" Rio repeated, her brow furrowed. "I used a Phillips head, Agatha. I didn't rewrite the deed to the house or change the locks."

"What about the garden?" Agatha spun back around, pointing a shaking finger at her. "About Nicky's math homework? My bed? You're seeping into everything, Rio! You're like... like mold! You're everywhere!"

Rio flinched. The hurt flashed across her face, sharp and immediate, before her eyes hardened.

"Mold," Rio said flatly. "Wow. Okay. I thought we had a pretty nice weekend, but apparently, I'm an infestation."

"You are!" Agatha lied, unable to reel her instincts back in. The need to rebuild the walls Rio had so effortlessly dismantled flared, and she couldn't stop it from manifesting in ugly words. "You're disrupting my system! I had a routine! The cabinet was crooked, and I liked it crooked! It was fine!"

"It was broken!" Rio argued, stepping forward, her own temper flaring. "Why do you want to live with broken things when it's so easy to fix them?"

"Because I know how to live with broken things!" Agatha screamed, the confession tearing out of her throat raw and jagged. "I know how to navigate the broken parts! I don't know how to... I don't know how to do this!"

She gestured wildly between them - at the domestic scene, the fixed cabinet, the intimacy hanging heavy in the air.

"Do what?" Rio challenged, dropping the screwdriver onto the counter with a clatter. "Be happy? Be functional?"

"Be dependent!" Agatha choked out. Tears pricked her eyes, hot and humiliating. "I can't need you to fix a hinge. I can't need you to help Nicky. I can't need you to... to help me sleep."

She wrapped her arms around herself as if afraid she'd fall apart without it.

"It's not dependency," Rio argued, crossing her arms in defiance. "It's... it's letting somebody help, letting somebody take care of you for once. Everybody needs that sometimes."

"I'm not everybody!" Agatha roared, her voice cracking under the strain of the lie she'd lived for decades. "I don't get that luxury! I don't get to be soft! I don't get to lean on people because when I do, I crush them!"

She pressed the heels of her hands into her eyes, trying to stem the tide of panic rising in her throat.

"I survive," she whispered, dropping her hands to glare at the woman standing calmly amidst the wreckage of her composure. "That's what I do. I hold up the sky and the walls. I don't... I don't hand the screwdriver to someone else and hope they don't stab me with it."

"Is that what you think I'm doing?" Rio asked, taking a deliberate step forward. She ignored Agatha's flinch, her gaze steady and anchoring. "You think I'm fixing a hinge so I can hurt you later?"

"I think you're making me weak!" Agatha corrected, the words tasting like ash. "You're making it easy. You're making it... nice. And I can't afford nice. Because when nice goes away, I won't remember how to live with everything that's left."

She backed up until her hips hit the edge of the island, trapping herself.

"Stop fixing things," Agatha pleaded, her voice barely audible. "Just... stop. Leave the cabinet broken. Leave the banister wobbly. Stop making me used to a house that works."

Stop fixing me. Stop making me want to be better for you. Stop changing me into a version of myself that I don't hate.

Rio stepped two feet away. She didn't look angry anymore. The hurt from being called mold had settled into a quiet, profound sadness that was infinitely harder for Agatha to witness.

Because she knew screams. She knew how to withstand harsh words and heated glares meant to hurt.

But she couldn't stand the way Rio was looking at her - like she was a trapped animal trying to chew itself free instead of letting someone help.

"I'm not fixing the house for you, Agatha," Rio said softly. "I'm fixing it because I live here. Because I don't want to wake Nicky in the middle of the night with a squeaking door. Because I worry you're going to trip on the stairs in your ridiculous heels and fall because the banister won't hold."

She reached out, her hands hovering in the space between them, palms up. An offering.

"And I'm not making you weak," Rio added, her voice dropping to a rough whisper. "I don't think anyone ever could because you're the strongest person I know. I'm just trying to keep you company while you're holding up the sky."

Agatha stared at Rio's hands. They were calloused, stained with a bit of grease from the hinge, and steady.

The fight drained out of her as quickly as it had arrived, leaving her hollowed out and trembling in her power suit. The silence of the kitchen rushed back in, but it didn't feel peaceful. It felt heavy with the things she couldn't say - about the contract, about the expiration date, about the terrified love expanding in her chest like a supernova.

"I drove home," Agatha said, the non-sequitur falling from her lips before she could think about it. "I had a strategy meeting. I cancelled it."

Rio's brow furrowed. "Why?"

"Because I couldn't breathe," Agatha whispered. She looked up, meeting Rio's dark eyes, letting the mask slip completely. "Nicky said I didn't look lonely anymore. And I sat in the car, and I couldn't breathe, because I realized... I realized I didn't want to be anywhere else. I just wanted to be here. With the mold."

A startled, wet laugh escaped Rio, quickly stifled. The hope that flared in her eyes was blinding.

"Agatha," Rio breathed, stepping into the space between them.

She didn't wait for permission this time. She closed the gap, her hands landing on Agatha's waist, warm and solid through the wool of her blazer.

"I'm not going to stab you," Rio promised, leaning her forehead against Agatha's. "And I'm not going to let the sky fall down on you. Or the walls."

Agatha let out a shuddering breath, her hands coming up to clutch the fabric of Rio's T-shirt. It was a surrender. It was a terrifying admission of the very dependency she had just screamed about.

"I hate this," she sobbed, pulling Rio closer until there was no air left between them. "I hate how much I need you right now."

"I know," Rio murmured, tilting her head to brush her lips against Agatha's jaw. "I know. It's terrible. I'm a nightmare."

Agatha turned her head, capturing Rio's mouth in a kiss that wasn't gentle. It was desperate. It was frantic. It was an apology and an accusation all at once. She kissed Rio like she was trying to consume her, trying to breathe her in so deeply that she'd never be able to exhale her again.

Rio groaned, accepting the weight of Agatha's need without faltering. She dug her fingers into Agatha's hips, steadying and anchoring them both, as Agatha's hands grabbed the hem of her shirt, pulling it up.

"Off," Agatha gasped against Rio's mouth. "Take this off."

The contact was severed immediately as Rio stepped back, a little out of breath. Her eyes were wide, pupils blown, but there was hesitance lurking in the shadows.

"Querida-"

Agatha cut her off with another searing kiss, turning them around to press Rio into the island. She swallowed the surprised gasp that slipped past Rio's lips and pushed forward, frantically reaching under her T-shirt.

She needed skin. She needed something to ground her, to tell her that Rio was there and not going anywhere.

Rio caught Agatha's wrists just as her fingers grazed her ribs, pulling them from under the fabric.

"Agatha, stop. Wait," Rio said, her voice strained. She didn't push Agatha away - she clearly didn't have the willpower for that - but she held her in place, her grip firm. "We need to... we can't just gloss over this. You looked like you were having a panic attack. You said you couldn't breathe in the car."

"I still can't," Agatha choked out, fighting against Rio's hold. She didn't want to talk. Talking meant acknowledging the precipice she was standing on. Talking meant admitting that she was terrified of the fall. "So help me. Fix it."

She yanked her hands free with a burst of hysterical strength and shoved them under the T-shirt again, seeking skin like a starving animal seeking sustenance.

"Don't you dare be a gentlewoman now," Agatha hissed, her eyes brimming with unshed tears. "Don't you dare be sensible. I don't want to talk about feelings, Rio. I don't want to analyze why I drove home in the middle of the day. I just need to know you're here. Physically here."

Rio's resolve fractured. She looked at Agatha - at the panic vibrating in her pupils, the desperation etched into the grim set of her mouth - and she realized that words weren't the medicine Agatha needed. They were the poison.

"I'm here," Rio swore, the fight leaving her body with a slow exhale. "I'm right here."

She raised her arms, allowing Agatha to rip the shirt over her head and toss it blindly onto the floor.

The moment the fabric was gone, Agatha collapsed forward. She pressed her palms flat against Rio's bare chest, right over her heart, and let her forehead drop onto Rio's shoulder.

The contact was immediately soothing. The heat of Rio's skin, the rapid, thundering beat of her heart under Agatha's hand, the solid reality of her ribcage expanding and contracting - it was the only thing that made sense in a world that had suddenly tilted on its axis.

"Real," Agatha whispered against the ink on Rio's shoulder. "You're real."

"I'm real," Rio assured her, her hands coming up to cup Agatha's face, forcing her to look up. "And I'm yours. Whether you're yelling at me about cabinets or crying in my arms. I'm yours."

Agatha let out a broken sound and surged up again, kissing her with a fierce, consuming hunger.

This time, Rio didn't pull back. She met Agatha's desperation with a steady, pouring heat. She wrapped her arms around Agatha's waist, her hands sliding over the expensive wool of the blazer, finding the curve of her spine.

Their roles reversed again, and Agatha found herself pressed against the island, surrounded by Rio. The sensation of Rio's bare chest pressing into her clothed one made her knees buckle. She gripped Rio's shoulders to stay upright, her nails biting into the muscle.

"Don't stop," Agatha gasped out, leaning back as Rio began trailing hot, open-mouthed kisses down the column of her throat, right over her fluttering pulse point. "Don't let me think."

"No thinking," Rio promised against her skin, her hands sliding down to grip Agatha's thighs. "Just feeling. I've got you."

She lifted Agatha easily, taking her weight as if it were nothing. But she didn't set her onto the edge of the marble island as Agatha expected.

Instead, Rio turned and started marching out of the kitchen, heading for the hallway, her lips never once separating from the sensitive skin of Agatha's neck.

Agatha wrapped her legs around Rio's waist instinctively, locking her ankles behind Rio's back. She let herself be carried, floating in the haze of endorphins and adrenaline as teeth and tongue worked over her skin. The sensation was overwhelming, a total surrender of control that Agatha hadn't realized she was starving for until this very moment.

It wasn't until the smooth glide of the hallway floor was replaced by the slight jostle of an upward step that Agatha's brain fought through the fog.

Rio's grip tightened on her thighs, hoisting her slightly higher to take the second step.

Agatha's mind kicked back into gear with sharp clarity.

"Rio, no," she breathed out, her hands tangling in Rio's hair and pulling her head back, detaching her from Agatha's neck. The answering moan made Agatha's stomach tighten, but she didn't let go. "Your knee. Put me down."

She could feel the strain in Rio's body, the slight tremor in the leg that had buckled under a soccer ball just two days ago.

Rio looked up at her, eyes dark and blown wide, lips swollen and slightly parted. She didn't look like she was in pain; she looked like she was on a mission. She ignored the command, shifting her weight to her good leg and taking another defiant step up.

"Rio!" Agatha hissed, wiggling in her hold to try and force a dismount. "I refuse to be the reason you need another surgery. Put me down, I can walk!"

"No thinking," Rio reminded her, her voice rough and firm. She adjusted her hold, clamping her hands tighter on Agatha's thighs to stop her from squirming. "You carried the weight all day. You carried it for forty fucking years. Let me carry you."

She took another step, her jaw set in stubborn determination.

"I've got you, mi alma," she said, the physical effort putting a slight strain on the words. "Just let me take care of you."

Agatha froze. The sheer determination in Rio's voice broke her resistance, but not her worry.

If Agatha struggled, the shifting weight would only make it harder. So she did the only thing she could: she went limp, wrapping her arms tightly around Rio's neck and burying her face in the crook of her shoulder, trying to make her center of gravity more manageable.

"You're a stubborn idiot," she mumbled into Rio's skin, her heart hammering against her ribs - partly from arousal, partly from something softer that came from being cradled in Rio's arms.

"And you worry too much," Rio said, taking another few steps as her breathing became heavier.

They made it to the landing, but Rio didn't stop. She marched straight down the hall to the master bedroom - Agatha's sanctuary, the fortress of solitude that Rio had only entered twice.

She kicked the door open with her foot, not caring about the loud bang it made against the wall, and crossed the threshold. She didn't stop until her knees hit the edge of the mattress, finally letting Agatha slide from her grip.

Agatha landed on the duvet, bouncing slightly, and immediately reached out to steady Rio, whose bad knee wobbled the second the weight was gone.

"I'm fine," Rio assured her quickly, even as she shifted her weight to the uninjured leg with a wince. "Totally fine."

"You're not fine," Agatha scolded, eyeing her worriedly. "You just carried a full-grown woman up a flight of stairs on a fucked up leg because you have a hero complex."

Rio met her eye. Her hair was falling out of its bun, her naked chest heaving, and her eyes were burning with a dark, satisfied heat.

"I carried you," Rio corrected, her voice dropping to a rough whisper, "because you needed to feel the weight off your feet. And I needed to prove I could take it."

She moved, leaning over Agatha and yanking her forward by the lapels of her blazer until only a few inches separated their faces.

"Did it work?" she asked, searching Agatha's eyes. "Do you believe me now? I'm not going to crumble, Agatha. I can handle the weight."

Agatha stared at her. She looked at the sweat on Rio's temples, the determined set of her jaw, the unshakeable certainty in her eyes.

She was fairly certain that if she said no, Rio would pick her up again and never set her down.

The realization made the last of her panic evaporate, replaced by a heavy, molten need.

"I believe you."

"Good," Rio whispered, the word hitting Agatha's lips with her breath.

She didn't kiss her again, not yet. Instead, she placed her hands on Agatha's shoulders, sliding them down to the lapels of her blazer.

"This," Rio murmured, playing with soft fabric. "This has to go. No armor allowed in here."

"No," Rio commanded softly. "Let me."

She peeled the blazer off with agonizing slowness, treating it not as a hindrance to be ripped away, but as a layer to be carefully excavated. When it finally slipped free, Rio tossed it onto the floor, not caring where it landed.

She returned her hands to Agatha immediately, working on the buttons of her blouse with the same unyielding patience. Whenever her hands brushed against her skin, Agatha's breath hitched, the touch reminding her of the solid presence towering over her.

"You've been holding yourself together all day," Rio whispered when the lapels fell open. Her hand rose to brush her fingertips over the fading bruise on Agatha's sternum. "Trying to be a shark. Trying to be the perfect mother. Trying not to crack."

She moved her hand, gently easing the blouse down Agatha's arms.

"You don't have to be any of that right now," Rio promised, her touch burning as she peeled Agatha's armor off. "You don't have to perform. You don't have to lead. You don't even have to move."

Agatha's breath hitched. "Rio..."

"Shh," Rio silenced her, leaning in to press a soft, open-mouthed kiss to Agatha's collarbone. "Just breathe. Let me take care of you."

It was a terrifying directive for a woman whose survival depended on control. Agatha's hands twitched at her sides, itching to reach out, to grab Rio and pull her onto the mattress, to turn this into a wrestle for dominance.

Because, much like screaming, she understood fighting, too. Fighting for control. Fighting for power.

Being worshipped? Being tended to like something precious and fragile? That was foreign territory.

Rio seemed to sense the internal struggle. She tossed the blouse to the side, leaving Agatha in her bra and slacks, and interlaced their fingers, brushing her lips against Agatha's knuckles.

"I've got you," she muttered, her eyes locking onto Agatha's. "I'm not going anywhere. I'm not scared of the weight. Just let go."

Agatha let out a shaky exhale. She didn't fight it when Rio guided her further up the mattress. She didn't lock her muscles when gentle hands urged her to lie down on the pillows.

"Okay," she whispered, barely audible even in the quiet room.

A surrender. A permission. A quiet gesture of handing Rio the screwdriver and trusting her not to plunge it into her heart.

Rio resumed her work. She smoothed her hands over the lace of Agatha's bra, the touch reverent. She traced the lines of Agatha's ribs, memorizing the map of her body with a tactile focus that made Agatha feel vividly, achingly seen.

"Beautiful," Rio murmured against her skin.

Just reverence. Worship.
