Instead, she stretched over Agatha's body, pressing their chests together as she looked her in the eye.

"I'm right here," she said with unwavering confidence. "I'm fixing the hinge. I'm holding up the wall. You can rest."

And for a moment, Agatha believed her.

But then the silence stretched for a beat too long, allowing the guilt to creep in. It whispered that she didn't deserve this tenderness - not after she had screamed in the kitchen, not after she had insulted Rio, not after she had treated Rio's care like a violation.

She didn't deserve to rest. She deserved the storm. She needed it to drown out the voice telling her she was unlovable.

"Don't," Agatha gasped, her hands flying up to grip Rio's shoulders, nails digging in hard enough to bruise. "Don't look at me like that."

Rio didn't flinch. She just blinked, slow and calm. "Like what?"

"Like I'm something breakable," Agatha hissed. She bucked her hips up, seeking friction against the soft cotton of Rio's shorts. "I'm not made of glass. Stop treating me like I am. I want... I want you to make me forget."

She tried to pull Rio down, wanting to incite the sharp, biting passion that she'd already experienced two days ago.

"Be rough," Agatha pleaded, the words tumbling out in a frantic rush. "Just... take it. Take what you want. Punish me for being a bitch downstairs. Stop looking at me like you've already forgiven me."

Rio resisted the pull, leaning further back on her arms.

The look in her eyes didn't change. If anything, it softened even further, and Agatha wanted to scream and cry at the same time.

"No."

The word was soft, but it had the weight of a granite block.

"Rio-"

"No," Rio repeated, shifting her weight so she was pressing Agatha deeper into the mattress, her thigh slotting heavy and warm between Agatha's legs. "I'm not going to punish you, Agatha. I'm not going to hurt you because you got scared. That's not how this works."

"I wasn't scared," Agatha lied, her voice trembling. "I was cruel. I yelled at you. I told you to stop fixing things."

"I know," Rio murmured. She leaned down, brushing her nose against Agatha's, forcing an intimacy that was far more terrifying than any bite or bruise. "And I know why. You think that if you push hard enough, I'll push back. You think making this a fight will stop me from holding you."

"I don't want to be held," Agatha choked out, even as her body betrayed her, arching into Rio's warmth.

"Too bad," Rio whispered against her lips. "Because I'm still holding you."

She kissed Agatha then, and it was agonizing. It was slow. It was deliberate. It was a kiss that tasted of patience and absolute, unshakeable resolve. Rio moved her hips in a slow, grinding roll, dragging the friction out, refusing to give Agatha the quick, sharp release she was begging for.

Agatha whimpered, frustration and pleasure warring in her throat. She tried to turn her head, to bite at Rio's lip, to turn the kiss into a battle, but Rio wouldn't take the bait. She just kept soothing, kept worshiping, kept pouring affection into every touch until Agatha felt like she was drowning in it.

"Rio, please," Agatha tried even as the fight drained out of her limbs, leaving them heavy and useless. She didn't know what she was asking for anymore - only that she needed this to stop, or she needed it to never end.

Rio shifted again, breaking the kiss to look down at her. She maneuvered her body, sliding her hand down Agatha's stomach and into the wet heat waiting between her legs. Her eyes caught Agatha's, dark and devastatingly gentle, as she slowly dragged her fingers through the slickness.

It wasn't enough. It was too much. The touch was deliberate, caring - everything Agatha didn't think she deserved.

Her hips bucked up, seeking a harder rhythm, demanding pressure, demanding roughness to punish the parts of her that had come out in the kitchen.

Rio didn't oblige. She kept her wrist steady, her fingers moving in a slow, maddening circle that forced Agatha to feel every gentle touch.

"You're doing great," she whispered, her voice rough with restraint. She leaned down to press a kiss to Agatha's cheek, catching the single tear that had slid down the pale skin. "My strong, beautiful girl. You're perfect."

The words shattered Agatha completely.

She'd always liked being praised in bed, and Rio had definitely clocked it the first time they did this. But the praise felt different this time. Not a part of dirty talk, but something gentler - an acknowledgment that even here, unraveled and desperate, she was seen.

"Rio," Agatha gasped, her head falling back into the pillow as her hips stuttered, trying to chase the hand that refused to hurt her.

"I've got you," Rio promised, maintaining that excruciatingly slow pace. She watched Agatha's face, cataloging every twitch, every flush. "I'm right here. Just focus on me."

Agatha sobbed, a broken, wet sound that she couldn't suppress. She reached up, her fingers finding purchase on Rio's bare shoulders, digging in not to push away, but to pull her closer.

Rio hummed against her neck, finally adding the slightest bit of pressure, slipping two fingers inside while her thumb continued its relentless, gentle work. It stripped Agatha bare, peeling back the layers of the shark, the mother, the lawyer, until there was nothing left but a woman trembling in the afternoon light, held together by someone who refused to let her fall apart.

"That's it," Rio murmured, resting her forehead against Agatha's temple. "Let go. You're safe."

And Agatha did.

The release didn't crash over her like a storm; it rose like a tide, warm and all-consuming. She arched off the mattress, a cry tearing from her throat as the pleasure washed through her, dissolving the panic and the anger and the fear.

Rio guided her through it, letting her ride out the aftershocks until Agatha collapsed, limp and gasping, back onto the sheets.

The room was quiet, save for the sound of their harsh breathing.

Agatha lay there, her eyes squeezed shut, her chest heaving against the lace of her bra. She felt raw. She felt terrifyingly open.

Rio withdrew her hand slowly, moving to push herself up, but Agatha's arms shot up immediately, circling her shoulders and pulling her down.

"Stay," Agatha pleaded, her voice wrecked.

Rio relaxed back into her, resting her entire weight on Agatha in a gesture that should feel suffocating but didn't.

It felt safe. It felt warm. And the steady thrum of Rio's heart against hers was a constant reminder that she was there.

And for now, it had to be enough.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! To make up for the wait, I think this was one of the longest chapters yet (over 12k). That being said, I may have to move from updating weekly to every other week for a while because, apparently, deadlines don't give a flying fuck that I have other (more important) things to do. It's not set in stone, but just a heads up that the next chapter might be late too, especially with the holidays and everything. As always, thanks for reading, kudos, comments, and see you when I see you!

Chapter 43: Promises and confessions

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The quiet in the room settled like dust.

Agatha lay still for a long time, feeling the rhythm of Rio's breathing slow down against her neck, letting the weight of the body pressing her into the mattress ground her. Her mind didn't buzz with frantic thoughts like it had the past two nights she'd spent in this room. The static was gone. Everything felt almost peaceful. Unburdened.

But as the endorphins began to recede, clarity returned, and something else caught her attention.

Rio was shifting. The movements were small enough to go unnoticed, but with the woman resting on top of her, Agatha could feel every microscopic tensing of muscles followed by a sharp, controlled exhale into her neck.

She opened her eyes, looking over Rio's shoulder to where their legs lay tangled together. Rio's injured knee rested flat on the mattress, wedged between Agatha's thighs, and the careful adjustments were undeniably meant to soothe a throbbing ache.

"Your knee-"

Rio buried her face further into Agatha's neck. "Is fine."

"You carried me up a flight of stairs," Agatha countered, the memory of it sending a fresh wave of heat - and guilt - through her. "And you almost fell when you put me down."

"I wobbled. At best."

"Because I caught you," Agatha pointed out, pressing her palms into her girlfriend's shoulders to peel her off. "Move, Rio."

"Mm," Rio hummed against her skin, a stubborn, dead weight. She used the hand toying with the loose hairs at the nape of Agatha's neck to hold on tighter. "No. I'm comfy."

"You're impossible," Agatha corrected, though her hands were gentle as she reached up to detach the stubborn fingers. She tilted her hips, using the leverage to ease Rio off her and onto the mattress, not missing the suppressed hiss.

"And in pain," she added pointedly, sitting up and pulling her legs back. She glanced at Rio's knee - it was swollen, the puffiness making the old surgery scar more visible.

Guilt pricked at her, sharp and familiar. She had caused this. She had basically demanded proof of Rio's strength, and Rio, the fucking idiot, had decided to break herself to prove it.

But unlike the existential panic in the kitchen, this was manageable. This was a problem with a protocol: swelling required ice, and pain required medication.

This, Agatha could fix.

"Stay," she commanded, pointing a finger at Rio, who was blinking up at her with a slightly confused expression.

Agatha slid out of bed, ignoring the discarded clothes on the floor, and grabbed her robe from the hook on the door. She tied it tight around her waist and marched out of the room.

She returned two minutes later with the T-shirt they'd left in the kitchen, a fresh ice pack, a glass of water, and a bottle of ibuprofen.

Rio watched her come in, propping herself up on her elbows. Her gaze followed Agatha's movements, softening into something devastatingly tender that made Agatha's hand tremble slightly as she set the glass on the nightstand.

"You don't have to do this," Rio murmured as Agatha climbed back onto the bed, careful not to jostle the mattress. "I've had worse."

"Shut up," Agatha ordered, but there was no bite in it.

She settled herself at the foot of the bed. With gentle, clinical precision, she grabbed a throw pillow and eased it under Rio's knee, lifting it slightly. Rio hissed in a sharp breath as the movement stretched the joint, but didn't pull away.

Agatha carefully secured the ice pack, making sure the Velcro straps didn't bite into the reddened skin, and Rio sighed, her head falling back against the pillows.

"Okay," she admitted, her eyes closing. "Maybe that helps a little."

Agatha shook two pills into her hand and crawled up the mattress, hovering over Rio to offer them.

"Take these."

Rio took them from her palm, her fingers brushing Agatha's skin and lingering there. She washed them down with a sip of the water before putting the glass aside and looking at Agatha.

"This brings back memories," Rio whispered, her voice careful. "You, taking care of me. Is it going to end the same way as the last time?"

The unasked question was visible in her eyes, drowning in worry and hesitance.

Are you going to push me away again?

"No," Agatha said curtly. She picked up the black T-shirt she'd brought up and handed it to Rio. "Put this on. You'll get cold."

Rio did, wincing slightly as she sat up, then settled back against the headboard. She reached out, snagging the belt of Agatha's robe and tugging her closer until Agatha was sitting by her hip.

"Agatha," she started, her voice dropping to a serious register. "About earlier. In the kitchen."

Agatha stiffened, her instinct to deflect rising. "We don't have to talk about it."

"We should," Rio said, her voice gentle but tense, as if she were bracing for another explosion. "I'm not asking you to tell me everything, but... you mentioned Nicky said you didn't look lonely. Was that the catalyst?"

Agatha looked down at the thumb tracing soothing circles over the silk covering her knee.

How was she supposed to explain that Nicky's observation was just the tip of the iceberg? That she'd rushed home with the intention of possibly admitting her feelings, only to see Rio fixing a stupid cabinet - looking so permanent, so integrated - and spiral into something dangerously close to a panic attack?

She didn't know how to articulate the terror of hope.

So she just nodded.

"He was right," she admitted, the words feeling heavy on her tongue. "And it threw me off because... I didn't even know I was lonely before you came along. I thought I was just efficient. Alone but not lonely." She let out a dry, humorless laugh. "Having your ten-year-old son point out the hollowness of your existence is humbling. And-"

She hesitated, clenching her jaw.

Rio's hand kept moving over her knee, a rhythmic tether to the present, as she gently supplied, "Scary?"

Agatha exhaled slowly, chewing on her bottom lip to stop it from trembling. "You snuck up on me," she said, sounding almost accusatory. "With your stupid smirk and your tattoos and those soft eyes that see everything. I've been building my life around loneliness without even realizing it because it was easier. Safer. And now... now I let you in. I gave you the power."

"The power?" Rio asked softly, her hand stilling.

"To destroy me," Agatha swallowed thickly to keep the tears at bay. She refused to cry again. She'd been crying too much over the past few days. "Being lonely is miserable, maybe. But it's safe. Being lonely is better than giving someone the means to ruin you. And I've been giving you those means, little by little, for months."

She finally looked up, meeting Rio's gaze.

"And the worst part is," she continued, voice cracking, "if the walls cave in now... it won't be just us under the rubble. I dragged Nicky into the blast zone. If I fall apart, he falls with me."

Rio stared at her for a long moment, absorbing the weight of the confession. She didn't offer empty platitudes. She didn't promise that they were safe or that bad things wouldn't happen to them.

Instead, she shifted, wincing slightly as she sat up straighter against the headboard to look Agatha in the eye on equal ground.

"You're right," Rio said, her voice steady. "I do have that power. And you have the power to destroy me, too. That's how it works, Agatha. That's the fine print of caring about someone."

She reached out, capturing Agatha's hand where it rested on the duvet, interlacing their fingers.

"But I'm not here to swing a wrecking ball," Rio promised, her thumb pressing into Agatha's pulse point. "Or to stab you with the screwdriver. And if the walls start caving in, then we brace them. Together. You don't have to shield Nicky from the fact that you're human, and you don't have to shield him from me."

Agatha looked at their joined hands. It sounded so simple when Rio said it. So attainable.

But simplicity had never been Agatha's strong suit. She dealt in worst-case scenarios and liability clauses.

"Can you promise me something?" she asked, her voice shaky, small in the quiet room.

"Anything."

Agatha closed her eyes, tightening her grip on Rio's hand until her knuckles turned white. "If this doesn't work out - if I ruin it - promise me you'll still be in Nicky's life."

The silence that followed felt thick. Heavy.

It was unfair to ask, Agatha knew that. It was asking the woman who she'd fake-married seven months ago and had recently started dating to commit to a partial custody arrangement for a child that wasn't hers, anticipating a breakup that hadn't happened yet.

But it was the only parachute Agatha had. It was the only safety net that allowed her to breathe, because she knew Rio kept her promises. Always.

"Agatha..."

The hesitant notes playing in her girlfriend's voice made her look up, panic flaring instantly. Rio was staring at her with a mixture of confusion and sadness, her mouth parted like she couldn't find the words.

"Please, Rio," Agatha pressed, desperation clawing at her throat. "He loves you so much. He thinks you hung the moon. I can't be the reason he loses you."

Rio bit down on her lower lip, worrying it between her teeth. She looked away, staring at the wall, then back at Agatha.

"Querida, that's..." she exhaled, the breath shuddering as she tried to keep the raw edge out of her voice. "That's a big promise to make. What if... what if you change your mind?"

Agatha blinked. "What?"

"If we crash," Rio said softly, her eyes searching Agatha's face. "If you decide I'm 'mold' again, or if you decide it's too much... you cut people off. You burn bridges and scorch the earth. If things go bad, are you really going to want your ex-girlfriend hanging around playing Minecraft with your son?"

The question hit Agatha like a physical blow.

Of course, Rio didn't consider herself in the scenario. She didn't say, What if I don't want to entertain your son after everything? She didn't say, It's too much responsibility. And it's not mine to take on.

She was worried that Agatha would lock the door.

They weren't even actually married, for fuck's sake. They shouldn't be discussing shared custody in a relationship that was only a few weeks old.

But Agatha had to know. She had to know that the fallout wouldn't bury Nicky.

"I won't," Agatha vowed, her voice fierce. "I promise. No matter what happens between us... I won't burn the bridge. He needs you."

Rio studied her for a long, agonizing moment. Then, she nodded slowly.

"Then I promise," Rio whispered. "I'm not going anywhere. The only way I'll ever leave Nicky's life is if you tell me to."

Agatha let out a breath she felt she'd been holding for three days. The knot in her chest loosened, just enough to let the air in.

"Okay," Agatha exhaled. "Okay."

"But," Rio added, leaning in to press a kiss to Agatha's temple. "Stop planning the funeral, yeah? We're not dead yet. We just started living, in fact."

She pulled back, glancing past Agatha at the digital clock on the bedside table.

"It's after four," she noted, her voice shifting, becoming lighter. "I should get started on dinner before the monster's back and ready to devour everything in the kitchen."

Agatha looked at her knee, which was still wrapped in an ice pack and elevated on a pillow. "I can do that," she said, already moving to get off the bed. "You shouldn't be on your feet too much."

"I'm-"

"And," Agatha cut in before the protest could form, pulling her underwear back on and turning toward the walk-in closet, "you better think of an excuse why you won't be coaching Nicky on penalties today. He's going to be disappointed, but I'm not driving you to the ER tonight."

Rio's head hit the headboard with a soft thud. "Shit," she muttered, the word barely loud enough to reach Agatha. "I forgot about that."

Agatha pulled on a simple white T-shirt and a pair of light blue jeans, hanging up the discarded suit with precision. If she were lucky, gravity would take care of the wrinkles it had earned from its time on the floor.

"Treat it as a lesson on stupid decisions," she said, reemerging from the closet, barefoot and infinitely more casual than she felt. "And don't even think about powering through it. I'll tie you to the bed if you do."

Rio - still leaning against the headboard with her hair disheveled and her knee propped up - smirked dangerously. "That's not the deterrent you want it to be, gorgeous."

Agatha froze in the middle of the room. A flush that had nothing to do with the summer heat and everything to do with the dark, heavy lilt of Rio's voice crept up her neck.

She turned slowly, expecting to see an amused glint in her girlfriend's eyes, but Rio clearly wasn't joking. She was watching Agatha with a predatory stillness, looking far too pleased for someone with an injured leg.

"Is that so?" Agatha managed, trying to keep her voice dry, though it came out a little breathless.

"It could be the other way around, too," Rio murmured, shifting without dropping her gaze even as her lips twitched a little in pain. "You were begging for it earlier. The rougher stuff. The friction."

Agatha crossed her arms, hoping the gesture seemed more defiant than protective. "I was upset. I wanted... I wanted to get out of my head."

"I know," Rio said, and her voice dropped, losing the teasing edge and becoming something grounded and serious. "You wanted a punishment. You wanted me to hurt you so you wouldn't have to feel the guilt."

She paused, letting the words hang in the air between them.

"That's why I didn't do it, Agatha. I won't get off on inflicting pain when you're already bleeding."

Agatha clenched her jaw at that, but the arousal burning low in her stomach was hard to miss. She summoned a coy smirk that felt brittle. "How very noble."

"Nobility had nothing to do with it," Rio corrected her sternly. "I was being selfish. Because when I put my hands on you like that - when I pin you down, or bite you, or... tie you..."

Agatha's breath hitched.

Rio held her gaze, her expression open and unapologetic. "I want it to be because you're enjoying it. Not because you think you deserve to suffer. And certainly not because you think I should take out my frustration or anger on you."

The room felt suddenly small, charged with an electricity that made the hair on Agatha's arms stand up. They had only slept together a handful of times - frantic releases from the weekend and the slow, healing tide from today - but the undercurrent of something sharper, darker, had always been there. It was in the way they argued. It was in the way Agatha craved control and the way Rio seemed to know exactly how to dismantle it.

"And if I am enjoying it?" Agatha asked, her voice barely above a whisper. "If it's not a punishment but... want?"

Rio's grin returned, positively wicked.

"Then we can revisit the 'ties' conversation," she promised. "Because contrary to the gentle act I just put on... I like the rougher stuff. I like it when you claw. I like leaving marks."

She gestured vaguely to her own shoulder, where three faint scratches from Agatha's nails were already blooming against the tan skin. Agatha didn't even remember leaving them there.

"I'm not made of glass either," Rio added softly. "You don't have to hold back with me. Just... not when you're spiraling. Okay?"

Agatha stared at her, feeling a strange mixture of relief and thrill unfurl in her chest.

"Okay," she said, taking a step toward the door. She needed to put some distance between herself and the temptation on the bed before she abandoned all responsibility for the second time that day. "I'm going to make pasta. Stay here. Rest the knee."

"Yes, ma'am," Rio smirked, settling back against the pillows.

Agatha paused in the doorway, glancing back. "And Rio?"

"Yeah?"

"When your knee's better..." Agatha trailed off, feeling the heat rise to her cheeks again, but forcing herself to finish. "I expect a drawing to see who gets to tie up whom first."

Rio laughed, a bright, startled sound that followed Agatha all the way down the hall.

"Count on it."

Agatha finished the pasta sauce - a simple marinara because the lingering tremor in her hands made her doubt if anything more complicated wouldn't end with a lost finger - and turned the burner off.

She checked her watch: 5:25 PM.

Rio hadn't come down to sit with her in the kitchen while she cooked. The forty minutes of silence offered some reprieve to collect her scattered thoughts, but it was mixed with the constant, itching urge to go upstairs. To check on the woman. To make sure she was actually still there.

She tried to chalk it up to her knowledge that Rio was incapable of stillness and would likely make her injury worse if left to her own devices. It was a valid concern. But even Agatha knew it was a lie.

She was worried about the knee, of course - especially since the injury was entirely her fault - but the need to have her girlfriend close was far more selfish than that. Rio had promised she wasn't going anywhere. She had promised that she was Agatha's. But without the visual confirmation, without the tactile proof, the words didn't feel reassuring.

Agatha walked back upstairs, telling herself that she'd just quickly check on Rio and make sure she was comfortable - and still there - before leaving to collect Nicky.

Her bedroom was empty.

The bed was neatly made, the duvet smoothed of all wrinkles, the pillows arranged in a sequence that only made sense to Rio's chaotic logic. It looked abandoned. It looked cold. It looked like no one had been there at all.

The voice at the back of her head hissed - she left, she realized it was too much - but before the panic could fully develop, the bathroom door opened.

Rio limped out, wearing the same T-shirt and shorts, her jaw set tight and a focused crease between her brows as she tested her weight on the right leg.

Her expression smoothed over instantly when she looked up and met Agatha's eye. "Hi."

Agatha frowned, the budding panic immediately replaced by protective worry. "What are you doing?"

"I'm going with you," Rio stated casually, limping forward. Her walk was so different from her usual effortless saunter - it was stiff, guarded, clearly painful.

Agatha stepped toward her automatically, her hands hovering as if afraid Rio might shatter. "No, you're not."

She grabbed Rio's waist, intending to steer her back toward the bed, but then she paused.

Rio had made the bed. She had erased the evidence of their afternoon. She clearly didn't plan on getting back in it.

Agatha changed course mid-step, slowly pulling the woman toward the door instead. "We are going to your room," Agatha corrected, her voice leaving no room for argument. "I'm depositing you on your bed with a fresh ice pack and whatever else you need. You're not coming with me."

"I am," Rio insisted, digging her heels in as much as she could on one good leg, halting their progress in the hallway.

"Look at yourself," Agatha argued, nodding her chin to the leg Rio was currently favoring. "You're grimacing every other step. Walking down the stairs and sitting in the car isn't going to help."

"Good thing you have a fancy car," Rio countered. "With heated seats and all. It's like a driving massage chair."

"It's not," Agatha snapped, frustration bubbling up - frustration at the injury, at herself, at the situation. "Why are you being difficult? Nicky doesn't expect you there. And he won't mind that you can't coach him today if this is your way of making it up to him."

"It's not about him," Rio said softly.

The words hung in the air, heavy and pointed.

Agatha stopped trying to pull her toward the guest room. She looked up, meeting Rio's gaze. Rio wasn't looking at her leg; she was looking directly into Agatha's eyes, reading the residual fear lingering there despite the time she'd spent trying to collect herself in the kitchen.

"You don't want to go alone," Rio stated.

"I am perfectly capable of picking up my son."

"It's not about capability," Rio murmured, stepping closer, closing the distance until she was leaning slightly against Agatha for support. "Today was... a lot. Your hands are still shaking. And if I don't go with you, you'll probably hurt yourself gripping the wheel and rebuilding your armor."

She reached down, pulling one of Agatha's hands away from her waist to thread their fingers together.

"I'm not letting that happen," she whispered. "Not today. So I'm coming. I'll sit in the car. I'll act as moral support. But I'm not letting you walk out that door by yourself."

Agatha felt her throat tighten. She wanted to argue logic. She wanted to cite medical advice. But the truth was, the thought of getting into the car alone, of leaving Rio behind even for an hour, made her chest ache.

God, since when was she so codependent?

Scared, she thought grimly. You're not codependent. You're scared that if you lose sight of her, she'll disappear like a figment of your imagination.

She looked at Rio's set jaw - not in pain, but in burning determination that there was no use fighting. She'd lost. Or maybe won. It was getting harder to tell the difference, honestly.

"You're incredibly annoying," Agatha grumbled, squeezing Rio's hand.

Rio grinned, easily breaking the tension. "Yeah, I've been told. Now come on. Be my crutch."

Agatha sighed, a sound of feigned suffering that fooled no one, and wrapped her arm firmly around Rio's waist.

"Lean on me," she commanded, taking the bulk of Rio's weight against her side. "And if I hear one hiss or groan or anything on the stairs, I'm carrying you to bed and locking the door."

"I'll climb out the window and chase after your car like an abandoned dog."

Agatha glared at her. "Rio."

"Alright, alright," Rio muttered, looking toward the stairs with a determined squint. "Let's do it."

The descent was slow, awkward, and filled with Rio muttering colorful curses in Spanish that Agatha pretended not to hear, keeping her grip tight. Her body acted as the anchor, bearing most of Rio's weight, and a selfish part of her felt almost content.

The injury was her fault. The trek down the stairs was her fault. But Rio needed her. In a way that she probably didn't need her since she'd gotten hurt at the bar.

It made Agatha feel marginally better in some fucked up way, like it was proof that she wasn't always the only one in their relationship who needed help.

"Okay," Agatha exhaled as she finally settled Rio into the passenger seat of the SUV, adjusting the seat back to give her more leg room. "We need a story."

Rio blinked, looking comfortable despite the sweat on her brow. "A story?"

"For the limp," Agatha clarified, rounding the car and sliding into the driver's seat. "I told you to think of something."

Rio smirked, buckling her seatbelt. "My mind got otherwise occupied after our 'ties' conversation."

Agatha started the car, pointedly ignoring the heat blooming in her lower belly as she began backing down the driveway. "Fine. Then I'll tell him you slipped and fell in the garden like a clumsy idiot."

"Absolutely not," Rio scoffed. "I have a reputation to maintain. I was... fighting a rabid raccoon."

"You'd rather get defeated by a raccoon than slip?"

"A rabid raccoon that I fought off," Rio stressed, tapping her shoulder. "And I have the scratches to prove it."

Agatha shot her an unamused glare. "You're not telling my son you wrestled with an animal carrying a dangerous disease. Or showing him the marks."

"They add credibility!"

"No."

"Fine," Rio grumbled. "What about-"

"We're going with a gardening incident," Agatha interrupted smoothly. "It's plausible, it's easy, and it doesn't involve traumatizing Nicky. You tripped while watering the raised beds."

Rio deflated in her seat, crossing her arms with a drawn-out sigh. "That's so lame."

"Lame?" Agatha repeated, amusement creeping into her voice. "Are you going to stomp your foot, too? Since we're apparently using the vocabulary of a pre-teen."

"It's a regular word," Rio argued despite her growing smile. "But fine. No badass stories about defeating raccoons to protect the house. Even though Nicky would think it was cool."

Agatha chuckled, drumming her fingers against the wheel. Her hands weren't shaking anymore. "He'd probably declare war against all raccoons," she mused before her voice softened. "You know he's going to be insufferable about this, right? He's going to give you the safety talk and try to nurse you back to health."

Rio shrugged, shifting slightly to alleviate the pressure on her leg, her smile widening into something soft. "I know. I got a taste of it after the chair incident."

"Attack," Agatha corrected automatically, feeling her old anger resurfacing. "It was an assault, Rio. Not an incident. And the guy-"

"Melissa did what she could," Rio said, her voice sobering instantly, the playfulness evaporating. She watched Agatha's profile, gauging her reaction. "It wasn't her fault the guy walked away with a slap on the wrist."

Agatha stared at the road, her jaw clenching. She knew it was true, logically. Her friend Melissa was a shark in the courtroom, and the case had seemed solid. Any reasonable judge would have listened to the witnesses' retelling of a drunk patron hurling a barstool at an innocent grad student and handed down a sentence involving jail time.

But the ruling had been shockingly lenient. Community service. Probation. A check that barely covered a third of the lawyer's pay.

It had smelled fishy then, and it still smelled fishy now. Whether it was corruption, laziness, or bad luck, Agatha didn't know. But what she did know was that she had let it go.

Rio had ordered her to drop it. She had refused an appeal and spoke against dragging it out, using money as an argument. Because it had been Agatha's money, and Rio would've rather bled out on a bar floor than have her spend a dime on her 'fake wife's' problems back then. And because they had been in the middle of that excruciating, silent cold war - where Agatha had pulled away in terror after realizing that seeing Rio hurt felt like dying - she had listened. She had respected the boundary because Rio had respected hers. Or maybe because she'd been too afraid to admit she wanted to tear the world apart for Rio.

She still was.

"I should have fought it," Agatha murmured, the regret tasting bitter on her tongue. "I shouldn't have listened to you. Melissa could've easily buried him in litigation until he couldn't breathe."

Rio reached across the console, tapping her fingers against Agatha's hand to urge her to lessen the white-knuckle hold she kept on the wheel. The brief contact acted like a magnet. Agatha automatically uncurled her fingers to tangle them with Rio's, keeping the car steady with her left hand while her right rested in the warm, calloused grip on the console.

"We were... complicated then," Rio said quietly. "I was too proud to let you help, and you were..."

"Too afraid to push," Agatha finished for her, the anger simmering low in her gut. "And it led to him getting away with hurting you."

"We made the best decision we could with the mess we were in."

Agatha clenched her jaw, keeping her eyes on the road. "The mess I put us in, you mean."

"No," Rio opposed quietly, but with a firmness that immediately caught Agatha's attention. "I started the chain reaction that led us there. I..." She hesitated, chewing on her bottom lip, looking down at their joined hands. "When I got that nurse to contact Billy - to tell him not to come to the hospital - he told me you were already on the way. And I could've asked him to stop you. I could have told him to tell you I didn't want you there. I knew you'd probably listen. Read it as a line in our contract that I didn't want you to cross."

She took a shaky breath.

"But the truth was... I wanted you with me. I didn't want to be alone in general, but I wanted you specifically."

Rio's grip on her hand tightened until it was almost painful. Agatha didn't react, squeezing her back with equal force, sensing that Rio needed the physical reassurance for whatever she wanted to say next.

"I hate hospitals. You already know my parents died in a car accident. On scene." Rio's voice went flat, clinical, a defense mechanism Agatha recognized instantly. "But I... I didn't die. They drove me to the nearest trauma center in an ambulance. I was seven. I was terrified. The paramedics had to sedate me because I wouldn't stop screaming for my parents and fighting them. It was making my injuries worse, so they knocked me out."

Agatha felt a chill run down her spine that had nothing to do with the car's AC. She kept her grip firm, urging Rio to continue or stop if it was too much.

"When I woke up..." Rio's voice cracked. "I was in a sterile white room. Alone. The silence was louder than the screaming had been. Then came in a doctor with a social worker, and suddenly I wasn't just alone in the room, I was alone in the world. An orphan. Just like that."

She turned her head to look at Agatha, her eyes shimmering with unshed tears.

"I wanted you in the hospital that night because... I knew you'd make me feel safe. I knew you'd fill the silence - maybe not with words but with your presence. I knew you'd notice I wasn't comfortable, but you wouldn't press me for details I wasn't ready to give. You're the only person who makes the room feel less... empty."

Agatha felt the burn of tears behind her own eyes. She blinked rapidly, focusing on the red taillights of the car in front of them.

She had spent that evening in the hospital chair, stiff and awkward, thinking she was an intruder. Thinking she was imposing on Rio's vulnerability for the sake of the deal.

Then she'd pulled away after realizing it had nothing to do with the deal and everything to do with the feelings still stirring in her chest. She'd pulled away because the reality of seeing Rio hurt and mortal had terrified her.

She hadn't realized she was the lifeline.

"I didn't know," Agatha whispered, her voice thick. "I thought... I thought I was overstepping. The entire time. And then I realized how real it felt, how right it felt to care for you, and I... I wanted to give you space."

"I never need space from you, Agatha," Rio said softly. "I might need space from the world. But never from you."

The confession hung between them, heavy and absolute.

Agatha brought their joined hands up to her lips, pressing a kiss to Rio's middle knuckle.

"I'm here now," Agatha said, using the red light to look directly into Rio's eyes. "And I really hope there won't be a next time, but if there is... I'll be there. No matter how complicated we are."

Rio smiled, a watery, relieved thing. "Deal."

Agatha cleared her throat, blinking away the moisture in her eyes as the light turned green. She lowered their hands back to the console and steered the car into the lot that was already crawling with waiting parents.

The bus's silhouette emerged from around a corner, the massive vehicle hissing as it made its way toward the curb.

"Okay," Agatha exhaled, killing the engine. "We're here. How's the knee holding up?"

"It's throbbing," Rio admitted honestly. "But it's dull. The painkillers are definitely working."

"Good," Agatha said, reluctantly untangling their hands to unbuckle her seatbelt. "But you're not getting out of the car. No unnecessary movement."

Rio saluted playfully, adjusting her leg again. "Of course, doctor."

Her grin was easy, and the words were dipped in amusement, but Agatha could see the remnants of their conversation in her eyes - heavy and solemn. She stopped, fighting the sudden, magnetic urge to lean across the console and kiss the shadows away.

But she couldn't. Not here. Not with the bus just yards away.

Instead, she settled for a final squeeze of Rio's hand that was lying limp on the center console.

"You didn't start the chain reaction," she said quietly, holding Rio's gaze. "Or maybe you did. Maybe I did when I showed up at the hospital. Either way... I think we both needed things to play out exactly how they did."

Rio's brows furrowed. "You mean... the silence?"

"The absence," Agatha muttered, chewing on her bottom lip. "They say it makes the heart grow fonder, right? And I think... no, I know, that mine did." She swallowed the lump in her throat. "The silence wasn't peaceful like it used to be. It was just empty. Seeing what my life looked like without you in it made me realize I didn't want to live that way."

Rio's breath hitched, her eyes softening into something devastatingly tender. She opened her mouth to speak, perhaps to offer a confession of her own, but the loud hiss of the bus doors opening cut through the moment.

Agatha pulled her hand back, glancing at herself in the rearview mirror. Her eyes were slightly red-rimmed, but she doubted Nicky would ask. "Stay put. I'll grab Nicky."

She slipped out of the car before the emotion could swallow her whole, closing the door and stepping into the humid afternoon air.

The parking lot was a chaotic sea of reunions, but Agatha spotted Nicky immediately. He was one of the last ones off, looking disheveled, sun-flushed, and dragging his duffel bag like it contained bricks. He scanned the crowd, looking tired, until his eyes landed on her.

"Mama!"

The exhaustion vanished instantly. He readjusted the bag and jogged toward her, colliding with her waist in a hug that nearly knocked the wind out of her.

"Hey, you," Agatha laughed, wrapping her arms around his sweaty shoulders and kissing the top of his head. He smelled like grass, sunscreen, and stale bus air. "No broken body parts. I'm glad."

"Or things!" Nicky beamed, pulling back. "Billy threw up on the way back, but I scored a goal in the scrimmage. A left-footer! It was awesome!"

"That's my boy," Agatha praised, smoothing his messy hair. "Ready to go? Have you said goodbye to everyone?"

"I'm ready. I'm starving," Nicky said, glancing around her. "Rio's here!"

Agatha's heart gave a light squeeze at the excitement in his voice.

"Yeah, she kept me company on-" she trailed off, not bothering to finish the sentence as Nicky surged past her, toward the car.

She followed him at a slower pace, reaching the driver's side after he'd already clambered into the back and leaned forward between the front seats, practically vibrating.

"-left-footer!"

Rio had angled her torso toward him, carefully keeping her lower half still, and was smiling at him brightly. The shadows were mostly gone. "That's incredible, bud!"

"Top corner!" Nicky bragged, buckling his seatbelt. "I wish you were there. Coach said my form was good."

"You'll give me a replay later," Rio said sincerely, though Agatha noticed the way her hand tightened on her thigh as she twisted.

"Totally!" Nicky slumped back into his seat, looking content. He didn't seem to care that Rio hadn't gotten out to greet him or notice that she was sitting a little stiffer than usual. "Can we get pizza? The one they ordered was meh."

"We have food at home," Agatha said automatically, starting the car. "Pasta with marinara sauce."

"Garlic bread?"

"Obviously," Agatha scoffed.

"Yes!" Nicky pumped a fist.

The drive home was filled with Nicky's play-by-play of the trip. Agatha focused on keeping both her hands on the wheel, constantly reminding herself that she couldn't reach for Rio's again, no matter how good it had felt. Her palms itched with the urge, and her eyes kept wandering to the way Rio's fingers drummed along to the radio against her knee, never crossing to the center console.

The rules were back in place, Nicky's chatter a steady reminder that some lines couldn't be crossed. It pained Agatha more than she was ready to admit.

Rio was either oblivious to her internal struggle or found pretending easier. She asked the right questions, laughed at the right moments, and entertained Nicky throughout the drive with an ease that made Agatha's chest ache with something warm.

When they pulled into the garage, the shadows were already getting longer. Agatha put the car in park and killed the engine.

"Alright, trip over," she announced. "Nicky, grab your bag."

"On it," Nicky said, opening the door and hopping out with the boundless energy of youth.

Agatha got out quickly, rounding the hood to the passenger side before Nicky could pay too much attention. She opened Rio's door, offering a hand that looked casual but was firm with intention.

"Ready?"

Rio took a breath, grabbed the offered hand, and swung her legs out.

The moment her right foot hit the floor and took her weight, her face paled. She let out a sharp, involuntary hiss as her grip around Agatha's fingers turned crushing.

Agatha immediately stepped in, wrapping an arm around Rio's waist to take the weight.

"Rio?"

Nicky came around the side, his duffel bag slipping from his shoulder. He looked at Rio - at the way she was leaning heavily on Agatha, at the wince she was trying to hide, and the stiff way her leg was held.

"You're walking funny," he said, his voice dropping the excitement and pitching into worry. "Are you okay?"

Rio forced a smile, though it was tighter than the one in the car. "I'm good, buddy. See, there was a-"

"Gardening incident," Agatha interjected, squeezing her waist warningly. She could almost hear the word 'raccoon' on the woman's tongue. "She tripped watering the tomatoes."

Rio grumbled something in Spanish, but nodded. "Yup. Just a small disagreement with gravity."

Nicky frowned, his eyes darting between them. He wasn't buying the 'I'm good' act, especially with Rio's knee partially uncovered by her shorts, the swelling clear as day.

"It looks bad," he observed bluntly. "And it's the one you hurt playing. Did you ice it? Put it up?"

He wasn't looking at Rio when he asked. He was looking at his mother, searching for the responsible adult in the room.

"She did," Agatha assured him, swallowing the strange cocktail of emotions rising in her throat - pride at having such an incredible, sensitive son mixed with the sharp dread at being the one he saw fit to manage Rio's care. "And she will do that again once we get her comfortable on the couch. Can you get the door?"

"Yeah!" Nicky whipped around, the bag almost slipping off his shoulder as her rushed ahead, yanking the door open with enough force to make it rattle on its hinges.

Agatha readjusted her grip on Rio and began leading her forward, feeling a pang of guilt every time the woman hissed under her breath or wobbled in her hold.

"Thanks, Nicky," Rio said when they passed the boy, the words slightly strained through gritted teeth.

Nicky closed the door behind them with a definitive thud, hovering on Rio's other side as Agatha guided them toward the living room. She mentally cursed herself for splurging on a house with such a grand, sprawling floor plan ten years ago - the trek would've been infinitely shorter in a cramped apartment.

"Can I help?" he asked, dropping his duffel on the floor with a thump and reaching for Rio's hand. He was small for his age, his head barely brushing Rio's elbow, but the determination in his eyes almost made Agatha believe he'd try to fireman-carry the woman if given the chance.

Rio sent him a small smile, ruffling his hair. "I already feel bad using your mom as a crutch. How about you bring me some juice?"

Nicky's eyebrows drew closer, his lips pursing slightly as he weighed the medical necessity of juice. Then he lit up, nodding. "I'll grab the ice pack too! The one that wraps around."

Agatha froze mid-step. Rio faltered, her weight becoming a dead load against Agatha's side.

The ice pack with the Velcro straps. The 'good' one.

The one that was currently sitting on Agatha's nightstand, next to a half-empty glass of water and a bottle of ibuprofen. In a space where Rio certainly shouldn't have been when injured after a gardening incident.

"Buddy-" Rio started, panic flaring in her eyes.

"Rio already used that one," Agatha interjected quickly, her voice pitching up just a fraction. "And we... didn't put it back in the freezer. It's warm."

"Mama," Nicky sighed, a sound so exasperated and deeply pre-teen that it made Agatha smile involuntarily. "You're supposed to put it back right after using it."

"I know, baby. I know," she said, sending him an apologetic smile that felt brittle at the edges. "I'll go grab it in a minute, okay?"

Nicky wasn't deterred. "I can do that!" he offered, looking at Rio with helpful intensity. "I'll go put it back for you so it gets cold faster. Is it in your room?"

Agatha sent her a sidelong, panicked glance that screamed fix this.

"It absolutely is," Rio agreed, the words tumbling out a beat too fast. "But, my room's kinda messy and, um, there are some things you shouldn't see?"

Nicky frowned, his nose scrunching up. "Like what?"

"Like... my underwear?" Rio tried, grasping at straws.

Nicky looked at her like she was an alien who had just landed and failed to understand human customs. "So? I wear underwear too."

Under other circumstances, Agatha would've been proud of this reaction. The last thing she wanted was to raise a boy who was weird about basic anatomy or clothing. But right now, his pragmatic lack of embarrassment was massively inconvenient.

"Listen, baby," Agatha cut in, using her 'mom voice' - firm, warm, and brooking no argument. "Rio's just... embarrassed because her room probably looks like a tornado hit it. We are not subjecting you to that health hazard."

She tacked on the 'probably' in a last-ditch effort to discourage any questions about how she knew the state of Rio's room.

"But-"

"Kitchen," Agatha ordered, pointing down the hall with her free hand. "Juice. And grab the other ice pack. It'll be fine until the other one's ready. Go."

Nicky hesitated for one second, looking between the two women, before his desire to be helpful overrode his desire to argue.

"Okay," he relented. "But it's not as good."

He turned and sprinted toward the kitchen, his shoes squeaking against the hardwood floors.

Agatha let out a breath that deflated her entire posture.

"He's your kid through and through," Rio whispered, shaking her head. "I was half-expecting him to march up to my room just to prove a point."

"Shut up and walk," Agatha muttered, hauling Rio the last few feet into the living room.

She maneuvered them to the large plush sofa. "Okay, sit. Slowly."

Rio obeyed, gripping Agatha's forearm as she lowered herself. She let out a long, ragged groan as her leg stretched out, her head falling back against the cushions.

"Fucking hell," she breathed, closing her eyes. "I'll have to call my boss. There's no way I'm working tomorrow."

"I'm so-"

"Don't start," Rio admonished her, cracking one eye open. "This is my own doing. And I wear it like a badge of honor."

Agatha just sighed, grabbing a throw pillow and gently lifting Rio's leg to prop it on the coffee table. "Is that okay?"

"Perfect," Rio murmured, still looking at her softly. "You better go grab that ice pack before he launches a search party."

"Shit, you're right," Agatha straightened up, sending her a warning look. "Don't move."

Rio leaned her head back against the pillows, winking at her. "Go. I'm fine."

Agatha turned and hurried toward the stairs, kicking off her shoes at the bottom to move faster. She took the steps two at a time - ironic, considering the earlier events - and practically vaulted into her bedroom.

There it was. The blue wrap-around ice pack, sitting innocently on her nightstand as if it weren't damning evidence of their entanglement.

She grabbed it, along with the painkillers, and shoved them against her chest. She took a second to scrutinize her room, searching for any other signs of Rio's presence, but there weren't any - the duvet was pristine, the pillows meticulously arranged, and there were no clothes thrown on the floor. All that was left was the memory of it all.

She ran back out, only slowing her pace as she hit the living room entryway, composing her face into a mask of calm capability.

Nicky was already there.

He was kneeling on the floor next to the couch, carefully balancing the ice pack on Rio's knee. Rio was sipping from the glass of orange juice he'd brought her, looking at the boy with an expression so tender it made Agatha's heart ache.

"Is that too cold?" Nicky asked, his brow furrowed in concentration.

"It's perfect, buddy," Rio assured him, setting the empty glass aside. "You're a pro."

Nicky beamed, puffing out his chest. Then he looked up and saw Agatha holding the warm ice pack.

"You found it!"

"I did. It was... under a pile of laundry," Agatha lied smoothly, leaning her shoulder against the doorframe with a casualness she didn't feel. "In Rio's room. Just like she said."

She exchanged a look with Rio - a shared secret, a mutual exhale of relief - and nodded toward the TV.

"How about you put something on while I reheat dinner?" she suggested. "Give Rio a distraction."

Nicky grinned at the directive, already grabbing the remote from the coffee table. He clambered onto the couch, careful of the injured leg but otherwise pressing himself into Rio's right side like he wanted to heal her through osmosis.

"The Minecraft movie," he declared, punching the buttons with purpose. He smushed his cheek against Rio's arm, just below the sleeve of her T-shirt.

Rio didn't flinch. She simply lifted her arm, creating a warm, inviting space under her shoulder, and Nicky didn't waste a second before snuggling into it.

Agatha watched Rio push a lock of hair out of Nicky's eyes, her fingers lingering on his forehead. She looked entirely unbothered by the intrusion of a sweaty pre-teen into her personal space. In fact, she looked like she belonged there.

Agatha's heart squeezed, a physical ache that was becoming alarmingly familiar.

"We'll have to pause it to eat, though," Rio told him softly, moving her hand from his forehead to his back. "No possibly-staining food on the couch."

Nicky leaned back just enough to look up at her, scandalized. "But you can't walk!" he pointed out before twisting to look at his mother, eyes wide and imploring. "And we can't let Rio eat alone here! That's rude!"

Agatha's breath stuttered under the weight of two identical sets of brown eyes staring at her. One pair was pleading, the other amused, but both were waiting for her verdict.

She looked at her pristine, cream-colored sofa. She looked at her expensive rug. She thought about the red marinara sauce that could lead to a disaster.

Then she looked at her son, safe and happy, and the woman who had carried her up the stairs a few hours ago because she knew Agatha needed to be held.

"We can eat here," Agatha said, the words slipping out before her brain could consult the rulebook.

Nicky's jaw dropped. Rio's eyebrows shot up.

"But," Agatha added quickly, pointing a warning finger at them, "if a single drop of sauce touches that fabric, Nicholas, you are grounded until college. And Rio, I will leave you in the garden to ponder your past mistakes."

But the threat lacked heat. One look at her two favorite people in the world, snuggled together, gazing at her as if she were the benevolent queen of their little kingdom, made the sanctity of her couch seem entirely unimportant.

"Awesome!" Nicky beamed, turning his attention back to the TV to finish picking the movie. "We can watch Hotel Transylvania later!"

Agatha groaned, turning toward the kitchen to hide her smile. "I don't love that movie, Nicky! Rio's been feeding you lies!"

"No, I haven't!" Rio called after her, voice dripping with amusement and affection. "We both saw you cry at the ending last time!"

"I had something in my eye!" Agatha shouted back, disappearing into the kitchen.

"Keep telling yourself that!"

Agatha shook her head, grabbing the pot holder. She was losing control of her house. She was losing control of her rules. She was losing control of her heart.

And she had never been happier.

Chapter End Notes

Hi! Bad news - the next chapter definitely won't be ready for next week. Honestly, it might not be ready in two weeks either, because I haven't had the time or energy to even think about this fic over the past few days, let alone write it. I haven't felt this disconnected from my writing in a long time (I blame uni), and I might have to sit a few weeks out to try and find my way back to it. As always, thank you for reading, all the kudos, and - most of all - the comments, which do wonders to pull me out of the slump. So, Happy New Year, and see you when I see you!

Afterword

Please drop by the Archive and comment to let the creator know if you enjoyed their work!
